column2: NEW HOPE, Pa., Dec, 5-- Rolf William Bauhan, an architect, died in his home here yesterday at the age of 74.

EDISON, N.J., Dec. 5--The Fedders Corporation foresees no adverse effect on its sales of residential air conditioners despite the decline in housing starts to a 20-year low, Salvatore Giordano, chairman and president, said here yesterday.

The Associates Investment Company of South Bend, Ind., one of the nation's largest salesfinance companies, announced yesterday that it had withdrawn from further negotiations with Pioner Finance Company of Detroit.

MORE than 18,000 people filled Madison Square Garden last night for the 16th Annual Hanukkah Festival for Israel. The audience heard an 80th birthday tribute from Edward G. Robinson to David Ben-Gurion, former Israeli Prime Minister. As is customary at these festivals, dance played a prominent part, and there were two new ballets given by the Sophie Maslow Company.

LISBON, Dec. 5 (AP)-- Luciano J. Fernandes, a 26year-old Portuguese soccer player, was electrocuted today by a new whirlpool machine in Benfica Stadium. A faulty wire apparently caused the shock that killed Fernandes and shook up six other Benfica players who were in the cement baths alongside their dressing rooms after a morning workout.

The scholar-athlete wears his hair close-cropped, pities those who think football players are "suave chimpanzees," and looks forward to a conservative, regulated life in medicine or the law. He agrees that he has been rarely privileged to gain acceptance among both the animals and the grinds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board suggested today that in a future boom, banks should raise interest rates and tighten loan terms for business borrowers more rapidly and more frequently as credit conditions tighten.
The appointment of Dr. Lyman R. Fink to the new post of vice president and chief technical officer of the Singer Company was announced here yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)--A 22-year old man, who allegedly sent threatening letters to President Johnson, was sentenced today to three years in Federal prison for failing to report for induction into the armed services.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 (UPI) --The United States Steel Corporation says it has made progress in the hiring and advancement of Negro employes, and that criticism of its Birmingham, Ala., operations is unwarranted.
Aeronautics students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have drawn up detailed plans for a sort of orbital coast guard."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Federal Aviation Agency gave the airlines more time today in which to install cockpit voice recorders in their large passenger planes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 (AP)--The Pacific Coast shipyard strike going into its second month today has prevented several thousand Navy men on Vietnam war zone duty from returning home for Christmas, a Navy official said today.
The election of Albert L. Diano Jr. as a vice president and director of the Sinclair Refining Company and its director of marketing was announced over the weekend by C.G. Drescher, president.
Edward Swayduck, president of Local 1, Amalgamated Lithographers of America, has appealed for a return to democratic practices in the labor movement.

Leo Solow, dance accompanist at the School of Performing Arts and a former concert pianist, died yesterday of a heart attack in the school, 120 West 48th Street. He was 64 years old and lived at 250 West 94th Street.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 5-- Dr. Carl A. Coppolino, a 34year-old physician accused of strangling a retired Army officer, went on trial for his life here today.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 5--As a crowd of almost 1,000 roared its approval, Prime Minister Ian D. Smith explained tonight why he had rejected Britain's proposals for settling the crisis over Rhodesian independence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois, defeated in his bid for re-election, will resume college teaching in New York City next month. He had left the profession when he was elected to the United Senate 18 years ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5-- Bayard Rustin said today that a guaranteed wage, not a guaranteed income, was the answer for people who were able to work.

GARY WOOD lived to play another day, such as next Sunday against Pittsburgh. The Giants' quarterback survived the debacle in Cleveland with merely a bruise --he was kicked in the leg. He is expected to recover quickly as has been his custom.
A NEW NAME has popped into the ranks of com panies with large, and perhaps significant, interests in the Studebaker Company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 5--North Vietnamese and Vietcong publications and broadcasts have devoted unusual attention in recent weeks to guerrilla warfare, analysts of Southeast Asian developments said today.

Requirements for an operator's license in New York State include a written test, a test of vision and a road test. New licenses include a sixmonth probationary period during which conviction for reckless or drunken driving, speeding or tail-gating brings automatic revocation of the license.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 5 (AP)--Ron Dunlap dropped in two free throws with 2 minutes 15 seconds to go in overtime tonight and led Illinois to a 98-97 victory over Kentucky, the country's third-ranked college basketball team.
About 30 housewives picketed Queens Borough Hall yesterday morning to protest the city's plans to build a low-cost housing project in middle-class Forest Hills.

ALBANY, Dec. 5--Governor Rockefeller made the first major cabinet change for his thirdterm administration today by announcing the appointment of Ronald B. Peterson, a career state employe, as the State Commissioner of Commerce.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 5--The Nationalist Chinese Government opened a special kind of plant processing zone yesterday where production is for export only.

Eastern Tennis Patrons, Inc., held its 10th annual ball in the Trianon Room at the New York Hilton last night. Among the 400 guests was James B. Somerall, president of the Pepsi-Cola Corporation, which sponsored the ball.
LONDON, Dec. 5--Britain won warm approval from her partners in the European Free Trade Association today for a renewed effort to join the Common Market.

A threatened slowdown by the city's 14,000 sanitationmen was averted at least temporarily yesterday when the Sanitation Commissioner promised to replace broken down equipment and apparently eased union resentment over the appointment of an inspector general.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5-- Senator George McGovern accused President Johnson today of "failure to match his words with deeds" in support of the world war on hunger he proclaimed two years ago.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, inspected the Opportunities Industrialization Center here today and praised its program as "most workmanlike."
Birdie Tebbetts was added to the official family of the New York Mets yesterday as special assistant to Bob Scheffing, the director of player development.

THE subject of shifting Mickey Mantle to first base is with us again. No one has ever doubted that it would be a great advantage to the Yankees if Mantle could be moved from the outfield to first. The question is not whether it is desirable, but whether it is at all possible.
Four of the seven directors of American Electronics, Inc., resigned on Nov. 1, according to Robert C. Loomis, president of the Fullerton, Calif., electronics concern.
IT appalls this corner to hear people complain each year at this time about the cold winds that come blowing down from the north.

The Electric Bond and Share Company announced yesterday that the initial quarterly dividend to be paid upon consummation of its merger with the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., would be 50 cents a share. Bond and Share paid 43 cents a share in each of this year's four quarters, while American and Foreign Power paid 29 cents a share in the period.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --Consumers increased their installment credit by only $380million during October, the smallest monthly advance in almost two years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 5 (AP)-- President Johnson disclosed today that the Post Office Department would start building and maintaining more of its own facilities, getting away from the 10-year-old program of leasing buildings from private interests.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 (AP)-- Buckpasser, Ogden Phipps's great 3-year-old thoroughbred, received another honor today when Turf and Sport Digest announced he had been named horse of the year and the top colt of his age in the magazine's annual poll of 195 racing writers and broadcasters.

TELL ME, TELL ME. New Poems and Prose. By Marianne Moore, 57 pages, Viking $3.95. IF, as Ezra Pound remarked, the best poetry consists of gists and piths, then put Marianne Moore down in the dossier as Exhibit A.

Copper futures rose the twocents-a-pound limit yesterday. The reason for the advance was not so much the increased copper set asides decreed last week by President Johnson, which did push up prices early in the day.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 5--At the Salisbury Club bar one day last spring a Rhodesian tobacco planter slapped a South African businessman on the back. "As long as they don't dare touch you, chum," he said, "we'll get by."
Three Metropolitan Hockey Association double-headers will be played at Madison Square Garden, the junior league's president, John Muckler, announced yesterday.
The Think Drink television campaign aimed at making coffee drinkers out of the 17-to-20 set will expand from its present 14 markets to a network push on Jan. 2.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary promoted 34 sergeants to lieutenant yesterday and 151 patrolmen to sergeant. Among those promoted were Wilmer A. Wichart, a 70,000-mile veteran of mayoral assignments that took him on the job to much of North America, Europe and the Far East.

Harry R. Held Jr., who retired last September as general superintendent of the Knickerbocker Construction Corporation, Three East 54th Street, died yesterday at his home in Arlington, Va. His age was 59.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city had almost reached the limit in imposing new taxes and that the Federal Government should help.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5--The United Nations was asked today to consider using a three-acre tract south of its headquarters property for acutely needed office space.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 5(AP)--Gov.-elect Ronald Reagan said at a news conference today that he did not believe the administration of the University of California should negotiate with students in the strife at the Berkeley campus.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced yesterday that savings and loan associations insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation had net outflow of savings of $59.8-million during October. State-chartered associations, the board said, had a net outflow of $92.7-million, but this was partly counterbalanced by an inflow of $32.9-million at Federally chartered associations.
After several weeks of relative stability, steel production declined sharply last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that poor inmates of prisons have the right to require the state to pay for legal papers used in appealing their convictions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --A Senate subcommittee is checking into allegations by a Foreign Service officer, Stephen A. Koczak, that he was forced into retirement after charging his superior with security violations.

Unless the Federal and state highway officials can be persuaded to change their plans, bids will be opened in Albany next week for construction of eleven miles of Interstate Highway 87 in Westchester County. This road is to be built along Chestnut Ridge.
ALBANY, Dec. 5--Four weeks ago tomorrow New York State voters chose 186 delegates to the 1967 Constitutional Convention, which could reshape state government for the next generation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI)--The Social Security Administration said today that it had no intention of budging from its insistence that each doctor sign a certification form when he puts a Medicare patient in the hospital.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 5 --Astronaut Edwin E. Aldrin Jr., a hero of the final Gemini space project flight, was welcomed home today.
MACAO, Dec. 5--A Macao pro-Communist newspaper said today that armed suppression of young Chinese rioters in this tiny territory "will bring serious consequences to the Portuguese Government."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused by one vote today to take on the question whether the right to counsel applies in misdemeanor cases.

The spot rate on the British pound dropped seven points to $2.7901 in moderate to fairly active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Traders linked the development to unfavorable news on the Rhodesian situation.
The Excelsior Savings Bank and the Empire City Savings Bank, two comparatively small Manhattan institutions, agreed yesterday on a merger.
BONN, Dec. 5--With West Germany's coalition Government only five days old, its two partners bridled at each other's policies today.
MONTREAL, Dec. 5 (AP)-- Twenty-five ocean-going vessels, only two of them above the Welland Canal, remained in the St. Lawrence seaway and the Great Lakes at 10 a.m. today, a Seaway spokesman said.
Barbara Hutton, heiress to the Woolworth fortune, made a brief stopover at Kennedy International Airport yesterday afternoon and denied reports that she was divorcing her seventh husband.
The election of Eric de Spirlet as president of Belgian Line, Inc., heads a list of executive changes announced here yesterday by the steamship company.

The world cannot yet know how close Britain and the white rebel regime may have come to agreement on steps to restore legitimate rule in Rhodesia. But what a world desperately anxious to head off economic war and racial explosion in all southern Africa will note above all is this:

LONDON, Nov. 5--Rootes Motors, Ltd., said tonight it had sought more money from and "a closer association" with the Chrysler Corporation but did not plan to let Chrysler acquire a majority of Rootes voting stock.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway's president, Ernest S. Marsh, informed his stockholders yesterday that the system would be able to slash its capital expenditures next year to about $80-million from this year's record $187.5-million and last year's, $157.1-million.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court ruled today that the Interstate Commerce Commission might determine maximum reasonable rates for rail shipments across the American border into Canada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to prevent the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads from making any changes in their operations prior to their merger.
The election of Sam M. Fleming, Edward Glassmeyer and John A. Hill to the board of Genesco, Inc., was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Nashville.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 5--Hudson County Judge Furman W. Reeves died today on the way to Chilton Memorial Hospital, Pompton Plains, after suffering a heart attack in his country home at Lake Iosco, Bloomingdale. He was 59 years old and lived at 2801 Kennedy Boulevard.
Air pollution has marred the $60-million, three-year-old New York Hilton Hotel at Rockefeller Center so badly that the building is already undergoing a $50,000 face lifting.

The Supreme Court's decision in the case of Julian Bond, the twice barred Georgia legislator, was a vigorous affirmation of the rights of free speech of all citizens as well as members of state legislatures.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 5 (UPI)--The Foreign Office said today it had asked Ambassador Hector Garcia Godoy in Washington for a report on disclosures that the Dominican Embassy telephones had been tapped on and off for the last 10 to 15 years by United States agencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The termination of Federal aid to six school districts and one college in the South for failure to comply with nondiscrimination provisions of the 1964 Civil Rights Act was announced today.

More than $22-million has been withdrawn from accounts in the Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National City Bank to protest loans the banks have made to South Africa's white-supremacist Government, the Committee of Conscience Against Apartheid said yesterday.

Eleven hands shot up in a fourth-grade classroom in South Jamaica, Queens, yesterday when a visitor from the Police Department's Youth Division asked: "Who of you boys would like to become a policeman?"
MACAO, Dec. 5 (AP)--With Chinese Communist gunboats appearing offshore, Portuguese and some Chinese residents left today for Hong Kong.

Something new and different, --Morton Subotnick's Prelude No. 4 for Piano and Electronic Sounds--was offered by Joy Pottle Smith at Town Hall last night. The pianist was joined by a couple of loudspeakers hooked to their source of electronic sounds backstage.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 5--President Johnson has been advised that the Air Force Academy is making a good recovery from last year's cheating scandal. The academy's board of visitors, including members of Congress and several educators, have reported no "permanent damage" to the school in Colorado Springs. Corrective actions have been taken slowly ...
Robin Flynn, a former editor of the broadcast desk at The New York Daily News, died yesterday in his home at 473 West End Avenue. He was 71 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court agreed today to hear three reapportionment cases in which groups seek to extend the one-man, one-vote doctrine to county government and school boards.

Roy Goodman, City Finance Administrator, said yesterday that he has been investigating for four months mail-order sales of tobacco by firms in Southern states to assure that New Yorkers were paying the proper cigarette tax.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 5 (AP)--Gov. George Romney said today he had told Michigan's Republican national committeemen, John Martin, to cancel a trip to New Hampshire, where Mr. Martin was to have conferred with Republican leaders about Mr. Romney's running in the Presidential primary there in 1968.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 6 (AP)-- In his role of Texas rancher, President Johnson turned up today at a corrugated steel building at Johnson City, where one of his prize bulls was auctioned off for $1,700--a bit less than $1 a pound.

Dick Gregory, the comedian, left for London from Kennedy International Airport yesterday on the first leg of his trip to Hanoi, North Vietnam. He left after receiving a United States State Department warning that his passport might be revoked or canceled.
Two detectives accused of having allowed a private investigator to take a picture for a divorce suit were brought up on disciplinary charges yesterday.
Charles G. Moerdler, the City Buildings Commissioner, called yesterday for the licensing of building superintendents in an effort to raise them above "just the guy who lives in the basement."
Robert E. Broome, who retired five years ago as a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York died on Saturday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 68 years old and lived in Delray Beach.
Lear-Siegler, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company, announced yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif., the election of R. Jamison Williams as vice president and a director.
NEWARK, Dec. 5 (AP)-- Dr. Angelo R. Bianchi, a physician for 65 years, died yesterday at the age of 93. He lived at 154 Elmwood Avenue.

LUXEMBOURG--The building looks like it should be in ancient Rome. Just below a cluster of stone figures on the roof are the initials A.R.B. E.D., which have come to symbolize the industrial importance of modern Luxembourg.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5-- An oil company executive said here tonight that the current unrest in the Middle East accentuates the need for the United States to develop its own petroleum resources.
The family of Sgt. Robert E. O'Malley left their home here yesterday to attend the Texas ceremony for the combat veteran.

FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 5-- A unified American aid group was established here today to coordinate the work of numer ous United States relief organizations seeking to help thousands of flood-stricken families.
"YOU don't have to worry about me this year," a 5-year-old named Richard assured Santa Claus at Gimbels last week. "We have a charge account."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --Public holdings of Series E and H Savings Bonds exceeded $50-billion for the first time last month, the Treasury Department reported today.
Leading Broadway showmen spoke yesterday on "How the Theater May Resolve Its Economic Dilemma" at the monthly luncheon-meeting held by the Drama Desk, the organization of theater writers, at Sardi's.

The Rockefeller Brothers Fund made 154 philanthropic grants totaling $6,559,129 in 1965, its 25th anniversary year, according to its annual report yesterday. This raised to more than $60,876,000 in grants made since 1940.
A roomful of judges sat in a conference room at the Civil Courthouse yesterday taking notes like law students on their first day in Torts I.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 5--The Texas White House denied today the surmise of some reporters that President Johnson exceeded the speed limit over a few stretches of a fogbound highway on his way to church yesterday morning.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 5--A Marine sergeant from Queens who jumped into a trench to attack the enemy with his rifle and grenades will receive the Corp's first Medal of Honor of the Vietnamese War tomorrow from President Johnson.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 (UPI) --Gene Shue, who played in the National Basketball Association for 10 years, was named today as the coach of the Baltimore Bullets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5-- Jesse M. Unruh, Democratic speaker of the California Assembly, said today that it was a "pipe dream" to expect Congress to share its tax revenues with the states.

Of the books about the United Nations, this is the first to combine a serious discussion of the world body with a chatty look at its insides. The book's value rests principally in the latter approach.

Don Hamilton, an executive of Affiliated Distillers Brands Corporation, a marketing subsidiary of Schenley Industries, Inc., died yesterday at Calvary Hospital, the Bronx. He was 61 years old and lived at 1140 Fifth Avenue, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The members of the Supreme Court were divided today over whether the Georgia Legislature can constitutionally select the state's next Governor.

BECAUSE Army and Navy were the topranking football teams in the land during the 1944 season, the national cham pionship was at stake in their climactic clash. The game not only had the entire country in a tizzy of anticipation, but interest in it also extended to battle fields and battle stations all over the globe.
PORTRAITS of two Renaissance scholars hang in the Washington office of Senator Paul Howard Douglas of Illinois. One is a giltframed oil of Erasmus, the other a pencil sketch of Sir Thomas More.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5-- Although it is early afternoon, 1,500 boys and girls ranging in age from 15 to 17 are wearing their shining morning faces. They fill every seat in the refurbished, old Civic Theater in downtown New Orleans. They have been brought here by bus from public and parochial high ...

The inscrutable and unpredictable Chinese Communists are presenting the world with another puzzle in Macao. Why all the fuss over a minor police clash concerning a new school, and why wait nearly three weeks after the incident occurred to call up the mobs of young hoodlums?
Prices on the American Stock Exchange eased yesterday in fairly active trading.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 (UPI)--A l964 peace proposal relayed from North Vietnam to the United States through Secretary General Thant was transmitted to him from Hanoi by the Soviet Union, unimpeachable sources said today.

That plume of rust colored something-or-other that puffed out of Consolidated Edison's generating plant in Ravenswood, Queens, on Sunday wasn't so bad as Mayor Lindsay seemed to think, the utility company said yesterday.

TRENTON, Dec. 5--A research report by the State Highway Department urges the banning of metal-studded snow tires in New Jersey. The study says they account for excessive wear and additional skidding hazards on road surfaces.
The shareholders of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., are expected to be offered at least $20 a share for their stock "within a reasonable time," Seven Arts Productions, Ltd., disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5--Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor said today that he considered prospects good for negotiations in 1967 to halt the war in Vietnam. He voiced concern, however, that premature negotiations might be ineffectual.

Mrs. Joan V., 35, has had a bitter struggle maintaining a home for her sons, David, 12, and Howard, 10. Deserted two years ago, she went to work as a sewingmachine operator, paying a neighbor to care for the boys after school. But the boys missed their father.

Three city and state legislators and the deputy borough president of Manhattan are seeking Mayor Lindsay's help in their intervention on behalf of a tenants' association of the Lincoln Towers apartment development in the group's dispute with the development's owner, the Aluminum Company of America, which is raising rents.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 5-- The faculty of the University of California, Berkeley, voted overwhelmingly tonight to support Chancellor Roger W. Heyns in his promise to enforce university rules. A student strike in a dispute over rules has been carried on since last Thursday.

Laurance Rockefeller, 22year-old nephew of Governor Rockefeller and son of Laurance S. Rockefeller, the business executive, was among 10 young people from across the country who began a training program here yesterday to qualify for VISTA (Volunteers in Service to America).
The Lindsay administration is considering creating a landscaped mall that would open a sweeping view between Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and Central Park.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Dec. 5-- Walter J. Hickel took the oath of office at noon today as the second Governor of Alaska, marking the state's turnover from a Democratic to a Republican Administration.

GENEVA, Dec. 5--Railroad workers should have the same basic right to strike as workers in other industries, it was agreed at a conference on inland transport held by the International Labor Organization, a United Nations agency.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 5 --Former Air Vice Marshal Omar Dhani, who was the commander of the Indonesian Air Force during the Communist attempt to seize power here last year, was accused today of having conspired with Communists and with other military officers to carry out "an armed rebellion."

The index numbers which the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics publishes each month an unemployment and living costs provide most Americans with their most intelligible barometer of the economy's ups and downs.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 5 (UPI)--Jo Jo White scored 23 points, most of them in the second half, as Kansas won its third straight game tonight, a 94-70 victory over Ohio State.

FAR-REACHING changes are being planned in the 20-by-20-foot office that Jorgen Reinhold Jenk said yesterday he had "pinched" from Georg Jensen's furniture floor when he moved to the store a year ago. Mr. Jenk, the Danish-born former vice president of Jensen's.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5--The Rev. Billy Graham told delegates to the general assembly of the National Council of Churches tonight that concern with social issues was an intrinsic part of religious conversion.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5--A Selective Service official opposed today a proposal to end student draft deferments and said that current needs did not require taking youths off campuses.

William I. Nichols, publisher and editorial director of This Week magazine, was elected chairman of the National Book Committee yesterday, succeeding Donald H. McGannon, president of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company. The committee is an organization devoted to the wider and wiser use of books.
A change in senior management was announced here yesterday by the BristolMyers Corporation, the drug producer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5-- United States officials indicated privately today that the Administration would support a British draft resolution proposing worldwide economic sanctions against Rhodesia.
BERLIN, Dec. 5. (UPI)-- East Germany was accused tonight of blocking agreement on passes for crossing into East Berlin and of confiscating holiday packages and sending them to North Vietnam.

A real "wake up" horse, David Frisch's Marchio, won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday to the surprise of most of the 25,520 chilled customers on hand. The outsider in the betting among the half-dozen contestants, Marchio paid $27.60 for $2.

The Department of Parks Marionette Theater will present "Beauty and the Beast" eight times during the Christmas holidays. The free performances will be held at 11 A.M. Dec. 28 through Dec. 31 and at 2:30 P.M. Dec. 27 through Dec. 30 at the Hunter College Playhouse, 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 5 (AP) --Thirty-four public health service nurses stayed home from work today and Mayor Thomas Whelan called their action "an illegal strike."
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 5--All the Hinds County schools that would lose Federal funds under the United States Office of Education order issued today are in rural and suburban sections outside Jackson.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Adopted series of resolu tions on four disarmament items; adopted two resolutions recommended by legal committee.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 5-- Reports from the Jordanian part of Jerusalem indicated tonight that there had been new violence today in Nablus, in Western Jordan. According to the reports, brought to Beirut by travelers, a policeman was killed.

MACKAY, Idaho Dec. 5 (AP)--Gene May, who is believed to have been the first pilot to fly faster than sound from a ground take-off, died today at his nearby hunting and fishing retreat, apparently of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI)--The Supreme Court agreed today to examine the constitutionality of a New York State law permitting the police to eavesdrop electronically with court approval.

Gunther Schuller's "The Visitation" will be given its American premiere by the Hamburg Opera at the Metropolitan Opera House next June. The opera was given its world premiere by the company in October, and will have 13 more performances in Hamburg this season. "The Visitation" will be performed twice during the opera's guest engagement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision that a loyalty oath requirement for membership in the Directors Guild of America is unreasonable and unlawful.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 5--United States Air Force pilots shot down one and possibly two MIG-17 jets yesterday during an attack on a fuel dump near Hanoi.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Nelson Rockefeller had scarcely been conceded his second re-election as Governor of New York when someone, in the early morning hours of Nov. 9, propounded a wisecrack. "Rocky will hold a news conference at Dartmouth tomorrow morning," it was suggested, "to tell the people of New Hampshire how much he loves them."
LONDON, Dec. 5 (Reuters)-- Following is text of Prime Minister Wilson's statement on the Rhodesian issue in the House of Commons today:
A new way to obtain diversification and modernization in the coat and suit manufacturing field was outlined yesterday by Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the New York Coat and Suit Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP)--Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Fla., announced today that he would not seek re-election as secretary of the Senate Democratic Conference in the 90th Congress. He has served six years in the post, which is one of three principal Senate Democratic leadership offices.
A priest in Brooklyn acted quickly yesterday to put out flames engulfing a 12-year-old altar boy whose surplice had brushed against a candle and caught fire.

Consolidated net earnings of Tektronix, Inc., for the second fiscal quarter ended Nov. 12 amounted to $3,172,000, or 40 cents a share, up 27.5 per cent from $2,491,000, or 31 cents a share, earned in the similar three months last year, the Beaverton, Ore., oscilloscope manufacturer reported yesterday.
Freeport Sulphur Company announced yesterday it had informed its domestic customers of a price increase for sulphur amounting to $2.50 a ton.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 5--A proposal that taxpayers be permitted to subtract their state income taxes from their Federal income tax payments "in order to increase local control of tax resources" was submitted today to a national farm organization.

MOSCOW, Dec. 5--Charges of illegal currency transactions confronting two American tourists--with possible sentences of three to eight years--involve a total of $70, the United States Embassy said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The Supreme Court left standing today a ruling that seven New York City newspapers committed unfair labor practices in 1964 when they refused to bargain individually with the International Typographical Union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the constitutional rights of Julian Bond, a Negro, had been violated when the Georgia House of Representatives excluded him from his elected seat because of his opposition to the draft and the Vietnam war.
SYDNEY, N.S., Dec. 5 (AP) --The Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation announced today additional layoffs at its steel plant here as a result of declining steel orders.
The Inter-American Development Bank announced yesterday the approval of loans equivalent to $31.65-million to finance water supply and sanitation projects in Venezuela and Brazil.
Levitt Sons, Inc., has decided to set up a branch office, its ninth, in Chicago. Richard L. Weiss, vice president of the homebuilding concern, will head the new office.
LAS VEGAS, Dec. 5--The administrator of the nation's space program heatedly defended space expenditures today in the face of criticism from the National League of Cities.
A firmer tone prevailed in the stock market yesterday as most leading averages moved ahead for the first time in more than a week.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec, 5--Britain called tonight for an early meeting of the Security Council to propose "additional measures to be taken against the illegal regime in Rhodesia."
TOULOUSE, France, Dec. 5 --Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin flew out of Paris today in President de Gaulle's Caravelle jet to inspect French technological progress.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 5 (Reuters)--Syria announced today it planned to impose fixed fees for the transit and export of oil across its territory by the Iraq Petroleum Company unless the company agreed to pay a lump sum to cover Syria's past losses.
Notre Dame defeated Michigan State by 35 points yesterday in the final Associated Press College Football poll of the 1966 season.

The Eltra Corporation--a leading producer of graphic arts equipment, automotive electrical equipment and other auto motive electrical equipment and parts made through its Electric Autolite subsidiary--reported yesterday a sharp rise in sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.
The following dispatch is by David Oancia of The Globe and Mail, Toronto.
HANUKKAH, the festival of lights and one of the happiest holidays in the Jewish calendar, begins at sundown tomorrow and lasts through Wednesday, Dec. 14.

Contributions of $1 or more to the American Campaign For Italian Flood Relief will serve as admission to special preview showings of the romantic comedy, "Arrivederci, Baby:" on Tuesday, Dec. 13, at the Forum Theater, Broadway and 47th Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The Government moved today to prod all states to include periodic driver examinations and motor vehicle inspections in their highway safety programs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court ruled today that a railroad worker does not have to exhaust Federal arbitration and contract grievance procedures before bringing suit for wrongful discharge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--It is good to see Mario Savio in the news again after his long disappearance from the headlines of campus protest. In the Berkeley student demonstrations of 1964 he was the only engaging figure who stood out among the drab masses of baffled bureaucrats, apoplectic cops and dreamy college kids quarreling among themselves about house rules, the future of humanity and whether pigs have wings.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 6-- Joseph Farano of Yorkers, a 36-year-old communications consultant, was sentenced today to serve eight months in the Westchester County Penitentiary for killing Harold Schmit, an executive of the International Business Machines Corporation. The court also set a fine of $1,000 if he does not submit to psychiatric treatment on release from prison.
The Securities and Exchange Commission's report on mutual funds has many virtues. But it also suffers from a major defect.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 6-- The student strike at the University of California was suspended tonight while students and teaching assistants debated their reaction to a stern threat from the Board of Regents.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 6--Bankers testified today before the Joint Legislative Committee on Banking Law that an increase in the 6 per cent maximum interest rate permitted on mortgages was vital to the state's economy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6--Paul G. Hoffman and David Owen have been confirmed as co-administrators of the United Nations Development Program for twoyear terms, on appointment by Secretary General Thant.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 6-- Mr. and Mrs. C. Ashley Wright have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Victoria Wright, to Charles Raymond Meyers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyers of Hampton, N.J.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 6 --Mark Donohue's victory in the Nassau Trophy race here last Sunday assured his selection as the outstanding American sports car driver of the year. It was his second major triumph of the season, the first having been registered in the Canadian-American ...

CAIRO, Dec. 6--Jordan's foreign minister arrived today for an emergency Arab League meeting that is expected to become a showdown between his Government and radical Arab leaders who have been demanding its overthrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) --A review board called today for drastic action to salvage the space agency's $741.2-million observatory satellite program.

CALCUTTA, Dec. 6 (AP)-- Ramanathan Krishnan battled back from the brink of defeat today for a 3-6, 6-4, 10-12, 7-5, 6-2 victory over Tomas Koch that upset Brazil, 3-2, and sent India into the Davis Cup challenge round for the first time.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 6 (UPI)--The United States tonight orbited a versatile new weather observer and broadcast relay satellite.
Thomas Scherman played a game of musical chairs in arranging the Little Orchestra Society program that he led at Philharmonic Hall last night. The result was refreshing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- The Treasury auctioned $800million in tax-anticipation bills today at an average discount rate of 5.246 per cent.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 6 (AP)--Marine scientists have reported that part of the ocean between Catalina Island and San Pedro supports no living things.
An investigation to determine whether Criminal Court Judge Benjamin H. Schor should be removed from the bench was ordered yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

A spokesman for Mrs. John F. Kennedy confirmed here yesterday that the widow of the President had rejected a $3,000 gift to the Kennedy Memorial Library from Paul B. Fay Jr., a wartime friend of her husband.
Christmas is a time for giving, but not a time for the public to be giving anything to city employes, Investigation Commissioner Arnold G. Fraiman warned yesterday.
VERMONT broke its previous high mark for deer shot during the regular season recently ended when hunters bagged 16,831 animals. This compares with 16,029 taken a year ago.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6--Homebuilders have been heartened by enthusiastic public response to the new "open-space" concept of suburban development, but they have learned that successful communities of this type must avoid a number of pitfalls.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Supreme Court yesterday extended its assertion of control of political procedures in the United States to a degree that could establish Dec. 5, 1966, as a new landmark date in the exercise of Federal judicial supremacy over popular and legislative actions in the states.
Louis E. Stephens, founder and retired head of the General Products Company, S.A., of Mexico, a chemical company, died last Thursday in Los Angeles. His age was 64.

For Mario Sucajayo, life back home may never be the same. Mario is a 12-year-old Aymara Indian and home is a village of adobe huts in the mountains of Bolivia. Mario was recently named his country's outstanding young scholar in a nationwide test conducted by the United Nations Children's Fund. His reward was a trip to the United States in behalf of UNICEF's 20th anniversary and appearances on at least two television programs.
Senator William Proxmire joined yesterday the widening public discussion of future Federal fiscal policy, declaring that a "tax increase could be a serious blunder."

BECAUSE baseball has long held the suspicion that Walter O'Malley springs from the Celtic branch of the Machi avelli family, not everybody in the sport accepts the official explanation of the reasoning behind the Dodger trade of Maury Wills to the Pirates. As a onetime kisser of the Blarney Stone, Wily Walter can make anything sound plausible. Yet folks still keep wondering what, if anything, lies below the surface.
CHESTER, Pa., Dec. 6 (AP) --Clarence H. Roberts, 68 years old, became the first Negro president of the Chester board of education last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) --The typical new member of the House favors military escalation if necessary to win the Vietnam war, wants to cut domestic spending rather than raise taxes and sees no need for more civil rights legislation now, a survey showed today.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6-- Lieut. Gen. Pascual Angel Pistarini, who led the military coup that toppled the constitutional Government of President Arturo U. Illia in June, has unexpectedly retired from active duty, the Argentine Government announced today.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that under no circumstances would he take a spot on the Republican national ticket in 1968.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Four oil paintings in the United States Capitol, three of them more than a century old, were slashed with sewing scissors today by a vandal.

A spokesman for the Lockheed Corporation in Los Angeles said yesterday that approximately 2,200 Starfighter planes were being flown in 14 countries and that apparently only West Germany was having trouble with the plane.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6 (AP)--The war in Vietnam "just might fade out" with no formal end, Henry Cabot Lodge said today.
IN going over the year's outstanding nonfiction titles, I have come up with a list of more than 50 books that are, in my opinion, particularly interesting, engaging, or likely to be of lasting value.
Vice President Humphrey said last night that the United States "must find a way to insure better exchange of technological and organizational experience without jeopardizing national security."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6--Africans will demand that the Security Council adopt a resolution telling United Nations members not to buy Rhodesian chrome ore, pig iron and tobacco, diplomats said today.

PARIS--Understandably the United States has had an obsession about surprise attacks since the terrible day, just 25 years ago, when an insidious but brilliantly devised Japanese assault destroyed our Pacific battle fleet at Pearl Harbor. What was possible then, in an age of battleships and carriers, is infinitely more possible now in an age of nuclear missiles and atomic submarines. The art of war has taken a quantum jump.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Bayard Rustin and A. Philip Randolph joined today the growing band of critics accusing the Johnson Administration of sacrificing the urban poor to military and scientific programs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) --In line with a new policy, the Civil Aeronautics Board has approved an agreement of World Airways, Inc., Oakland, Calif., and Berry World Travel, Kansas City, Mo., setting up the largest domestic package tour program in airline history.

The Polar International Brokerage Corporation, general insurance brokers, announced here yesterday the acquisition of two insurance companies and the election of their owners as corporate officers. Lee Gertner, formerly president of Magna Brokers, Ltd., was elected a senior vice president. Jack L. Snyder, head of the Jack L. Snyder Company, was elected a vice president.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP)--The American Medical Association says an Ohio controversy over payment for care of some welfare patients has tied up about $1.2-million in unpaid medical bills.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 6--Common Market ministers made a small amount of progress today in narrowing their differences on agricultural offers to be made in the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations.
A traffic expert was talking humorously yesterday about confusing road signs scattered around the state when he bumped head-on into an unusual roadblock--Governor Rockefeller.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 6 (UPI)--Juvenile authorities said today that three straight-A high school students had admitted taking up to $100,000 worth of equipment from seven commercial airplanes lined up for maintenance at an airport.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 6--A sophomore center, Pete Tufford, scored four goals in the first period to lead the Cornell hockey team to a surprisingly easy 8-0 victory over St. Lawrence University at Lynah Rink tonight.
PARIS, Dec. 6--The French Communist party gave emphatic support today to the Soviet case in the ideological conflict between the Soviet and Chinese Communists.

Rick Barry, the New Jersey boy from Miami, Fla., who is responsible for a renewal of basketball interest in San Francisco, Calif., showed New York last night why he is the scoring-champion-to-be of the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Probably the best place to start cutting the budget is on Page 394 of The Statistical Abstract of the United States, headed "Subsidy Programs of the Federal Government." It puts the cost of Federal subsidies at $3.853 billion in 1955 and estimates it as $8.536 billion in fiscal 1967.
Approval by the European Free Trade Association now clears the way for Prime Minister Wilson to pursue entry into the Common Market with visits to the capitals of its six member nations.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 6-- Arthur S. Flemming, president of the University of Oregon and former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Eisenhower Administration, was elected today to a three-year term as president of the National Council of Churches.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (AP)-- The United States Embassy delivered a protest to the Foreign Ministry today over the "impermissible treatment" of Vladimir Kazan-Komarek, an American citizen being held in Czechoslovakia on spy charges, and demanded his release.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The United Automobile Workers union has fallen behind in its financial payments to the merged labor federation and faces suspension from membership unless it pays up by Dec. 15.
The Maimonides Institute for Exceptional Children, which serves youngsters with learning disabilities, will receive the proceeds of a dinner to be held on Sunday evening at the New York Hilton.

TRENTON, Dec. 6--Governor Richard J. Hughes called today for an end to the state's muchcriticized Migrant Labor Board. He said he would recommend this formally in his message to the Legislature next month.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday ended six straight sessions of losses. The list advanced in its most active trading in almost a month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a number of relatively minor amendments to its rules covering the solicitation of proxies and the materials that are sent to shareholders in connection with such proxy solicitations.
BELGRADE, Yugoslvia, Dec. 6--A series of recent incidents have highlighted disputes on nationality questions between Yugoslavia and Bulgaria, on the one hand, and Yugoslavia and Rumania on the other.
OTTAWA, Dec. 6--Philip Givens of Toronto was one of five Mayors to be defeated in municipal elections in Ontario yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6--The advantages and drawbacks of an all volunteer military force in the place of Selective Service were debated today at the National Conference on the Draft at the University of Chicago.
LYONS, France, Dec. 6-- Cheering workers mobbed Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin today as he toured factories outside France's third most populous city.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Dec. 6-- The defense counsel for Dr. Carl A. Coppolino admitted in court today that the anesthesiologist accused of murder may have carried on a love affair with the wife of the man he is accused of slaying.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 (UPI) --The grand jury investigating the 1954 murder of Samuel H. Sheppard's first wife suspended its hearing into the case today after hearing two witnesses.

More than 50,000 commutersfrom Westchester and Connecticut scrambled in the cold yesterday morning to subways, buses and cabs as their trains were delayed for more than two hours because of a fire on the New York Central tracks. The blaze was in a transformer on the tracks at Park Avenue near 90th Street.

Mayor Lindsay predicted yesterday that within the next two years the city would be "well on the road to ending many types of air pollution," especially those emanating from industrial plants and incinerators.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 6 --Albin E. Elander, a vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died last night at Lawrence Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived here.
The bond market got over its first hurdle yesterday in excellent shape as it entered a threeday obstacle race of newissue sales.

The appointment of William G. Gridley as executive director of the English Speaking Union of the United States was announced yesterday. Mr. Gridley, a former vice president of the National City Bank, succeeds John J. Schieffelin, who served as executive director for the last three years.

Samuel Culviner Jr. of 549 West 123d Street and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, N.Y., retired publicity and advertising manager of the former Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died on Monday at St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 81.
Lincoln Center's new chartered-bus service drew only two customers in its first run to the upper East Side Monday night. But by the second trip there was standing room only.
When word of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor was received in New York on Sunday afternoon, Dec. 7, 1941, the city and its surroundings immediately went on a war footing.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that two large merchandisers--Lerner Stores and Spartans Industries, owners of the Korvette stores--would lease space in a building to rise over the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks between 31st and 33d Streets from Ninth to Tenth Avenues.
BUJUMBURA, Burundi, Dec. 6 (Reuters)--Col. Michel Micombero, who became Burundi's first President after a military coup d'etat last month, formed a Government today.

Myron D. Reeser, who retired in 1962 as vice president and a director of the Howes Publishing Company, 44 East 23d Street, died Sunday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived at 82 Southgate Road, Murray Hill N.J.

BONN, Dec. 6--Kurt Georg Kiesinger had an especially friendly word for President de Gaulle when he replied to messages of congratulations on his becoming Chancellor from the heads of government of West Germany's principal allies.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press)--Seven ocean-going ships still remained in the St. Lawrence Seaway and Lake Ontario today, but a seaway spokesman said all the ships should be out before the winter freeze. The seaway probably will stay open on a day-to-day basis until at least Friday, he said.
A 14-year-old boy was arrested yesterday on charges that he demolished three telephone booths in the Bronx with homemade bombs.
ROME, Dec. 6--Deputy Mario Alicata, a high-ranking Communist leader and the director of the party newspaper L'Unita, died today of a heart attack. He was 48 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) --Organized labor is protesting that a tighter new Federal policy for counting the unemployed will slow action by Congress and the Johnson Administration aimed at helping the nation's jobless.

Copies of a 10-page newsletter, The Crusader, from Communist China were received here yesterday, the first published from Peking by Robert F Williams, who described himself "an Afro-American freedom fighter."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 6 (AP)--The State of Iowa filed suit in United States District Court today charging 22 companies with conspiring to fix asphalt prices in sales to the State Highway Commission and many cities, towns and counties.
Robert Moses has proposed that the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority build a new home for the New York Stock Exchange on filled-in land in the Hudson River.

A YEAR ago, the Pittsburgh Steelers were in a condition similar to that of the New York Giants now. The team had lost 10 of 12 games (and was to lose two more, finishing last in the National Football League). The route to future respectability looked like a long uphill ...
A sailor sought for more than a year as a deserter was found yesterday, serving as a shore patrolman at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.7 on Monday from 102.9 on Friday.

Paperboard production rose 3 per cent with 443,800 tons in the week ended Dec. 3, from 430,700 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has issued subpoenas to 24 Broadway ticket brokers and box-office treasurers in an inquiry into possible violations of the law governing the resale of tickets.

AN evening of soothing pleasure came to televi sion last night in the Columbia Broadcasting System's exquisite special entitled "S. Hurok Presents." The little box in the home, so often raucous and so often dingy, found its dignity in the enduring joy of letting artistry speak for itself.
"The Sound of Music," which will end a 93-week reservedseat first-run stand at the Rivoli Theater on Sunday, will begin engagements on Dec. 21 at nine theaters in the metropolitan area.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday it had broken up a major ring of obscenity dealers by the arrest of nine men described as national suppliers of lewd color photographs and movies.
Brooklyn was depicted yesterday as a crime-ridden borough where women were afraid to visit their doctors at night, church services were not held after dark and merchants closed their stores early.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Dec. 6 (AP) --A Princeton sophomore, Chris Thomforde, sparked a strong defense and added 14 points to lead the Tigers to a 48-37 basketball victory over Villanova tonight.

LAST week, in a program called "Past Midnight! Past the Morning Star!," a young actress named Julia Beals portrayed Emily Dickinson as a repressed and slightly stiff spinster whose poems were a safety valve for emotions she was otherwise powerless to express.

Lew Abrams Greene, a vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company advertising agency until his retirement in 1953, died yesterday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived on Long Ridge Road in Bedford Village, N.Y.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that a Harlem block had been selected as the site for a new 23-story state office building and possibly, at some future time, a cultural and community center.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 6--Former members of India's governing Congress party decided today to form a nationwide opposition party called the People's Congress.

HANTHAWADDY DISTRICT, Burma, Nov. 30--The army regime's determined efforts to achieve an agrarian revolution in Burma's green countryside have not significantly improved the lot of the farmers, according to villagers here in the Irrawaddy River delta.
The election of Delbert L. Mills to the board of the Radio Corporation of America was announced here yesterday.
The United Artists Corporation had an abundance of news for shareholders yesterday.
A group of the nation's major chain store organizations achieved moderately higher sales in November than in the corresponding 1965 month, reports showed yesterday.

Camp Moodna, an affiliate of the Grand Street Settlement, will benefit from a supper dance at L'Etoile on Dec. 20 and a party earlier that evening at the premiere of the film "Funeral in Berlin" at the Tower East Theater.

The Metropolitan Opera and the musicians of its orchestra have reached agreement on the final terms of a new labor contract, it was announced jointly yesterday by the Met and Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, representing the orchestra members.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--After three months of negotiations, the United States and France have reached an impasse on terms under which United States forces might be permitted to return to bases in France.

Mrs. Alice Higinbotham Patterson, first wife of the late Joseph Medill Patterson, a founder of The New York Daily News, and mother of the late Mrs. Alicia Patterson Guggenheim, editor and publisher of Newsday, Long Island newspaper, died yesterday in her Chicago home. Her age was 87.
The hottest jockey to spring from the sidewalks of New York since Mike Venezia is a 4-foot-10-inch 95-pounder from the Bronx named Ernie Cardone.
Personalities in broadcasting and music will join for a tribute to Milton Cross on Tuesday in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre.

President Johnson rewarded bravery in Vietnam with a well-merited Medal of Honor for a marine from Queens, Robert O'Malley--and then inexcusably marred his tribute with the implication that dissenters against the war in Vietnam are little better than cowards who allow others to do their fighting for them.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 7--A MIG-17 pilot shot down a United States Air Force F-105 Thunderchief as intensified raids continued northwest of Hanoi, an American military spokesman said today.

On Oct. 23, 1962, when Mayor Robert F. Wagner arrived to dedicate a new 14-story nurses' residence and training hall at Metropolitan Hospital, the ceremony had to be moved to another site because brickwork had broken away from the building where the program was to have been held.
Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Dudley, former Borough President of Manhattan, was designated yesterday to be Administrative Judge of the city's Criminal Court.
JERUSALEM (Jordan), Dec. 6--Nablus and Hebron, trouble spots in western Jordan, were under tight curfew tonight in the wake of demonstrations yesterday against the regime of King Hussein.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 6 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower canceled a trip to New York today because of the widespread public concern over his health, a spokesman said.

The New York Academy of Sciences said yesterday it would press ahead with plans to build a World Science Center in the block where the city is studying the creation of a mall to link Central Park and the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 6 (AP)--Municipal leaders should not hope to save the nation's cities by continuous surgery through urban renewal, a top international planner said here today.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 (AP)--The Chrysler corporation announced today that it would lay off nearly 700 employes in two of its seven assembly plants, effective Jan. 9.
AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Dec. 6 (AP)--Col. Francis E. Merritt, of Englewood, N.J., was named today the Air Force Academy's fifth director of athletics, replacing Col. Edmund A. Rafalko.

The fronds of the palm trees still wave above Ford Island, and beyond the fringing reef with its white crescent of surf the deep blue of the Pacific frames a mid-ocean scene of peace. The soft breezes riffle the surface of Pearl Harbor today, just as they did 25 years ago, on that day that changed the world.
The long gray line of Army football passed in review yesterday at the West Point Society's luncheon at the Hotel Americana.
HONOLULU, Dec. 6--War came brutally and suddenly as these sun-drenched islands emerged from sleep on a serene Sunday 25 years ago tomorrow.

Arthur I. Goldstein, a lawyer who practiced for many years in Forest Hills, Queens, and who had been active in the Liberal party, died Saturday. He was 66 years old and lived at 62-60 108th Street, Forest Hills.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Administration acted today for the second time in less than a week to provide funds to finance home mortgages and thereby to help revive the depressed housing industry.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 6--President Johnson disclosed today that he would ask Congress to appropriate $9-billion to $10billion more to pay for the war in Vietnam in the current fiscal year.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 6 (AP)--The bodies of a 22-yearold woman and her 10-monthold son, reported missing since Friday, have been found hidden in the basement and in a second-floor closet of their home.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 6-- Peter H. Odegard, a professor of political science at the University of California, died early today at Kaiser Hospital, Oakland, where he was admitted last night after a heart attack. He was 65 years old.
EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 6 (AP) --Second-ranked Texas Western downed East Texas State, 61-30, in basketball tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) --Gregory W. Maxwell, president of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad, testified today that the line might lose more than half its iron-ore traffic by 1968.

Mr. and Mrs. Dawson Coleman Glover of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Deere Glover, to Arnold Harold Dunne, son of Mrs. Ben Pincus of New York and the late Sydney Dunne.

PEKING, Dec. 6--The wall poster was unsigned and its phraseology somewhat ambiguous, but its implications were sweeping and it suggested that a roundup of opponents of Chairman Mao Tse-tung was beginning.
PRETORIA, South Afirca, Dec. 6 (Reuters)--Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster made tonight what amounted to a strong appeal to Britain and Rhodesia to settle their dispute "even at this late hour."
Walston Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of Glenn R. Miller as executive vice president.
DALLAS, Dec. 6--The nations state insurance commissioners, meeting in convention here, have agreed to ask Congress to guarantee insurance protection for homes and businesses damaged by floods.

A magnificent "thank you" gift came yesterday to the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, a weighty, manypaged 15th-century Hebrew manuscript on vellum that reveals on each page the art of an unusually gifted illuminator.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 6-- In a symbolic setting of unprofitable opulence, the Thoroughbred Racing Association raised today the familiar cry of "foul!" against excessive pari-mutuel taxation.
FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 6 --The first of some 300 flooddamaged wood panel paintings began today a winter "hibernation" in near-freezing temperatures and almost 100 per cent humidity.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 6 (AP)--The Memphis police faced their third murder case in three days as the body of a liquor store clerk, father of a well-known, golfer, was found in the store.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6-- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court refused this afternoon to take further action in the dispute over the admission of Negroes to Girard College.
Mayor Lindsay returned yesterday to his attack on the Johnson Administration for cutting back on funds for housing, antipoverty programs and urban development.
HONOLULU, Dec. 6--Mitsuo Fuchida, the former Japanese naval officer who led the attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, is a secret visitor to Honolulu on the eve of the 25th aniversary of the event.

Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan told a group of Negro and white parents yesterday that he would review the appointment of the principal for the combined Public School 36-125 on the western edge of Harlem.
Two 18-year-old Manhattan youths were booked in Brooklyn yesterday on homicide charges in connection with the knife slaying last Thursday of Hyman Getnick, an 80-year-old tailor.

WARWICK, N.Y., Dec. 6-- Mrs. Grace Remsen Nelson, first wife of Godfrey N. Nelson, who was a vice president and secretary of The New York Times at his death in 1954, died here Sunday at her home. She was 87 years old.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 6 (AP) --State District Judge Louis T. Holland announced today that Jack L. Ruby's new trial for the slaying of Lee Harvey Oswald would be held in Wichita Falls sometime next year, possibly in February.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Dr. Lazar Volin, who retired last year as agricultural specialist on the Soviet Union for the Department of Agriculture, died today at George Washington University Hospital. He was 70 years old.
Prayers, gift-giving and the traditional lighting of candles will mark the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, which begins at sundown today.
The three-year-old Saigon Daily News--whose 10,000 readers are G.I.'s and members of the diplomatic corps, aid missions and business community-- is going to make a big push for American advertisers.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Dec. 6 --The police raided an exclusive preparatory school here yesterday and arrested two 17-yearold students on narcotics charges.
In an effort to insure that answers to a policeman's questions will stand up as evidence in court, the Police Department has drafted a new interrogation report form, it was learned yesterday.
The State University College at New Paltz, N.Y., has acquired a 25,000-volume research library of French colonial history dating from 1830.
Plans for the construction of a new $10-million international terminal for Boston's Logan Airport got under way yesterday with the selection of architects by the Massachusetts Port Authority.
ROME, Dec. 6 (AP)--The Italian Government is considering forming a women's auxiliary military corps. The first big question is not what they will do but what they will wear.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 6 (UPI) --All but a handful of Jersey City's 50 public health nurses reported sick for a second day today despite threats of court action by Mayor Thomas J. Whelan, who charged the nurses with staging "an illegal strike."

Fans who are worried that Coach Ara Parseghian might be playing "What's My Line?" this winter need not be concerned. The Notre Dame coach indicated in an interview yesterday that he had plenty of replacements for the seven topnotch linemen being lost at South Bend through graduation.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would ask the next Legislature to create a State Department of Transportation.
At Lincoln Center tonight "Tristan and Isolde," Metropolitan Opera, 7:45; Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
VIENNA, Dec. 6--An Austrian jury sentenced a former guard of the Treblinka concen-- tration camp in Poland to 10 years in prison today.

THE South American Championships played in Sao Paulo, Brazil, last month, resulted in the closest finish ever recorded in an international event. Venezuela and Brazil tied for first position on victory point scores, and played an additional 30-board match to decide the title.
BOSTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)-- Gary Peters staged a complete reversal in form during 1966 to win the American League earned-run-average title with a 1.98 percentage.

QUEBEC, Dec. 6--The shaky reception accorded the last two Quebec provincial bond issues has prompted Quebec's Premier, Daniel Johnson, to plan meetings next month with investors in New York and Toronto.
LONDON, Dec. 6--British newspapers expressed concern today about the possible consequences of Rhodesia's rejection of the British plan to settle the independence crisis.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., which is negotiating for $100-million in new financing to tide it over a critical period of heavy losses, has asked the Defense Department to guarantee the repayment of somewhat more than half of its borrowing.
Miss Judith Ann Mendlowitz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Mendlowitz, was married yesterday evening to Pvt. David L. Buskin. U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Buskin of the Bronx.

LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)-- The Guardian, A 110-year-old national liberal daily newspaper, is seeking to cut costs by 500,000 ($1.4 million) a year because of serious financial difficulties, the management announced tonight.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 6 (UPI)--Rini Zarova Willson, wife of the composer Meredith Willson, died of cancer today in St. John's Hospital. She was 54 years old.

PARIS--The prettiest thing in the house of Lanvin has big blue eyes and black hair. She is 25-year-old Mrs. Bernard Lanvin. Not a typical Lanvin lady at all, she wears her skirts very short and her hair very long, belts her fur coat, buys high boots or Vivier shoes, drives a small car, laughs a lot and takes life in big skips.
ROME, Dec. 6--Nineteen international airlines that fly the North Atlantic opened a meeting here today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 6 --Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Ring have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Ring, to David Joel Kolasky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Kolasky of Brooklyn. New York.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 6 (AP)--Competition began today in the 14th annual Goodwill golf tournament over three Bermuda courses, with American teams shooting the best rounds on two of them.
City officials conceded last night that New York would pay "about $50,000" in overtime to former antipoverty executives earning $10,000 to $25,000 a year.
The Cerro Corporation, a large copper producer, plans a $45-million, partly financed by a $30-million, 20-year loan from "institutional investors," Robert P. Koenig, president, announced yesterday.
Tom Vcleckie set a school wrestling record with a 20-second victory as New York University defeated Hunter, 36-10, at the loser's gymnasium in the Bronx last night.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange suffered sharp setbacks at the opening of trading yesterday in the wake of the Rhodesian Government's rejection of British proposals in talks seeking a settlement of the dispute between London and Salisbury.
WASHINGTON Dec. 6 (UPI)--Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, attacked the Federal Reserve Board today for causing a "second day of infamy" by deciding to raise interest rates a year ago.
PARIS, Dec. 6--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he thought United States ground forces in Europe could be reduced by two-thirds without harming allied security.

FANTASTIC--or words to that effect. It could be, just possibly, that that ol' demon dance is returning to the choreographic avantgarde. In this matter I can report merely from the exterior, but I report all the same.
"MY SWEET CHARLIE" is a restless little play about two people who have no place to go. It puts its actors into precisely the same situation.
GROTON, Conn., Dec. 6 (AP)--Husband E. Kimmel has not forgotten Pearl Harbor, and never will.
The retirement of A.J. (Gush Keller, manager of the customs, immigration and crew department of Furness, Withy Co., Ltd. has been announced.
SUFFERN, N.Y.--The first state-supported vocational guidance center for women in the country, a development that underlines the feminine in American society, is now operating here.
Resilience--the mark of most good teams--has been a New York Ranger trademark throughout the National Hockey League season.

The first day of a sale of the jewels collected by the late Mrs. Sidney Gilder de Kay of New York and Greenwich, Conn., brought $487,520 yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. Gallery officials hope the sale, which continues today, will bring a total of more than $1-million.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 6-- On Dec. 24, the newly elected president of the National Council of Churches will assemble his five grown children and their spouses and children in Washington, and lead them on a Christmas shopping spree.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 6-- A high official of the foreign aid administration said today that the United States was losing the battle against world hunger and that unless the tide was reversed, a third world war was only a question of time.

The merger of the Bank of New York and the Empire Trust Company takes effect today as the banks open for business under the name of the Bank of New York. The institution will be New York City's ninth billion-dollar bank.
The Commerce Department issued yesterday a report recommending an overhaul of railroad, truck and barge-line accounting methods that would enable those industries to improve their profit margins.
One of the art world's most intensive talent hunts--the international search for a successor to the late James J. Rorimer as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art--may end in the next few weeks.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 6 (AP)--Navy sank 59 per cent of its shots in gaining an 88-81 basketball victory over American University today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6--Prolonged and enthusiastic applause exploded at a Kremlin meeting today in response to praise of the wartime leadership of Stalin and Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov.

THE PHOTOCOPY companies--at least three of the leaders anyway--shone in yesterday's rising market. Xerox achieved a 6 gain to 207. SCM was up 2 1/8, at 64 1/8, and AddressographMultigraph rose 1, to 53.
EASTON, Pa., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Ken Bunn resigned tonight as head football coach at Lafayette College.
For the first time in the history of the United States, a Negro has been chosen to preside in a Federal court in the deep South.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 6-- The controversy over building Interstate Highway 87 through wildlife sanctuaries and scenic estates of Chestnut Ridge in Bedford-flared anew today.
Two top-ranking state officials suggested yesterday that delegates to State Constitutional Conventions be chosen hereafter at special elections.

Letters to the Neediest Cases Fund revealed yesterday the pleasure that donors feel in giving, not only in memory of beloved relatives or friends, but also in recognition of others who have made life happier.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dcc. 6 (AP)--Gale warnings flew along the California coast today as more heavy rains flooded lowlands in that's storm-battered state. A bridge collapsed and power was out for hours.

GENEVA, Dec. 6--The theological dialogue about Christian unity cannot go on forever, according to the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, the new General Secretary of the World Council of Churches. The dialogue must end in decisions, Dr. Blake said, and the present desire among Christians for unity is a hopeful sign.
Treasured awards were presented to Earl (Red) Blaik, the former Army football coach, and Bill Carpenter, Blaik's lonely end and more recently a war hero in Vietnam.

The champion of the first half, Cassius Clay, couldn't sleep at night, wracked by the memory of that burning question posed by young and old, by black and white, by rich and poor from North to South: "What about Ernie Terrell?"

PHILADELPHIA, Dec.6 (AP) --The Philadelphia 76ers, with Wilt Chamberlain and Chet Walker leading the offense, defeated the slumping Chicago Bulls, 129-119, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 6 (Reuters)--The officers of a Dutch freighter opened fire on mutinous Chinese seamen who tried to storm the captain's bridge with hatchets, Knives and crowbars while in port here today.
Price increases were announced yesterday by manufacturers of tungsten, chlorine and caustic soda.
The spot rate on the British pound turned lower in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

JERUSALEM (Israel), Dec. 6--Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that Israel's thrust against Jordan three weeks ago, far from bringing the Middle East to the brink of war, had apparently stabilized the situation.
FLINT, Mich. Dec. 6 (AP)-- Cemetery operators in Flint say they are ending racial discrimination in graveyards because of a Negro's successful fight to bury his mother in an all-white cemetery.
Shaking off its recent sluggishness, the stock market yesterday scored its first fullfledged advance in seven sessions.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 6--Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said tonight that he thought it unreasonable and irresponsible of Prime Minister Wilson of Britain not to be satisfied with Rhodesia's acceptance of his proposals for constitutional reform in this former colony.
Two initial public offerings of common stock reached the market yesterday and both met good receptions.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 6-- Miss Mary Ann Barbara Peters and Vincent Quadre Giffuni plan to be married on Feb. 4. Their engagement has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Peters of Glen Cove and Lakeville, Conn., parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Giffuni is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew L. Giffuni of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.
The escalation in Vietnam has given Brig. Gen. Clarence W. Clapsaddle Jr. a "whole hatful of problems" but generally the New York area defense industry has "responded quite well" to the build-up.
James (Jimmy) Donahue, 53 years old, an heir to the Woolworth dime-store fortune, was found dead yesterday in the home of his mother, Mrs. James P. Donahue, 834 Fifth Avenue.

All the rhetoric unleashed during the House Rules Committee's pointless interrogation of United States Education Commissioner Harold Howe 2d two months ago could not obscure the fact that recalcitrant segregationist school districts rather than the Federal enforcement procedures remain on trial.

For the first time since its formation in 1948, the International Theater Institute, which promotes exchange and knowledge in theater arts, will hold its convention in New York. About 150 delegates from 48 countries will assemble at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel from June 4 through June 11.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., is seeking to put to work part of the $32,702,066 condemnation award it received last October from the city.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP)-- Louis Wildermeersch of Antwerp, Belgium, averaged 205 and won eight of 14 games today to take the opening day lead in the international masters bowling tournament.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 6 (AP)-- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today that the Cincinnati School Board did not have to transport children by bus to prevent segregation.
LONDON, Dec. 6--Commonwealth representatives put pressure on Britain today to include oil supplies for Rhodesia among the items on which she will seek United Nations sanctions.
MIAMI, Dec. 6 (AP)--Jesterson, ridden by Larry Adams, held off favored Dempsey and fast-closing Onward Upward to score a hard-earned victory today in the ninth race at Tropical Park.
Martin Rarback, the painters union official indicted on charges of having taken $840,000 in bribes, has been appointed to an organizing position in New York District Council 9.
A special three-man board of inquiry on the long plumbers' strike will make its report public today.
