Copper futures trading was more of the same yesterday. Prices for some contracts again moved up the 2-cent-a-pound limit, responding to news that Rhodesia had rejected British proposals to end the rebellion.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP)-- Mark Twain's "Huckleberry Finn" is considered embarrassing by a group of students who have protested against the book's being on the required reading list at the University of Massachusetts.
ATHENS, Dec. 6--The Greek Government said today that it had settled its dispute with Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, over his secret arms deal with Czechoslovakia.
Two measures to protect consumers--one against fraudulent retail advertising, the other against unscrupulous travel agents--were passed overwhelmingly by the City Council yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Members of the Supreme Court sharply criticized today the treatment of children in some of the nation's juvenile courts.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 6-- John O'Malley of County Mayo, Ireland, and Lyndon Johnson of Gillespie County, Texas, joined with a Governor, a Senator, the Defense Secretary and the Joint Chiefs of Staff today to honor a young man from Woodside, Queens, a hero at the age of 23 whose only problem is deciding what to do now.
An odor usually associated with the presence of natural gas drifted across Lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, causing hundreds of residents to call the Police and Fire Departments.
A bill designed to curb frauds in the promotion and sale of charter travel by air and sea will be prefiled in the Legislature today, it was announced yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

Walter P. Reuther is hinting that his split with George Meany may lead to a walkout of the 1.5 million-member United Automobile Workers from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Such a withdrawal, especially if accompanied by the secession of other industrial unions, would be bad for the country and worse still for organized labor.
The New York Mets traded their best pitcher, Dennis Ribant, to the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday for an unknown center fielder, Don Bosch, and a hurler, Don Cardwell.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 6 --President Sukarno appeared to have given his blessing to the murder of six leading army generals here by leaders of an unsuccessful coup last fall, the defendant in a trial for military subversion testified today.
BONN, Dec. 6--Gen. Johannes Steinhoff, commander of the West German Air Force, today ordered the grounding of the Luftwaffe's entire fleet of F-104G Starfighter jets for an indefinite period.

MADRID, Dec. 6--The church in Spain told Roman Catholics today to vote according to their consciences in the national referendum next week on the new Constitution proposed by Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
Plans to increase the tuition at New York University by $200 in two years beginning next fall were announced yesterday by Dr. James M. Hester, president of the university.
Goldman, Sachs Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the proposed admission as general partners of Richard P. Oakley, Sidney J. Weinberg Jr., and Robert G. Wilson.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 7--Tran Van Van, one of South Vietnam's most prominent civilian politicians, was assassinated this morning in downtown Saigon.

Five men claiming to be followers of Elijah Muhammad, leader of the Black Muslims, were arrested last night after allegedly trying to "take over" the Islamic Center and its mosque at 1 Riverside Drive, at West 72d Street.
The directors of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., elected Benjamin Kalmenson yesterday as president and chief executive officer at a special meeting here.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Dec. 6--A group of Negro housewives has complained to the State University branch here about a mock "slave auction" of coeds, planned as a freshman fund-raising drive.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 6-- Abe Aikins scored a 3-point play with 34 seconds to go to give Hofstra a 71-69 victory over Seton Hall in a Metropolitan Conference basketball game tonight.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (Reuters) --The Kremlin announced the death today of Lieut. Gen. Ivan Lavrenov, chief political officer of the Soviet Union's strategic rocket forces. He was 54 years old.
The Community Service Society of New York, a nonsectarian voluntary family agency, elected Clifton W. Phalen as president yesterday.
On the basis of the entire record, the Board of Inquiry submits the following recommendations in settlement of all issues in dispute:

The Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases dedicated yesterday its new $2-million Russell A. Firestone Radiation Therapy Center, described by speakers as having the largest and most complete concentration of radiation therapy equipemnt in the world.
LONDON, Dec. 7 After the first emotional outpouring of bitterness against the Rhodesian rebels over the failure of peace negotiations, a sober and even depressed mood has begun to set in Britain.

Senator Inouye Cautions Against Vietnam Pullout SYRACUSE, Dec. 7 Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, said tonight that if the United States withdrew from Vietnam "such an act may signal the beginning of an era of chaotic international relations for our nation."
Eleven witnesses, including some described by Federal officials as Maria leaders, were called before a Federal grand jury here yesterday.

A 21-year-old woman who shot a tear-gas fountain pen gun into the face of a 26-yearold man in a bar in what she said was self-defense was convicted yesterday in Criminal Court on three charges: thirddegree assault, violation of the weapons law and unlawful possession of a tear-gas gun.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (UPI) Wilt Chamberlain hauled in the 14,000th rebound of his pro cage career and the Philadelphia 76ers converted 39 of 52 chances from the free throw line to beat the Chicago Bulls, 117-103, tonight running their winning streak to eight games.

The New York State Banking Department published yesterday a "major research study" whose conclusions indicated the department intends to take a generally liberal attitude toward merger and holding-company applications by the state's larger banks.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Newton of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ellen Newton, to William Franklin Rosenblum Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Resenblum of Manhattan.

THEY stood there, 60 indulgent husbands and well heeled, generous bachelors, surrounded by the pink and green decor and crystal chandeliers, and tried to look as if the whole thing were nothing more than a routine cocktail party at a good address.
A special board of inquiry made recommendations yesterday to settle the Manhattan and Bronx plumbers' walkout, but the union promptly rejected the proposals.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, in a further expansion of its food operations, reported yesterday the proposed acquisition of the Pearce-Young-Angel Company of Greenville, S.C. The transaction would involve stock exceeding $4.6-million.

Five Black Muslims demanded in Criminal Court yeaterday that they be taken before an Islamic court to hear charges that they tried to take over a Moslem mosque Tuesday night. The demand was rejected and they were held without bail.

SCIENCE fiction writers periodically turn out pen ny-dreadful stories about insects taking over the earth and reducing mankind to penury, slavery and other unfortunate pastimes. They are missing the boat. It's the birds we have to watch.
Miehle-Goss-Dexter, Inc., realized more than 80 per cent of its income for the fiscal year ended Oct. 29 in the second half, Hames W. Coultrap, president, reported yesterday.
An official of the National Urban League said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's plan for a state office building in Harlem "falls radically short" of the Negro community.

Mayor Lindsay announced a new agency yesterday designed to bring more volunteers into the city government. Called the Volunteer Coordinating Council, it will be co-sponsored by the office of Deputy Mayor-City Administrator Timothy W. Costello and the Community Council of Greater New York, Inc.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 7--Army's hockey team, forced to rally twice, scored two goals in the final period to hand Princeton a 5-3 setback today. The victory was the second straight for the cadets, while Princeton suffered its second loss in as many games.
Herbert E. Stern Co. will be merged into Herzfeld Stern, effective Jan. 3, the two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday.

ATHENS, Thursday, Dec. 8 Greece's Shipping Minister announced today that the ferry Iraklion was missing with 280 passengers and crew on an overnight trip from Crete and should be considered lost with all hands.
Worker layoffs are mounting in the nation's automobile, appliance and construction industries. Companies experiencing slower sales have scheduled cutbacks in 1967 production.

HONOLULU, Dec. 7 Hundreds of American survivors of Pearl Harbor took part today in a solemn memorial service marking the 25th anniversary of the Japanese surprise attack that propelled this country into world war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) Hearings in the Federal Communications Commission's investigation of the Bell System, now in their sixth month, centered briefly today on who should run the telephone company's finances, the Government or the company's management.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 A threeday conference at the University of Chicago ended today with strong expressions of support for abolishing the draft in favor of a system of voluntary service in the armed forces.
NOEL COWARD'S "Blithe Spirit" has much in common with a martini. The rewards of the ectoplasmic trifle lie in a minimum of Hollywood vermouth and a maximum of high style in serving.

The Mayor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement, which has been giving higher education scholarships for the last 11 years to high school graduates from the city, is about to make its awards statewide.
Copper futures turned in a puzzling performance yesterday. Traders apparently ignored a report that might be construed as slightly bearish, and followed instead some bullish aspects.

In the first subscription concert of its Town Hall series, the Bach Aria Group followed its familiar pattern last night. Groups of Bach's arias were sandwiched between complete cantatas two groups, two cantatas in last night's case.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The State Department acknowledged today that United States helicopters were flying Thai troops to zones near antiguerrilla operations in northeast Thailand.
NABLUS, Jordan, Dec. 7 This troubled spot of western Jordan, a center of militant Palestinian agitation and antimonarchist sentiment, was at peace today after lifting of a 44-hour curfew at 6 A.M.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (UPI) Four-foot snow drifts clogged Rocky Mountain passes and the threat of tornadoes menaced the Southern Plains today Heavy rains brought flood warnings in Illinois and Indiana.
Mayor Lindsay swore in two key aides yesterday at City Hall.
Stock prices surged on a broad front yesterday in the market's sharpest advance in seven weeks.
Vice President Humphrey predicted yesterday that despite cuts in the Administration's budget more Federal money would be available to the nation's cities in 1967 than in the current year.

CAIRO, Thursday, Dec. 8--The chief of the Arab League's Unified Military Command, in a speech yesterday, said that the command was "paralyzed" and "incapable of shouldering its responsibilities" against Israel, it was reported today.

THE first four moves of the Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez are 1 P-K4, P-K4; 2 N-KB3, N-QB3; 3 B-N5, P-QR3; 4 BxN, QPxB. Old hat with every player, White's fourth move, was considered devoid of any frightening consequences for Black.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 7 The defense attorney for Dr. Carl A. Coppolino said today that he would "vigorously contest" that Lieut. Col. William E. Farber was murdered and that even if he were, "certainly Carl Coppolino didn't do it."
LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) Two-Gun Cohen is back from another trip to his beloved China and he brings word that the Communist Red Guards now are an orderly lot.

PARIS, Dec. 7 The Ministerial Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is expected to set up a permanent nuclear planning group comprising West Germany, the United States, Britain, Italy and two rotating members, according to informed allied sources.

Nineteen Eastern colleges, including such major football powers as Syracuse and Penn State, expressed a strong desire to return to limited substitution yesterday, hoping to eliminate the two-platoon system in college football.

The Constitutional Convention that convenes next year should put one reform close to the head of its list. That is to improve the procedure for selecting delegates to future Constitutional Conventions while the sorry lessons of this year's wretched botch of the business are fresh in mind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Two companies that are paying New York City for the right to pipe unblurred television pictures to subscribers have complained to the Federal Government about a third company they say is doing the same thing and not paying.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 7 The United States Navy has sent its only nuclear-powered cruiser into the Gulf of Tonkin for patrol duty off the coast of North Vietnam, an American military spokesman said tonight.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 7 The Yale University hockey team scored seven goals in the last period tonight to defeat Renssclaer Polytechnic Institute, 11-9.
TOKYO, Dec. 7 (AP) Communist China said today that reports of "rich harvests won in the teeth of drought or other natural adversities" had been received from the southeastern part of the country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 7 Thomas P.F. Hoving, New York City Commissioner of Parks, proposed at a conference here today the redevelopment of Arthur Von Briesen Park on Saten Island that would "hopefully" incorporate nearby Battery Weed, an inactive part of Fort Wadsworth, as a restaurant facing the city skyline.
ONE way to become owner of a ton of Great Danes is to acquire a member of the breed as a guard dog, then become crowded out of living space when the puppies come along.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 7 Even at wondrous Turf Paradise, where the horses bounce like kangaroos, the mud gets fetlock deep. And when it comes up mud, the world's fastest race track loses its bounce.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 High Administration sources reported progress today in the discussions between the United States and its Latin-American partners to halt the proliferation of armaments.

LONDON, Dec. 7 "The wise and noble ruler of the British Empire," King Edward VIII, played a notable part in preventing Britain from going to war over Nazi Germany's reoccupation of the Rhineland, according to a March, 1936, dispatch to Berlin from Leopold von Hosch, German Ambassador in London.

THAILAND won the Far East Championship title, which ended in Bangkok last Sunday, and so qualified to play in the world championship in Miami Beach next May along with Italy, North America, France and Venezuela.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles had a lot more going than the long-ball power of Frank and Brooks Robinson en route to the American League pennant and a World Series sweep of the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Charles A. Buckley has told political intimates in the Bronx that he will resign soon as the Democratic county leader because of illness.
For the first time in its 100year history, the Salvation Army honored a prelate of the Roman Catholic Church yesterday.
A proposal to exempt aged property owners of limited incomes who own their own homes from half the real-estate tax was weighed yesterday by the City Council's Committee on Codification.

WARSAW, Dec. 7 Twentyone Polish authors, all members of the Communist party, recently signed a letter to party authorities questioning the party's policy toward writers and other intellectuals, informed sources reported today.

General Wallace M. Greene Jr., commandant of the United States Marine Corps, urged the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday to regard the Vietnam war as merely the prelude to Communist China's drive for world conquest.
Sterling Drug, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Lawrence M. Spalton as a vice president.
Richard Rodgers received the Sam S. Shubert Foundation award yesterday "in recognition of his contribution to the American theater."

FORM and content were happily met last night in the American Broadcasting Company's holiday special, "Christ Is Born." The onehour color documentary, filmed in the Holy Land and in Rome as part of the network's esteemed "Saga of Western Man" series, was a visual meditation that caught in picture and narrative the deep religious soundings of the familiar story of the Nativity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Representative Adam Clayton Powell's office announced today that he was prepared to pay $60 a week on a $164,000 defamation judgment. But counsel for the Harlem woman he defamed said the sum was inadequate and unacceptable.
Ernie Cardone's quest of the riding championship of the New York season suffered a setback when his mount, the favored Sultan's Lady, hit the fence in the third race at Aqueduct yesterday.

It took the Rangers almost a full period to get moving last night. But once they did, they overcame a 2-0 Boston Bruins' lead and went on to a 4-2 victory with a performance that was just about perfect.

Special to The New York Times PROSPECTVILLE, Pa., Dec. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Boesler Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Boesler, to Lieut. (jg.) Walter P. Schneiderwind Jr. U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Schneiderwind of Middlesex, N.J.
GRENOBLE, France, Dec. 7--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin wound up a quick 1,200-mile trip through the south of France today and returned to Paris for final talks with President de Gaulle.
Some form of guaranteed annual income for families below the $3,000-a-year poverty level should be provided, in the opinion of Mrs. Ellen Winston, United States Commissioner of Welfare.

The American Civil Liberties Union, in a special report on the growing controversy over pretrial publicity, said last night that if sanctions had to be placed against anyone, they should be placed against lawenforcement officials, the courts and the bar, rather than against the press.

There is a great deal of sound and fury in the Middle East these days as a reaction to Israel's ill-considered retaliatory raid on the Jordanian village of Es Samu. Its worst effect has been to give King Hussein of Jordan a hard time, internally and with his Arab enemies.
PLAINVIEW, L.I., Dec. 7 Arthur I. Pitt, a New York City police captain attached to the Queens Borough Squad, died of cancer yesterday in his home here. He was 47 years old.
LONDON, Dec. 7 The Conservative party broke with the Government on Rhodesian policy today and roundly condemned the move to seek mandatory sanctions at the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 An error in the Government's own reckoning, disclosed officially for the first time yesterday by the Texas White House, has thrown this year's economic policy out of kilter.
PARIS, Dec. 7 The last five months of warfare do not seem to have weakened the confidence of the leaders of North Vietnam, according to first-hand reports published here today.

WATER MILL, L.I., Dec. 7 J. Carlton Corwith, a leader in agricultural and civic affairs in New York State, died today in Southampton Hospital, of which he was president until recently. He was 71 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 A move to make Senator George Murphy of California chairman of the Senate Republican Campaign Committee is threatening the first post-election effort by liberal Republicans to reassert their influence in the party.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's dissident director, Philip J. Levin, is going to conduct another proxy contest. His goal is still to unseat the management headed by Robert H. O'Brien, president of the film company.

YESTERDAY'S buoyant market saw aluminum bob bing at the top of the action. Not only did the aluminum stocks share the spotlight on renewed hopes for an increase in ingot prices, Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., stole the show with the biggest single block of shares traded in stock exchange history.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.9 per cent in the week ended Dec. 3 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

Dr. James M. Hester, president of New York University, agreed last night to delay action on a proposed increase in charges for students' room and board but refused to comment on student demands that an increase in tuition be rescinded.
The resignation of Wilfred N. Hall as president and a director or Domtar, Ltd., a manufacturer of pulp and paper, was announced yesterday in Montreal following a meeting of its board of directors.
Myron J. Kleban, an international lawyer, died at Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at the Hyde Park Hotel, Madison Avenue and East 72d Street.
The New York Academy of Sciences last night named a Philadelphia surgeon and cancer authority, Dr. N. Henry Moss, as its president for 1967.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies sent a right-handed pitcher, Ray Culp, and gave an undisclosed amount of money to the Chicago Cubs today fir Dick Ellsworth, a left-hander who was a 22-game winner three years ago.
Frank DelCamp, a tenor who has sung in Washington, made his local debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. He was an affable performer, but his voice badly needed finishing.
HARTFORD, Dec. 7--Aviation leaders were told tonight that there was too much research on supersonic and longhaul jets and too little on planes for intermediate ranges and small community airports.

Three major maritime unions urged President Johnson yesterday to halt the University of Miami's alleged recruitment of nonunion labor to man the struck oceanographic research vessel John Elliott Pillsbury.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Dec. 8 Chinese Communist Red Guards held a rally in Canton yesterday to protest "Fascist atrocities" by Portuguese authorities in Macao, the official Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported today.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Dec. 7 (UPI) Three children died in a fire at their home today after their 16-year-old sister allegedly had been given some beer and lured out of the house by a Young man, the police said.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 7 An elderly legislator from Hopeh province was asked last evening whether he managed to keep track of developments in the district near Peking that elected him.
Milton M. Rulnick, an associate in the law firm of Goldstein, Judd Gurfein, 655 Madison Avenue, died of leukemia Tuesday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 181 East 73d Street.

The campus lights were extinguished, the traditional shofar was sounded, and then a solemn torchlight procession in behalf of the Jews in the Soviet Union took place at Columbia University last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (UPI) Two cars of an elevated train jumped their rain-slicked tracks today, clumped along a wooden trestle and plunged 25 feet to the ground. One person was killed and 25 were injured.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Organized labor began today to shape a new council to spur unionization among white collar workers and to convince them that union membership is not beneath them.
RICHMOND, Dec. 7 (UPI) Gov. Mills E. Godwin Jr declared war today on cross burning, a practice long associated with the Ku Klux Klan.

The American Broadcasting Company, following up its success with "Brigadoon" earlier this season, announced yesterday that it would televise in the near future two more musical adaptations, "Carousel" and "Kismet."

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 7 (UPI) President Johnson announced today he planned to nominate John J. Linnehan, a former New Frontiersman, of Haverhill, Mass., to be Federal cochairman of the New England Regional Development Commission at a $27,000 annual salary.

State Supreme Court Justice Nathan R. Sobel warned the 28 newly elected state judges here yesterday that Federal courts would soon "step in" to reverse convictions based solely on eyewitness identification unless "we find out what we're doing and start to correct the abuses."
BERKELEY, Calif. Dec. 7 The student strike at the University of California was ended today. Student leaders spoke of reopening it next term if the university provoked them.

DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 7 Mrs. Louise Harris Dovell, a former copy editor with The Houston Post for many years, died yesterday at her home at 43 Stony Brook Road here. She was the wife of Ray C. Dovell, a former city editor of The Houston Post and founder of the History Book Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The House Armed Services Committee disclosed today that it had its own civilian advisory panel studying the draft.
ROME, Dec. 7 What did Pope Pius IX think of Abraham Lincoln? Of Karl Marx? Napoleon III?

Mandell Rosenblatt, chairman of the board of M. Rosenblatt Son, Inc., one of the largest marine design companies in the world, died yesterday at Beekman-Downtown Hospital. He was stricken with a heart attack on Tuesday evening while attending a meeting of the Society of Naval Architects Marine Engineers at the Downtown Athletic Club.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 7 (UPI) Juan Natalicio Gonzalez, who was President of Paraguay for five and a half months in 194849, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. About 12 hours later, his wife, Lidia, died. The police, said they were investigating Mrs. Gonzalez's death.
The International Longshoremen's Association asked shipping management in the Port of New York yesterday to renegotiate a contract that still has a theoretical life of almost two years.
LONDON. Dec. 7 The Guardian, one of Britain's leading national daily newspapers, may be forced by financial difficulties to resume printing in one place.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Dec. 7 Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, usually individual stars, formed a perfect golfing partnership today. With a best-ball score of 63, they led the Professional Golfers' Association national team championship by one stroke.
MADRID, Dec. 7 The Supreme Court reversed sentences against five members of the Jehovah's Witnesses sect today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 The closing of one theater and the threatened closing of another has spread gloom in legitimate theater circles here.
VIENNA, Austria, Dec. 7 (Reuters) The Hungarian Government today replaced two of its ministers, the Hungarian press agency M.T.I. reported.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 7 (AP) Australia defeated the United States, 4-2, today in tennis competition along the lines of David Cup play.
A trio of sophomores led by Pat Raftery helped Fordham gain its first victory of the basketball season last night in the Rose Hill gymnasium.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 7 (AP) Three witnesses to an airline crash on Aug. 7 that killed 42 persons agreed today that the plane seemed to break up in mid-air.
Abraham Aikin worked last summer as a junior clerk in a Manhattan branch of the First National City Bank.

A critic of the Warren Commission contended yesterday that a key timing for the assassination of President Kennedy should have been reckoned at 3.5 seconds instead of 5. The contention evoked new, although mainly private, rebuttals.

State Senator Seymour R. Thaler charged yesterday that $100-million budgeted for the city's hospitals had "gone down the drain" in the last four years, because of payroll padding and other abuses by doctors and administrators.
Price increases were announced yesterday in a wide variety of products that included chemicals, utility equipment, stainless steel, flooring and refractory brick.
LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP)--John Wilcox of Williamsport, Pa., went from 13th to first place today in the international masters bowling tournament.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 Will the Super Bowl at tract a super crowd? Will the people of Los Angeles, with no home team involved, fill the 93,750 seats in the Memorial Coliseum next month when the National Football League champion opposes the American Football League champion?
BRUSSELS, Dec, 7 The European Common Market has again dragged its heels in offering to reduce farm tariff protection in the Kennedy round of world tariff-cutting talks in Geneva.
The 29-year old widow of a city Housing Authority construction inspector who was killed by a falling wooden brace in June, 1963, won a $224,000 tax-free settlement yesterday.

The swift collapse of the latest rebellion at Berkeley is a sign of increased maturity in the student body, coupled with an admirable blend of firmness and sophistication on the part of administration, faculty and regents.

James Paul Donahue, the youngest grandson of the late F.W. Woolworth, the dimestore magnate, died Tuesday of "visceral congestion," according to a preliminary autopsy report issued yesterday by the medical examiner's office.

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Freidberg of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Freidberg's daughter, Miss Anne Hebald, to Peter Lubin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Lubin of Lexington, Mass., and Cambridge, England.

HONOLULU, Dec. 7 A mild-looking Japanese wearing glasses stood unnoticed under a tree at the Punchbowl Memorial Cemetery today as thousands of war veterans and their families gathered for a service commemorating the 25th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

Thirty Negro and white parents kept a recently appointed principal confined to her office for nearly an hour yesterday and let her leave only after she announced that she did not want to continue at the West Harlem school.
The City Planning Commission published yesterday its capital budget detailing how the city should spend its money for permanent improvements during the coming fiscal year.
Mayor Lindsay was put on notice yesterday that his longheralded plan for a sweeping reorganization of the city government faces a critical appraisal by the City Council.
DETROIT, Dec. 7--The United Automobile Workers union denied tonight that it was "delinquent" in its financial payments to the merged labor federation.
The spot rate on the British pound recovered most of its Tuesday losses yesterday and closed 12 points higher in moderately active trading on foreign-exchange markets.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 7 (UPI) Eugene (Bull) Connor, who became a symbol of risistance to the integration movement while serving as Birmingham's Police Commissioner, suffered a stroke today and was hospitalized with his left side paralyzed.
IT was enough to make an epicure drown his sorrows in a bottle of 1959 bubbly. Here he was in New York, the Baron Roy de Groot, awaiting a shipment that contained among other things,...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) A 27-year-old New Jersey man, arrested in the slashing of four historic paintings in the United State Capitol yesterday, was arraigned today on a charge of willfully damaging Government property.
The two-year old Metropolitan Opera National Company may skip next season while the parent Metropolitan Opera Company, which supports it, catches up on an unexpectedly large deficit of its own.
Three agencies will play in the finals for the ad account of the Cities Service Company, with the prize about $5-million in billings.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 (Ap) Indictments against Richard Rock and Clyde Simmons in the Dow Wilson murder case were dismissed today by Superior Court Judge Norman Elkington.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 7 Vice President Humphrey suggested today that American churches have not put enough of their funds into programs to aid the poor.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) A landscape by Camille Pissarro owned by Martha Hyer, a Hollywood actress sold for $103,600, the top price at Sotheby's auction today of impressionist and modern painting and drawings. The painting, signed and dated 1875, was bought by an unidentified French collector.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 The Security Council is expected to reject Rhodesia's appeal for a hearing to defend itself against Britain's proposal for mandatory, selective economic sanctions, Council members said tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 7 A spurt in Westchester's economic growth was attributed by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian today to a movement of business from New York City because of the municipal income tax there.

The days of the campus are punctuated from time to time by the reflective thinking of college students who reach out to help the less fortunate. This attitude brightened four letters to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

At a time when stock prices are down, investors tend to analyze their brokers. There's nothing Freudian about it; it's just a matter of wondering why those registered representatives don't "do something" about low stock prices and vanished paper profits.
The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, a supplier of natural gas to the Middle West, announced here yesterday the election of H.W. Cain and Richard C. Dixon as vice presidents.

Mrs. Harold N. Prenske of Hollis, Queens, has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Judith Ann Prenske, to Bruce Allan Rich. He is the son of Mrs. Maurice H. Rich of New York, and the late Mr. Rich, who was professor of taxation at the New York University School of Law.

David Kligman, secretarytreasurer of Joseph Haskel, Inc., 499 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn, manufacturers of cemetery monuments, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 69-40 Yellowstone Boulevard Forest Hills, Queens. He was 61 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wood's daughter, Miss Robin Murray Roche, to William Waller Morton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Waller Morton of Baltimore and Southampton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 President Johnson announced in Austin yesterday that he would have to ask a $9- to $10-billion supplemental appropriation to pay the costs of the war in Vietnam. This means that war costs are twice the figure of just over $10 billion in the last budget.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 As President Johnson ponders whether to deploy a costly NikeX missile defense around the United States, the American intelligence community is poring over every scrap of information it can gather on what, precisely, the Russians are doing in this field.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) The Marine Corps' new Medal of Honor winner, Sgt. Robert Emmett O'Malley, said today that he was "disgusted about the idea" of demonstrations against the war in Vietnam.

WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 7 The post of chairman of the board of overseers of Brandeis University's Lemberg Center for the Study of Violence has been assumed by Philip M. Klutznick, a Chicago businessman and lawyer. He was United States representative on the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations in 1961-62.

Long before the unilateral declaration of independence by the white minority regime thirteen months ago the situation in Rhodesia had taken on an air of inexorable tragedy. Britain's Foreign Secretary will begin a new chapter in that tragedy before the United Nations Security Council today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) The Supreme Court caught itself in a rare error today and announced that it had not refused a hearing to the operator of a California movie theater after all.
EASTBOURNE, England, Dec. 7 A figure from the history books of dance, Kurt Jooss, reappeared here last night and proved himself startlingly in touch with the present.

HOUSTON, Dec. 7 The engagement of Miss Judith Ann Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth R. Wood of Houston, formerly of Westfield, N.J. to John Bowden Lenox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Lenox of Livingston, N.J. has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

The indexes of representative stocks made good gains on the London stock market yesterday. The chief factor affecting prices was a rumor that South Africa might mediate in the Rhodesian crisis. Southern Rhodesia bonds gained several points. Most issues were firm at the close.

ROME, Dec. 7 The Roman Catholic hierarchy in the Netherlands, considered by many observers to be the most restlessly progressive in western Europe, has received a papal warning against "rash and erring opinions."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) must share ownership of its ground stations with communication carriers.

REVERE, Mass., Dec. 7 (AP) A volley of armor-piercing rifle bullets killed Joseph (Chico) Amico, 27 years old, of Boston, today in what the police said was the 36th gangland slaying in the Boston area in the last two and a half years.
The Equity Corporation, a nondiversified investment company, announced here yesterday the election of Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retired, as a director. He succeeds John J. McMullen, who has resigned.

The uncertainty surrounding the financing plans of the beleagured Douglas Aircraft Company deepened yesterday with estimates by well-informed bankers that the company's. money needs would be likely to run "far in excess" of the $100 million figure that had been assumed to be its target.
HAMPTON, Va., Dec. 7 (AP)--Lunar Orbiter 2 unexpectedly ended its transmission of moon photos today, a week early.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 7 (UPI) America's new transPacific satellite obeyed commands from the earth today and drifted slowly to a parking spot over Christmas Island. There it will keep an eye on a third of the world's weather and serve as a radio-television relay.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 7 A confessed Vietcong terrorist who allegedly assassinated a prominent member of the Constituent Assembly this morning said tonight he was "satisfied" with his work.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 7 (Reuters) The South African Government today announced a series of strong measures to combat inflation, including restrictions on bank credit and relaxation of import controls on almost all groups of commodities.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 102.9 on Tuesday from 102.7 on Monday.

A grand jury is investigating delays by the city in an urban renewal project in Arverne, Queens. District Attorney Nat H. Hentel feels the delays may have accelerated deterioration of the once popular beach resort, a spokesman said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 Harry H. Blum, who with his wife, Becky, founded Blum's Vogue, a women's apparel store at 630 South Michigan Avenue, and four similar stores in the city and the suburbs, died last night at his home. He was 88 years old.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7 A 10-member Lebanese Cabinet drawn from outside Parliament was announced here today.

DETROIT, Dec. 7 (UPI) Walt Bellamy scored 5 points in the last two minutes tonight to help the New York Knickerbockers withstand Detroit's late rally and take a 118-116 National Basketball Association victory.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 7 (Reuters) Indonesia renounced today an agreement to hold a plebiscite in 1969 in West Irian, the former Netherlands New Guinea, which it took over three years ago.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 Homebuilders were advised today to join the fight for conservation of natural resources as a matter of self-interest.

ABERAVON, Wales, Dec. 7 (UPI) Howard Winstone decisively outpunched a fellow Welshman, Lenny (The Lion) Williams, tonight and retained his European and British featherweight titles with an eighthround technical knockout.

An investigator for the State Liquor Authority testified yesterday that when Peter Petersen, operator of the Left Bank, a discotheque in Lindenhurst, L.I., applied for a $10,000 bank loan, he listed as among his assets $7,000 in stock shares owned by Julius F. Klein, an exconvict.
PEKING, Dec. 7 A trade who visited the recently concluded Chinese Export Commodities Fair at Canton summed up one facet of Chinese trade at the end of a harrowing day of negotiations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 (AP) A Chinese delegates speech broke up a session of the General Council of the World Trade Union Federation in Sofia today, forcing an adjournment, Tanyug, the Yugoslav press agency said.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 The Government of the Slovenian Republic resigned today in what appeared to be a move without precedent in a Communist state.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The Office of Education has nearly doubled the rate of desegregation in Southern schools, according to a Government survey that is close to completion.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7 The Syrian chief of state, Dr. Nureddin Attassi, urged Jordanians today to overthrow King Hussein and his Government.
The American Stock Exchange made its second consecutive advance yesterday. The list moved higher in its most hectic trading in more than three months.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (UPI) The National Professional Soccer League dropped two franchise holders today and went ahead with plans to open the season for a 34-game schedule for each club starting next April 16.

William Schutzman, associate professor of mathematics at the School of Continuing Education at New York University, collapsed while lecturing and died yesterday at the university's Washington Square Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 7714 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn.

Two employes of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company filed a strongly worded appeal and the Securities and Exchange Commission filed another that was equally outspoken in the Second Circuit Court here yesterday.
Special to The New York Times HARTFORD, Dec. 7 Francis W. Cole, chairman of the Travelers Insurance Companies, from 1945 to 1955, died today in his home. His age was 83.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 (AP) The chief dispatches for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Great Lakes Steam Ship Division testified today that lack of radio contact with the freighter Daniel J. Morrell had not been considered cause for immediate concern.
City College rallied in the second half from an 11-point deficit to beat Brooklyn College, 54-49, last night at Roosevelt Hall in Brooklyn.
Directors of the United States Steel Corporation have elected R. Heath Larry executive vice president and assistant to the chairman, Roger M. Blough, chairman, announced yesterday.
GEN. GEORGE C. MARSHALL (18801959), Chief of Staff during World War II, characteristically declined a million dollars or so to write his memoirs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Confusion and concern over the Soviet Union's space plans have been increased here by three recent launchings in which unusual secrecy played a part.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 7 Gov. George Romney of Michigan, in his first visit to the South since his re-election last month, declared here today that too many persons still preached the "dusty dogma" of states' rights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 One of the key witnesses scheduled to appear before the Senate hearings on urban problems has told the subcommittee that she would not be able to testify because her appearance might prove awkward for herself and, possibly, the Administration.

MONTREAL, Dec. 7 (AP)--Henri Richard's 250th career goal triggered a three-goal first-period drive that carried the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-3 National Hockey League victory over the first-place Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

ROME, Dec. 7 Representatives of airlines flying North Atlantic services began today preliminary discussions of proposed fare reductions for first class flights and group flight and the establishment of a "youth fare" to encourage student travel.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 7 Rhodesia asked the United Nations Security Council today for a chance to be heard in any debate on the imposition of mandatory economic sanctions against it.
NEWARK, Dec. 7 (UPI) Dr. Caesar O. Bottone, 39 years old, was found guilty of criminal contempt today by a Federal jury.

TO mark the centennial of the American Water color Society, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has mounted a comprehensive exhibition of "200 Years of Water-color Painting in America" which includes some of the finest examples of the medium, selected from the museum's own extensive collection as well as from a number of outstanding private collections.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 7 Providence weathered a Brown blitz midway in the second half tonight and then pulled away from the upstart Ivy Leaguers for a 76-62 victory in an intracity basketball game at Alumni Hall.
When Norrito-Ress, Inc., asked 147 people what they knew about stocks and bonds, most of the answers it got were apologies they thought they ought to know, but were just too busy to learn.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 7 (AP) An "elastic water" that continues flowing up and over the edge of a pitcher after the pitcher has been set back on the shelf was reported today by the California Institute of Technology.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Dec. 7 (UPI) Officials at the Shapley School believe pupils from a local high school have been supplying narcotics to Shapley students, a school spokesman said today.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 7--An Illinois Sunday school teacher spoke today against a background of whirring slot machines and the clicking of dice.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 7 (AP) Three resolutions calling for more Federal assistance were approved today by delegates to the National League of Cities' 43d annual convention, which closed here this afternoon.
The investment concern of Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., announced yesterday the election as vice presidents of Albert F. Haiback, Robert T. Madden, Julian H. Robertson Jr. and Richard B. Wigton.

An audience of several hundred dealers and private buyers bid avidly for costly baubles at auction yesterday. When the competition had ended, $1,115,585 had been paid for the jewels of the late Mrs. Helen M. de Kay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower will enter Walter Reed Army Medical Center tomorrow for removal of his gall bladder.

The retirement of Carl W. Buchheister as president of the National Audubon Society, effective Jan. 31, was announced last night at the society's annual dinner meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel. Mr. Buchheister's successor has not been selected.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 7--The Government has dismissed its American-born Price Controller, J.T. Daniels, only two months after he took office.

MILAN, Italy, Dec. 7 (AP) The grand opera season opened tonight at La Scala in an atmosphere of some austerity because of Italy's disastrous floods. The opera was Verdi's "Nabucco" with an international cast.
John P. Howland, president of the Erwin Mills division of Burlington Industries, Inc., was elected yesterday to the board of the large textiles producer.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 7 (AP) The 34 public health nurses now striking over a pay dispute will return to work tomorrow, a spokesman for J. Jerome Olitt, the nurses' representative said today.

EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., Dec. 7 Republic Airfield was opened to private and industrial aircraft here today after three decades as a test field of warplanes.
The bond market acted like a well-conditioned weight-lifter yesterday as it handled its heavy burden of new issues almost with ease.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 (UPI) Herman Lee Henry, a 41year-old mild-mannered welder, convicted in a plot to poison the entire Negro population in the United States, was fined $500 today and placed on probation for five years provided he spends one year in county jail.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Dec. 7 Without benefit of diagrams, scrimmage sessions and scouting reports, directors of ski areas in the southern Catskills have been thinking like football coaches before the season starts.

LEXINGTON, Mass., Dec. 7 (AP) The Raytheon Company rejected today a proposal by Local 1505 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers to arbitrate differences that led to a walkout of some 10,000 workers last month.

Marianne Moore, the poet, queenly with her tricornered hat, extended a delicate hand into a tall silk hat provided by Roger L. Stevens on Tuesday night and drew out a dubiously valued award for a publisher.
LONDON, Dec. 8--The British Broadcasting Corporation has asked an author to rewrite a television version of "Cinderella" in which Prince Charming strangles Cinderella at midnight.

Ernie Cardone almost made it yesterday. The 22-year-old apprentice jockey from the Bronx who is seeking the riding championship of the New York season, came within two victories of his goal as he piloted two winners at Aqueduct.

Jason R. Nathan, Administrator of Housing and Development, agreed yesterday with charges that extensive delays in the rehabilitation of the Arverne section of Queens had contributed to its serious decay in recent years.
New Yorkers will soon be seeing three police radio patrol cars for every two that had been on the streets.

The first student to fulfill the requirements for a doctoral degree in City College's School of Engineering and Architecture was honored at a reception at the college yesterday. The doctoral program was established in 1962.
Despite the slump in the industry, a number of manufacturers of gypsum materials announced yesterday that they were going to increase prices for the products.

The new Volunteer Coordinating Council announced by the Mayor could significantly stimulate the American tradition of neighbor helping neighbor, a tradition that has been suffering from the bigness of cities and the compartmentalization of urban living.
The election of Charles V. Parl, Leonard A. Siwek and Robert L. Riedel as vice presidents was announced here yesterday by the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company.
Operations of Oscar Mayer Co. in the fiscal year ended Oct. 29 resulted in record earnings and sales, the meat packer reported yesterday.

United States airlines will spend $6-billion for new aircraft between now and the end of 1970, 20 per cent above an estimate given less than a year ago, Stuart G. Tipton, president of the Air Transport Association of America, said yesterday.
COMMACK, L.I., Dec. 8--Arrest warrants for the first of 35,000 scofflaws were issued here today by the Suffolk District Court.
United States participation in the Vietnam war was assailed in speeches, songs, plays and poems and with balloons at Madison Square Garden last night.

New York merchants and heads of retail chains yesterday promised to pay the interest, up tto 5 per cent, on loans of more than $500,000 to small industries and artisans who had suffered losses in the Florence floods.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, his cheeks pink and his smile broad, entered Walter Reed Army Hospital today to have his gall bladder removed.

Long, lonesome-sounding whistles floated across the prairie; they echoed among the mountains and the calls reverberated from peak to peak. The steam engines of yesteryear sent their strangely stirring notes through the pine lands of the South and along the river valleys of the Midwest.

Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has upheld "rural justice in Vermont" that awarded damages to a dairy farmer in a suit against a trespassing company that had mixed weed killer at his waterhole, causing injury to his cattle.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8--Soviet and United States officials agreed today on the terms of the first international treaty to govern the exploration of space.

PARIS, Dec. 8--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin pledged in a television speech to the French people today that the Soviet Government would continue to give political and material aid to North Vietnam until American "aggression" stops.

EASTON, Pa., Dec. 8--The engagement of Miss Lynn Nelson Williams to W. Bourne Ruthrauff, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Bourne Ruthrauff of Little Silver, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. James Hilgert Williams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) --The Agriculture Department, in its last report on cotton for this year, estimated today that the cotton crop would total 9,627,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, or 663,000 bales fewer than the November forecast.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8-- Political enemies of United States Senator Joseph S. Clark, Democrat of Pennsylvania, have formed an organization to oppose his re-election in 1968, it was announced this afternoon.
A fire apparently started by burglars burned out Our Lady of Mount Carmel-St. Benedict's Roman Catholic Church on Staten Island early yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec.9 (AP)--United States B-52 jet bombers again pounded Vietcong bases northwest of Saigon early today, hitting an area in Tayninh Province, near Cambodia, containing enemy bunkers, trenches, foxholes and suspected troop concentrations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI)-- Rare Christmas season tornadoes, spawned in some of the warmest December weather on record, ripped across the lower Middle West today, flattening buildings and felling power lines.

THE end of an era may be at hand tomorrow for the Baltimore Colts and Paul Hornung of the Green Bay Packers. The Colts, an aging team with a quarterback wracked by aches and pains, will try to stop the Packers who need a victory or a tie to win the Western Conference ...
The stock market rally continued yesterday. Prices advanced for the third consecutive session.
ALBANY, Dec. 8--Governor Rockefeller announced tonight the appointment of Richard E. Stewart, a 33-year-old first assistant counsel to the Governor, as State Superintendent of Insurance.
Despite the pained outcry, the Securities and Exchange Commission's recommendations for reform of the mutual fund industry are neither revolutionary nor unrealistic.

FROM the moment the colleges abandoned the two-platoon system in favor of a limitation of substitutions more than a dozen years ago, a relentless campaign began to restore the free and easy replacement program. The leaders in this drive were the coaches of the big-time teams and embraced those at both the respectable schools and those at the boiler factories.

CAIRO, Dec. 8--The Egyptian police released today an American student who was arrested two weeks ago, along with scores of other students, in an effort to quell unrest at Al Azhar University here, in formed sources said.
More than 5,000 homes in Queens were blacked out last night when a 27,000-volt feeder cable outside a Consolidated Ed ison substation in Maspeth caught fire.

ROME, Dec. 8 (UPI)--The Vatican, in an apparently unprecedented step, granted a Presbyterian woman permission to receive holy communion during her recent wedding to a Roman Catholic, the Vatican radio reported today.

The United Jewish Appeal opened its 1967 campaign last night with a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria that probably set a record in costliness for its patrons: the minimum contribution was $10,000.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 8--President Johnson welcomed today the agreement on a treaty prohibiting weapons in space as an important step toward peace. He said he would ask the Senate for quick approval next year so that the United States would be among the first to ratify it.
The appointment of Lee N. Mays as the general sales manager of the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation was announced yesterday in Detroit.

Vice President Humphrey, enthusiastic over a recent twohour talk with Pablo Casals, would like the Johnson Administration to be represented officially at the cellist's 90th birthday celebration on Dec. 29.
New York was a summer festival yesterday--almost.

Max L. Arons has been elected president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, it was announced yesterday. The local's executive board had named Mr. Arons to serve as president until Dec. 31, when the position was left vacant by the death of Alfred J. Manuti on Sept. 11.

The American-Korean Foundation announced today that two million doses of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine, which Dr. Jonas Salk promised would "break the back" of the disease in Korea, are en route to Inchon as a Christmas gift to the children of South Korea.

Student leaders at New York University's Washington Square Center estimated yesterday that 4,000 to 6,000 of the 8,200 enrolled undergraduates had boycotted classes to protest tuition increases scheduled for 1967 and 1968.

PARIS, Dec. 8 (AP)--Jaywalking Parisian shoppers are about to be hailed in midstreet-and midcrime by loudspeakers set up at busy corners.

The preliminary report of a Senate investigative team that has just returned from Vietnam indicates that the United States is not "significantly closer to bringing the war to conclusion" than it was a year ago.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 8 (AP)--A drifter was charged with first degree murder today in the bludgeon slaying here of Dr. Robert W. Spike, nationally known theologian and civil rights leader.
COIMBRA, Portugal, Dec. 8 --The heir to the Portuguese throne declared today that he was ready to serve the nation if called upon.
