RACHGIA, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 The exodus of 2,300 people from a Vietcong-dominated village 36 miles northwest of here to havens protected by the South Vietnamese Government means different things to different people.
Michael Borodkin, swimming coach and adjunct assistant professor at Long Island University's Brooklyn center, died Thursday night at the Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 61 years old.

Abraham Straus, Brooklyn, a store division of Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday a realignment of duties of three of its vice presidents, effective Jan. 3. A. said the reassignments were being made to "handle the operations of a rapidly expanding business."
Prices eased yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. The decline was led by industrial, auto motive, tobacco and aircraft issues.

COHASSET, Mass., Dec. 9 Mr, and Mrs. Carl E. Nelson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Nelson, to Carl Frederick Theiler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans J. Theiler of Whitinsville, Mass., and Lucerne, Switzerland.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 9 (AP) Paul Garrett Blazer Sr., a founder in 1924 of Ashland Oil and Refining Corporation, died today in a hospital here. He was 76 years old and had been hospitalized early this week for a heart condition. He maintained a home in Paradise Valley, a suburb of Phoenix.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 Zambia scornfully, rejected today Britain's plan for sanctions against Rhodesia, and demanded instead a complete embargo on oil shipments and sanctions covering all exports and imports.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 2 The first glimpse of Ice land in the afternoon darkness was of the glow of volcanic fire.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 An East German family of five escaped without serious injury to the West early this morning despite a hail of bullets from East German border guards.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 9 Many Indians cannot find enough to eat these days, but the Government's most immediate problem is caused by the ones who will not eat.

Squash tennis, which is returning to popularity in the metropolitan area after some relatively inactive years, is to have its first national open championship today and tomorrow at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn. Seven professionals and 10 amateurs will compete.
PARIS, Dec. 9 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin flew home today, leaving a vague feeling of letdown behind him in the French capital.
Government bonds, as though miffed by all the attention that corporate and municipal securities got this week, broke into the limelight yesterday with a strong advance in active trading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Senator Thomas H. Kuchel of California, the Republican Whip, urged President Johnson today to call for frank "United States-Soviet talks on curbing nuclear weapons in the face of a threatened "new and ominous round in the nuclear arms race."
ALGIERS, Dec. 9 France has agreed in principle to cancel $200-million of Algeria's pre-independence public debts, it was reported here today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 (Reuters)--President Tito tonight pardoned his former heir-apparent, Aleksandar Rankovic, after the Yugoslav Parliament decided not to proceed with criminal charges against Mr. Rankovic and his group of associates.

William H. Booth, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, said yesterday the Police Department had been lax in prosecuting cab drivers who refused to carry Negroes, and his commission intends to take over the prosecution of such drivers.
The state of Mississippi is beginning a concerted drive to lure new industry from New York and New Jersey.

PRESTON CLARK is an 11-year-old never beset by indecision. He spent $5 and completed his Christmas shopping in 15 minutes yesterday and he got exactly what he wanted--a projector with slides for himself and a set of toy trap drums for his mother.
Moscow, Dec. 9 (AP) Two Americans will be put on trial in Leningrad Dec. 19 on charges of violations of Soviet currency regulations, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 The American Civil Liberties Union has come to the defense of high school boys who affect off-beat hair styles.
The demand for hamburgers is rising in the quick-service operation of the Royal Castle System, Inc.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10 "The Palm Tree Prophet," convinced he can end the war before the New Year if he is allowed to travel abroad, has asked the United States Embassy to intervene with the Saigon authorities to give him a passport.
Adolph W. Samborski, the athletic director at Harvard, was elected president of the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday. He succeeds Benton A. Kribbs, Bucknell's director of athletics.

THE Green Bay Packers, who are old hands at this sort of thing, and the Dallas Cowboys, who have never before been this close to the glory land, hope to close in this weekend on the National Football League's conference titles.
The election of Lee B. Harris as vice president for administration of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace was announced yesterday.

Minerva Davidson wiped away a tear, and one of the high-ranking military officials who could not, because he was standing at attention, blinked hard. They were among several hundred persons on the parade ground of the Brooklyn Army Terminal yesterday when Taps was played for the closing of the 47-year-old terminal.

Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello, with the support of Mayor Lindsay, yesterday denounced State Senator Seymour R. Thaler. He said the Senator's attack on the city's hospital system was "a heartless and reckless broadside smear attack on both the municipal and voluntary hospital system to serve his own political interests."
BONN, Dec. 9 Bonn and Paris have agreed on the status of French troops in West Germany, Government sources reported today.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 9 Andrew David Banks, chairman of the board and general manager of the Banks Ship Rigging Corporation in New York, died yesterday at the East Orange General Hospital. He lived at 346 Tremont Avenue.

The "Colgate Comedy Hour," one of the most popular TV series of the early 1950's, will be brought back for a one-night stand on the National Broadcasting Company, it was learned yesterday. The one hour telecast will be on sometime in the spring, probably in April.
The United Nations Security Council debate about sanctions against Rhodesia has taken a course that can only help Ian Smith and the white supremacists in Salisbury.

Jack D. Levine of 35 East 35th Street, president of the Jack D. Levine Company, Inc., of 10 West 33d Street, manufacturer of Par-mate golf gloves, died of a heart attack Thursday in Miami Beach. His age was 59.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The president of Consolidated EdiEdison said today that putting the company's controversial Storm King power plant "around the bend" of the Hudson River would cost millions of dollars less than its present plan.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of the president of the city's new Public Development Corporation.

A private health research group reported yesterday that about 10 per cent of New York's residents suffered some ill effects smarting eyes, difficulty in breathing, coughing and wheezing under the blanket of air pollution that covered the city on Thanksgiving weekend.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--The Institute for American Democracy, Inc., said today that the John Birch Society was "relying on three big lies as part of a shift even further to the right."
The Department of Welfare may televise its staff meetings over the city-owned Municipal Broadcasting System to improve communication between the Commissioner and his workers.
MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Dec. 9 ((UPI) An archer entered a cage filled with tame, miniature deer last night, lured them close to him, and then killed two of them with arrows, the police said today.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 9 James W. Walter who parlayed an $800 investment into assets worth $500-million in 20 years, dedicated today the new headquarters here for the Jim Walter Corporation. At a brief stockholders meeting;

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Dec. 9 Young Negroes smashed windows, looted a liquor store and painted a Confederate statue black today in protest over the acquittal of a white man accused of fatally shooting one of their fellow students.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 9 (UPI) A day of pagentry capped the opening of the Fifth Asian games today with athletes from 18 countries parading before a capacity crowd of 30,000 in the National Stadium.

WARSAW, Dec. 9 Plans for the Broadway visit and American tour of the famous Yiddish State Theater of Warsaw, headed by Ida Kaminska, have moved closer to realization with the visit here of Harold Leventhal, the American producer.

PARIS, Dec. 9 A policeman patrolling the Boulevard du Montparnasse the other night was startled to see an arm holding a hack-saw protruding from the back door of a news kiosk. It was sawing the bumper of a car parked against the door.

BONN, Dec. 9 Dr. Joachim Prinz, chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, declared today that West Germany's new Government "will be judged by its ability to neutralize the nation's neo-Nazi movement."
HATTLESBURG, Miss., Dec. 9(AP) Sylvester Magee, who began life as a slave and says he is 125 years old, has filed suit to divorce his wife on the ground that she deserted him.
TRENTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The State Racing Commission said today that two of New Jersey's three flat tracks were seeking spring racing dates in 1967 that would overlap.
MIAMI, Dec. 9 (AP) Codorniz, the 7-10 favorite, took the lead at the start and held it all the way today in winning the feature race at Tropical Park before a crowd of 7,144.

GENEVA, Dec. 9 Bernard Cornfield, president of the Investors Overseas Services, said tonight that recent adverse criticism in the Swiss press had nothing to do with a decision to transfer some of the financial corperation operation from its Geneva, headquarter to London.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 A grayhaired woman wearing boots, a heavy red shawl and a black coat emerged slowly from a taxi on the broad boulevard in front of the yellow stucco building of the United States Embassy.
GENEVA, Dec. 9 An order attaching all of the assets of the Chase Manhattan Bank in Swiss banks has been revoked.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 9 District Judge Marvin Blackburn Jr. dismissed today a lawsuit seeking to stop condemnation of land for the proposed Lyndon B. Johnson State Park.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 9 The first attempted sabotage by Arab terrorists since the Israeli reprisal raid against Jordan on Nov. 13 was thwarted today.
A 23-hour sit-in by students at New York Universitie's Washington Square campus ended at 6 o'clock last night, with strong indications it could begin again on Monday.
Spokesmen for apartmenthouse owners, tenants and incinerator manufacturers pleaded with the city yesterday to ease rigid new rules for refuse burning, or at least to delay their enforcement.
A splended commemorative cup of enameled gold, made in Vienna and dated 1665, was the star of an auction sale yesterday, bringing $50,000 from the Antique Company of New York. York.

New Yorkers carried their coats instead of wearing them and perspired through a recordshattering heat wave yesterday, as the thermometer shot up to 66 degrees at 1:40 P.M. The Weather Bureau said that its old record for a Dec. 9 had been broken by 5 degrees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)--Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that in the next Congress the Senate Juvenile Delinquency Subcommittee would try to find out why so many young people steal cars.
DETROIT, Dec. 9--Forest H. Akers, who retired in 1947 as a vice president of the Chrysler Corporation's Dodge division, died here last night at the age of 79.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Frank H. Weitzel, the Controller General, said in a report to Congress made public today that the Government had overpaid the General Electric Company by more than $1.7-million on 10 subcontracts for Navy equipment.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.8 on Thursday from l02.9 on Wednesday.

Robert Welch, one of the founders of the John Birch Society, opened the organization's eighth anniversary celebration yesterday by restating some of the society's recent pronouncements in a rambling 55-minute news conference.
Tragedies in the lives of people portrayed in the annual Christmastime appeal of the Neediest Cases Fund evoke a sensitive response from donors with troubles of their own.
PALISADES, N.J., Dec. 9 Dr. Harry F. Ward, national chairman of the American Civil Liberties Union from its founding in 1920 until 1940, died today in his home at 1116 Arcadia Way. His age was 93.

The New York State Public Service Commission rejected yesterday a request by the Delaware Hudson Company for authority to discontinue trains No. 34 and No. 35, its daylight Laurentians, which have been operated for more than 90 years between Albany and Rouses Point, N.Y., on the Canadian border.
Puccini's "La Boheme" will return to the Metropolitan Opera on Jan. 13. Also during the 16th week of the season, there will be a nonsubscription performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 Barbados became the 122d member of the United Nations today. The Security Council's recommendation was approved by acclamation in the General Assembly without a formal vote.
ROME, Dec. 9 Pope Paul VI, in his peace appeal yesterday, envisaged a truce in Vietnam lasting 51 days, from Dec. 24 to Feb. 12, a Vatican spokesman said today.

The 500th basketball game played by the New York Knickerbockers on the Madison Square Garden court will take place tonight when they meet the Baltimore Bullets at 8:30 in a National Basketball Association contest.

DALLAS, Dec. 9--Jack Ruby, slayer of Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin of President Kennedy, was taken from the Dallas County Jail and brought to Parkland Memorial Hospital late this afternoon, suffering from pneumonia.

An athlete may now receive financial aid from a college in the Eastern College Athletic Conference for being just that an athlete. No longer are financial needs of his family or his own high academic achievements the only excuses for giving an E.C.A.C. studentathlete free room, board and tuition.
Five writers have been elected to membership in the elite 50-seat American Academy of Arts and Letters.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec!. 9 Arthur J. Goldberg announced today a United States gift of $1-million to the United Nations Children's Fund and stressed American support for the fund's activities in the field of family planning.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 9 (UPI) Johnny Coatta, who as a quarterback helped raise the University of Wisconsin football team from the doldrums to national prominence, was named to day to succeed Milt Bruhn as coach of the Badgers.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (UPI) A college English teacher who became violent on his second LSD "trip" and ran naked into the street, where he battled policemen, was held in $1,000 bail today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 9 Secretary of State Dean Rusk, who arrived in Saigon today, met for an hour with Dr. Tran Van Do, the South Vietnamese Foreign Minister.

Detectives from District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office raided a three-room apartment in Greenwich Village yesterday morning and seized an assortment of allegedly stolen merchandise worth thousands of dollars.

Just when horse players hereabouts thought that they had found the formula for cashing bets with reasonable regularity, the whole thing had to end. The formula turned out to be "bet on Ernie Cardone" but, after today, there won't be any place locally to apply the theory.
William McKnight Bowman, an architect at 154 East 61st Street, died Tuesday at his home at 320 East 57th Street. He would have been 71 years old on Monday.
More than 500 machinists went on strike early yesterday at Mohawk Airlines' l4 terminals, and the line said that service would be cut to 70 per cent of normal today.

FOLSOM, N.J., Dec. 9 (UPI) A teen-age boy described by authorities as "a mental defective" was arrested yesterday, hours after a PennsylvaniaReading Seashore Line train carrying 70 passengers was nearly derailed in an apparent sabotage attempt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has been asked to investigate charges that professional athletes have been shown favoritism in enlisting in the Army Reserve or the National Guard.

LISBON, Dec. 9 (AP)--Rear Adm. Edwin S. Miller, a veteran of Pacific and Atlantic service, tokk charge of the first North Atlantic Treaty Organization command on the Iberian Peninsula today. This assignment is to protect the alliance's shipping in the Western approaches of the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The United States has agreed to purchase about $35-million worth of military equipment in Great Britain as part of a deal in which the British will postpone a cutback in their Army of the Rhine in West Germany.
Two men were shot to death land a third fatally stabbed yesterday in a period of five hours in the area between 37th and 117th Streets.

Joseph Ross, former president of Davidson Bros., Inc., a national chain of 46 department stores, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital of a heart attack. He was 52 years old and lived at 1 Mitchell Place.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Dec. 9 Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus came back to lead the Professional Golfers Association team championship today as darkness settled over the course. Just as they did in the opening round, they combined for a best-ball score of 63. This nine-under-par tally gave them a 54-hole aggregate of 192 and a two-stroke edge.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 9 (AP)--A shortage of $390,518 in the accounts of John Pinchin, Fairfield tax collector, was reported today by the chief of police.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 A conference of teachers was urged today to mount a drive to drop the "slave name" Negro and use the term AfroAmerican to describe the black population of the United States.
The spot rate on the British pound dropped 8 points, to $2.7897, in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The decline was attributed to technical factors.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 9 (AP) The United States champion, Earl Elms of San Diego, regained the lead today by finishing second in the fifth race of the Western Hemisphere Snipe Class yachting championships.

Consumers will be in for fresh trouble if the National Farmers Organization, the most militant of agricultural pressure groups, carries out its threat to stage a milk strike. Delegates attending its annual convention have voted unanimously to draw up plans for a milk holding action in order to gain increased prices from milk processors.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 9--Arthur S. Flemming, president of the University of Oregon and newly elected president of the National Council of Churches, called today for increased teaching "about" religion in the public schools.
Hazel Bishop, Inc., announced yesterday it had accepted "with regret" the resignation of Philip J. Levin as a director.
Evidence has been found that the same "calendar;" in the form of a great magnetic zebra pattern, lies imprinted on the floor of every ocean.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 9 (Ap) Dr. Maurice E. Rogalin, assistant dean and professor of education at the Fairfield University Graduate School of Education, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 Senator Edward M. Kennedy suggested today that the United States call an international conference to explore the problems of "brain

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 In what one Senator described as a "moving and memorable" statement, a young Negro from the Watts ghetto in California traced his life today from Louisiana to Los Angeles to Harvard. He then told a subcommittee: "One does not ever really escape from the ghetto."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission said today it had approved the sale of KFWB in Los Angeles. But the commission coupled the approval with a strong rebuke of the former owner.

PARIS, Dec. 9 Thirteen intellectuals have been expelled from the Polish Communist party after having written a letter to the party's Cenrtal Committee, according to the Polish-language exile magazine Kultura here.

"THE MAPLESON MEMOIRS" will help feed the interests of the hot-stove league good for endless rounds of talk on the good old days (more or less) of Patti, Nilsson, Tietjens and Gerster. It doesn't say much about music, but it does say what operas were sung in 19th-century England and America, what the performances were like and who the stars were.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 9 (AP) Norbert Grupe, a German-American from Los Angeles, who fights under the name Wilhelm Von Homburg, knocked out Archie McBride of Trenton in the ninth round of a scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout tonight.
The scholarship fund of Athens College will receive the proceeds of the Athenian Ball to be held Wednesday in the Plaza's Terrace Room.
Russell C. Taylor, ACF president, said here yesterday that the cutback would have little effect on the company's overall position.

Within a span of two weeks, New York has been treated to a number of extraordinary recitals, vocal and instrumental. Last night, there was still another, given in Carnegie Hall by Emil Gilels, the Soviet pianist, and New York musical cup was overflowing. An artist in the great romantic tradition, he made the piano the personal, communicative, beautiful-sounding instrument it can be in the hands of a master.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) President Johnson returned today from a 20-day visit to his Texas ranch and got caught up on an accumulation of paper work.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The United States confirmed today that it had offered through international channels to exchange prisoners of war with North Vietnam and the Vietcong.

A relaxed, philosophical Representative Adam Clayton Powell said yesterday that he would not fight the efforts of several of his Congressional colleagues to bar him from taking his House seat in January.
NOUMEA, Now Caledonia. Dec. 9 The French Government will permit competition in the industrialized mining and processing of New Caledonia's vast reserves of nickel ore.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Dec. 9 The Government announced today that it had broken off negotiations with Union Miniere du Haute Katanga over the future of the giant, Belgium-based mining company.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 9 Gov. George Romney moved measurably closer today to declaring himself a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1968.
A 78-year-old cosmetics executive left his housekeeper approximately one-eighth of his estate, estimated to be worth more than $1 million, it was disclosed yesterday.
The benefit last night for the African-American Institute held at the Hunter College Assembly Hall was a success on the stage and in the till.
The Parks Department will start stagecoaches and hay wagons rolling through two city parks today.

HONG KONG, Dec. 9 Communist China's masses are being exhorted to study and restudy three short essays by Chairman Mao Tse-tung and to use their principles to solve almost every problem of life and work.
Consolidated Edison was still not sure last night exactly what had happened to cause a 27,000-volt underground cable to catch fire Thursday night and produce a Queens blackout.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Teacher salary increases, lagging for years by some standards, are accelerating, especially in big cities, according to a Labor Department report.

Reports of more snow and rain over the Southwestern plains clouded the thinking of traders in wheat futures yesterday. They did enough selling to push prices down as much as 2 cents a bushel. The winter wheat area getting much-needed moisture after a dry spell includes southwest Kansas, parts of Oklahoma and northern Texas.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Dec. 9 A pert little nun, whose head barely reached the shoulders of people beside her on the dais, smiled broadly at the audience of 1,500 today and produced a footstool from folds of her flowing black habit. Stepping gingerly onto the stool so she could see over the lectern and microphones, she said:

Undefeated San Diego State, the No. 1 small college team in the nation, takes Montana State, in the Camellia Bowl at Sacramento, Calif, today in the top game of four National Collegiate Athletic Association college division playoff contests. The games will be telecast regionally by ABC.

TAKE your family to see the perfect Victorian Christmas tree displayed at the Museum of the City of New York on Fifth Avenue at 104th Street. If you have access to the sort of good Christmas collection that can accumulate in a family over the years, this table-top tree can guide you in displaying it to the best advantage.

Dr. C.Raymond Wells, a retired Brooklyn dentist and retired rear admiral in the Naval Reserve, who was president of the American Dental Association in 1943-44, died yesterday in Great Lakes Naval Hospital, Chicago.

The parents group of Public Schools 125 and 36 on Morningside Heights has labored conscientiously to assure that its children will be able to enjoy quality education in integrated classrooms. In doing so, they have applied to the actual neighborhood scene the priorities which are supposed to be dominant in the school system's blueprints.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 Having observed carefully while the Harlem Globetrotters rolled up their umpity-umpth consecutive victory in a preliminary game, the New York Knickerbockers faced an almost equally foregone conclusion tonight as they opposed the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)--Frank Robinson is the "slugging" man, Harmon Killebrew the "walking" man and George Scott, the Boston rookie, the "missingest" man, according to the American League statistics released today by Joe Cronin, the league president.

Dick Gregory, the comedian, arrived at Kennedy International Airport yesterday from London and said that American bombing of Hanoi had prevented him from visiting the North Vietnamese capital. He had said he hoped to go there to entertain captured American fliers.
PARIS, Dec. 9 Jacques Duclos, elder statesman of the French Communist party, sought to explain today why he shook hands with President de Gaulle.
MIDDLE BASS ISLAND, Ohio On her way to school each morning, Carolyn Riddle, walks, rides a taxi and flies across a stretch of Lake Erie in a venerable Ford trimotor airplane.

CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V.I., Dec. 9 (UPI) Morris De Castro, Governor of the United States Virgin Islands from 1950 to 1954, died of a heart attack today. He was 64 years old. Mr. De Castro was Island Budget Director at his death.
TUCSON, Ariz, Dec. 9 (AP)--Arthur Krock, former editorial page columnist of The New York Times, has been selected this year's recipient of the University of Arizona's John Peter Zenger Award.

A cocktail party and fashion show are being planned for Tuesday at the Jamaica Arms, 1315 Second Avenue, as a benefit for the Third Street Music School Settlement. Miss Joanne Colon is chairman and Mrs. Richard A. Stuart is co-chairman.

ROME, Dec. 9 The Vatican announced today publication of the official edition of the decrees of the Second Vatican Council (1962-65), a 1,320-page red-clothbound volume with gilt title and decorations.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 9 The General Assembly of the National Council of Churches overwhelmingly approved today a statement calling for the placing of the Vietnam issue on the United Nations agenda.
CANTON, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP)--Harvard scored three goals in the third period to defeat Clarkson's hockey team, 7-4, tonight for its third victory in three games this season.

A GERMAN repertory company made its New York debut Thursday evening with an admirable and moving performance of "Nathan der Weise," Gotthold Ephraim Lessing's classic drama about religious and racial tolerance.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 9 Senator Robert F. Kennedy leafed through a book today called "The Dog That Barked at Midnight," applauded a chorus of teen-agers singing "Born in Bethlehem," and whispered to a 7-year-old boy painting a Christmas tree: "You know, I flunked painting in school."
Reports of a possible tender offer for stock of the financially ailing Douglas Aircraft Company sent its shares briskly higher yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The index of primary market prices declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 105.7 during the week ended Dec. 6, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices moved lower in all 3 major commodity areas farm products, processed foods and industrials.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 9 (UP) A twin-engine plane crashed in flames on Interstate Route 35-W in suburban Richfield as the afternoon traffic rush was beginning today. The pilot was thrown into the windshield of a car and was instantly killed.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 9 (AP) The Green Bay Packers are favored to clinch the Western Conference title for the fifth time in eight years of Vince Lombardi rule tomorrow by beating or tying the Balitmore Colts.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9 A hot-shooting Princeton team established a Dillon Gym scoring record tonight en route to a 110-72 victory over Colgate. The Tigers had set the previous mark in their opening game with a 108-59 victory over Lafayette, Dec. 1. It was the unbeaten Tigers' fourth victory.

A shareholder suit seeking $10-million in damages and another $30-million in punitive damages was filed yesterday in United States District Court in Cleveland by five shareholders against the G.C. Computer Corporation, the Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corporation, the Greyhound Corporation and Lehman Brothers.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to lower rates on some telephone calls between the United States and Canada.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 9 (UPI) Viking Dancer, winner of the Maryland Futurity, headed a field of 13 Maryland-bred 2year-olds entered today for tomorrow's $27,500 Marylander Stakes at Laurel.

WIELAND WAGNER'S last and incomplete work his production of his grandfather's opera "Lohengrin"was presented Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Wagner died Oct. 16 at the age of 49. His Bayreuth assistant, Peter Lehmann, came here to carry out the original designs and staging.
KANSAS CITY, No., Dec. 9 (AP) Sinclair oil companies today offered a package wage proposal in negotiations with the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union.

General de Gaulle and Mr. Kosygin gave first attention to European problems, in the spirit of the French-Soviet declaration of June 30. A detente is the first stage necessary in the evolution that appears desirable in relations between European countries, whatever their political regime and respecting their independence and their national personality. The first positive results are starting to appear in this respect.

MENASHA, Wisc., Dec. 9 Miss Emogene Below, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett W. Below of New York, formerly of Menasha, was married here this evening to George Coxe Bland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bland of Philadelphia. The Rev. John C. Hanchett performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 9 (AP) Another woman the sixth in about a year was found strangled in an apartment elevator today and a new wave of fear gripped Cincinnati, where sale of guns and chain door locks already had shown a sharp rise.
The color-television industry erupted yesterday with reports of zooming sales in contrast to the bearish figures that came from Wall Street several weeks ago.
Under Secretary of State Nicholas deB. Katzenbach urged American industry last night to support President Johnson's proposal for ending the "tariff blockade" of Communist Eastern Europe.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 9--Mrs. Edith Lee Wilkinson, widow of Henry Wilkinson, a prominent New York architect, died at her home this morning after a brief illness. She was 88 years old and lived in Llewellyn Park here.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a revision of the West Side Urban Renewal project to include 2,500 apartments for low-income families.

Douglass M. Allen Jr., a former newspaperman, and a senior editor of the magazine, Atlas, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital of a heart attack after a brief illness. Mr. Allen, who had lived on Riverside Drive, Clinton, Conn., was 48 years old.

The Helen Menken Scholarship Fund, established by the board of directors of the American Theater Wing in honor of its late president, will benefit from a preview exhibition tomorrow of sculptures by Patricia Peardon, actress and artist. The event will be held at the Burgos Galleries, 127 East 57th Street, from 5 to 9 P.M.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia said in a television interview tonight that he had no worries about an oil embargo.
The American Stock Exchange scored its fourth successive advance yesterday, rising on moderate trading.
LONDON, Dec. 9 The only public concert of Leonard Bernstein's London visit drew a capacity audience to the Royal Festival Hall last night and enthusiastic notices from the critics in today's papers.
HUNTSVILLE Tex., Dec. 9 (AP) An 83-year-old spinster who died this week left her estate estimated at $400,000 to the United States Treasury.

The completed draft treaty governing man's activity in space is more important for the fact of SovietAmerican agreement and the provisions for future scientific cooperation than for its ban on nuclear weapons.
MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (AP) Trud, the labor newspaper, today urged Russians to mind their manners but to avoid the "bourgeois etiquette" attributed to capitalist countries.

STAMFORD, Dec. 9 The Federal Government served notice today that "coordinated local interest" was the key to its participation in an $80-million program of improvements for the bankrupt New Haven Railroad.

POOR judgment in slam bidding has been an important factor in the long series of American world championship defeats at the hands of the Italians. In the recent International Team Trials, four pairs out of eight were content to rest timidly in three no-trump on the diagramed deal. As can be seen, the North-South hands are almost certain to produce 12 tricks in hearts or no-trump.
Democrats, Republicans and Liberals appeared willing yesterday to establish a common approach in organizing the state's Constitutional Convention.

Spartans Industries, Inc., whose merger with E.J. Korvette, Inc., became effective in late September, reported yesterday little change in its earnings for the 13 weeks ended Oct. 30 despite increased sales.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 9 The breakdown in talks over revamping the structure of Union Miniere du Haut Katanga to make it conform to new Congolose law was viewed here as potentially grave.

HARTFORD, Dec. 9 The director of the Civil Aeronautics Board's bureau of operating rights said today that major airlines lacked drive and imagination "in the area of economic innovation." He suggested there was a need for "new entrants" into the airline business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The president of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation assured two Federal Communications Commissioners today that the concern's proposed merger with the American Broadcasting Company would not affect the network's news coverage.

THE question of the validity of piano rolls as accurate recordings has not really been settled. Rabbi Albert Stum performed the ceremony at the Fountainhead. Miss Marilynn Sue Alpert was her sister's maid of honor. Mitchell Kurzban was best man for his brother. best man for his brother.

Four men have been elected to the board of trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Whitney North Seymour, chairman of the board, announced this week. They are Thomas W. Braden, Hedley Donovan, George Cabot Lodge and Donald B. Straus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 In the old days, before that very strange election of 1964, an observer of the House of Representatives could look out across the floor or back through the cloak rooms and see evidence of one of the strongest political forces in Washington.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 10 Britain was unwilling or unable to accept a settlement with Rhodesia that was anything short of its unconditional surrender, according to an official Rhodesian account of the dispute published today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he would ask the United States North Atlantic Treaty Organiztion allies to give more help in the Vietnam war.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Dec. 10 Boris Koutzen, a violinist, composer teacher and conductor, died today in Northern Westchester Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Pleasantville.

HARRY GOLDEN is as authentically American as Mark Twain, Artemus Ward or Finley Peter Dunne. This 10th book of his personal writings, with its Yiddish title, reminds one again of the boy reared on Rivington Street on New York's East Side who has turned up so surprisingly as a syndicated and successful editor in Charlotte. N.C.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy announced yesterday the formation of two corporations one made up of community leaders, the other of prominent businessmen to cooperate in redeveloping Bedford-Stuyvesant, the Negro and Puerto Rican ghetto in the heart of Brooklyn.

Luther Lassiter, the world pocket billiard champion, will defend his title in a 1,500-point match against Cicero Murphy of Brooklyn. The games trill be held at the Golden Q in Woodside, Queens, from Dec. 26 to 30, with afternoon and evening sessions.

Elizabeth Marshall returned to Town Hall yesterday afternoon for her third local recital,, and the 27-year-old New Jersey pianist again displayed a flashy technique and an intelligent understanding of music.

The Ribicoff subcommittee of the Senate, in its exploration of the crisis confronting America's cities, has heard a remarkable range of witnesses testify in support of a challenging new approach to urban redevelopment one that would fuse public and private resources in dynamic partnership against the slums.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 10 (UPI) Protests, political un- rest, and three meet records in track highlighted today's opening of the Fifth Asian games in Thailand's 39,000-seat National Stadium.

"Whadda we do now?" That common expression of puzzlement, uttered by so many losing horse players after almost every race every day, was voiced by all, winners as well as losers, after the last race at Aqueduct yesterday.

WESTWOOD, Mass., Dec. 10 Mrs. Thomas N. Perkins has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Bissell Perkins, to William Wallace McDowell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McDowell of Binghamton, N.Y. A March wedding in Boston is planned.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 Edward J. Fehrenbach of Bethpage, a former Assemblyman, has been appointed to the New York State Thruway Authority. Appointment of Mr. Fehrenbach to the 17,000 a year position was announced today by Governor Rockefeller.

PARIS, Dec. 10 The Roman Catholic hierarchy of France has authorized an updated catechism series that will reflect the thinking of Vatican Council II. In the words of Archbishop Pierre Veuillot of Paris, it "will benefit from the progress achieved in the teaching of secular subjects."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) The same reasons that helped make the California Zephyr one of the most popular passenger trains in the West outstanding scenery and service were cited this week by the Western Pacific Railroad for asking the discontinuance of the operation.

A discotheque party benefiting the Easter Seal Society of New York State will be given at El Morocco on Tuesday at 5 P.M. The sponsor is the New York chapter of the National Society of Interior Designers. Mrs. Geraldine Nicosia is chairman of the annual benefit.

THE state of the coin business has been up for discussion in all quarters lately. Reports of cobwebs on the cash register have been outweighed by reports of a steady resumption of traditional coin col lecting, accompanied by continued dormancy in bag and roll speculation.

STROUDSBURG, Pa In the Poconos this winter, a visitor can ski by day and hotel-hop at night. Two dozen hotels and lodges that have dancing and entertainment will be open to all comers, whether they are registered guests or not. In other years, the dance floors and the floor shows at most of these places were for guests only.

PARIS, Dec. 10 A magistrate here has decided, after four years of investigation, that it's no crime to bet on a sure thing.

DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 10 Miss Nancy Anne Dole, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Llewellyn Dole of Pasadena, Calif., was married here today to Charles Jarvis Harriman Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles J. Harriman of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Nelson Back in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Goodman of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Ellen Goodman, to Kenneth Ivan May, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving May of New Rochelle, N.Y.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 10 (AP) Upsala College, scoring the first 8 points, went on to defeat Drexel University 'of Philadelphia, 79-65, today in . a Middle Atlantic Conference basketball game.

WANTAGH, L.I., Dec. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Frank Webster Herstin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Herstin, to Richard Benjamin Wearn Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Wearn of Short Hills, N.J.

The Mount Holyoke College Glee Club will give its annual carol concert on Friday at 8:30 P.M. in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at 53d Street. The sponsor is the Mount Holyoke College Club of New York. Proceeds will go to the college.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 Richard Cardinal Coshing defended the right of dissent today in a pastoral letter deploring apathy as a betrayal of Christian heritage.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Silverstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Mary Silverstein, to Robert Kenneth Gordon. He is the son of Mrs. Andrew K. Bernath of New York and Ridgefield, Conn., and the late Ernest Andrew Gordon. The couple plan a March wedding.
NEW YORKERS once again will have the opportunity to bone up on the means and methods of salt-water fishing through classroom instruction under the auspices of the New York Power Squadrons.

CINCINATI, Dec. 10 (AP)--A 29-year-old former cab driver, held for questioning in connection with the latest of Cincinnati's six strangling cases, was convicted today in Police Court of assault in an unrelated case.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 10 The Navy wrestling team defeated Cornell in Barton Hall today, 26 to 10, while in Teagle Hall, Yale swimmers topped the Big Red, 57 to 38.
Construction of an enclosedmall shopping center that will envelope a six-acre site in the heart of downtown Norwalk, Conn., is scheduled to begin early next year.
The former Hudson River Day Line excursion steamer Peter Stuyvesant is about to take leave of the Port of New York, where she has been a familiar sight since 1927.

Vice President Humphrey's offer to mediate the controversy over the cutting off of Federal antipoverty funds to a Mississippi Head Start project opens the road to peace in a conflict that has deeply split the vanguard forces in the war on poverty.
Product News International, a new multilingual publication to promote international trade, recently made its debut with a 24-page issue.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 10 The engagement of Miss Katharine Bradlee Record, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Record, to Paul Joseph Redmond Jr. of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Redmond of Southboro, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. The wedding is planned for June.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Probably no outdoor participation sport, except fishing and golf, has become more popular in Florida than shuffleboard, especially among older visitors. In fact, at hotels and motels throughout the state, a shuffleboard court is as much a part of life as air-conditioning and television.

The bleak Grand Central end of the Times Square shuttle run is beginning to look bright, even cheerful Tiles in the city's colors of orange, white and blue, interspersed with black are a sharp contrast to the smokeblackened walls in the aftermath of the electrical fire that closed the station for 48 hours in April, 1964.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 One of the most harmless forms of whistling past a graveyard is the American penchant for using loyalty oaths as a defense against Communism.

The LTV Aerospace Corporation has announced formation of a new missiles and space division with capabilities "rivaling those of any company in the industry. Paul Thayer, president, said the division would be formed by drawing together the astronautics division and the missile segment of the Vought Aeronautics division of Dallas and the corporation's Michigan division at Detroit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) President Johnson has been asked to seek Congressional approval to build as many as four nuclear-powered merchant ships over 25 years at a cost of up to $300-million.
William J. Ward, the director of intramurals at St. John's University, has been appointed the director of games for the United States Track and Field Federation.

The report on mutual funds recently issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission will form the basis of a special conference to be conducted next Feb. 9 to 10 by the University of Pennsylvania Law School in Philadelphia.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Dec. 10 (AP) William Dubois' Shelard captured the Au Revoir Handicap at Narragansett Park today in the wind-up of the 1966 New England racing season.

WASHINGTON, Dec.10 (AP) The Washington Senators will open the 1967 American League baseball season April 10 against the New York Yankees here. It will be the Yank's first openingday appearance here since 1956.

AUGUSTA, Me. Two new ski areas in the heart of the state's snow belt, greatly ex panded facilities at a third and an accent on night skiing are the principal developments in the Maine ski story this winter.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10--Herbert C. Felix, a retired Swedish industrialist with bright blue eyes and snowy hair, may be the first commercial "matchmaker" authorized to operate on a world scale.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Aron Rome have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Gersten Rome, to Stephen Toby Kunian of Boston. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. David Saul Kunian of Swampscott, Mass.

Editions that are planned to be definitive for the works of eight American 19th-century authors are being produced under a program of the Modern Language Association backed by a $300,000 grant from the National Endowment of the Arts and Humanities.
DETROIT, Dec. 10 (UPI) Two Negro ministers said yesterday they would go to South Vietnam next month to dramatize their opposition to Stokely Carmichael, advocate of Black Power.

LIKE most novels of initiation, this one tells of the conflict between man's desire for transcendence and the necessary compromise with things as they are. Noel Hiliiard, a New Zealand newspaperman who was awarded a literary scholarship to write this book, treats with considerable restraint the story of a sensitive boy's coming of age.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 10 (UPI) Eddie Valdez threw six touchdown passes today to lead Henderson County (Tex.) Junior College to a 40-13 route of Pasadena City College in the 21st annual Junior Rose Bowl game.

In St. Batholomew's Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Eleanor Perine Wheeler, daughter of Edward Adams Wheeler of Ipswich, Mass., and Mrs. Stanley Freeman Elliott of Baltimore, became the bride of Lansing Reed Palmer. His parents are Arthur Edward Palmer Jr., the city's Administrator of Transportation, and Mrs. Palmer of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 A movement for a special party conference to draft a pre-convention statement of Republican policies for the 1968 Presidential campaign has apparently collapsed.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 10 Blessed Sacrament High School of New Rochelle defeated Cardinal O'Hara High School of Philadelphia today in the senior high school eight-oar race of the second winter regatta of the New York Rowing Association.

Yesterday, Dec. 10, was the official postmark deadline for ordering the 1966 Special Mint Set. However, the Treasury Department has indicated that orders postmarked today or tomorrow may have a chance to be filled.
WEST CHESTER, Pa., Dec. 10 Miss Virginia Cullen Ryan and Peter Hans DeHaas were married this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity by the Rev. Kenneth H. Anthony.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 10 Rutgers set school scoring records tonight in defeating Colgate, 118-75, for its fourth straight victory of the season.

A perspiring Santa Claus outside Lord Taylor on Fifth Avenue growled "Merry Christmas" to a staring youngster, and at the Weather Bureau office in Hangar 11 at Kennedy International Airport, the meteorologists "kept the door open to catch a breeze." It was Dec. 10.

Dr. Irving Matusoff, who organized in 1929 and headed until 1937 the children's cardiac clinic at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, where he had been associate pediatrician, died there Thursday. He was 70 years old and lived at 1639 President Street, Brooklyn.
A prominent economist criticized yesterday those who maintain that the United States cannot fight the war in Vietnam while continuing to pay for the fight against poverty at home.
The city's construction plumbers, who have been on for 140 days, elected a new president of their union last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien mailed his Christmas cards yesterday with ceremony and a plug for zip codes.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Michael Pivirotto have announced the engagement of Mr. Pivirotto's daughter, Miss Justine Joy Pivirotto, to Dale Milton Flanagan of New York, son of Mrs. Lurana R. Flanagan of Colum bus, Kan.
About 435 United States and Canadian concert managers will visit here this week to shop for talent and to attend two conventions.

DUCHOA, South Vietnam, Dec, 10 Bad blood between a touchy South Vietnamese division commander and his senior American adviser has led to public accusations that the Unied States is interfering in purely South Vietnamese affairs.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 10 Mrs. Flora Bachrach Schreiber Wald, wife of William Wald, a retired real-estate man, died yesterday in Long Beach Hos pital. She was 84 years old and lived at 210 Shore Road.
A 26,000-square-foot plant for packing and distributing olives has been completed in a New Jersey bog.

A woman was shot in the head in her Bronx apartment by her husband, and a friend of the estranged couple was stabbed to death by the woman's landlord in a barbershop six block away yesterday, according to the police.

THE Opera Company of Boston, two weeks ago, gave us a chance to hear Arnold Schoen berg's "Moses and Aaron." It was in many respects a moving experience an experience that transcended the worth of the opera itself. The chances are that "Moses and Aaron" will never be a repertory piece; it is too static, too "unoperatic," if you will.
KANSAS CITY, Dec.10 (UPI) The Kansas City Athletics announced today a 28-game spring exhibition schedule that included a four-game series in Caracas, Venezuela.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 10 Miss Joyce Evelyn Laverty and Walter Willard Miller Jr. plan to marry Dec. 17. Announcement of their engagement and approaching marriage has been made by Miss Laverty's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clevis Owen Laverty. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Buffalo.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10 Miss Pamela Osgood, daughter of Prof. Cornelius Osgood of Yale University's graduate anthropology faculty and the late Mrs. Harrlett Kenney Osgood, was married this afternoon to Charles Francis Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Adams of Mobile, Ala.
STARKVILLE, Miss., Dec. 10 (AP) Mississippi State University dismissed its athletic director, Wade Walker, and its head football coach, Paul Davis, today.

THE dialogue on the future shape of Ameri can television begins in earnest this week. Thursday night, barring the possibility of a further extension, is the deadline for the submission of further comments to the Federal Communications Commission on possible ways of financing and operating communications satellites to expand the usefulness and diversity of the home screen.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 In the first report it has ever made to the public, the National Advisory Cancer Council blames cigarette smoking for producing an "enormous man-made epidemic" of lung cancer.

The Rev. Dr. Bryant Mays Kirkland, senior pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, and Mrs. Kirkland of New York and Grand Haven, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elinor Ann Kirkland, to Anthony Landrum Hite, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Landrum Hite of Burbank, Calif.
MADRID, Dec.10 The Spanish Government's campaign for "yes" votes in next Wednesday's national referendum on the new Constitution has begun to produce a negative reaction.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10 In line with the worldwide ecumenical movement, Princeton University's seven Christian chaplains have formed a "United Christian Ministry" to investi gate concrete ways by which interdenominational unity can be expressed.

Carl F. Hotopp, who retired in 1953 as purchasing agent of The New York Times, died yesterday in the Birchwood Nursing Home at Huntington, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived at 330 West Neck Road, Huntington.
DALLAS, Dec. 10 Jack Ruby has cancer, doctors at the Parkland Memorial Hospital reported today.

PARIS This week will feature a curious diplomatic spectacle when NATO ministers gather for their final meeting in Gaullist Paris which just did honor to the alliance's greatest adversary, Russia. Hammer and sickle banners are still flapping beside the tricolore and French newspapers are still commenting on Premier Kosygin's unusually affable visit. A strange kind of shadow play now begins.
Reaction was mixed here yesterday to a proposal to substitute the term "Afro-American" for the "slave name" Negro.

TORONTO, Dec. 10 (AP) Ron Ellis scored three goals, two in the third period, tonight as he led Toronto to a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The triumph moved the Maple Leafs back into first place in the National Hockey League.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 Wendy Jones, a 16-year-old Hershey, Pa., high school senior, won the South Atlantic States senior ladies figure skating championship tonight at the Wissahickon Skating Club before a crowd of 1,000.

After nearly six weeks of studying American marketing methods here, a group of Japanese executives has concluded that there is a gap between what is being preached in lecture halls and what American managers do.

FREEPORT, L.I., Dec. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Lester H. Bau mann have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Ellen Baumann, to Steven Paul Kahn, son of Victor Kahn and Mrs. Victor F. Kahn, both of New York.

HAMILTON, Bermuda Dec. 10 (AP) The Olympic Country Club of San Francisco won the 14th Bermuda Goodwill golf tournament today, beating Plainfield (N.J.) Country Club on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff.
Last spring's heroes were honored last night at the 84th annual dinner of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association.
Thomas P.F. Hoving has submitted to Mayor Lindsay a counter proposal to a plan for a tree-lined mall running from Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts to Central Park.

Mutual fund executives are fond of citing the old saw that investment company shares "aren't bought, they're sold." The name of the sales game these days is clearly the "performance" fund--involving volatile, high portfolio-turnover operations that strive for maximum capital gains.
LONDON, Dec, 11--Sir Carleton Kemp Allen, Oxford secretary of the Rhodes Trustees and warden of Rhodes House of Oxford University from 1931 to 1952, died today in Oxford. His age was 79.

ATLANTA, Dec. 11 (UPI)-- Billy Lothridge of Atlanta kept St. Louis deep in its own territory with his booming kicks today and the Falcons beat the Cardinals, 16-10, for their third victory in their last four games.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 11 (UPI)-- The Air Force launched today two scientific research satellites into polar orbit atop a single Atlas D rocket, putting 12 radiation studying experiments into space.
A number of life insurance companies have been urging policyholders to buy additional paid-up life insurance with the so-called dividends they receive.
The State Mediation Board will resume efforts today to end the strike by plumbers that has tied up building construction in Manhattan and the Bronx for 141 days.
A reorganization of the transportation operations of United Fruit Company was announced yesterday by R. Berry, vice president of the Boston-based company.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 11 (Reuters)--Attempts to establish a Latin-American common market erupted in disagreement here today.
MADRID, Dec. 11--The United States was reported here tonight to be considering the unilateral release of a handful of sick or wounded North Vietnamese war prisoners under its control.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 11 (Reuters)-- Opium, heroin and possibly other dangerous narcotics are being distributed throughout New Zealand by mail order, according to an official report issued here.

LYONS, France, Dec. 11-- The Hilton hotel chain is examining the southern outskirts of France's third largest city as the site for a 200room "moberge," a combination American motel and French countryside auberge.
LAKE WALES, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP)--A five-man team from China Vista, Calif., won the first annual Winchester national claybird tournament today after a close battle with a team from Greene, N.Y.
Two Negro leaders rejected black power extremism in a debate on race relations yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) --Representative Paul Findley, charged today that the State Department was trying to arrange a $20-million wheat sale to Yugoslavia despite Congressional action cutting off authority for such transactions.
BONN, Dec. 11--Warning that West Germany was threatened with a recession, a government economic expert predicted today that unemployment would rise to 500,000 within a few months.

WARSAW Dec. 11--A novel that is not published in Polish and of which few copies circulate in this country is being talked and written about here with a near-obsessive insistence.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 11-- The National Urban League is suddenly booming in the South.

Fourteen contiguous blockfronts between Stuyvesant and Tompkins Streets, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, have been proposed for a historic district designation by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The blockfronts are among five proposed designations on which the commission will hold a public hearing tomorrow at City Hall.

BALBAO, C.Z., Dec. 10-- Seven United States soldiers visited a bat-infested cave on their day off last summer, and now science knows more than it did about a respiratory disease caused by a fungus and often mistaken for tuberculosis.
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 11--Sweden's military chief, Gen. Torsten Rapp, has become the center of mounting criticism, but he has refused to yield to demands that he resign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Dr. Stanley K. Hornbeck, for many years a Far Eastern expert in the State Department and a former Ambassador to the Netherlands, died yesterday at the George Washington Hospital. He was 83 years old.
TOKYO--The world's largest city is beginning to grow up as well as out.

Howard Mitchell led the Washington National Symphony in another concert of his Sunday afternoon series yesterday at Philharmonic Hall. He introduced each number with informal remarks about the music to be played.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP)--The police said tonight that paintings valued at a quarter of a million dollars were missing from the home of the late artist and teacher Hans Hofmann.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Although defense spending will continue to rise in calendar year 1967, the rise will be far less than in 1966.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 10--The pale leaves in the American Ambassador's garden shone moistly last night in the colored lights set up for his pre-Christmas jump-up.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Documents relating to the Zinoviev affair, one of Britain's major political scandals, have vanished from Foreign Office files, it was disclosed today.

The members of the Board of Estimate--with the exception of Mayor Lindsay--will meet privately today to discuss what they consider to be interference by the Mayor with their efforts to transfer $84.3-million to the Transit Authority.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--"I haven't had a crowd this big for some time," the Vice President of the United States said.

THESE three new titles represent, in appearance three modes of publishing: the pamphlet, the regular or ordinary book in hardcover and paperback editions, and the outright extravaganza. In subject, they represent three new, or supposedly new, overlapping departures from what is currently thought of as traditional theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--J. Edgar Hoover and Robert F. Kennedy made new charges today in their dispute over the responsibility for electronic eavesdropping by Federal agents during President Kennedy's Administration.
LONDON, Dec. 11--William A. Douglass spent most of last week draining brains from Britain to America and part of the week trying to stanch the drain.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 11-- Jordan's Minister of Information reported today that the meeting of the Arab League's defense council is Cairo had been marked by bitter recriminations over Jordan's purchase of United States aircraft and the general conditions of Arab mobilization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) --Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower undergoes surgery tomorrow morning for the removal of one of the body's most ingenious but often cantankerous organs--his gall bladder.

The twin corporations announced by Senator Robert F. Kennedy to remake Bedford-Stuyvesant represent a start in what could become the country's most exciting endeavor to give the people in racial ghettos meaningful participation in reviving their decaying neighborhoods.
The bond market, which successfully negotiated all the hurdles in last week's heavy schedule of new offerings, faces another test this week before it takes a two-week breather at year-end.

DALLAS, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Charlie Gogolak kicked a 29yard field goal with only eight seconds left to play today to give the Washington Redskins a 34-31 victory over Dallas and keep the Cowboys from nailing down the Eastern Conference championship of the National Football League.

The marriage of Miss Natalie Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Rosen of Brooklyn, to Lewis Weinfeld took place here yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Weinfeld of Bridgeport, Conn. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has announced plans for placing in service in 1968 a new "supercapacity" undersea telephone cable between the mainland and Caribbean points.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)--The Republicans' top policy-making committee meets Monday for the first time since the election last Nov. 8 to assess the party's new strength and plan how to enlarge it.

HOUSTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)-- Babe Parilli's pin-point passing and Jim Nance's explosive running led the Boston Patriots a step closer to the American Football League's Eastern Di vision title today with a 38-14 victory over the Houston Oilers.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 11--The wedding of Miss Barbara P. Sondik, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Sondik, and Louis Perlmutter, son of Mrs. Kermit Perlmutter of Springfield, Mass., and Boston and the late Mr. Perlmutter took place today.

Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff outlined last night's program for urban universities designed to achieve a physical and social rebirth of American cities. It included the establishment of "urban action centers" through which urban universities could pool resources on various problems.

Johnny Wooden insists Lew Alcindor isn't going to wreck the game of basketball, but Lew and his teammates at the University of California, Los Angeles, aren't going to make it much fun for anyone else the next three seasons.

The Port of New York Authority announced last week that it would seek Congressional action next year on appropriations totaling $10,733,000 for six vital channel and waterways improvements in the New Jersey-New York port area.

TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 11-- Mr. and Mrs. William W. Brotherton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Hall Brotherton, to Dr. John J. Caronna. He is the son of Mrs. Joseph P. Caronna of Jackson Heights, Queens,and the late Dr. Caronna.

Miss Constance Patricia Malone and Maj. Everett James Gatley, U.S.A., were married yesterday in the chapel at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens. The Lutheran ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry Von Schlichten.

The Paul Taylor Dance Company is to have a brief Broadway season before it leaves in January for a tour that will take it from Egypt as far as Korea, Japan and Australia. The company will open a week's New York season at the ANTA Theater on Monday, Dec. 26.

A civil rights leader said yesterday that American Negroes believe they cannot gain their rights without resorting to violence.
Legislation to deal with strikes by public employes has been given top priority by Democratic leaders in the Legislature.

ALBANY, Dec. 11--Alexander Aldrich, special assistant to Governor Rockefeller, today was appointed executive director of the Hudson River Valley Commission. The appointment, which becomes effective Dec. 22, was announced by Frank Wells McCabe, chairman of the commission.

Planning for 1976 Publishers are making plans now for 1976. Edward E. Booher, president of the McGrawHill Book Company, has set up a board to advise on publications to mark the bicentennial of the United States. In the planning stage are monographs, reprints, source materials, new editions of out-of-print titles, biographies and histories. Dial Press is working on a 35-volume series "Two Centuries of American Life: A Bicentennial

Alfred T. Pouch, who headed Staten Island waterfront facilities established by his grandfather in 1875 and by his father in 1917, died yesterday in his home at 120 Circle Road, Dongan Hills, S.I. He was 69 years old.

PEKING, Dec. 11 (Reuters) --Communist China protested today against what it called sanguinary suppression of Chinese by Portuguese authorities in Macao and warned Britain and the United States not to intervene in the enclave's affairs.
TORONTO, Dec. 11--Canada's billion-dollar machinery industry appears to be facing a rough overhaul by the Government, all in the name of greater efficiency and trade liberalization.

IF you are a bridge player who likes spy stories or a spy who likes bridge hands you will enjoy a recent paperback by Don Von Elsner. It is "The Ace of Spades," published by Award Books at 50 cents, and is the second adventure of Jake Winkman.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11-- Mrs. Charles Krug of Haddonfield, N.J., and William L. Berlinghof of Jenkintown, Pa., won the veteran's dance title today as the three-day South Atlantic States figure-skating championships ended at the Wissahickon Skating Club.
A 27-year-old probationary patrolman was shot and killed with his own revolver early today by a man who had been refused service in a bar.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 11 (UPI)--Japan built a big lead over 17 rivals today in the Asian Games.
The Cross Brown Company has announced that Charles J. Murphy, a former city official, has joined the commercial realty concern as vice president in charge of coordinating administrative functions.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 11-- Miss Miriam Jane Goodfriend, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Goodfriend of New Rochelle, was married this evening to Michael Simon Rapaport, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry N. Rapaport of Scarsdale.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11--"Our management is more apprehensive than the numbers seem to warrant," a steel analyst said last week.
A Brooklyn patrolman lassoed a 450-pound steer from his patrol car yesterday.
WELLINGTON, Kan., Dec. 11 (AP)--A bus carrying members of a Los Angeles revue struck a bridge abutment today and seven of the 13 occupants were taken to a hospital with injuries.
The city plans to canvass house-to-house to get people to sign up for Medicaid. Welfare recipients will be paid $1.50 an hour to ring the doorbells.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (Reuters) --West Germany underestimates dangers in the growth of the rightist National Democratic party, Jewish leaders were told here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 (UPI)--The Continental Football League has reached a tentative agreement to set up an eight-team, West Coast division in 1967, league officials announced today.
Governor Rockefeller ordered yesterday that a study be made of the feasibility of constructing a tunnel under Long Island Sound as an alternative to proposals for a bridge.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 11 --Miss Roanne Bockar, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Bockar, was married here today to Paul Katcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Katcher of New York.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 11 (UPI)-- A man who alleged that he had been kicked in the head by a Philadelphia 76er player during a National Basketball Association game said today that he was considering legal action.
A slowdown in the rate of the nation's economic expansion appears probable during 1967, Standard Poor's Corporation predicted over the weekend.

Mrs. Billie Jean King, who reluctantly gave up a career as a touch-football halfback at the age of 12, was selected as the nation's top woman tennis player for the second year in a row yesterday in the 1966 rankings made public by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 11-- Alan S. Boyd, Under Secretary of Commerce who has been named Secretary of Transportation, refused today to reconsider construction plans for Interstate Highway 87, now scheduled to cut through scenic estates and wildlife preserves on Chestnut Ridge in Bedford.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Nick Eddy, all-America halfback from Notre Dame, has signed a National Football League contract with the Detroit Lions, the club announced today Contract terms were not announced.
Jean-Pierre Rampal, flutist and Robert Veyron-Lacroix, harpsichordist, an intrepid duo, indeed, undertook to play all the Bach flute sonatas in their program at Philharmonic Hall last night.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 11--Austria and the Common Market Commission face many more months of tough negotiations on the Austrian application for an association agreement with the six-nation European Economic Community.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)--Alabama's Attorney General, Richmond M. Flowers, said today that he expected to face former Gov. George C. Wallace and "draw some blood" in the state's next Democratic governorship primary in 1970.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced over the weekend the election of Frederick R. Moseley Jr. as an executive vice president.

The Rev. R.T. Hudson, president of the Northeastern Conference of Seventh Day Adventists, died Saturday in Flint, Mich., apparently of a heart attack, while preaching at a funeral service. He was 55 years old' and lived at 895 Pine Lake Drive in West Hempstead, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 11--An Administration spokesman today urged greater flexibility in United States trade relations with Eastern Europe and indirectly criticized right-wing pressures and boycotts of Communist imports as being against the national interest.
Representative Emanuel Celler said yesterday that Congress should investigate the behavior of Representative Adam Clayton Powell.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Dec. 11 --Red Shoes, a 10--year--old chestnut mare who likes to do things her own way--and sometimes does them wrong--won the open jumper championship today at the Holiday Farms horse show.
Moscow, Dec. 11 (UPI)-- Americans cannot work without coffee, do not know how to laugh, cannot sleep because of fear and would rather used Negroes than dogs for scientific experiments.

The marriage of Miss Jill Montag, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Montag of Brooklyn, to Elliot B. Goldman took place yesterday in the Terrace Room at the Plaza. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Benjamin Goldman of New York and the late Mr. Goldman.
The Port of New York Authority's 11th annual salute to the holiday season--Christmas carols for travelers at bus, rail and air terminals-- will start a 12-day run today.
NEPTUNE, N.J., Dec. 11-- Dr. Charles Nathaniel Dezer Jr., a retired eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, died today in the Jersey Shore Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Sea Girt.

A record expense budget was proposed yesterday by Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of Schools, to make possible "new and drastic changes in the school program." He asked for funds to move toward a program of "individualized" instruction in the elementary grades; to employ 2,000 college seniors as "assistant teachers"; to extend the school day in disadvantaged areas, and to give each elementary school pupil about three paperback "classics" to read and to keep.
MIAMI, Dec. 11 (AP)--Len Dawson threw a 25-yard touchdown pass to Chris Burford with two minutes and 10 seconds to play and the Kansas City Chiefs beat the Dolphins, 19-18, today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) --Cold weather covered the nation's midsection today and continued its eastward march. Temperatures dropped early today toward the 20-below-zero mark in Minnesota, and belowfreezing readings were recorded as far south as the Mexican border and the Gulf Coast. Early morning readings ranged from 19 below zero at International Falls, Minn., to 75 degrees at Key West, Fla.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11--A platoon of the First United States Infantry Division, patrolling terrain fought over last month in Operation Attleboro, was ambushed by a larger Vietcong force today and took heavy casualties.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 11--New York lawyers for Otto Frank, father of the ill-fated wartime diarist, have demanded that the Israeli army immediately halt a Soldiers Theater production of

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- The United States Navy has widened its attacks on North Vietnamese coastal shipping and is seeking permission to expand its role to include regular bombardment of shore installa- tions.

Two weeks ago a 45-year-old woman with malignant hypertension was transferred by ambulance from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center to Bellevue Hospital, where she arrived in a coma. She died a day later.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP)--Jerry West hit a 16-foot jump shot with 28 seconds left to give the Los Angeles Lakers a 119-118 triumph over the Cincinnati Royals tonight. It was the seventh straight loss for the Royals.

A vital legal service for New York's indigent is in jeopardy because interested community action groups and the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court have not agreed on an acceptable plan. Unless an accord is reached soon, the city may lose $3.5 million in Federal funds. Worse still, many of its neediest citizens will be excluded from protection through a pioneering national program that is already functioning in more than a hundred other communities.
A $10.4-million, 13-month capital improvement program has been approved by the Oakland, Calif., Board of Port Commissioners.
Mayor Lindsay has decided to name Robert W. Sweet, now his executive assistant, as Deputy Mayor succeeding Robert Price.
SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 11 (AP)--Five United States infantrymen from South Vietnam are visiting a Jewish Hanukkah retreat here--and it may have been the result of a mailing mistake.
BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Some 10,000 Raytheon employes turned down a new contract offer by management today and voted to continue a strike that began Nov. 13.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 (UPI)--Alvin Randolph raced 94 yards to a touchdown with an intercepted pass today and Kermit Alexander scored twice on a recovered fumble and a punt return as the San Francisco 49ers routed the Chicago Bears, 41-14.
The Tishman Realty Construction Co., Inc., has taken a greater interest in the new Madison Square Garden area with the purchase of the city's largest parking garage.

A TRADITIONALLY austere meal of boiled vegetables, bread and perhaps a bit of fruit would have been, up until recently, the standard supper for thousands of Roman Catholic nuns and monks throughout the country.

The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen bade's reverent good-by yesterday to his friends and colleagues in New York.

Karl Kraber, Charles Kuskin, William Lewis, Jane Taylor and Barry Benjamin, otherwise known as The Dorian Quintet, demonstrated anew that music for wind instruments can provide a deeply satisfying musical experience.
Bobby Fischer opened a defence of his United States Chess Championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel last night.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 11 (AP)--The National Catholic Reporter says 62 per cent of the Catholic priests who replied to a questionnaire believe diocesan priests should have freedom of choice between marriage and celibacy.

The United Jewish Appeal yesterday adopted a 1967 fundraising goal of $75,620,000, which it termed "minimal" to aid needy Jewish men, women and children over the world.
Chanting religious songs and holding signs aloft, 3,000 high school and college students marched yesterday's to protest the Soviet Union's cultural and religious restrictions on Jews.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 (UPI)-- George Gardner, a rookie goal tender, helped the Detroit Red Wings break a four-game losing streak tonight with a 4-1 National Hockey League triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

Frances Fanelli, a 23-yearold pianist from Philadelphia, made her New York debut late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. She was treated to the recital as first prize winner of the Leschetizky Association's 1966 Town Hall award.

FOE of filthy air, archenemy of urban removal, cellar dweller, conservationist, architectural designer and critic, iconoclast, Greenwich Village civic leader, gadfly, freelance writer, rebel with many causes, "but not a beatnik."
