Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., announced yesterday the formation of a food processing council to work closely with the Food and Drug Administration and related governmental agencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, said today he favored using the training facilities of the armed forces to raise the educational, physical and moral standards of the nation's youth.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 14 An American battalion will be sent to South Vietnam's IV Corps area in the Mekong delta before the end of January and possibly before the end of 1966, informed sources said today.

WHEN Viggo Hansen, chef of Scandinavian Airlines, married one of his junior chefs, no one was shocked. All their co-workers agreed that Mrs. Hansen was one of the nicest, most engaging women imaginable.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 14 Miss Cornelia E. Sullivan and John Kaylor Northway Jr., son of Mrs. Eleanor Weist Northway of White Plains and the late Mr. Northway, plan to marry here in May.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday the election of J. Leland Atwood and Charles W. Buek as directors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The New York Stock Exchange and other securities-industry organizations have protested strongly a proposed Government rule that would require some securities salesmen to inquire into their customers' financial condition before recommending specific stocks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration ordered today an indefinite delay for the effective date of new regulations on special diet foods and diet supplements, including vitamins.
Mayor Lindsay designated yesterday a route for part of the $34-million Richmond Parkway on Staten Island that is different from the route planned and fought for by Robert Moses.

Archbishop Iakovos, primate of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Americas, praised yesterday last Friday's statement by the General Assembly of the National Council of Churches urging that the Vietnam conflict be placed on the United Nations agenda.

ALICIA DE LARROCHA, the diminutive Spanish lady with the big technique, came to the stage of Philharmonic Hall last night, adjusted herself before the piano and launched into "Evocation" by Albeniz. It was the first of the 12 pieces that make up the "Iberia" Suite, and Miss De Larrocha played all four books, all 12 pieces.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec 14 India, the United Arab Republic and Yugoslavia agreed today on preferential tariffs, special payment facilities and a joint shipping service for trade between the three countries.

The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has issued its annual reminder to all aliens that under Federal law they must register each year at post offices or immigration offices in January. The only exception is for diplomats and United Nations personnel.
DAVID MERRICK'S decision to close "Breakfast at Tiffany's" must have been a painful one for him and for everyone else associated with the musical.

MADRID, Thursday, Dec. 15 The Government of Generalissimo Francisco Franco announced early today that the new Constitution it had drafted was approved by an overwhelming margin in yesterday's referendum.

BONN, Dec. 14 Herbert Wehner, West Germany's new Minister for All-German Affairs, said today that Bonn should reconsider its policy of not recognizing the East German regime in the Communist Government became "democratized."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Industrial production declined in November as output of automobiles, other consumer goods and iron and steel dropped.

SEARINGTOWN, L.I., Dec.14--The engagement of Miss Lauren Dinger to Arthur McCauley Jr., son of Mr. McCauley of West Islip and the late Mrs. Lillian O'Readen McCauley, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Sadlier Dinger.
DALLAS, Dec. 14 (AP) Diagnostic studies are near an end for cancer-stricken Jack Ruby, doctors announced tonight. Earlier today, one of his doctors expressed further doubt that Ruby can survive.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants, off to a late start in the trading market, made their second deal in two days today when they obtained Norm Siebern, the California Angels' first baseman, for Len Gabrielson, a reserve outfielder.
A new short-haul air service, operating from major airports to outlying areas, has been announced by Trans World Airlines and Piper Twinair Service, Inc.
FOSTORIA, Ohio, Dec. 14 Robert Twells, founder of the Autolite Spark Plug Company and a leader in the automotive parts and ceramic industries, died at City Hospital here today. He was 71 years old.
GENEVA, Dec. 14 The Swiss Parliament made history today by electing as the country's President a native of the Canton of Valais.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 14 (AP) Intra Bank, Lebanon's largest, which was forced to close two months ago when it ran out of ready cash, opened its doors a tiny crack today to start reimbursing small depositors from a special loan advanced by the Government.
Time is growing short for the investor who is considering securities transactions with an eye to reducing his income-tax liability.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (Reuters) The Labor Government was urged tonight to set up a public trust to take over The Times of London.

WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J., Dec. 14 Dr. and Mrs. Seymour E. Rosenthal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurie Jane Rosenthal, to Michael Roger Slater, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Slater of Rye, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla.
Private and corporate concern over the pollution of air and water is growing.
Thirty-four City College students will be barred from classes for eight days, beginning this morning, for having violated college regulations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 14 A week after the assassination of an opposition politician, allegedly by Vietcong terrorists, the Saigon regime is faced with a Constituent Assembly, a press and a public that refuse to accept its word completely.
State Senator-elect Eugene Rodriguez, on trial on perjury and attempted grand larceny charges, was described by his attorney yesterday as the victim of a "political frame."

New York University's hopes of regaining the Metropolitan Conference swimming championship were dimmed yesterday, when St. John's University, the titleholder, defeated the Violets, 60-43, in Quigley Pool.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 A tape recorder will turn 24 hours a day in a police interrogation room somewhere in Manhattan.
The New York Jets plan to go "all out to win" and disregard a possible tie in a crucial American Football League game with the Boston Patriots Saturday at Shea Stadium.

TORONTO, Dec. 14 The Canadian investment community reacted with shock today to a Quebec court decision ordering Baker, Weeks Co., a New York brokerage house, to pay $7,000 in damages to clients who claimed they had suffered losses because of advice from Baker, Weeks.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 14 Mr. and Mrs. David Kellock Elwell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lyon Elwell, to Rufus King Griscom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Preston Griscom of Syosset, L.I., and New York.

Rudolf Bing will continue as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association through the 1969-70 season. His contract, which ran through the 1968-69 season, had an option for a one-year extension. The association's decision to exercise this option was made known yesterday by Anthony Bliss, its president, following a board meeting.
Following is the forword by William Manchester to his book, "The Death of a President," scheduled to be published in 1967 by Harper Row, Publishers, Inc.:

Steve Cady of The New York Times and Dave Alexander, a freelance writer and novelist, were named yesterday as the winners of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association's first awards for "outstanding achievement in journalism."

Two colleges whose basketball teams have rarely played in Madison Square Garden Rutgers and the University of Missouri oppose each other tonight in the opener of a basketball double-header at the Eighth Avenue arena.

The Mannes College of Music presented a benefit concert for its scholarship fund last night at Town Hall, complete with gold-tasseled programs and a warm atmosphere of friend greeting old friend in the audience.

Victor Andres Belaunde, the Peruvian representative to the United Nations and a former president of the United Nations General Assembly, died last night in the headquarters of the Peruvian mission to the United Nations at 301 East 47th Street. He would have been 83 years old today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Bill D. Moyers, President Johnson's intimate friend, adviser and press secretary, is resigning from the White House staff to become publisher of Newsday, the prosperous Long Island afternoon newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The creation of a coastto-coast communications network that will tie the vast crime files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to police departments across the nation was announced today by Acting Attorney General Ramsey Clark.
The Chrysler Corporation has been formally notified by a group of rebellious Dodge automobile dealers in the New York ...
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14 Miss Renee Braun, a senior at Syracuse University, plans to be married in February to James Stuart Augins, a magna cum laude graduate of Syracuse's College of Engineering.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The Treasury borrowed $169million from the Federal Reserve System last Friday and repaid the barrowing Monday, it was disclosed today.
Filigree Foods, Inc., wholesaler of grocery products and frozen foods, has broken ground for a $2.6-million distribution and office center in Totowa, N.J.
West, Weir Bartel, Inc., held its annual Christmas party yesterday and its president, Walter Weir, played Santa without any of that ho, ho, ho and red-suit stuff.
CHESS has its spiritual rewards. The most soul satisfying is the queen sacrifice for a climactic finale.

CHUB CAY, Berry Islands, the Bahamas, Dec. 14 The wind was blowing out of the east. It wasn't of great velocity and it was warm and pleasant but it had been steady through the night and the morning and it had stirred up the ocean so that the going was a bit rough.
ON a spot adjacent to heavy Long Island Expressway traffic, high-rise construction and a man-made hill, more than 50 Queens College students are learning to ski for college credits.
The spot rate on the British pound was steady and unchanged at $2.7909 in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Currency for delivery tomorrow as quoted as $2.7914/16.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) Millions of plants and insects were put, into orbit today to spend three days helping scientists learn if long-distance trips in space could make humans ill.
Danny Thomas, who tired of a weekly television show and gave it up 2 years ago, will return next fall as the star of a one-hour weekly series over the National Broadcasting Company network.
ROCHESTER, Dec. 14--The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, the new Bishop of this Roman Catholic diocese, arrived here to a tumultuous welcome this afternoon.

The Dressmakers Joint Council of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union asked yesterday for a 20 per cent wage increase for 80,000 workers employed in the eight-state metropolitan dress market.

Commuters on the New Haven and New York Central Railroads were delayed up to 80 minutes last night, when an obstruction on the tracks halted two New Haven trains in the Park Avenue tunnel at 77th street.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 14 St. John's University coasted to a 91.58 basketball victory over Seton Hall tonight, its third victory in three starts.

The Bronx Borough President, Herman Badillo, urged the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday to file a formal application to build a new St. Francis Hospital in the Bronx so that he could appeal any adverse decision to the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Harold Howe 2d, the United States Commissioner of Education, told Congress today that his office's controversial guidelines for achieving desegregation did not "attack or undermine" the concept of neighborhood schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it had begun action to remove Relay aspirin tablets from the market.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 14 (UPI) Sun Tumble, a 4-year-old filly owned by G.H. Burt, withstood a late challenge by Huila today to win the feature race at Laurel as the Maryland track resumed racing after a day's postponement forced by a snowstorm.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frederick Smith of Germantown and Mantoloking, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Abigail Smith, to Stuart Strothard Holder, son of Dr. and Mrs. Clinton Howard Holder of Westfield, N.J.
The Association of Czechoslovak Sportsmen in the Western World will hold its first benefit, a dinner dance, at the Plaza on New Year's Eve. Proceeds will go to the Czechoslovakian Refugee Fund.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Cotton farmers have approved a new program that will involve the Government more deeply in their affairs.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy will seek an injunction shortly to block the publication of "Death of a President," William Manchester's account of the assassination of her husband, on the ground of breach of contract.
The Riverside Singers, a vocal group that gave a charming program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is all the Swingle Singers should be.

Three major airlines received anonymous telephone threats of bombing here yesterday, the day after the National Broadcasting Company televised a two-hour dramatization of a fictitious plot to bomb an airliner.
Stock prices closed with slight gains yesterday after wavering in a narrow range.
PARIS, Dec. 14 The French Communist party charged today that Chinese agents had attempted to bribe a party member into setting up a rival Communist party.
Lithium Corporation of America, Inc., yesterday announced a general price increase for lithium products effective immediately.

Stokely Carmichael, chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, said last night, "Lyndon Baines Johnson had better wake up or all our cities will be in a constant state of insurrection."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Department of Labor took over three new antipoverty employment programs today from the Office of Economic Opportunity.

Bond prices continued to move ahead yesterday, although the advance was not as great as in sessions earlier in the week. Government bonds registered gains from 2/32 to 8/32, while Treasury bills rose enough to depress yields 2 to 4 basis points.

The election of John S. Pillsbury Jr., president of the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company of Minneapolis, as chairman of Life Insurance Association of America was announced here yesterday at the association's 60th annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

After a one-day setback, most stocks yesterday on the American Stock Exchange resumed their advance.
The board of directors of No. 1 (that's J. Walter Thompson, not Hertz) trooped out of their final 1966 meeting today to announce that this year had been the best in the company's 102 years.

The stock market shivered yesterday in reaction to further indications that the nation's economy was cooling off.

THE 1966 Annual Exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, which is devoted to sculpture and prints, is a very large show--larger than a count of its 148 sculptures and 66 prints might suggest.

Directors of the Carrier Corporation recommended yesterday a two-for-one stock split. They also raised the quarterly dividend on the present stock to 50 cents from 40 cents. The itinerary for the New York Yacht Club cruise, for which the dates only had been announced previously, was made public yesterday at the organization's annual meeting in the West 44th Street clubhouse.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI)--President Johnson said today that he would nominate six Coast Guard captains to become rear admirals. Two of the captains are twin brothers.

Massive traffic tie-ups on the East Side harried drivers in both the morning and evening rush hours yesterday following the fall of a 20-foot slab of concrete on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. The slab hit two cars and injured two persons.
A 14-story building at 8 East 83d Street has joined the trend toward conversion of postwar apartment buildings, erected as rental buildings, to cooperative ownership.
The upward climb of the performing artist is long, slow and hard. By comparison, Mayor Lindsay's stage career has been meteoric.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15--The Soviet Government denounced today as a "grave crime" the bombing attacks made this week by the United States against targets in the Hanoi area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15-- The "freedom of choice" plan for desegregating schools in the South was denounced by high Government officials today as largely unfree, unfair, unrealistic, inconvenient and inefficient.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 15--The fourth successive 1 per cent increase in oil production by prorated wells in Texas fields was ordered today by the Texas Railroad Commission, to take effect Jan. 1.
LOS ALAMITOS, Calif., Dec. 15 (AP)--A Navy plane fell into a cluster of houses today after taking off in blinding fog but no one was injured, the Navy said.
Marie-Claire Blais, the 27year-old French-Canadian novelist, recently received the 1966 Prix Medicis for her "A Season in the Life of Emmanuel."

"There is no evidence of antiwhite racism in the Chinese Communist internal propaganda directed against America and the Soviet Union," the head of a research team looking into Chinese propaganda reported yesterday.
WARSAW, Dec. 15--The Polish Government, in a formal statement tonight, denounced the United States air attacks in the Hanoi area.
Pokey Watson, an 18-year-old high school senior from Santa Clara, Calif., heads the AllAmerica women's swimming team listed yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union.

Guests at the Bal Masque at the Pierre Dec. 31 will vie for the honor of starting the New Year with the most beautiful mask on. The winner will be chosen at midnight at the ball, arranged in behalf of Boys' Towns of Italy.

Bernhard M. Auer, who started work 27 years ago as a copy boy with Time, Inc., and rose to the post of publisher of Time magazine, will become a senior vice president next Feb. 1, the comnany announced yesterday.

NEWARK, Dec. 15--Blue Shield of New Jersey petitioned the state today for an average increase of 24.7 per cent in medical-surgical insurance rates for approximately 75 per cent of its 2.7 million members.

SEOUL, South Korea,--Two leading American petroleum companies have agreed to help expand South Korea's oil refining facilities to meet its increasing need for fuel oil and supply raw materials for a proposed petrochemical industry.

MIAMI, Dec. 15 (UPI)-- Breeze Maker went to the front halfway through the $3,500 Gallant Man purse at Tropical Park today and then breezed to a length and three-quarter victory in the race honoring his sire.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Friday, Dec. 16--Angry resentment against the political leadership of President Johnson broke into the open early today among the nation's Democratic Governors.
The Guggenheim Museum was host last night to a concert that made Verdi's "Anvil Chorus" sound like a lullaby. The Manhattan School of Music Percussion Ensemble.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.6 on Wednesday from 102.9 on Tuesday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 15-- Ibrahim Makhos, Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister of Syria, has made an offer to Iraq that seems to be an open invitation for Iraq to nationalize the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company.

PARIS--General de Gaulle would be happy, indeed interested, to see President Johnson if the American Chief of State wishes to visit France in 1967, but this does not mean de Gaulle considers a meeting wise at this time.

Tommy Davis, late of Hornell, Kokoma, Victoria, Montreal, Spokane and Los Angeles, arrived in Shea Stadium yesterday to take up residence as a member of the New York Mets and said: "It's beautiful. I'm home."
Thomas P.F. Hoving is expected to be named next week as the new director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
DALLAS, Dec. 15--Doctors said today that they had been unable to find the primary cancer that has hospitalized Jack Ruby, slayer of Lee Harvey Oswald.

A high Jesuit official said yesterday that Woodstock College, a Jesuit seminary, was giving "serious consideration" to abandoning its relatively isolated campus in Woodstock, Md., and affiliating with a large urban university.

NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Dec. 15 (UPI)--Verna Felton, the grandmotherly actress in the television series "December Bride" and "Pete and Gladys," died of a stroke last night in her, home here. She was 76 years old.
Two thousand cheering, jeering Park Department employes shoved through police barriers at City Hall last night and disrupted the annual ceremony of lighting the Christmas tree.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 15 (UPI) --Demon Doug, the favorite, romped to a six-length victory today in the $5,500 Kelso Purse at Laurel.
BIMINI, the Bahamas, Dec. 14--Representative Adam Clayton Powell laughed loudly as he strutted along the dock at Alice Town in Bimini late yesterday afternoon with a group of local fishermen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--A change in the Government's tax collection procedures that will reduce this year's budget deficit but add to the already large difficulties of holding next year's deficit within reasonable bounds was announced today by the Treasury Department.

Chang Key Young, Deputy Premier of South Korea, said here yesterday that he expected construction to start next March on his country's first integrated iron and steel mill. The venture is expected to cost about $100-million.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15-- Consumers, through "confusion and ignorance, some deception and even fraud," often fail to get their money's worth in the market place, a consumer panel said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP)--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara announced today he had ordered the Army to expand its pilot training by 50 per cent and to enlarge facilities at Fort Wolters, Tex., and Hunter Air Force Base, Ga.

WASHINGTON, Dec.15--President Johnson has asked McGeorge Bundy, the president of the Ford Foundation, to explore the possibilities of establishing a permanent forum for the exchange of management knowledge with the Soviet Union and all other advanced societies.
WASHINGTON, Dec.15--The American economy can grow no faster than about 4 per cent a year between now and 1970, a Labor Department study concluded today.
WALL STREET seems to feel that Walt Disney Productions still has star quality following the death of the man who founded the company and carried it to greatness.

Allie Reynolds, former New York Yankee pitcher, filed suit in federal court yesterday against administrators of they baseball pension system, charging them with "whittling away" the rights of retired and older players.

DENVER, Dec. 15 (UPI)-- Lou Saban, who directed the Buffalo Bills to successive American Football League championships, was reported today ready to sign a contract as general manager and head coach of the Denver roncos of the A.F.L.
At Lincoln Center today: New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15 P.M.; Verdi's "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Handel's "Messiah," Masterwork Chorus, Philharmonic Hall, 8.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, Dec. 15 (AP)--Thirty-nine postulants to an order of Roman Catholic nuns will take lessons in charm from those who train airline hostesses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15-- President Johnson inaugurated the Christmas season in and around the White House today by portraying this as a time of testing and uncertainty, relieved by "some signs of hope."

The National Football League awarded the coveted New Orleans franchise yesterday to a syndicate whose principal is John Whitfield Mecom Jr., a 27year-old Texan from Houston with a wealthy father, a handsome wife, a clutch of oil wells, ...

TORONTO, Dec. 15--Canada reported today a third-quarter surplus of $128-million in her trade in goods and services with other countries. The figure was sharply higher than the $36-million surplus a year ago.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 16--Bad weather over Hanoi yesterday prevented United States fighter-bombers from returning to attack targets in the area, American military spokesmen said early today.

Teachers dismissed a year ago from St. John's University returned yesterday with their sympathizers to demonstrate outside the school's Downtown Center in Brooklyn. But they found themselves heavily outnumbered by counter-demonstrators.
For the fifth consecutive trading day, bond prices advanced yesterday, giving Wall Street's dealers and traders a bit of holiday cheer that was a welcome prelude to the ending of a hectic year.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15-- Walt Disney, who built his whimsical cartoon world of Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs into a $100-million-ayear entertainment empire, died in St. Joseph's Hospital here this morning. He was 65 years old.

A selective list of restaurants in New York City and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 15 (AP)--The prosecutor-elect for Pulaski (Little Rock) and Perry Counties said today that he would appoint Christopher C. Mercer Jr., a Negro, as a deputy prosecuting attorney.

BONN, Dec. 15--Karl Marx, publisher of the respected West German Weekly Jewish newspaper. Allgemeine Wochenzeitung der Juden, died today in a hospital at Ebernsteinberg, near Baden-Baden. He was 69 years old and had been in poor health for several years.
United States military headquarters in Saigon denied today that any U.S. bombs fell in the city of Hanoi in the raids on the Hanoi area this week.

TOKYO, Dec. 15--Japan's six major shipping lines will be organized into two groups under a Transportation Ministry plan for container-cargo service between Japan and the West Coast of the United States. The companies have consented.

The Social Service Employes Union warned yesterday of the possibility of a strike on Jan. 3 against the Welfare Department unless the city bargained "seriously" on demands for increased wages and higher standards in the department.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 15 (AP) --The chief engineer of a sister ship of the ore carrier Daniel J. Morrell, which sank Nov. 29 in a Lake Huron storm with a loss of 28 lives, said today the Morrell was in "good condition" when he left her as chief engineer in 1965.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 15 --A pair of 11-year-old Livingston, N.J., girls were among the winners today as the North Atlantic figure-skating championships started at the Olympic Arena.

John T. Reynolds resigned yesterday as president of the Columbia Broadcasting System television network to become head of TV activities for Paramount Pictures. He had been in the C.B.S. post 10 months.
The following are among the special programs of Christmas music planned by the city's churches for tomorrow, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith announced yesterday that they would sponsor a committee to promote greater understanding.

A top official of the Chase Manhattan Bank sharply attacked yesterday a decision of a Federal District Court in Washington that commercial banks are barred from underwriting or dealing in tax-exempt revenue bonds sold by public authorities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) Education Commissioner Harold Howe 2d came under renewed fire today, but this time he was accused of being too soft in administering Federal laws to end school segregation.

OTTAWA, Dec. 16 (UPI) Negotiators for Canada's 800 air-traffic controllers called off a threatened strike and agreed today to a proposal that will keep the country's airports operating through the Christmas season. The walkout had been scheduled to start Tuesday.

William A. Lockwood, a Wall Street lawyer for 65 year's, died Thursday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 92 years old and lived at 969 Park Avenue and in East Hampton, L.I.
The formation of Avon Steamship Company, Inc., a ship operating and management company, to be headed by Capt. Leo V. Berger, has been announced.

The Wakabayashi-Boily-Gray line consists of the team's three leading scorers, but Coach John H. Kelley considers it his second line. The No. 1 line has Jim Quinn at center, with Fred Bassi and Mike Sobeski at the wings.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 16 The fight of an Italian-American brunet couple to adopt their blue-eyed, blond foster child appeared today to have a growing chance of victory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Dr. John T. Middleton of California will be director of the new National Center for Air Pollution Control, it was announced today.
Broadway showmen, who for many years campaigned for the right to operate bars in theaters, have failed to install them to any great extent since they won their point two years ago.

At ringside, it appeared that Jose Torres was wincing more than a boxer should whenever Dick Tiger clubbed him in the mid-section last night at Madison Square Gardcn. Torres has had a recent history of pancreatic inflammation.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 16 With snow patches covering the international grass course at Laurel, the $30,000 added Laurel Turf Cup will be transferred to the main dirt course tomorrow, where a field of 14 will race 1 3/8 miles.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Undefeated Cornell routed Northeastern, 9-1, and the defending National Collegiate champion, Michigan State, beat Boston College, 5-3, tonight in the first round of the E.C.A.C. Christmas hockey tournament at the Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 (AP) A $13-million longshoreman's wage guarantee fund will be distributed among 10,400 West Coast longshoremen and ship clerks, with each worker getting about $1,200 extra in his Dec. 30 nag-check.
MADRID, Dec. 16 For the first time under the rule of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, a Government-run union today threatened a work stoppage.
HOUSTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) Mississippi and Texas meet Saturday in the Bluebonnet Bowl before a crowd expected to number 70,000.

A conundrum this reader cannot fathom is the current decline in popularity of two of the finest novelists of this century, Joseph Conrad and Arnold Bennett. Conrad, who has given us rousing tales and unforgettable characters, generally in exotic surroundings and Jamesian prose; Bennett, whose naturalism and superb observation showed us an England we would hardly otherwise have known, deserve better.
The way appeared clear yesterday toward a merger of the two major deck and engineer ship officers' unions.

WILMINGTON, N. C., Dec. 16 Miss Suzanne Nash Ruffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Browne Ruffin, will be married here tomorrow evening to Daniel Powell Roth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence S. Roth of Wilmette, Ill.
Bart Starr and Jim Nance were named yesterday as players of the year by the New York Professional Football Writers Association.
LONDON, Dec. 16 Britain will make her annual December loan payments to the United States and Canada after skipping them for two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 A crime investigator who answered two ads in a magazine seven years ago has since received 419 unsolicited mailed advertisements, most of them obscene, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

As predicted, several hundred million hairlike "needles," placed in orbit in 1963 in a military communications experiment, have entered the atmosphere and drifted gently to earth, it was reported yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 17 (UPI) South Vietnam's Constituent Assembly, which is drafting a constitution, voted today to include a vice president as well as a president and premier in the nation's future civilian government.

Under the terms of the War saw Convention, an airline cannot restrict its liability on international flights unless passengers are furnished with a statement on ticket or baggage check that the flight is subject to the pact's liability restrictions.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 16-Two covenants on human rights, 19 years in preparation, were approved unanimously today by the General Assembly.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16 Andover and Trinity College School of Port Hope, Ont. moved into tomorrow's final of the Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament with victories today in the quarterfinals and semi-finals.

Although Mrs. Ruth S., 67, is ill with ulcers, she uncomplainingly took on the burden of being both housekeeper and baby sitter for her grandchildren Maria, 7; Roseann, 4; and Emily, 2. But the strain has been too much for her.

An object lesson for the Constitutional Convention could be drawn from the results of the voting on eleven proposed constitutional amendments at last month's election. In an election in which 6,159,578 votes were cast, not a single amendment was voted on by as many as two-thirds of those voting.
In an unusual move, the General Electric Company announced yesterday that its earnings in 1966 might be somewhat below 1965's record level.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy asked a justice of the State Supreme Court yesterday to block the publication of "Death of a President," a book she said she once had authorized in the interest of "accuracy, good taste and dignity."
Another barometer game confronts the New York Knickerbockers tonight as they face the St. Louis Hawks at Madison Square Garden in a National Basketball Association game at 8:30 o'clock.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 16 (UPI) Two dead heats for first place were recorded today at Bay Meadows, including a head-and-head finish by Appleofhereye and My Thel in the feature.
Faint signs of a more abundant world copper supply have appeared recently, Simon D. Strauss, vice president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, said here yesterday.

Two young men with a wealth of background as assistants at top football schools were named head coaches yesterday at the University of Kansas and Kansas State University. The schools had 1966 won-lost-tied records of 2-7-1 and 0-9-1, respectively.

Lammot du Pont Copeland, president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., testified in Federal Court yesterday that he had never heard of the du Pont company exerting influence or trying to exert influence over the buying decisions of the General Motors Corporation.

The United States Rubber Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the third straight year. George R. Vila, chairman and president, said continued improvement in 1967 was anticipated, "assuming no sharp downturn in the economy."
J. Seymour Sloan, founder and chairman of the board of Harris and Sloan, an insurance brokerage firm here, died Thursday evening at the home of a friend. He was 74 years old.
Announcement was made yesterday of the election of Leo J. Pantas as chairman of the board of trustees of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn.

New York is the financial center of the world, and the great commercial banks whose headquarters are here have immense stakes in the city's well-being. Despite their huge investments in real estate, in people and in the city's obligations, they have paid relatively little attention to its problems or its potential. They have usually shown more interest in what goes on elsewhere than in their own front yard.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16A six-week-old shipyard electricians strike is being studied by the Government in order to determine its effects on shipping to South Vietnam.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 16 (AP)-Senator Birch Bayh told the Great Lakes Commission last night that the proposed 10 per cent increase in St. Lawrence Seaway tolls could bring financial disaster for the operation.
The moonlighting activities of 120 city employes who close up shop at dusk and go home to discover art will come to light next week.

Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it had purchased 16 Boeing aircraft at a total cost of about $65-million.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) A spokesman for the North American Soccer League said today that three European teams Stoke City of England, Hibernian of Scotland and Valencia of Spain would compete in the league next summer.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 16 Miss Barbara Fairchild Young, daughter of Mrs. Stanley E. Young Jr. of Syosset and the late Mr. Young, was married this afternoon to Richard S. Sullivan of Oyster Bay, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Sullivan of Boston. The Rev. James E. Collins performed the ceremony in St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church.

Rabbi Alvin Kass, 31-yearold leader of an Astoria, Queens, synagogue, was made a chaplain of the Police Department yesterday.
WASHINGTON, DEC. 16 President Johnson is apparently looking around for a new Democratic National Chairman.
Three associates of Philip J. Levin have formally given notice they will join him in a proxy fight for control of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc.
Ervin Albert Schutz, a vice president of Burlington Industries, textile producers, died of a heart attack yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 60 years old and lived in Leonia, N.J.

TORONTO, Dec. 16 The Toronto Maple Leafs' have five players who have competed in at least 15 National Hockey League campaigns, a 42-yearold goalie with a lowly goalsagainst average of 3.22, and only one player among the top 10 scorers.
SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 16Dr. Carl A. Coppolino was welcomed back to Florida today with a handshake from the sheriff and the news that he will go on trial for his life again on Feb. 13:

Cornelius W. Middleton, a retired executive of the Babcock Wilcox Company, steam generating and nuclear energy equipment, died on Thursday while on a cruise in the South Pacific. He was 73 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street and at Birdwood Farms in Charlottesville, Va.
The Government bond market faltered yesterday after its fiveday upward sprint, although Treasury bills and other shorterterm issues continued to advance in price.

JACQUELINE B. KENNEDY, being duly sworn, deposes and says: 1. I am the plaintiff in this action and submit this affidavit in support of a motion for an injunction pendente lite. (Copies of the summons and complaint are annexed to these papers. Defendants Harper and Cowles have been served with the summons.)
The Communications Satellite Corporation asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday for immediate and exclusive authority to introduce a domestic communications satellite system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) Government advisers on alcoholism said today that alcohol was a fine tranquilizer and an excellent source of food energy but an agent of death when consumed at Christmas office parties.

The election of Lewis J. Byrne as senior vice presi dent and mortgage officer of the Dollar Savings Bank, the Bronx, was announced yesterday. As senior vice president, he succeeds Thomas W. Christy, who is retiring.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 16 (UPI) Chuck Nagle's two free throws in the last 2 seconds led Wisconsin to victory over Fordham, 67-66, tonight and into the title game of the Wisconsin Classic.

CRANBURY, N.J. Christmas comes early to this picturesque town halfway between New York and Philadelphia. In September, Christmas tree connoisseurs start coming to C.B. Hutchinson's Evergreens to select the richest, bushiest, most evenly branched trees they can find.
Dr. Solomon Wind, rabbi, educator and author, died Thursday in a hospital in Raanana, Israel. He was 62 years old and lived at 1713 52d Street, Brooklyn.
Mayor Lindsay swore in Mrs. Shirley Adelson Siegel, former assistant state attorney general, as the city's assistant administrator of housing and development yesterday.

Robert B. Dunlop has been named president of the Systems Manufacturing division of the International Business Machines Corporation. Mr. Dunlop was formerly director of data proc essing manufacturing for the IBM World Trade Corporation, a subsidiary.

Alexander Trachtenberg, founder of International Publishers, the chief disseminators of Marxist books in the United States, and a Communist revolutionary for more than half a century, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 82 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16-The General Assembly's Political Committee de-. feated a resolution today that was designed to end United Nations involvement in Korea.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 A fine collection of African art, brought together by G. Mennen Williams, former Governor of Michigan, and his wife, made its public debut today as it was formally presented to the Detroit Institute of Arts.
A new motion picture, "BlowUp," will open here tomorrow night in the first commercial showing of a film that has been denied approval by the recently liberalized Production Code.
The Great Northern Railway announced yesterday that it would cut $12-million from its capital-improvement program for next year. This year's expenditures totaled $41.5-million.

Events today at Lincoln Center: New York Philharmonic Young People's Concert, Philnarmonic Hall, 12 noon and 2:30; Strauss's "Die Frau ohne Schatten," Metropolitan Opera, 1:30, and Puccini's "Turandot" at 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Karl Richter, organist, Philharmonic Hall 11:30 P.M.

Boston University's undefeated hockey team, led by a Canadian of Japanese descent, is favored in the sixth annual Eastern College Athletic Conference invitation tournament starting today at Madison Square Garden.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 16 (UPI) Masashi Ouchi, a Japanese weightlifter, bettered the world record in the middle weight division today as the Asian Games continued despite heavy rain that forced postponement of some events.

THE Winter Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association continues this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel with a twosession Master Pair contest in three flights at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 On a clear day you can see, if not forever, then an awfully long way from the Vice President's new highrise apartment.

The International Association of Concert Managers ends its 19th annual convention tonight with a cocktail party and dinner at the New York Hilton. The three-day conference of approximately 150 concert managers from the United States, with on efrom Paris and another from London, was a sounding board for ideas and complaints. And bookings for the 1967-68 season were made behind the scenes.

THE Duchess of Windsor once walked into the tiny Dorothee Bis boutique at 39 rue de Sevres in Paris and ordered some clothes.
Approved resolution imposing mandatory sanctions against Rhodesia by vote of 11 to 0 with four abstentions.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Dec. 16 Announcement has been made by Prof. and Mrs. Charles E. Schaffner of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Jean Schaffner, to Timothy John Sharp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot H. Sharp of Brooklyn and Awosting, N.J.
MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (AP) The North Vietnamese Embassy said today that it had issued visas to four American women who want to visit Hanoi to see. whether United States planes are bombing civilian targets.
THE Department of State in Washington has just acquired a card table.

MIAMI, Dec. 18 (AP) Ernest Cardone, the nation's leading apprentice rider, won two races at Tropical Park today his first victories at the meeting. Cardone arrived at Tropical from Aqueduct on Wednesday and had been blanked on his first 11 mounts.

Private builders and social service organizations should play a much larger role in providing decent housing for the city's poor, according to Walter E. Washington, the new chairman of the City Housing Authority.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 16 Argentina and Brazil, the two biggest military powers in South America, have indicated interest in a regional agreement to limit "exhorbitant" arms expenditures, a high United States official said today.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 16 Edmund L. Kenyon, a retired vice president of the Manhattan Shirt Company died today in his home at 127 Lawrence Court after a short illness. He was 72 years old.

LONDON, Dec. 16 A Labor Member of Parliament, Maurice Orbach, today withdrew an amendment to the Race Relations Act of 1965 after receiving assurances from the Government that it was making surveys to determine whether new legislation against racial discrimination was needed.
TURIN, Italy, Dec. 16 (AP) -Luigi Patruno of Italy was awarded an unpopular eightround decision tonight over James Shelton of Bakersfield. Calif.
A jury of 11 men and one woman was completed yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court for the trial of State Senatorelect Eugene Rodriguez, Democratic leader in the Southeast Bronx.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 The Board of Regents will ask the 1967 Legislature for another increase in financial aid to public schools, state education officials said today.

NEW ORLEANS The old beat that was New Orleans jazz half a century ago is hard to find in this busy, thriving, changing city. It cannot be met along Bourbon Street in the French Quarter, where the night spots crudely blare their obvious attractions. But if you turn the corner onto St. Peter Street, you come to Preservation Hall.

Roosevelt Hospital's 14th annual Ball of the Roses will be held Jan. 12 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Mrs. M. Donald Grant is chairman of the event, arranged to benefit the hospital's Free Medical Care Fund.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Dec. 16 (AP) Mrs. John F. Kennedy has called off her plan to spend a Christmas-New Year's skiing holiday at this resort, a spokesman said today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 16 (AP) Attorneys for a 23-yearold former mental patient contended today they could prove he was in Washington, D.C., on the day he is accused of having killed, in Columbus, a prominent theologian and civil rights leader.
Sol Solowey, vice chairman of the board of the Ipco Hospital Supply Corporation, died Wednesday at his home, 101 West 12th Street. He was 68 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) The American Association for the Advancement of Science announced today that John Kolesar of The Trenton Evening Times, Evert Clark of The New York Times and Albert Rosenfeld of Life will each receive a $1,000 science writing award sponsored by the association and Westinghouse.
The Society of Magazine Writers awarded its sixth Richard L. Neuberger Award last night to the Saturday Review for "its courage and persistence in presenting the issue of peace."
A Federal grant of $1,241,850 was allocated yesterday to assist Sullivan County in building an airport large enough to accommodate commercial jet planes.
AUSTWELL, Tex., Dec. 16 (UPI) The loss of a whooping crane was attributed today to the birds' nesting habits, rather than the perils of their annual 2,500-mile fall flight.

Kurt Georg Kiesinger broke dramatic new ground when he formed West Germany's first "grand coalition" of Christian and Social Democrats two weeks ago. He has now signaled the beginning of a new phase for the Federal Republic in his first policy statement to the Bundestag.
The Government handed the orange juice industry a sweetener yesterday in the form of its promise to buy large amounts of frozen orange juice, starting in January.
WALDWICK, N.J., Dec. 16 Roger and Steve Hartman of Columbia University advanced to the quarter-final round of the men's indoor singles tennis championship today.

The Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive was completely reopened to traffic at 7:30 A.M. yesterday after the removal of weakened concrete that had fallen during the morning rush hour Thursday, injuring two motorists.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced the election here yesterday of Eugene H. Morrison and Maurice R. Forman as directors.
DETROIT, Dec. 16 (UPI) The American Motors Corporation, smallest of the major automobile makers, said today that proposed Government safety standards might drive it out of business.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 15 (UPI) Air Force Sgt. Herbert W. Boeckenhaupt was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiracy to spy for the Russians. Sergeant Boeckenhaupt, 24 years old, has been held in jail since his arrest at March Air Force Base, Calif., on Oct. 31.
The spot rate on the British pound dropped 11 points to $2.7901 in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

With American backing, the United Nations Security Council has taken an unprecedented step. It has voted mandatory but selective economic sanctions against Rhodesia in an effort to bring down the white rebel regime. The most that can be said for this Council action is that it was the least damaging of the courses open to a hard-pressed Britain.
PLEIKU, South Vietnam (UPI) They had a tiger hunt at D Troop of the Fifth Cavalry.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 16 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds traded Jim O'Toole, a left-handed pitcher, to the Chicago White Sox for Floyd Robinson, an outfielder, just before the midnight deadline last night on interleague baseball trades.
LONDON, Dec. 16 (UPI) Australia will be the next challenger for the Little America's Cup, the international catamaran trophy, officials said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (UPI) Wilt Chamberlain scored 22 points as the Philadelphia 76ers coasted to a 124-113 triumph over St. Louis at Convention Hall tonight. The victory was the 29th straight regular-season home triumph for Philadelphia.

California Governor Brown's suggestion to have the Democrats run Gregory Peck for Senator may have been pure pique: his way of saying that it takes an actor to beat an actor. Yet behind the hidden humor there may be a prophetic truth namely, the sleek shall inherit the earth.

Dick Tiger, crouching to conquer, became light-heavyweight champion of the world last night with a unanimous decision over Jose Torres, who seemed too busy protecting his midsection to fight.

A plan for foundation support of commercial Broadway and Off Broadway theater has been initiated by the 20th Century Fund.
THIS completely engrossing study of the Roman state from its beginnings to the death of Constantine has the Symmetry of a round arch.

DETROIT Dec. 16 (UPI)Kevin Loughery scored 35 points as the Baltimore Bullets won their fourth game of the six they have played under their new coach, Gene Shue, beating the Pistons, 121-113, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. (UPI) President Johnson sought counsel from former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and called a Vietnam strategy conference with top advisers today before flying to Texas fore Christmas.
BERRYVILLE, Va., Dec. 16 (AP) Former Senator Harry F. Byrd Sr. left an estate of about $2-million, it was disclosed today in his will filed for probate at the Clarke County Clerk's office.
Frances K. Crouch, a retired psychologist who had lived and practiced in New York City, died last Saturday in Guadalajara, Mexico of leukemia following surgery. She was 67.
ST. LOUIS Scruggs-Vander voort-Barney, Inc., is a department store here seeking to regain its luster of elegance.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 16 (UPI) This city's public health nurses rejected Mayor Thomas J. Whelan's offer today to settle their salary dispute with the city.
LONDON, Dec. 16 (UPI) Sales of Scotch whisky in Britain have fallen beneath Prime Minister Wilson's program of emergency economic measures.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 16 (UPI) A contract settlement between the Memphis Newspaper Guild and the Memphis Publishing Company, publisher of The Commercial Appeal and The Press-Scimitar, was reached early today, 15 minutes before a scheduled walkout.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 A spirited two-year search for a site for the world's largest atom smasher ended today with the choice of Weston, Ill., a tiny village near Chicago.

Robert Edward Lee, a partner in the law firm of Hawkins, Delafield Wood, which he joined in 1920, died Wednesday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 73 years old and lived at 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.
A group of New York University students asked yesterday for a commission of faculty, students and administration representatives that would have a veto power over the university's board of trustees.

Woodrow Chan, 57 years old, of 133-54 Avery Avenue, Flushing, Queens, pleaded guilty to attempted forgery yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court. He had been charged with having collected $18,400 in unemploy ment claims through the use of 13 ficticious names.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation is malting a bid to enter the electronic quotations systems business through the proposed acquisition for $16-million of the Ultronic Systems Corporation.

Channel 6, a closed-circuit television station that provides 35 New York hotels with news and information about entertainment and dining, was unable to transmit programs for about eight hours on Thursday because its coaxial cable had been cut, apparently intentionally.

Hart Schaffner Marx, one of the nation's leading manufacturers and retailers of men's wear, had earnings after taxes of about $10 million, or about $2.40 a share, in the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, against $8,124,000, or $1.95 a share, the year before, John D. Gray, president, estimated yesterday following a director's meeting in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Attorneys for a citizens' group asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its 5-to-4 decision that the Georgia legislature may pick the state's next Governor.

THE management of Loew's Theatres, which has shown an affinity for the company's own stock for some time, has been buying the stock heavily again.

CLEVELAND. Dec. 16 (AP) -The captain of a Great Lakes freighter, which was blown aground in the Lake 'Huron storm that sank the ore carrier Daniel J. Morrell on Nov. 29, said today that the storm was not unusual for the time of year.

Hundreds of parents, teachers, civic leaders and children appeared before the City Planning Commission at City Hall yesterday to make impassioned pleas for schools they fear will not be included in the 1967-68 capital budget.

Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 18 per cent in production for the week ended Dec. 10, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.

BOURGES, France, Dec. 15 In the Beauregard Psychiatric Hospital here Tuesday night, there were screams, groans, retching, ranting and stretches of nearly rational speech. Pale figures pranced under wild spotlights, leaped out of a window and set off a smokebomb in a crowded room.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The index of primary market prices was unchanged at 105.8 during the week ended Dec. 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products declined in price while processed foods advanced. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

New York is preparing its first full-scale preservation project a downtown museum development known as the Fraunces Tavern block. A request of $375,000 in the 1967-68 capital budget will be taken up at a hearing of the City Planning Commission on Monday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 18-- Mrs. Cynthia Burke-Roche Cary, prominent in Newport society and the widow of Guy Fairfax Cary, a New York lawyer and banker, died today in her home, Elm Court. Her age was 82.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--Republican leaders have decided not to press for greater party representation on the House Rules Committee. They will concentrate instead on winning satisfactorily large increases in the Republican membership of all other House committees, trustworthy party sources said today.
Bar-Ilan University, Israel's only American-chartered institution of higher learning, will start an 8-year, $20-million program to double its student body. It now has about 3,000 students.
