DORTMUND, Germany, Dec. 19 (Reuters)--A court here today dropped proceedings against a former SS (Elite Guard) captain, Herbert Haertla, 74 years old, who was charged with the wartime killing of at least 17,700 Jews.

William F. Rockwell Jr., president of the RockwellStandard Corporation, complained yesterday that "unskillful" selling on the part of three mutual funds had needlessly knocked down the price of his company's stock.

A committee of major airlines that 14 months ago questioned the urgency of the need for a fourth jetport in the New York area switched its stand yesterday and asked for prompt construction of a new field.
John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, announced yesterday that members of his union had ratified the new agreement with the city reached last week.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 19 (UPI) --Silwall, a 3-5 favorite, took the lead shortly after the start of the $11,000 feature race at Laurel today and swept to a 1 -length victory in the sixfurlong sprint.

ATLANTA, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Capt. Pres Judy, who made his first appearance of the season, scored 23 points tonight and led Georgia Tech to a 93-75 conquest of Brown. Judy was scholastically ineligible during the first quarter of the school year.
Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, called yesterday on the Big Board membership to develop "constructive ideas" on the pressing industry problem of commission structure.
SAM STAYMAN of New York scored a very rare double during the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Tournament, which ended Sunday.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy took President de Gaulle of France aside just after the funeral of President Kennedy and told him of the ideals and hopes for Franco-American relations that her husband had held, according to a source who has read the manuscript of William Man chester's "The Death of a President."
On a warm spring night in 1965, Stephanie Sills sat in a Spanish reastaurant in Greenwich Village, her hands on the table, her mind on the theater, her unemployment insurance check in her pocketbook.
TRENTON, Dec. 19--The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that insurance companies could no longer include loopholes in the fine print at the end of their policies.
The internationally known Elizabeth Arden collection of custom-made clothes for women is being discontinued at the end of this year after more than two decades.

ARMONK, N.Y., Dec. 19-- The engagement of Miss Carolyn Cole Trenbath to Henry E. Marx has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Stockton Trenbath, parents of the future bride. Mr. Marx is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Marx of Byram, Conn.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20 (AP)--B-52 bombers hammered the demilitarized zone before dawn today in the sixth raid in three days aimed at smashing a suspected build-up by North Vietnamese forces.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP)-- The Observer said the traffic in steel reached a peak earlier this year "when only Peking could plug a crucial gap in American supplies by meeting the specifications, the quantities and the six-week delivery date that alone would satisfy hardpressed U.S. military purchasing officers."
Most stocks on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday in moderate trading.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- The Republican National Committee will give G.O.P. governors more than $100,000 next year to finance a full-time national office here, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- The Government announced today a resumption of sales of "participation certificates" in Government loans by the Federal National Mortgage Association.
OMAHA--On the Saturday after Thanksgiving, 2,700 children boarded four "Santa Trains" at the railroad station here. It was the first railroad trip for many of them.
The London Stock Exchange was firm yesterday in slow preholiday trading. Hopes that a bank-rate reduction might be forthcoming helped buoy sentiment.
The legal dispute over "The Death of a President" reads so far like the first half of a law school examination question in Contracts I.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 19--Mr. and Mrs. Cary Ingram Crockett Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Herndon Crockett, to Edward Throckmorton McLean Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McLean of West Grove, Pa.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Dr. Joseph J. Romoda of Canton, vice president and dean of St. Lawrence University, died today at Syracuse Memorial Hospital. He was 59 years old.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- The striking International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers will meet tomorrow at noon on a proposed contract with the Raytheon Company.

Jim Nance, Boston's recordbreaking fullback, unanimously was voted to the American Football League all-star team yesterday, while Kansas City's Western Division champions placed nine men on the squad selected for The Associated Press.

VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., Dec. 19--Joseph W. Kennedy, who retired in January, 1965, as president of the People's Bank of Rockland County, died yesterday of a heart attack while attending mass at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Congers. He was 72 years old.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 19--President Johnson invoked the TaftHartley Act today to try to end a strike of steelworkers that, the White House says, is hampering the flow of vital aircraft components to Vietnam.
LONDON, Dec. 19--The longdebated bill to reform and liberalize Britain's law on homosexual conduct was accepted by the House of Commons tonight without a dissenting vote.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 19--The Johnson Administration expects the rest of the world to match its shipments of wheat to India with either grain or money, Orville L. Freeman, the Secretary of Agriculture, said here today.
CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 19-- The Peking radio has hailed student agitators at Calcutta University as path blazers in India's "cultural revolution."
BRUSSELS, Dec. 19--The boys, some wearing short pants, arrive at the flat expanse of lawn in the shadow of the Atomium, lay their bicycles down and begin kicking a soccer ball.

HONG KONG, Dec. 19-- North Vietnam has reaffirmed its determination to "carry out a protracted war of resistance" against the United States and to continue the fight until "complete victory," the North Vietnam press agency reported today.
A leading authority on the composition of the earth's rocks believes they have a story to tell about the origin of life that contradicts current theories on the subject.
Steel production, which has moved up and down erratically from week to week recently, increased 2 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Ninety-one young women were presented at the 31st annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The event, largest of the mass presentation parties here, always benefits the New York Infirmary.
The smoker who is physically inactive is three times more likely to suffer a heart attack than the smoker who is moderately active, a study reported yesterday indicates.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Philip Kitzer Sr., 69 years old, one of 17 persons under indictment in Minneapolis, filed a $3million libel suit against Reader's Digest magazine today.

The American premier of Luciano Berio's opera, "Passagio" will take place at the Juillard Concert Hall at 8:30 P.M. on Jan. 9. It will appear on a double bill with a new production of Monteverdi's "Il Combattimento di Tancredi a Clorinda."
Communist party Secretary General Brezhnev's sixtieth birthday was certainly celebrated in style in Moscow--on television, in the newspapers, and even in the Supreme Soviet.

HARRISON, N.Y., Dec. 19-- Victor M. Earle, who retired four years ago as chairman of the board of Hanfield, Callen; Ruland Benjamin, Inc., a New York real estate concern, died last night in his home on Pleasant Ridge Road. He was 86 years old.

MANILA, Dec. 19--The Asian Development Bank was officially inaugurated here this afternoon with the cutting of a ceremonial ribbon by Mrs. Imelda Marcos, the wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- The United States moved quickly today to try to squelch any false hopes for peace in Vietnam raised the letter to Secretary General Thant.

ROME, Dec. 19--Two American leaders of B'nai B'rith discussed with Pope Paul VI today the implementation of the declarations on religious liberty and non-Christian religions made by the Ecumenical Council, Vatican II.
Drexel Harriman Ripley, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Clay J. Anderson Jr., and Clifford L. Fitzgerald Jr. as directors of the securities research-oriented investment banking concern.

Jasper C. Brown, a former insurance salesman here, died Saturday in Venice, Fla. Mr. Brown, who had represented the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark, retired to Venice 12 years ago. He was 78 years old.

The president of the Board of Education abruptly halted a raucous hearing on the school budget yesterday, and angry Harlem residents promptly elected what they called replacements for the regular board members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- There is increasing evidence that the hard-line faction of Chairman Mao Tse-tung is in the minority at the upper levels of the Chinese Communist party, some specialists on China have reported.

The form, the timing, the aims and the conditions surrounding Ambassador Goldberg's letter to Secretary General Thant of the United Nations on a ceasefire in Vietnam give the move some importance. This is true even though, in substance, no new or changed policy on the part of the United States was involved.
John A. Straley Jr., who reminded Wall Street to laugh occasionally, through his writings in The Investment Dealers Digest and The Bawl Street Journal, died yesterday of cancer. He was 70 years old.
The nation's railroad executives are split over the question of whether their industry should seek early next year the first general freight rate increase since October, 1960.
The Union Carbide Corporation's electronics division announced yesterday it had raised on Dec. 5 its prices on certain solid tantalum capacitors by an average of 17 per cent.
EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 19 (UPI)--Texas Western used its superior height and shooting to defeat Wichita State, 77-60, tonight for its seventh victory against one loss.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)-- --Chicago handled more foreign trade in 1966 than any other Great Lakes port, Capt. John J. Manley, Port of Chicago director, said today. He said total tonnage through September was 1,840,949, an increase of almost 400,000 over last year.

THERE is a fascinating story told by H. Warner Allen in his long revered work, "The Wines of France." It concerns his days as a student at Oxford and his first encounter with that greatest of all Bordeaux wines, Chateau Lafite-Rothschild.
The managing director of the International Monetary Fund criticized the industrial countries yesterday for relying almost exclusively on tight money to check inflation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- The antipoverty organization here is planning to test the effectiveness of birth control information and materials among teen-age girls whose family background indicates that, left alone, they would probably bear illegitimate children.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19--The General Assembly rebuffed the United States, Canada and others today by agreeing to a Soviet demand that it put off until April action on the financing of future peace-keeping operations.

CYPRESS GARDENS, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP)--Joe Powroznik of Richmond, Joker Osborn of Cypress Gardens and Barbara Clack of Lakeland captured over-all honors yesterday in the All-American water-ski championships on Lake Eloise.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19--The issue of Communist China's membership in the United Nations was revived today when the Credentials Committee presented its report to the General Assembly.

HIGHLAND, N.Y., Dec. 16 --State highway engineers have given an emphatic "no" to historians, architects, schoolchildren and Hudson Valley officials who want to preserve on its present site the historic Halfway House, a former tavern for stagecoach stops here halfway between New York and Albany.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 19--Some of the iron and steel imported from Communist China into Singapore is being sold quietly to South Vietnam for American use. Sales to South Vietnam are camouflaged and lumped together with Chinese products made here.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 19 --C. Berkley Cooke Jr., who retired two years ago as president and director of the First Reinvesting Plan, Inc., investment advisers, of New York, died here on Saturday of a heart attack. His age was 70.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday in Wilmington, Del., the election of Irenee du Pont Jr. as a vice president and excecutive committee member.
The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday total operating revenues of $390,975,269 for the 12 months ended Nov. 30.

Boston University's undefeated hockey team continued to tie and set scoring records as it easily beat Minnesota, 8-5, in the semi-final round of the sixth annual Eastern College Athletic Conference invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.
A harness racing driver and three owners were named yesterday in an indictment charging the driver with bribery, perjury and conspiracy to fix a race at Monticello, N.Y., last August.
The Martin-Marietta Corporation confirmed yesterday that it was studying the possibility of a merger with the beleagured Douglas Aircraft Company.
GRENOBLE, France, Dec. 19 --This headquarters city for the 1968 winter Olympics is worried about the morning after.
New York City lost about $20-million in cigarette tax revenue in the fiscal year that ended June 30, mostly because of large-scale cigarette smuggling.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP)--Taxes and outstanding debts have reduced the nearly $2-million estate of the late Ernie Kovacs to $16,184, his widow, Edie Adams, said in Superior Court today.
Queens College defeated Oswego State, 62-51, at Fitzgerald Gymnasium in Flushing last night. Charlie Rosenberg was top man for Queens with 16 points and Greg Wilson led the losers with 23 points.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) --The National Education Association, the country's largest teacher organization, announced today a legislative program emphasizing tax deductions for teachers.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UPI)-- Mrs. Marion McDougal Thorne, widow of an heir to the Montgomery Ward mail-order fortune, died today at the age of 70.
The City Planning Commission has cut the capital budget requests of the Transit Authority from $220-million to $74million, it became known during budget hearings at City Hall yesterday.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Dec. 19--Miss Robin Hart Wood and David Carl Bertsche plan to marry in June.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- The year 1966 has been a better year than we had any right to expect. President de Gaulle did not demand that we give back the Statue of Liberty, medical science did not discover that shaving may be a contributing factor in coronary thrombosis, and even in London young men did not start wearing skirts in public.
PARIS, Dec. 19 (UPI)--Canada, the Netherlands, Turkey and Greece were named today as the first of the rotating members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's new nuclear planning group.
LONDON, Dec. 19--The first conviction under a 1965 law against stirring up racial hatred was upset on appeal today.

The United Federation of Teachers announced yesterday that it would refuse to negotiate with the Board of Education until the Superintendent of Schools agreed to discuss reduction of teaching hours, diminution of class size and "all appropriate matters."
Emily Lowe, an artist who with her husband donated art buildings to three universities, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 785 Park Avenue.
Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. charged yesterday that the Sanitation Department was "the most politically dominated department" in the city administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- Administration officials said today that the United States planned to raise at the Geneva disarmament conference the question of a United StatesSoviet moratorium on the deployment of ballistic missile defense systems.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy said last night that neither the publisher of "The Death of a President" nor Look magazine had allowed representatives of the Kennedy family to see the versions of the works they now plan to publish until after a lawsuit was filed last Friday.

Many race tracks can lay claim to more important stakes and more expensive purse schedules, but only Georgetown can boast that a number of its nightly patrons must make an ocean voyage to see harness racing. The new track is near Georgetown in Southern Delaware about 15 miles from the Lewes terminus of the Cape May-Lewes Ferry.
World sugar futures reaped a harvest of new lows in trading yesterday, mostly because of the continued bearish feeling in the London market.
Ther's a lot of heart over there on the Avenue that doesn't show on the chic, sophisticated surface, and all it takes is a little thing like Christmas to make it visible.

Plans for the construction of the world's largest single shipbuilding facility, a dockyard a half a mile long and capable of being used for the construction of 500,000-ton vessels, was announced here yesterday by Nippon Kokan K.K.
The City Commission on Human Rights charged yesterday that the city's retail merchants discriminated against Negro employes.

City Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that he hoped to complete a preliminary report on "every phase" of the city's hospital system this week and indicated it would back up his previous charge that "some equipment has been stolen."
Emotion threatens to get in the way of action on measures to overcome the grave deficiencies that have accumulated over the years in the municipal hospital system.
The State Insurance Department has revoked the licenses of a Manhattan insurance agent and a Long Island insurance agent and broker for failing to remit premium collections, among other charges.

The stock market mostly declined yesterday for the third consecutive session, despite a recovery movement in the afternoon that erased some of the early losses. Volume was relatively light, indicating no urgent selling pressure.
The Pittsburgh Playhouse, faced recently with the possibility of extinction for lack of operating funds, is continuing for at least this season.
The spot rate on the British pound dropped 3 points, to $2.7898, in very quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)--In a numbing wind outside the Pentagon, 1st Lieut. Walter J. Marm Jr. of the Army received today the military prize of a lifetime --the nation's Medal of Honor --for action in Vietnam.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19--The United States asked Secretary General Thant today to take whatever steps he considered necessary to bring about talks for a cease-fire in Vietnam.

In a major bankruptcy move in the discount-store field, Miracle Mart, Inc., operator of 30 discount department stores in the East and Middle West, filed a petition yesterday for a Chtpter XI arrangement under the Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

Is there a "masculine mystique"? Mr. Lipsyte says he has found one and tells us about it in a robust inside joke that will appeal to a sorely beset segment of American society: men who have wives or girl ...
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 19-- Thirteen men, the entire crew of the Greek freighter Sinergasia died this morning when the ship was wrecked at Holmoen off the Swedish port of Umea in the Gulf of Bothnia.

District Attorney Nat H. Hentel of Queens was accused in open court yesterday of having caused the arrest of 13 reputed leaders of the Mafia last Sept. 22 to obtain publicity in his unsuccessful campaign for election.
IRVINGTON, N.J., Dec. 19 (AP)--A 27-year-old man was killed early today, apparently run over by his own car.

THERE was virtually nothing in the last dreary season that the New York Giants will want to remember in the years to come. But future historians are likely to find fascination in the two-footed attempt for a field goal by Pete Gogolak against Dallas on Sunday, a play so freakish that not even the oldest inhabitant could remember anything approximating it.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19-- Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Boehm have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deena Louise Boehm, to Gregory Weimer Dickerson. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Albert I. Dickerson of Norwich, Vt.

ROME, Dec. 19 (AP)--The International Equestrian Federation has decided to hold the three-day equestrian event of the 1968 Mexico Olympics outside of Mexico City because of the possible effects of the high altitude on the horses.
Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, will present a $100,000 check for Italian flood victims to the consul general of Italy here today.

LINDEN, N.J., Dec. 19-- Dr. William E. Doherty of 42 Gesner Street, a practicing physician here for 21 years and a former member of the Board of Education, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home. He was 52 years old.
Mayor Lindsay received a "C" rating yesterday on a "report card" for his accomplishments during the first year of his four-year term. The mark was given by Councilman Robert A. Low.
BONN, Dec. 19--Foreign Minister Willy Brandt said today that he favored a "step-bystep and carefully weighed" reduction of military forces and nuclear armaments in Europe.
The City Council hired professional help yesterday to help dissect Mayor Lindsay's massive governmental reorganization plan.
ALTHOUGH he is not given to blustering, or even raising his voice, members of the Board of Higher Education have found their chairman, Porter Ralph Chandler, to be a man of strong convictions.
ATLANTA, Dec. 19--A citizens' lawsuit was filed in a state court here today asking for a run-off election in the Georgia governor's race instead of letting the Legislature choose the next Governor.
The gross overweight of economic power possessed by the building trades unions is being demonstrated with crushing force in the five-month-old strike of Manhattan and Bronx plumbers.
THERE is still hope for Christmas shoppers who have put off until the last week finding gifts for friends or relatives who already have everything.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 19 (UPI)--Sixty-one damage cases demanding a total of $29-million for the deaths of 81 persons in an air crash at Lake Tahoe two years ago were settled today for $4-million in Alameda County Superior Court.

Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to The New York Times. Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036 or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--A Government spokesman said today he was "highly skeptical" of reports that the United States bought steel made in China, but he avoided making a direct denial.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19--A blazing eight-minute machine-gun battle at pointblank range between four United States river patrol boats and a Vietcong company was reported today by a military spokesman.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 19 (AP)--The Fifth Asian Games went through the final full day of competition today, with Japan partially beating back a South Korean challenge to its table tennis supremacy and Israel taking the basketball title in a turbulent game.
The New York Association of Consulting Engineers has elected Donald A. Ostrower, a professional engineer, as president.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Auto makers planned limited production this week as the holidays neared.

BONN, Dec. 19--During the recent state election campaign in Bavaria a clean-cut young man wearing the uniform of a captain in the West German Army stood up at a rally of the National Democratic party and declared, "The manifesto of the N.P.D. is written on my soul."

While a massive metal ball bashed down brick remnants of the old New York Tribune building yesterday, Vice President Humphrey helped break ground across the street for a $12-million college complex that will rise where the old structure stood.

Although blind, Herman G., 43, worked for years as a photographic technician. His wife Mary, 40, who was partly blind, had been trained as a door-to-door saleswoman. Together they supported themselves and their daughter Jennifer, now 16 and an honor student.

PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Dec. 19--The marriage of Miss Gaylen Stevens Hicks, daughter of Mrs. H. Grant Theis of Los Angeles, and Frederick S. Hicks of Alexandria, Va., to Dennis Baker Bent of Brookline, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard O. Bent of Northwest, Wash., took place here this afternoon.

Sharply higher results in the fourth fiscal quarter raised earnings of Deere Co. to a new record for the fourth consecutive year with sales exceeding a billion dollars for the first time, the big farm machinery and industrial equipment maker reported yesterday.

LAUREL, Miss., Dec. 19 (UPI)--Lieut. Gov. Carroll Gartin, who said there was no place in Mississippi for "black power or white bullying" died today several hours after being taken to a hospital complaining of chest pains. He was 53 years old.
State Senator-elect Eugene Rodriguez, on trial in State Supreme Court, was quoted yesterday as having suggested that he could "fix" a narcotics case with certain judges.
MEMPHIS, Dec. 19 (AP )-- The Chicago Bulls won their fourth straight National Basketball Association game tonight, beating the St. Louis Hawks. 102-97, before a crowd of 7,531.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- James Tobin, the distinguished professor of economics at Yale, has provided a succinct indictment of the approach to public welfare that emerged from the New Deal of thirty years ago and has since grown to such massive proportions.
The United States Savings and Loan League estimated yesterday that the nation's 6,200 savings and loan associations had a net inflow of $640-million in savings accounts in November.

ORADELL, N.J., Dec. 19.-- George R. Cory, of Park Ridge, assistant news editor of The Record in Hackensack, died early yesterday in an automobile accident on Kinderkamack Road here. He died on his 55th birthday.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday reported that bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in November rose $98-million to $3,457,000,000. The increase followed a decline of $28-million in the precding two months.
IT'S a market of stocks, not a stock market, goes the Wall Street cliche, an observation that was amply borne out in yesterday's performance of EG, Inc.
DENVER, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Lou Saban formally signed a 10-year contract today as the head coach and general manager of the Denver Broncos of the American Football League.

MADRID, Dec, 19--The big Madrid Province metalworkers union today suspended its plans for a two-hour strike to protest recent layoffs in this area as the Spanish Government moved to investigate the complaints.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- Federal District Judge Oliver Gasch refused today to dismiss the nine-count indictment against Robert G. Baker.
What happens when professional baseball's Willie Mays of the Giants meets professional football's Johnny Unitas of the Baltimore Colts on a golf course?

Increased funds from city taxes and Federal and state grants may permit the city to beat its own five-year target date in a fight against air pollution, Commissioner Austin N. Heller of the Department of Air Pollution Control said yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19--Following is the text of a letter today from Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg to Secretary General Thant on a truce in Vietnam:

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UPI)-- The Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League obtained Howie Young, a defenseman, today in a three-way deal with the Chicago Black Hawks and the Los Angeles Blades of the Western Hockey League.

The bond market, which showed remarkable strength last week, took in stride Government's formal announcement yesterday of plans to sell $1.1-billion of participation certificates, and most prices continued to rise.

Mrs. Charlotte Faith Messenheimer of Villefranche, France and Lewis Cotlow, explorer and author of 480 Park Avenue, were married Sunday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Howeth T. Ford, 7 Gracie Square. Judge Evelyn Richman of the Criminal Court performed the ceremony.
DETROIT, Dec. 19--General Motors recalled more than 16,000 new Pontiacs today to be checked for a possible defect that might cause the steering column to snap in two.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J. Dec. 19 (UPI)--A former mental patient and a truck-loader are being held pending arraignment tomorrow in the murder of an 18-month-old boy and the torture of his 3-year-old brother.

A probation officer of the Welfare Department assigned to the Bronx Family Court was arrested yesterday morning on a charge of attempted bribery in allegedly seeking $100 from a man under his supervision, according to Assistant District Attorney Seymour Rotker.

The election of J. Robert Baylis as president and chief operating officer was announced yesterday by the Consolidated Cigar Corporation, producer of Dutch Masters, El Producto, Muriel and Harvester cigars.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 19 (UPI)--A Bogota court today restored the political rights of Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, the deposed dictator, reversing a Senate action of 1959.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 20-- Japan failed today for the second time to orbit a space carrying satellite experiment.
BUFFALO, Dec. 19 (AP)-- The American Steamship Company of Buffalo, operator of Great Lakes freighters, and the Oswego Steamship Corporation of New York City plan to merge.
The Christmas office party-- that delight of cartoonists and bane of personnel managers-- is beating a sober retreat from New York this season.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Top-seeded Larry Terrell of the Harvard freshman team won the annual United States junior squash racquets championship by defeating Sandy McAdoo of Penn Charter School, 15-10, 157, 15-7, at Episcopal Academy today.
HOBE SOUND, Fla., Dec. 19 --Adm. Sir Charles Gordon Ramsey, a retired officer of the British Royal Navy, died in his home here today. His age was 84.

The State Supreme Court was asked yesterday to strike out as highly "prejudicial" and "scandalous" portions of the complaint in which Ralph Nader, automobile safety crusader, seeks $26-million damages from the General Motors Corporation and other defendants.
Continued growth for the national economy is forecast by 15 leading executives, representing a cross-section of opinion among leaders of the business community here.

Huntley and Brinkley had better look to their laurels. Channel 13, New York's enterprising educational outlet, has entered the lists for journalistic honors. At 9 P.M. on Dec. 29, the little station with the big ideas will present its own yearend review of the major news stories and cultural events of 1666.
Stocks mostly declined in more active trading; volume, 7,340,000 shares Corporate bonds steady; transactions, $13,060,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- One of the most consistently reliable of all the advance indicators of economic trends--new orders received by manufacturers of durable goods--declined in November for the second consecutive month.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19--A report that Chinese-made steel has been used to build military bases for use against North Vietnam could bolster Soviet accusations that the Peking regime's stand on Vietnam is helping the "imperialists," observers said today.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Dec. 19--Mrs. John Clinton Smack has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Smack, to Ens. Ronald Edward Yates, U.S.N.R. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Yates of West Greenwich, R.I.A spring wedding is planned.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19--Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party's General Secretary, received a standing ovation in the Supreme Soviet (parliament) today, on his 60th birthday, after a day of honors and high tributes in the press.

LOUIS AUCHINCLOSS, adding the status of a pro duced playwright to his other pursuits as lawyer, author and president of the Museum of the City of New York, fashioned a vignette on expiring gentility in his short play "The Club Bedroom," which was seen last night on "New York Television Theater" over Channel 13.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) --Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien said today that the Post Office was handling half a billion pieces of mail a day in the current Christmas rush without any serious delays.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)--State tax collections increased by one-eighth in the last year and have almost doubled in six years, a Congressional commission reported tonight.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19--The murder trial of Richard F. Speck, accused slayer of eight student nurses here last July, was transferred today to Peoria, 150 miles southwest of Chicago.

LONDON, Dec. 19--Foreign Secretary George Brown told the House of Commons today that allegations of cruelty to prisoners in the British colony of Aden actually amounted to charges against three interrogators and that inquiry into these charges would be "pursued to a conclusion," including possible courts-martial.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)--Surgical stitches were removed today from former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, one week after removal of his gall bladder.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19--As each Georgetown starter was introduced before tonight's basketball game, Rutgers students shouted: "Who's he?"

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19--A treaty to outlaw all nonpeaceful activities in space was approved unanimously today by the General Assembly. The action paralleled that of the Political Committee, which approved the text on Saturday.
The Maritime Administration has determined that surface effect ships are eligible for Federal ship mortgage insurance.
BARI, Italy, Dec. 19 (AP)-- An Italian movie producer and 23 owners of film houses were indicted tonight on obscenity charges involving the French film, "La Curee," directed by Roger Vadim.
HAVANA, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Strictly rationed pork, black beans, wine, fruit, nuts and candy went on sale today for the Cuban holiday season.
A gift of $51 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund arrived yesterday from a sixth-grade class at the Henry Barnard School in New Rochelle, N.Y. A note from the class told the story:

THE woman with a clutch of party invitations this season may find that popularity is expensive. Lacking a well-padded bank account or a fairy godmother to wave up a lot of finery, today's Cinderella might check the lower-priced departments of stores for an evening wardrobe.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind. Dec. 19 (UPI)--A gasoline truck flipped over on a busy street today and spewed flaming gasoline over three automobiles as they crashed into the wreckage. Flames shot 50 feet in the air.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 19 (AP)--State Attorney General Bronson C. La Follette said today he would ask the United States Supreme Court to reconsider its refusal to review a state court ruling that baseball was exempt from antitrust law.

Dear Santa Claus: Are you a pregnant woman? Are you a benevolent father figure? Are you the opium of little children? Or are you just a nice, jolly fat man?

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 19 (UPI)--Prime Minister Harold Holt rejected today a proposal that the Rhodesian Government apparently hoped could lead to further talks on its independence crisis with Britain.
The New York State Athletic Commission turned down a challenge yesterday from Roger Rouse to meet the titleholder, Dick Tiger, for the light-heavyweight championship.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 19 (Reuters)--More than 400 pilots of Qantas, Australia's international airline, voted today to continue their three-weekold strike despite reports that the Government may impose penalties on them, informed sources said.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 19 (UPI)--A United States Embassy spokesman said today that the number of American Peace Corps field workers was being reduced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- Enough nursing care beds will be available for Medicare patients when the second half of the program goes into effect on Jan. 1, Robert M. Ball, Commissioner of Social Security, said today.
TRENTON, Dec. 19--Twelve young women will make their debuts Wednesday at the Trenton Debutante Cotillion in the Trenton Country Club.
OTTAWA, Dec. 19--The Government tonight proposed raising old-age-security taxes to meet increased pension payments.

Harper Row, Publishers, Inc., defended yesterday its decision to publish "The Death of a President," and said that the people had a "right to know the facts of the awesome tragedy" --the assassination of President Kennedy.

"Lohengrin" was sung with special intensity and lift last night at the Metropolitan Opera. Karl Bohm, who conducted, made the orchestra a concentrated, supple protagonist, along with the singers. Pacing was powerful, sounds were rich and details served the drama with sureness.
LENINGRAD, Dec. 19 (AP) --Two Americans pleaded guilty today to Soviet charges of currency violations and both expressed regrets for what one called "foolish acts."
St. John's added distinction to its undefeated basketball record by crushing highly regarded Kansas, 68-44, before a crowd of 4,811 at Alumni Hall last night.

The McCrory Corporation will seek to reacquire one million shares of its common stock, or about 20 per cent of its outstanding shares, through a proposed recapitalization tender offer, Meshulam Riklis, chairman, announced yesterday, fol lowing a director's meeting.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Dec. 20 (AP)--Students smashed windows of the United States consulate here today, invaded the reading room and sacked it in a demonstration against American involvement in Vietnam.

In the low ceilinged, woodpaneled upstairs room at Toots Shor's restaurant, Bill Jennings, the general chairman of the 1967 Westchester Classic golf tournament, was saying yesterday that he was "hopeful that the first prize will be $50,000." Sitting nearby, Dave Marr, the 1965 Professional Golfers' Association champion, whistled softly.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 20-- Twenty-three Negroes walked out of a public meeting of the school board tonight while a school chorus sang carols under the direction of a teacher who allegedly made a remark derogatory to Negroes last week.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 20-- The defending Ivy League hockey champion, Cornell, defeated Harvard tonight, 4-3, for the Big Red's ninth straight victory this season and second in the Ivy League.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 20 (UPI)--Sam Jones made a basket and a free throw with 1:20 left in overtime tonight to give the Boston Celtics a 116-113 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons.
Assemblyman Stanley Steingut called the city's Children's Center at 104th Street and Fifth Avenue a "house of despair" yesterday.

John P. Kremenezky, Inc., was co-broker with Joseph O'Gara Co. and Ralph Roberts in the 60-year lease of the property at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and 50th Street, which is owned by the Second Corporate Development Company and leased by Edward Schwartz.

An electronics expert who was arrested last Thursday on charges of illegal eavesdropping asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to force District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to return hundreds of items allegedly seized in raids on his upstate home.

Top leaders of the International Typographical Union and the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union reported yesterday that they had made "substantial progress" in discussions about the eventual merger of the two organizations.
A feeling that his contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund might be insufficient has spurred a donor to repeat his $100 gift.
Stock prices lost ground slightly yesterday. It was the fourth consecutive decline on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading continued on the quiet side.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- Seventeen members of the House of Representatives called on President Johnson yesterday to use the Christmas truce in Vietnam to pursue peace there.
At Lincoln Center tonight: "Lucia, di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera, 8; An Evening of Indian Ragas, with Ravi Shankar and Alla Rakha, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) --Dan Mohr, a 6-foot-7-inch center, poured in 5 points in overtime tonight to lead The Citadel to a 74-71 victory over Columbia for third place in the Tampa Invitation basketball tournament.

Miss Benita Marta Braggiotti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sebastian Herbert Braggiotti of Ogunquit, Me., was married yesterday afternoon to Dean Ronald Carey, son of Mrs. Mark T. Carey of Des Moines, Iowa, and the late Mr. Carey.
Long Island University's basketball team overpowered Oswego State, 80-35, last night on the winner's court. Luther Green led the Blackbirds with 19 points.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Massachusetts scored 15 points at the free-throw line in the final three minutes to defeat Manhattan, 86-76, tonight in the opening game of the Christmas basketball tournament at the Boston Garden.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 20 (AP) --"Several Governors" will confer with President Johnson at the LBJ Ranch tomorrow, the Texas White House announced tonight.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 20 --A mighty nuclear blast deep beneath a desert mesa-called the most powerful ever touched off in the United States--caused the earth to shudder over much of Nevada today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 20 (Reuters)--The wife and daughter of a former Indonesian Communist leader, D.N. Aidit, have been captured here, an army newspaper said today. Her husband is believed to have been shot to death in Central Java after a Communist-led coup attempt failed a year ago.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell is resorting to the same kind of evasion he has used so long and successfully in the courts to keep a House subcom-- -- mittee from investigating his official spending. He brands the inquiry a "conspiratorial tarnishment" of his name, and one which must be militantly fought.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company plans to start the new year with a new look.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- The 5 million-member Maritime Trades Department of the labor movement received assurances today of support by Republicans in the next Congress for important merchant marine measures.

Mrs. Dorothy Steele McCrea, a partner in the law firm of Delafield, Hope, Linker Blanc, 342 Madison Avenue, died here of a heart attack Sunday. She was 62 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street. Her husband, James A. McCrea Jr., a consulting oil geologist, died in 1948.

BACK in 1938, an editor of Life magazine told Gerard Piel, then only one year out of Harvard College, where he majored in history and graduated magna cum laude, that he was a "certified illiterate in science." Believing that quality all important, the editor made Mr. Piel science editor of the magazine, a Job he held for six years.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20 (UPI)-- Bill White, the first baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, underwent surgery today for a torn Achilles tendon in his right ankle.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP)--The San Francisco Warriors, the Western Division leader of the National Basketball Association, received bad news today. Their ace forward, Rick Barry, leading scorer of the N.B.A., will be out of the line-up a week to 10 days with an ankle injury.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 20 (AP)--Ron Clarke of Australia, with no one close to him over the last three miles, ran the second fastest six miles ever today with a clocking of 26 minutes 52 seconds.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 20 (UPI) --Western Kentucky won the Ohio Valley Conference tournament for the second year in a row tonight by drubbing East Tennessee, 72-59. It was the Toppers' seventh basketball victory against one defeat.
HONG KONG, Dec. 20-- Communist China urged North Vietnam and the Vietcong today to reject attempts to draw them into negotiations with the United States.
A Sunday afternoon children's film festival, including motion pictures made in Japan, the Soviet Union, Poland and France, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System beginning Feb. 5.

Handel's organ concertos have not fared well in American concert halls. One by one they turn up in an orchestral concert, usually as a curtain raiser for the program, usually played on cumbersome-sounding Victorian organs against a heavy symphonic ensemble.
The London Stock Exchange closed marginally higher yesterday after a day of quiet trading and small turnover. Prices were firm although some of the early advances were trimmed at the close.

DANVILLE, Va., Dec. 20 (AP)--A former Danville pastor was fined $50 and given a 30-day jail sentence in Corporation Court today for violating a court order of 1963 aimed at stifling racial demonstrations.

Boston University added to its record-breaking performance and continued undefeated against college competition this season as it swept to the championship of the Eastern College Athletic Conference invitation hockey tournament by beating Clarkson, 3-2, last night at Madison Square Garden.
A ball arranged after the premiere of "The Sand Pebbles" at the Rivoli Theater as a tribute to Korea was held last night at the New York Hilton.

The ceremony was performed in St. Mary's of the Hill Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Martin of the Carmelite Monastery.

On Sunday the minister of the Siloam Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn preached a sermon telling how the Magi were able to hear the footsteps of God on the roof of the world because they had been listening, had been ready to hear it.

PARIS, Dec. 20--The noncommunist left and the Communist party agreed early today to fight Gaullism together in next spring's parliamentary elections.

About 130 persons have responded to the call by Edward I. Koch, Councilman-elect from Manhattan, for legislative aides to assist him with his duties on the City Council.

Louis Emilio Gomez Ruiz, a banker and former Foreign Affairs Minister of Venezuela, died Monday in Caracas. His age was 55.

Miss Lesley Bonnie Somerville of London, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rabert Somerville of South Devon, England, was married yesterday afternoon to Sidney G. Stricker Jr. of 4. East 82d Street. He is the son of Mrs. Stricker of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Stricker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- The United States is trying to arrange the repatriation of 48 fishermen from Communist China who were rescued by American naval vessels in the Gulf of Tonkin two weeks ago, the State Department said today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 20--Miss Jane Marshall was married this evening to Airman 2d Cl. Richard Francis Burke, U.S.A.F. SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 20 (UPI)--Gov. Edmund G. Brown disclosed today that he made an agreement with John F. Kennedy that avoided a bitter party fight in California before the Democratic Presidential primary in 1960.

TRENTON, Dec. 20--The Port of New York Authority has been unable to find a suitable alternative to the Great Swamp in New Jersey's Morris County as a site for the metropolitan area's fourth major jetport.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)--The space agency announced today that its Advanced Technology Satellite had arrived at its permanent station nearly 22,300 miles above the Pacific east of Christmas Island.

HONOLULU--One of the most characteristic sounds of Hawaiian music, the moaning sigh of the steel guitar, is fading away, an inadvertent victim of rock 'n' roll. According to local musicians, there are only six or seven steel guitarists still playing in the islands and no young guitarists are coming along to take their places.

Florentine manufacturers of handbags, leather goods and fashion accessories, struck down by the floods in northern Italy last month have made a remarkable recovery and should be able to deliver merchandise for spring and Easter.

WATERVILLE, Me., Dec. 20 (AP)--Dr. Carl J. Weber, an authority on Thomas Hardy, the English author-poet, died Sunday at a hospital here. He was 72 years old.

BONN, Dec. 20 (AP)--The West German Defense Ministry ordered today a limited resumption of flights by the controversial F-104G Starfighter, the American-designed plane that had been grounded since Dec. 6.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20--The President of the General Assembly appealed today to the United States, North Vietnam, South Vietnam and the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam to declare during the holiday truces their "unconditional willingness" to make efforts toward negotiations on peace in Vietnam.
BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The five-week strike of some 10,000 employes of the Raytheon Company ended today when union members voted to accept a contract agreement and return to work tomorrow.

Dick Tiger, the new lightheavyweight champion from Negeria and one of the oldest fighters ever to win a world crown, was named fighter of the year yesterday by the Boxing Writers Association.

BONN, Dec. 20--Six former members of the SS (Nazi Elite Guard) today received prison terms ranging from life to three years for their part in the murder of Jews at the German extermination camp in Sobibor, Poland. ROME, Dec. 20--Jean Anouilh's tragedy, "Medea," opened here tonight in a semi-moderndress version starring Anna Magnani and directed by Gian Carlo Menotti.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- The trucking industry's top labor negotiators rejected today a request that they try to get the Government to delay the jailing of James R. Hoffa until forthcoming bargaining is completed.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 20--New Zealand may soon transfer an infantry battalion stationed in Malaysia to South Vietnam.

There was a report that, if Look pledged not to publish any of Mrs. Kennedy's personal recollections that did not deal directly with the assassination of her husband, she would end her suit against the magazine.
