The election of Thomas F. Kloberg as a vice president of the Fred F. French Investing Company, effective Jan. 1, has been announced by the real estate concern's board of directors.
A 100-year-old man who came to the United States in 1903, but never got around to taking out naturalization papers because "I had to work so hard for my family," became a citizen yesterday.

MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 20-- Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Taylor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurel Taylor, to Joseph Martin Heyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezekiel Heyman of Jamaica, Queens, and Rhinebeck, N.Y.

John J. Burns, the Democratic state chairman, named a committee yesterday to begin the party's preparations for the State Constitutional Convention and to seek Republican support for a bipartisan approach to the precedures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- Representative Wright Patman of Texas said today that the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York had avoided taxes, in an entirely legal way, on millions of dollars through a series of stock and real estate transactions with a tax-exempt foundation for which it is trustee.
HONG KONG, Dec. 20-- Portugese in Macao has handed over to Chinese Communist authorities seven men accused of being agents of Nationalist China, pro-Communist newspapers in Macao said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) --Former Ambassador John Kenneth Galbraith and David E. Lilienthal, who pioneered the Tennessee Valley Authority, were among 18 advisers named to a panel by the State Department today for its Bureau of Near East and South Asian Affairs.

THE American Contract Bridge League's 13th con tinentwide charity game last month was won by Jack and Joan Meyer of Baldwin, L.I. They headed a field of over 19,000 players, and were the first pair from the metropolitan area ever to win the event.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20--Suspension of operations of the International Development Association is weeks away, the Economic and Social Council was informed today by George D. Woods, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).
American Potash and Mineral Corporation announced yesterday an immediate increase of 4 cents a pound in the price of lithium carbonate.
A 30-year-old woman was arrested yesterday morning at Kennedy International Airport when, the police said, she went there to pick up four packages that contained firearms and ammunition.
The French franc continued to show weakness in foreign exchange dealings here and in European markets.
The Terriers of St. Francis, living up to the tenacity of their nickname, battled Fordham University's basketball team right down to the final seconds last night before losing, 66-65.
An optical illusion created by a cloud effect was given yesterday as the probable cause of a mid-air collision of two airliners over Westchester on Dec. 4, 1965.

LONDON, Dec. 20--Prime Minister Wilson withdrew all British settlement offers to rebel Rhodesia today and indicated that he would not again offer legal independence except under African majority rule.
Thomas P.F. Hoving was officially named director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 20 (UPI) --Heavy snow, with a forecast of more to come, 'forced officials at Laurel to cancel the remaining card today after five races had been run.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 20 (UPI)--The United States Coast Guard reported today that it is searching the Atlantic for a 65foot Texas shrimp boat with an apparently mentally ill captain who chased his crew off the ship six days ago and is now being pursued by two sister ships.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20-- The Sierra Club announced today that its favored Federal tax status had been revoked because the club advocated legislation affecting natural resources.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 20-- Lieut, Col. Richard Donald Sullivan, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Sullivan of Ithaca end Santa Barbara, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Lewis Sullivan, to James Wilson White.
The "big" work on last night's Evenings for New Music concert at Carnegie Recital Hall was called "Treatise" and was written by the English avantgardist Cornelius Cardew.

Carnegie Hall is celebrating its 75th anniversary this season, and last night one of the organizations for which the hall was built by Andrew Carnegie was on hand to glue one of its customary performances there. The organization was the 93year-old Oratorio Society of New York, and the work of the evening was Handel's "Messiah." It was being sung for the 144th time by the Oratorio Society.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 20--Walter Lathrop Johnson, president of the New York Cotton Exchange from 1918 to 1920 and vice president of the New York Stock Exchange from 1924 to 1928 and in 1937-38, died today in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown. He was 92 years old and lived at 175 Holbrook Lane.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- The Government has stumbled upon an accounting device that enables it to reduce officially recorded budget expenditures, the budget deficit and the national debt at any time by any amount up to $45-billion without reducing real spending at all.
ATHENS, Dec. 20--Premier Stephanos Stephanopoulos of Greece lost most of his support in Parliament tonight and announced that his minority Government would resign tomorrow.
H. Belin Voorhees, a former vice president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, died after a short illness at a nursing home in Fairfield, Conn., Monday afternoon. He was 90 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it was exploring the possibility of establishing an underground nuclear testing site in Alaska.

NEW CITY, N.Y,. Dec. 20-- The Rockland County Board of Supervisors authorized today a county health and welfare complex that will eventually cost $15.5-million. It was called the first of its kind in the nation.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 20 (AP) --Miss Elizabeth Jenkins, who was a bridesmaid at the wedding of President Johnson's younger daughter Luci this year, was married today to Peter Clayton Alandt. Mrs. Luci Johnson Nugent was one of the attendants.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Dec. 20 (UPI)--The sole survivor of the Lake Huron sinking of the steamer Daniel J. Morrell said that the bow section had sunk about 15 minutes after the ship split in half but that the last time he had seen the aft section it was moving erratically under its own power.

BLUE POINT, L.I., Dec. 20 --Dr. Anne C. Couch French, a child psychologist and a physiologist, died yesterday in South Side Hospital, Bay Shore, after a long illness. She was 55 years old, and lived and had her office at 30 Madison Street here.
The election of Douglas C. Welton as president of the Dry Dock Savings Bank was one of several executive changes announced by banks yesterday.
WOODMERE, L.I., Dec. 20-- Joseph S. Hewlett, a civic leader and a descendant of l7thcentury settlers of nearby Hewlett, died today in his home at 135 Lafayette Place. He was 84 years old.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered an end to the assignment of city automobiles to individuals, a move he said would save the city $600,000 a year.

DALLAS, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Don Meredith, the quarterback who led the Dallas Cowboys to their first Eastern Conference championship this year in the National Football League, was hospitalized today with severe stomach cramps.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose nearly 3 per cent to a record of 14,619,258 shares for the month ended Dec. 15. The preceding high of 14,135,515 shares was established a month earlier.

The Bolshoi Opera will present four operas during its engagement next summer at Expo 67, the world's fair in Montreal The company will perform Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov," Tchaikovsky's "Queen of Spades," Rimsky-Korsakov's "The Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh and the Maiden Severonia" and Prokofiev's "War and Peace."

PARIS--The striking thing about the French-German reconciliation again shaping up is that it is based entirely upon General de Gaulle's terms and rests on his realistic, tough view of existing possibilities. This view holds forth scant hope of Germany's political reunification in the foreseeable future.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP)--A Roman Catholic priest and theologian announced today that he was leaving the church, saying it was more concerned with authority than truth and people.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The Aerospace industry has "slipped into the mainstream of American economic and social life," an industry leader said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- The United States and the Soviet Union entered a new and comprehensive phase of atomic testing today with an underground blast in Nevada designed to develop a warhead for an antimissile missile.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (UPI)-- The American auto industry, which has been plagued by sluggish sales, has cut January production schedules by nearly 50,000 units.

LENINGRAD, Dec. 20 (Reuters)--A young American pleaded tonight for freedom after the state demanded that he be sentenced to five years in a labor camp for theft and violation of the Soviet Union's strict currency laws.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 20--Finance Minister Pinhas Sapir acknowledged today that Israel's planned economic slowdown had gone too far. By his reckoning, unemployment more than trebled during the year.
CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 20-- Every Tuesday night, two American officers are portrayed raping a Vietnamese nurse and then torturing her to death with electric shocks in a play being given here.
Mayor Lindsay will set up a citizens' committee soon to review all aspects of the city's hospital system and public health services and make recommendations for improvement.

NORTHAMPTON, Eng., Dec. 20--Using surplus equipment from World War II, a borrowed toy globe and paper clips, some 100 pupils from 15 to 18 years old are operating a full-fledged, dependable satellite tracking station here.

The city received yesterday from the National Audubon Society a plan for establishment of a 50-acre nature center in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, designed basically to educate children in the natural sciences.
NASHVILLE, Dec. 20 (UPI) --Vanderbilt University turned to the Southwest today and named Bill Pace of Arkansas as head football coach and Jess Neely of Rice as athletic director.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 20-- Thomas J. Davis of Stamford, Conn., has resigned, effective Dec. 31, as the East Coast public relations director of the John Birch Society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)--A Federal judge said today that Governement eavesdropping on Robert G. Baker was illegal but apparently unrelated to the former Senate aide's indictment on charges of income tax exasion, theft and fraud.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--A secret new space launching base at Plesetsk, 400 miles north of Moscow, may be the Soviet Union's version of Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, informed sources said today.
The New York Knickerbockers will seek their fourth straight victory over the Chicago Bulls, who have won their last four games, in Chicago tonight.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 20--The six Common Market countries, hoping to smooth out economic cycles, took a cautious first step today toward the coordination of short-term financial policies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20--A resolution recommending an increase in United Nations personnel hired on a term basis rather than with permanent status was adopted unanimously by the General Assembly this afternoon.
A lay Roman Catholic publication has called for the United States to withdraw from Vietnam "even at the cost of a Communist victory."

With one stroke of a mallet against a steel blade yesterday, a cutter cleaved a rought diamond into two gems that will eventually be worth about $1million. A mistake would have made the 240-carat stone value

Hospitals Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio said yesterday he "was not disturbed" by current criticism of the hospital system and went on to sketch plans that he said would make New York's treatment facilities a "prototype" for the nation.

KATONAH, N.Y., Dec. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Warburton Strong have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Crawford Strong, to Edgar Robert Sullivan, son of Mrs. Carlton V. Sullivan of Mount Kisco and the late Mr. Sullivan.
The spot rate on the British pound rose 5 points, to $2.7903, in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

Paperboard production rose 3.1 per cent with 455,200 tons in the week ended Dec. 17 from 441,600 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
Anahid Kerpitchian, made her American debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, but there was nothing debut-like about her singing.

Greenwich Village residents, civic groups and sympathetic political figures in and outside the area made a last-minute stand yesterday in a landmarks battle. They sought to persuade the Landmarks Preservation Commission to follow through on its original proposal and designate a 65-block section of the Village as a single historic district.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 A 10-man American expedition has climbed the highest known peak in the Antarctic, the first time such a feat has been achieved, the National Science Foundation was informed today.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Dec. 21 (UPI) Capitalizing on more than 70 per cent of its free throws, Purdue defeated Army tonight, 79-69, in an overtime basketball game.
An immediate suspension of United States bombing of North Vietnam and extension of the Christmas and New Year's truces were urged yesterday by 40 New York Democratic legislators and officeholders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Ralph Nader said today there was considerable room for improvement in aviation safety.
Three major oil companies took an initial step yesterday toward building an offshore, deepwater unloading facility for tankers in Lower Delaware Bay.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 21 (AP) Frank Costello, whose appeal of a Federal gambling conviction was scheduled to be heard by the United States Supreme Court, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Trumbull.

Investors reduced their purchases of new mutual-fund shares in November and increased their redemptions of old shares, it was announced yesterday by the industry's trade association, the Investment Company Institute.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 21--The United States and Brazil have agreed in a tax treaty to reduce double taxation and increase the exchange of information on taxpayers to control evasion.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 21 (AP)--Bill White, the Philadelphia Phils' first baseman, who underwent surgery yesterday for a torn Achilles tendon in his right ankle, was feeling fine today and hoping to get out of bed soon.

TOKYO, Dec. 21 Communist China is prepared to intervene at any time with military forces in the war in Vietnam but hopes to avoid direct involvement, the chief correspondent in Peking of the influential Japanese newspaper Asahi reported this week.

Ernie Calverly, the coach of Rhode Island, had just startled the usually phlegmatic audience at the weekly basketball writers' luncheon on Monday by calling Jimmy Walker of Providence, "the best college player I have ever seen."
A group of New York and New Jersey air pollution officials recommended yesterday that some of the voluntary antipollution measures now called for in the first stage of a smog alert be made mandatory.
Mayor Lindsay called on the major cities of the state yesterday to develop a "unity of purpose" at next spring's State Constitutional Convention to serve the best interests of each.
Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., Canadian aluminum producer, is buying 50 per cent of the stateowned Norwegian aluminum maker, A/S Aardal og Sunndal Verk for some $35-million in stock and notes.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 21 Mexican farm leaders have leveled charges that United States loan funds meant to help small farmers have been misused.
PARIS, Dec. 21 The new political alliance of France's Communist and non-Communist left disclosed today that it was less than completely agreed on how to win elections.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 21 The Rev. Harold Elliott, former assistant rector of Christ Church in Babylon, received a suspended sentence of 5 to 10 years in prison in County Court here today after pleading guilty to a charge of sodomy.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21 Arthur J. Goldberg emphasized today the "unconditional willingness" of the United States to discuss a peaceful solution of the war in Vietnam.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed yesterday with a flurry of small gains despite profit taking.
The students of the Senior English Class at Locust Valley (L.I.) High School sent a check for $120.37 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 The Constituent Assembly made another key decision today in its continuing debate on how South Vietnam is to be governed.

CAMRANH BAY, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 Bob Hope said today that "a few" performers had turned down his invitation to join his Christmas tour for servicemen in South Vietnam because they disapproved of United States policy here.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 Governor Rockefeller repeated today a six-month-old pledge to Mayor Lindsay that the state would make up any revenue loss to New York City if the yields of the city's commuter earnings and resident income taxes fell below original estimates.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 (AP) A Navy surgeon removed a lethal rifle grenade from the throat of a United States Marine Corps private last night. He showed it around the operating room before he found out it might kill the eight people there.
The laying of the keel for the first large gas-turbinepowered merchant ship under United States registry was announced here yesterday by the American Export Isbrandtsen Lines.
UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 21 (AP) A Federal judge cleared the way today for the sale of the Rome Cable division of the Aluminum Corporation of America to the Okonite Company, Dallas.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 21 The vice chairman of the Nassa County Board of Supervisors declared today that if Mayor Lindsay persisted in his plan to r,aise the New York City earnings tax on commuters "legislation authorizing a reciprocal income tax on city residents ...

Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036 or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:
Ten hotdog pushcarts were trundled to Police Headquarters at noon yesterday by irate peddlers, who protested what they called police harassment.

LITTLE mannequins have more fun than big ones do. While waiting their turn on the runway to present the first collection of knitted children's fashions by Micia of Rome, this group played games like pat-acake and sang songs, instead of fussing with their hair and make-up.
SYDNEY, Dec. 21 Pilots of Qantas Empire Airways voted in Sydney tonight to end their 27-day strike.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 A small number of North Korean pilots are flying MIG jet fighters in North Vietnam, informed sources disclosed today.

BONN, Dec. 21 The West German authorities today disclosed the seizure of 25 tons of Rhodesian banknotes. It is surmised that the notes, similar to those now circulating in Rhodesia, had been destined for use in a currency reform.

Miss Joan Rebecca Lipson, daughter of Mrs. Jerome I. Lipson of New York and the late Mr. Lipson, was married yesterday evening to Michael Davidson, son of Sidney Davidson of Baldwin, L.I., and Mrs. Adelaide Davidson of Miami.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 (UPI) The New York State Department of Commerce issued the following ski reports today:

Kansas City's plans to become the air capital of the Middle United States with the most modern and convenient international airport in the United States, were described here yesterday by Mayor Ilus W. Davis of Kansas City.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (UPI) A cantata set to a poem by Boris Pasternak, the novelist, was given its premiere performance here tonight.
FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 21 Florence today reopened all but one of its art galleries and museums, some of whose art treasures were gravely damaged in the disastrous flood of Nov. 4.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 21 (AP) About 200 workers walked off a construction project here today in a dispute over whether a Christmas cross they erected should be permitted to stand.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) Boston College took a quick 3830 half-time lead and never was headed tonight as the Eagles captured the Christmas college basketball tournament at Boston Garden with a 75-67 victory over Massachusetts.
THE Doug Rogers Dance Theater made its New York debut at the Kaufmann Hall of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. That was inconsiderate of it.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (Reuters) Matvei Manizer, sculptor and vice chairman of the Soviet Academy of Arts, died yesterday at age age of 75, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

GENEVA, Dec. 21 West Germany has agreed to contribute $875,000 for a new fund for victims of Nazi persecution who failed to qualify for earlier benefits, Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, announced today.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 21 (AP) The United States Government takes precautions to keep from buying Chinese Communist goods, but slips can occur, American sources said today.

GLEN ROCK, N.J., Dec. 21 Dr. Robert W. Smith, educational administrator of the American Institute of Banking, died of a heart attack today in New York, where he was staying on a business appointment. He was 43 years old and lived at 70 South Highwood Avenue here.

LIBERTY HOUSE is a small store at 343 Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village that is attempting to do a big job. It is the New York branch of the original Liberty House in Jackson, Miss., and it sells "the crafts of freedom," articles made by the Poor People's Corporation.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 21 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that she had no indication yet from the United States of any new authorization of food shipments to India. An announcement of such authorization has been expected ...
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 21 (AP) St. Louis University used every trick in the book to slow the game down, but secondranked Louisville scored a 75-68 basketball victory tonight.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 21 (AP) When Criminal Court Judge Joseph L. Carter agreed to George McChan's release from prison he remarked that recent court decisions left him no choice but to "foist a professional holdup man on the public."

American businesses cut back the pace of new foreign ventures during the first half of 1966 to its lowest level in six years, according to a study issued yesterday by Booz, Allen Hamilton, Inc., management consultants.
Twelve demonstrators were arrested yesterday and evicted by the police from the hearing room the group had seized on Monday from the Board of Education at its headquarters in Brooklyn.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 21 (UPI) A flat-iron-shaped space vehicle, designed to bring an astronaut safely through the atmosphere someday and land like an airplane, was lost today on its maiden launching test.

Venezuela is providing sensational news stories of attempted assassination, bombings, guerrillas and the occupation of the university in Caracas by Government troops and police. Paradoxically, the country is as stable as any in Latin America and it is certainly the richest of all Latin governments.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 21 (UPI) Club owners from the American Football League tentatively agreed yesterday to pay players with five years of professional experience $450 a month when they reach 65 years of age.

The defending titleholder, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, retained the lead after the seventh round of the 1966/67 United States chess championship when he adjourned his game with his nearest rival, Larry Evans of Las Vegas, ...

Dr. Jack Reiss, a physician and lawyer residing in Coral Gables, Fla., died Saturday of a heart attack in a hotel in Topeka, Kan. He had been a patient in the Veterans Administration Hospital there for a heart ailment. He was 60 years old.

Miss Eleanor Fisher Trevor was honored at a dinner dance given yesterday evening at the Colony Club by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bronson Trevor. Miss Trevor, who was presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball on Monday, received with her mother.
Bowing to society seemed like a habit to some of the 19 young women who were presented last night in the Pierre at the 10th Mistletoe Debutante Ball.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 Governor Rockefeller said today that he favored a liberalization of the state's 84-year-old abortion law.

A new design for the proposed Franklin D. Roosevelt memorial in Washington's West Potomac Park, midway between the Jefferson and Lincoln Memorials, was made public here yesterday. Starkly sharp in its lines, the memorial consists of seven ...
A former narcotics peddler and State Senator-elect Ivan L. Warner were accused in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday of trying to ruin Eugene Rodriguez, also a Senator-elect.

Joe Namath, the flamboyant but fragile quarterback of the New York Jets, will undergo more surgery on his right knee next week. There is a remote possibility the operation could end Namath's celebrated career.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 22 North Vietnamese aircraft have been intercepted while heading toward a nuclear-powered cruiser ship of the United States Seventh Fleet, an American military spokesman said last night.

The National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians announced yesterday that it would file complaints with four Federal offices against television pickup plans forn ext month's Super Bowl game between the champions of the American and National Football Leagues.

MADRID, Dec. 21 Generalissimo Francisco Franco was reported to have told two visiting Jewish leaders from the United States today that Spain's new legislation on freedom of religion was "a simple act of justice."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) Hubie Marshall scored 31 points in leading La Salle College to an 85-83 victory over Penn tonight in the second game of a college basketball double-header at the Palestra.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Dina Merrill, the actress, and Cliff Robertson, the actor, were married today at Hillwood, the baronial Rock Creek Park estate of her mother, the cereal heiress Marjorie Merriweather Post (Mrs. Herbert A. May). It was a second marriage for both.

IT'S been said that doormen smile a little wider and open doors a little faster as Christmas approaches. "Mine has even started calling me by name," said a Manhattan career girl who lives on East 80th Street. "It used to be 'young lady.'"
John K. Hanrahan, who lives on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, cut his own Christmas tree again this year, and two more besides.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The thoughtful Gov. William W. Scranton, in a little noticed speech to the Pennsylvania Society of New York on Dec.10, offered an analysis of the 1966 elections in which he said in part:
Experiments on textile yarns that began 100 years ago are now proving valuable in the space program.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) The Chicago Bulls gained their fifth consecutive victory tonight by beating the New York Knickerbockers, 110-107, in a National Basketball Association contest.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 21 "Fiddler on the Roof" was given its first performance in Western Europe tonight.

The case of the Kennedy-Manchester manuscript, which was at least partially settled last night, is an example of every one being wrong in some respect, everyone coming out badly, and everyone suffering. Temporarily, one of the victims may well be the truth about the circumstances surrounding the assassination of President Kennedy.

Four hundred thousand children are growing up on public relief in this city, the great bulk of them in fatherless homes. The decision of the State Board of Social Welfare requiring local welfare districts to make known the availability of birth-control services should help curb the steep rise in this huge total of children born into poverty and despair.
WRIGHT Advisory Reports has taken a long look at 1,250 common stocks on the New York Stock Exchange and has come up with what it calls "25 proven growth stocks for 1967."

The Puerto Rican Bar Association of New York has charged that State Supreme Court Justice Charles Marks "would appear to lack tact and proper judicial temperament" in suggesting recently that Puerto Ricans "should be able to read and "write before coming here."
The American Stock Exchange made a strong advance yesterday as most stocks snapped out of their recent sluggishness.
BOSTON, Dec. 21 The Boston School Committee scored a tentative victory today in its struggle with the State Board of Education over racial imbalance.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 21 (AP) Joe Caldwell put on an 11-point spurt that sparked the St. Louis Hawks to a 118109 victory over the Baltimore Bullets in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 21 Lord Thomson of Fleet won the Government's approval today, without significant conditions, to take over The Times of London.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--American Federation of Laborand Congress of Industrial Organizations assumed the leadership today in recruiting and screening young men in Appalachia for the Job Corps.
Commuters put on their overshoes yesterday and sloshed through snowy suburbs to trains and buses that carried them to a city where the streets were no worse than damp.

THE headline was sufficient to make every old-timer bristle and splutter into his long, gray beard. It was an eye- catcher, all right, and was packed with shock appeal. It said: "Johnny Weissmuller was a slow swimmer," and appeared in last Sunday's magazine section of this newspaper over a lively article by Keith Monroe about the phenomenal upsurge of swift swimmers in the United States.
Children living in affluent suburban communities are more likely to develop asthma than those in urban or rural areas, a survey of 10,000 Maryland families has shown.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Senator Joseph S. Clark of Pennsylvania said today he had the votes to win the No. 3 Democratic leadership position in the Senate.

DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 21 St. Luke's Episcopal Church was the setting tonight for the marriage of Miss Beverly Alexander Bowers, daughter of Mrs. J. Paul Stabler and the late J. Foster Bowers, to Keith Slater Jennings. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Jennings of New Canaan.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) The Chicago White Sox signed today Manager Eddie Stanky's revised coaching staff for the 1967 baseball season.

ANKARA, Dec. 21 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union was reported tonight to have expressed his regret to the Turkish Premier, Suleyman Demirel, over Czechoslovakia's recent sale of arms to the proGreek Government of Cyprus.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Dec. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Claypoole Wells have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Keller Wells, to Dr. John James Mooney. He is the son of Mrs. Bernard J. Mooney of Winnetka, Ill., and the late Mr. Mooney.

A NATIONWIDE television audience will get a jump on the competitive ski-racing season Saturday. On the agenda is last summer's world Alpine championships, which were filmed in color by the American Broadcasting Company for its Wide World of Sports program.
Sidney Shuman resigned yesterday as president, chief executive officer and a director of Reed International, Inc., at the request of George W. Murphy, chairman and controlling stockholder.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (UPI) The Rev. E. Marshall Bevins, who resigned as rector of two rural Episcopal churches in Chester County because of "racial prejudice" in the congregations, will become vicar of a small church in the Richmond section here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Representative Adam Clayton Powell's estranged wife, who is on his office payroll at $20,578 a year, is now receiving her salary checks at her home in Puerto Rico, House investigators said today.

The Gotham Dinner Dance, one of the junior dances benefiting the New York Foundling Hospital, was held in the Plaza yesterday evening. Attending were girls in the first and second years of preparatory school and boys in the second, third and fourth years.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 21 (AP) Jim Hickman, the outfielder who was traded by the New York Mets to the Los Angeles Dodgers, was released today by the Caguas Oriolles of the Puerto Rican League.

CAMP BEARCAT, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 Some soldiers of the United States Army's Ninth Infantry Division, who have been streaming into this compound 15 miles north of Saigon, will be part of the first American push into the ...

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Dec. 21 President Johnson took some restive Democratic Governors out to the shed behind his ranch house today to have them testify about how easy it is to bring their complaints and criticisms to the White House.
Esteban Cevilla, the second client to enter the cream-colored law office on wheels, said that his Social Security payments were not enough to live on.
The hearings on New York City's financial problems held by the Joint Legislative Committee revealed that there has been no breaking of the deadlock between state and city.
NEIL SIMON, your friendly neighborhood gagman, hasn't had an idea for a play this season, but he's gone ahead and written one anyway.
Matson Lines has embarked on a $46-million program to expand its unsubsidized Hawaii freight container service to the Far East, according to an announcement by the carrier's board of directors.
Gabriel (Flash) Elorde and Jose Torres, both guilty of mediocre boxing performances in recent title fights, felt the restrictive hand of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.
CAIRO, Dec. 21 The Egyptian Government has decided to ease its restrictions on belly dancing, a high Government official said today.
The nation's electric power production rose 8 per cent in the week ended Dec. 17 from the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

GERALDINE PAGE imparted a glow to the tele vision screen last night with an exquisitely perceptive and radiantly gentle performance as the elderly spinster in Truman Capote's Yuletide story entitled "A Christmas Memory."
American Airlines announced yesterday that it had retained Henry Dreyfuss, an industrial designer, to develop a new corporate identification program for the company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Secretary of State Dean Rusk expressed hope today that the Soviet Union would help avert another upward spiral in the arms race by agreeing with the United States not to deploy a ballistic missile defense system.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 21 Miss Helen Handley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Kenneth Handley, was married today to Wilson McCarthy 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis McCarthy.

As a result of President Johnson's suspension of shipments, the last American grain ship to India sailed Dec. 10. With famine threatening, a break of several weeks in the bridge of ships could contribute to starvation and public disturbances just at the time of India's national elections in February.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest corporate enterprise, chose H.I. Romnes yesterday as chairman.
Ling-Temco Vought, Inc., offered in a surprise move yesterday to buy 750,000 common shares of Wilson Co., Inc., at $62.50 a share, for a total price of $47-million.

Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, the politician-turnedperformer, has been booked for a guest appearance on a television variety show to read excerpts from his new record album, "Gallant Men." The disk salutes American patriots.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 21 (AP) The striking Springfield Indians of the American Hockey League resumed practice today in a move they said was to fulfill "our contract obligations."
The Gallup Poll reported yesterday that the Democratic party had less appeal for voters now than at any time in 26 years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Federal Communications Commission, by a 4 to 3 vote, approved today the acquisition of the American Broadcasting Company by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Senator Jacob K. Javits urged today an immediate discussion to determine whether a fourth New York area jetport is needed to avert "economic disaster."
David E. Gothe, retired president of the dress-manufacturing company bearing his name, died Tuesday of a heart attack in his home at 70-44 Kessel Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 69 years old.

THE connoisseur of bridge hands takes particular de- light in those that depend on the size of a small spot card. In today's deal, which was played at the Town and Country Club at Great Neck, L.I., the declarer was able to make ...

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 21 Miss Mary Hill Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lathrop Gilbert of Cambridge and Gilbertsville, N.Y., was married today to Dr. John Ieuan Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emrys John Harris of The Mayals in Swansea, Wales.
The stock market reversed itself yesterday and closed with gains, ending four consecutive sessions of declines. The volume of trading rose slightly as prices advanced.

SCARSDALE, N.Y. There is a wonderland in Scarsdale, a child's dream of Christmas. It is a three-story home, with a tree panoplied with ornaments, some of them more than a hundred years old. Some of the branches of the tree sweep a ceiling hung with a hundred handmade stars, and from cellar to roof there is the smell ...
Mrs. John F. Kennedy and Look magazine resolved their dispute last night on the serialization of "The Death of a President."
Edmond S. Fish, community relations manager of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, died yesterday in his home at 1 Gracie Terrace. His age was 59.
MIAMI, Dec. 21 (AP) Shelly Bee Stable's favored Carrasco uncorked another powerful stretch run and overwhelmed his opponents today in winning the Sunshine Endurance Handicap at Tropical Park.
TRENTON, Dec. 21 Plans were announced today for the first state college in New Jersey to be devoted to the liberal arts.
Mayor Lindsay vetoed yesterday a City Council bill providing for the licensing of travel agencies and another regulating price claims in written advertisements.

More than 500 members of the Social Service Employes Union marched in a picket line demonstration yesterday in front of the Department of Welfare's central office in protest against the impasse in contract negotiations with the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 An investigation of possibly illegal discrimination in the rates charged by newspapers and magazines to different types of advertisers has been started by the Federal Trade Commission.
LONDON, Dec. 21 The biggest and most influential business organization in Britain urged today that the British negotiate entry into the European Economic Community "as soon as possible."
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) The family of cancer-stricken Barney Ross, former world lightweight and welterweight champion, asked for discontinuance of benefits today for the former champion.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Medina Jr. of New York and Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Hillyer Medina, to Philip Blakely Lyons, son of Mrs. Charlotte H. Lyons of Boston and Philip V. Lyons of Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The chances that James R. Hoffa will be around to complete forthcoming truck labor negotiations were enhanced today when he won at least a few more weeks of freedom.
TIJUANA, Mexico, Dec. 21 (UPI) An agreement ending a strike that began Oct. 1 at Caliente Race Track was signed yesterday in the office of Mayor Francisco Lopez Gutierrez.
"The Death of a President" is not the first book to which Mrs. John F. Kennedy objected before publication, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) Is the Federal Government practicing what it preaches about truth in financial advertising?

PAOLI, Pa., Dec. 21--Miss Barbara Lee Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dunbar Scott, was married today to Pfc. William Romeyn Everdell, U.S.M.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Everdell 3d of Syosset, L.I., and Edgartown, Mass.
The First National City Bank announced here yesterday the appointment of Lester Garvin as senior vice president and senior credit officer in the overseas division. He had been a vice president.
The election of George C. Neumann as vice president in charge of special projects was announced here yesterday by the Canada Dry Corporation.
Two modern-day offshoots of the House of Morgan the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Morgan Stanley Co. announced plans yesterday to form a new joint venture in international investment banking.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 21 (UPI) A judge who has convicted scores of civil rights demonstrators and handed down contempt citations against persons criticizing his actions came under fire today from one of the state's top Negro leaders.
A prison guard was indicted here yesterday on charges of kicking one prisoner fracturing a rib and beating another with a blackjack.

Underprivileged children of the New York area will benefit from a gift of 3,165 books by 53 publishers, advertising agencies and individuals. The books were sorted and packed Monday night by a committee representing the Publishers Publicity Association, the Publishers ...
The Signal Oil and Gas Company, a medium-sized producer based in Los Angeles, has made a proposal to assist the financially beleaguered Douglas Aircraft Company, situated at nearby Santa Monica.
WINDSOR, Ont., Dec. 21--A trailer truck overturned at an intersection today and dumped 10 tons of sand into a crowded school bus, killing eight children.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a loss of $53,000 for November in contrast to a profit of $73,000 in the 1965 month.
WATERTOWN, N.Y. That nostalgic yearning of New Yorkers Christmas with sentiment, but not frenzy can be found in this urban heart of the state's rural "north country."

The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and the Ford Foundation are discussing the establishment of a noncommercial television service that would offer a comprehensive weekly review of news events in international and national affairs, the arts, books, education and science.

Leroy A. Van Bomel, former chairman and president of National Dairy Products Corporation, one of the country's leading food-processing companies, died yesterday in his home at 960 Fifth Avenue. He was 81 years old.

Copper futures prices rose the limit yesterday for most contracts and then closed a little below the high levels of the day but well above the preceding day's figures. The daily limit on a rise is 2 cents a pound.
The New York Democratic Congressional delegation agreed yesterday to back Representative Jacob H. Gilbert of the Bronx for a vacant seat on the powerful House Ways and Means Committee.
The Federal Reserve System bought long-term Government bonds yesterday for the first time since July. The purchases cut short one of the few declines in the market in the last two weeks.
The Hanes Corporation has announced the election of Gordon Hanes as president and cheif executive officer.
ATHENS, Dec. 21 King Constantine moved swiftly today to end a political crisis that toppled the 15-month-old minority cabinet of Premier Stephanos Stephanopoulos.
BONN, Dec. 12 West Germany and France exchanged letters today that put in formal terms the agreement under which 62,000 French troops will remain in the Federal Republic of Germany.

About a dozen leaders of the Hunts Point section of the Bronx proposed yesterday "to transform the neighborhood from one of the large poverty areas of the city to a selfsufficient, middle-income community by changing the conditions of life and opportunities."

Look magazine has agreed to remove or modify all those passages in the magazine version of "The Death of a President" relating to the personal life of Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her children. These paragraphs were the sole reasons for the initiation of her legal action.
Samuel R. Pierce Jr., a Negro lawyer and former judge of the Court of General Sessions in New York City, is one of several persons being considered for a vacancy on the State Court of Appeals.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 The Soviet Union fired another spacecraft, Luna 13, toward the moon today, the fifth in 10 months. A few minutes late, it was announced that the 137th in the Cosmos series had been put into orbit around the earth.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 21 Opponents of President Sukarno have gained fresh political ammunition in their newest and most intensive drive to call the President to account for his role In last year's unsuccessful Communist-led coup.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Has anyone tried lately to find out whether it was going to rain? You turn on the radio, wait patiently and after a while the voice says, "After this message we will bring you the latest U.S. Weather Bureau forecast," and after the message the voice says, "There is less than a 5 per cent chance of precipitation."
THE best thing about Eric Solomon's "Stephen Crane: From Parody to Realism" is that it will make more people read Crane's stories. Whatever does that deserves well of the Republic.
Mayor Lindsay impressed exhibition ice skaters yesterday as he whirled with teenage girls to waltz tunes and dashed with Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving around the city's newest skating rink.
ANKARA, Dec. 21 (Reuters) The Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Kosygin, and his party ate lunch alone today while most of their Turkish hosts just watched.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (UPI) Bobby Hull scored his 12th and 13th goals tonight to help the Chicago Black Hawks post a 6-4 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings and retain a share of the National Hockey League lead with the New York Rangers.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 21 (UPI) President Eduardo Frei Montalva announced tonight that Chile would not need loans from the United States and the International Monetary Fund next year to support Chile's budget.
Hilde Somer, an American pianist, and a group of Rumanian diplomats joined together yesterday to promote a modest but promising cultural-exchange venture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the "most prominent [diplomatic] failure" of the past year had been the inability to find some way to bring the Vietnam war to the negotiating table.
There are nights when, for both fans and players, hockey becomes a game purely of emotion.
Carol Management, a real estate concern that operates many apartment houses, has contracted to sell seven of its buildings in Forest Hills, Queens, for $7.5-million.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21 An officer of the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company said today that the line sprang a leak Dec. 12 near Arar in Saudi Arabia but denied an Egyptian report that the line had also been damaged at Turaif 125 miles to the west.

A "general understanding" on a new contract was reported to have been reached yesterday by negotiators for the General Electric Company and leaders of 11,500 electrical workers who have been on strike at the company's Schenectady plant since Oct. 17.
MIAMI, Dec. 21 (UPI) The 5-foot-long "watchdog" that Hialeah race track keeps in its wishing well has finally earned his room and board.

LENINGRAD, Dec. 21 A Leningrad court sentenced a young American today to three years in a labor camp on charges of theft and changing dollars for rubles on the black market. The United States Embassy in Moscow called the sentence harsh.
The Police Department called on the city government yesterday to add 1,000 policemen to its 28,000-man force in the fiscal year beginning next July 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Federal District Court here issued an injunction tonight ordering strikers back to work at a jet engine component plant of the Union Carbide Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) Striking a note of Christmas cheer, the Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today that an $819 check was on its way to help pay the rent of 13 elderly persons in Lorain, Ohio.
PARIS, Dec. 21 The editor of a Yiddish language Communist publication here has called on the Soviet Union to modify its policy toward the Jews of the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 An Albany County grand jury criticized. The Knickerbocker News today for having made "accusations, innuendos and charges" against county officials and grand jurors "without any foundation or semblance of evidence."
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (AP) The will of Walt Disney leaving three major trust funds was filed for probate today, naming his widow, Lillian, as a trustee and executor of the estate.

The prestige of the Burroughs Corporation's data-processing business rose sharply yesterday as the University of Wisconsin announced it had selected a B8500 computer to form the basis of a giant statewide information-processing system.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 22 (UPI) Laurel celebrated its 55th anniversary today by admitting fans free to its holiday decorated grandstand and clubhouse and most of the 11,621 persons on hand successfully played Hansom Harve in the $4,500 anniversary purse.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy has challenged New York State Surrogates to make public the names of persons they have appointed as special guardians and the fees paid for such work. If the Joint Legislative Committee on Court Reorganization is serious about its inquiry into the Surrogate Courts, it is impossible to see how this request can be ignored.

Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036 or to any of the following eight organizations that Certify these cases:

In the troubled British newspaper world and beyond there will be relief that the Monopolies Commission and the Government have cleared the way for the corporate marriage of The Times of London with The Sunday Times.

The following list shows last May's reading scores for each elementary and junior high school in the New York City public school system. It was compiled by The New York Times from data made available by the Board of Education.
The New York Rangers received another vote of confidence from a fan yesterday.
Two of the nation's major insurance companies announced the election of new board members yesterday.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 22 Edward McSorley, a novelist newspaperman and press agent, died of emphysema and a heart ailment today at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown. He was 64 years old and lived on Glengary Road.
The Lindsay administration is planning to increase fines for parking violations next month as a further step to keep cars out of the city's congested areas.

ROME, Dec. 22 Pope Paul VI expressed hope today that the combatants in Vietnam would achieve a Christmas "miracle of goodwill" that could transform the holiday true there into "peace in freedom and justice."
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 22 (AP) The Springfield Indians' week-long revolt over suspensions by owner Eddie Shore ended today, 24 hours before an American Hockey League game with the Providence Reds.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22 Statements purporting to come from a new leftist-nationalist organization operating in Saudi Arabia were published here today. They claimed credit for acts of sabotage against the Saudi Government and oil pipelines.

THIS week's snow flurry officially inaugurated boot weather, but most New York women hadn't waited for it to get slushy underfoot. Even on reasonably mild days, the clickety-clack of shoes had given way to the clumpclump of boots.

A bridge accident in Central America that caused the death of 12 construction workers four years ago will result in an unusual $2.5-million negligence trial that will be held in New Jersey under Costa Rican law.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) The first six planning grants to states under the 1965 Water Resources Planning Act were announced tonight. They totaled $118,980.
An investigation by the State Attorney General's office has uncovered more than 200 members of the paramilitary rightist Minuteman organization in New York.
Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday that he and Governor Rockefeller had been unable to agree on a program of expanded state aid for New York City during the next fiscal year.
Robert G. Hazen, director of downtown renewal in Boston, was named yesterday as deputy administrator of New York's Housing and Development Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Game in Washington this Christmas is redesigning the Administration. Everybody's playing it but the President, and this is just the trouble. For his Government is sinking, not because it's a failure, as the Republicans say, but because it's a bore. Merry Christmas? Not here. This town hasn't had a good laugh since Arthur Schlesinger fell into Bobby Kennedy's swimming pool.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) Talks in a mechanics' strike against Mohawk Airlines were recessed indefinitely today after a deadlock was reached over how many workers would be allowed to return to their jobs.
The Board of Estimate yesterday approved the final plan for the 49.3-acre Coney Island West urban renewal project.

BUFFALO, Dec. 22 Mr. and Mrs. J. Benjamin Townsend of Buffalo and Charlotte, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josephine Rice Townsend, to Benjamin Henry Kaestner 3d, son of Mr.Kaestner Jr. of Baltimore and the late Mrs. Alice Reed Kaestner.
Jim Nance, the powerful fullback of the Boston Patriots, was voted two awards yesterday and his coach, Mike Holovak, was named coach of the year in a poll conducted by the Sporting News.

For Mrs. Etta O., 60, life has become a nightmare of illness. Ten years ago her husband Harry, a factory worker, now 62, was so crippled by a stroke he could no longer walk without aid. To supplement his disability benefits, Mrs. O. went to work as a cashier, leaving Mr. 0. in the care of Marsha, the O.'s emotionally unstable daughter, and Mrs. O.'s elderly mother, who lived with them.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 22 (AP) John P. Burns who commanded convoys over the Burma Road in World War II, died of a heart attack last night in the Alexian Brothers Hospital. He was 53 years old.

The Mayors of 11 municipalities on the west shore of the Hudson River have been called to a meeting with New Jersey's Commissioner of Conservation and Economic Development to seek a way possibly through a tax-sharing arrangement for coordinated development of the river's lower 10 miles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 As a result of a decline in a number of food prices, the Consumer Price Index rose in November by the smallest amount in six months.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 22 The Common Market, in an unexpected burst of year-end enthusiasm, completed most of its Kennedy round agricultural offers today and undertook its first discussion on possible British entry.
ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 22 Emmanuel Omaboe, Ghana's chief economic adviser, announced today that her creditor nations had agreed to new, generous repayment terms for part of the country's external debt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Food and Drug Administration announced today it would allow doctors to resume using DMSO on human patients in research studies provided the controversial drug was given under strictly controlled circumstances.
BRASILIA, Dec. 22 President Humberto Castelo Branco submitted a press bill to Congress today that would broaden penalties against the publication of articles that affect security and personal honor.
Technical factors associated with the long holiday weekend pushed up the spot rate of the British pound by eight points to $2.7911 on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Trading was limited.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Dec. 22 The Sleepy Hollow Country Club was the setting here this evening for the Sleepy Hollow Assembly, at which five young women were presented. The club hall was trimmed with birch sprayed blue and silver, and the debutantes carried muffs of red roses.

The merger of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation will create a super corporation out of the fruits of what were originally the separate business ideas of some of America's most individualistic entrepreneurs.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 22 Intensified efforts to deal with the most dreaded of sea perils fire on shipboard are highlighted by the world maritime organization in its 1966 year-end report.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 22 (Reuters) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin called today for the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Cyprus and the dismantling of all foreign bases on the island. British, Turkish, Greek and United Nations forces are there.

Two hundred firemen, studying for advancement, temporarily shelved the theory of their classes yesterday at the Delehanty Institute at 126 East 13th Street to study the real thing a small fire that broke out in an oil burner in the basement of the two-story building.
"Suddenly," the young fireman said, "the whole building started to shake. We heard the old familiar cry--'Get out, get out'--but we weren't fast enough."
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 22 (AP) The Green Bay Packers, Westerrn Conference champions of the National Football League, ran through another no contact out-door drill today in 15 degree weather.
BASILIA, Dec. 22--Congress approved early today in a first reading the controversial new Constitution submitted by President Humberto Castelo Branco.
A raging fire in a four-story midtown commercial building trapped nine firemen last night when the second floor collapsed, but fast, desperate rescue efforts saved all nine.
A warning that the current shortage of capital now plaguing the developing countries may grow more acute has come from George D. Woods, president of the World Bank.
WHEN Constellation torpedoed Sovereign in the 1964 America's Cup, the consensus was that Olin Stephens had designed a superboat.

LISBON, Dec. 22 Portugal plans to extend the maximum draft period to four years in view of present defense needs in Portuguese Africa, it was disclosed here today. For the first time, women will also be allowed to volunteer and thus make more men available for combat duty.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 22 The Soviet Union informed India today that it would provide 200,000 tons of wheat to meet the country's food shortage.
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of the ski areas (messages were filed at the times indicated in parentheses):

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 (UPI) Negotiators for California race track owners stood firm today on their final offer to a union representing parimutuel clerks and other employes, increasing the possibility of a strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The legal arm of the civil rights movement set the stage today for a possible wave of lawsuits charging that local urban renewal agencies overlook the rights of Negro city dwellers.

PARIS, Dec. 22 The General Motors Corporation is planning a major new installation in France an $80-million plant at Strasbourg to make automatic transmissions, with the possibility of later expansion to make automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 An Interstate Commerce Commissioner today recommended that the Norfolk Western Railway be required to absorb two smaller railroads and that it be given the option of taking over a third line.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 22 (UPI) Since the first American soldier died in Vietnam exactly five years ago, a total of 6,407 Americans have been killed in action, military spokesmen said today.
A United Nations agency has expressed interest in the possibility of making the old Metropolitan Opera House an international cultural center.
Miss Norris Ruan Luddy and Dillon Kent Herzer, students at Kentucky Wesleyan College, plan to be married next month.

The State Commissioner of investigation, Jacob Grumet, announced yesterday that he would conduct "an investigation of great magnitude" into the municipal hospital system and its affiliated voluntary hospitals.

A suit charging SCM Corporation with blocking competitors from selling supplies and replacement parts to users of SCM electrostatic-copying machines was filed in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by the Advanced Business Systems and Supply Company of Baltimore.

Sales of Massey Ferguson, Ltd., reached the highest point in the company's history in the final quarter and fiscal year ended Oct. 31. Earnings for the quarter declined but those for the year exceeded the level for fiscal 1965, the report disclosed yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 22 (AP) A United States District Court jury found three defendants guilty but was unable to reach a verdict on a fourth today in a smuggling conspiracy trial involving $2.5-million in marijuana.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the defending titleholder, maintained a one-point lead over his nearest rival, Larry Evans of Las Vegas, Nev., as a result of his eighth-round draw with William Addison of San Francisco in the 1966-67 United States chess championship Wednesday night. Fischer has scored six points, consisting of five victories and two draws, and has one materially even adjourned game with Evans.

The childish obstructionism with which a group of dissident parents and immature civil rights advocates "appointed" themselves as an insurgent Board of Education has come to an end, but not without toll.
MADELEINE BOULLENGER stirred a ragout de veau Provencale in a wellused heavy copper pot and said, "We do the best soup in the oldest pot."

CINCINNATI, Dec. 22 (AP) About 150 Negro teenagers are busily preparing placards for a march on the District 4 police station the day before Christmas for a Christmas party, with gifts, for the District's 83 policemen.

PARIS Perhaps the key to General de Gaulle's formulation of Asian policy is his conviction that China is fated to be a superpower and will then make claims against much of the world. He clearly does not foresee establishment of such a dynamic and demanding state for another thirty years, but he regards it as inevitable.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 22 (AP) A Dusseldorf record company has come out with just the thing for any German who wants to relive the heady days of Nazi victory.

Caribbean-Atlantic Airlines, Inc. (Caribair), the Puerto Ricobased carrier, has been granted new routes linking San Juan and the Virgin Islands with the islands of Martinique, Antigua, St. Lucia, Dominica, St. Vincent, Barbados, Grenada, and Trinidad, the Civil Aeronautics Board has announced.

An industrial plant designer was shot and critically wounded in the spine yesterday morning as he walked through a downtown subway arcade. He told the police he had never seen his assailant before. The gunman escaped down a nearby stairway.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) The House subcommittee investigating Representative Adam Clayton Powell will recommend criminal prosecution of the New York Democrat, a member of the unit predicted today.
The Board of Estimate, in effect, declared war yesterday on its chairman, Mayor Lindsay, and threatened to sue him in the controversy over an $84.3million subsidy for the Transit Authority.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 22 An organization of Indonesian women dealt a new blow to the waning prestige of President Sukarno today by canceling its planned commemoration of Mother's Day at the Presidential Palace.
SUNLAND, Calif., "What," a visitor said to Jess Willard, "are you going to do on your birthday?"
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 22 (UPI) Michigan's superior shooting and rebounding proved too much for Ohio University tonight as the Wolverines scored an 86-80 basketball victory.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 22 (UPI) Kentucky put forth its best defensive effort of the season tonight in a surprisingly easy 96-66 triumph over previously unbeaten Oregon State in the first round of the University of Kentucky invitation tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) I. Lee Potter, credited with having helped Republican successes in the South, was picked today to become chief of staff of the party's Congressional Campaign Committee.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 22 Prof. James Washington Bell, former chairman of the department of economics of Northwestern University and lecturer and writer on money and banking, died in Evanston Hospital yesterday. He was 76 years old.

POTOMAC, Md., Dec. 22 Miss Robin Diane Ladd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Daniel Ladd, was married this afternoon to Richard William McEntire, son of Capt. Paul William McEntire, U.S.N., and Mrs. McEntire of Portsmouth, R.I.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec 22 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has revived his plans for a goodwill tour of the United States, his associates said today.
New York City, which has never defaulted on its obligations since it was incorporated as a Dutch town in the mid1600's made good yesterday on a 1-cent shinplaster that was 152 years old.

MIAMI, Dec. 22 (AP)--The "heavy air" of South Florida was worrying Don Cockroft. The best college punter in the nation practiced today with the North team for the Shrine All-Star game in the Orange Bowl Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Twenty-four members of Congress have come to the aid of college Democrats who say their representative was banished from the office of the Democratic National Committee because of disagreement with the Administration's policy on Vietnam.
The Koppers Company, a Pittsburgh producer of tar products, announced yesterday the election of Douglas Grymes as executive vice president.

MACAO, Dec. 22 (AP) The Portuguese Governor of Macao is reported to have bowed to a Chinese Communist ultimatum today and to have sent two representatives to Canton with a promise that the colonial government would prohibit all Chinese Nationalist activities.

THE devastation of Florence by the rising waters of the Arno River was shown last night in by far the best documentary on the November disaster. The remarkable film was directed by Franco Zeffirelli and produced by RAI--Radio Television Italiana, the state-chartered television service of Italy.

The Museum of Modern Art has lost a brown manila envelope containing plans necessary for a forthcoming exhibition. It was left on the 5:51 New York Central train to Mamaroneck Wednesday evening by Irving Harper, a free-lance designer who is acting as consultant for the exhibition catalogue.

ONE of the oldest bridge organizations in the world is the College Clubs Bridge League, which is in its fortieth year. Six events are organized annually, with Manny Mason as director, a position he has held for 35 years. The other officers are: president, Lothar Klestadt of New York University; vice president, William Greenfield of Columbia; treasurer, James Carney of Yale; secretary, Bernard Lampert of Cornell; and tournament chairman, Harding Johnson of Princeton.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 22 The city of Norfolk appropriated $5-million this week as a first step toward becoming a containership port.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that the delinquency rate among girls in 1965 rose more than 1.6 times as fast as among boys.
The city's upstate reservoirs yesterday were reported to be at 63.9 per cent of capacity, with 304.4 billion gallons.

THE punchbowl will be filled with many potent concoc tions this holiday season, but none is more acceptable than the traditional eggnog. Here is a recipe for a rich, velvety eggnog spiked with bourbon and cognac.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Revenue freight traffic volume generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Dec. 17 were both ahead of the corresponding week of 1965.
ATHENS, Dec. 22 King Constantine set up an interim Government under Ioannis Paraskevopoulos today and asked it to prepare the country for general elections next May.
LONDON, Dec. 22 Unemployment in Britain went up again this month, but the rate of the rise may be slowing, the Government said today. The jobless total has increased each month since July.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 The Hughes administration has started looking away from the Great Swamp in Morris County to an area elsewhere in the county west of Morristown for a potential site for the for the metropolitan area's fourth jetport.

The Rev. Milton A. Galamison, leader of 12 demonstrators who were arrested Wednesday afternoon after a three-day sitin at the Board of Education headquarters, said yesterday that the group would seek a million names on a petition calling for the board's resignation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The long pause in the Soviet Union's manned space flights is explained by "strict economy" and preparations for ambitious new manned missions, a Czechoslovak correspondent has reported from Moscow.
DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP) A group of Detroit clergymen has invited draft-eligible youths to a seminar next Wednesday on how to avoid fighting in Vietnam.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 22 The engagement of Miss Enid Ford Jones to John Anthony McSherry, son of Mr. and Mrs. John McSherry of Brooklyn, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. William Ford Jones.

WHEN Cornell Green showed up at the Dal las Cowboys training camp in the summer of 1962, several of the other 26 freeagent rookies asked him what position he had played in college, Utah State. Green said "Forward."
Father Christmas stood at the top of the gangplank of the Queen Elizabeth yesterday afternoon with a cheery Christmas greeting for passengers bound on a five-day cruise to Nassau, the Bahamas.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 22 Alonzo F. Bonsal, since September the president of Joshua L.Baily Co., Inc., a selling agency for textile companies in North and South Carolina and in Georgia, died today at the Mountainside Hospital here. He was 71 years old and lived at 288 Upper Mountain Avenue in Upper Montcalir.

Moses Friedman is a lifelong admirer of the Irish and their ways. So when money problems began plaguing "Three Hand Reel," the trio of oneacters about Irish life based on stories by Frank O'Connor, he came forward with financial help and took over as producer.
MURRAY LOUIS, who offered a new program at the Henry Street Playhouse for the first time last week, repeated it last night. It was of mixed effectiveness.

Arts Management, a newsletter for administrators of arts programs that has been sold by subscription for five years, will be circulated free from now on. Its sponsorship is being taken over from arts organizations by the New York Board of Trade.
More than 18,000 persons filled Madison Square Garden last night for the second performance of the Hanukkah Festival, held under the auspices of the Israel Bond Organization.

Mr. and Mrs. John Hill Tyner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Deacon Tyner, to Lee Wallace Peck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Knowlton Peck. Both families are of New York and Cedarhurst, L.I.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (UPI) Lew Alcindor, a sophomore center, poured in 22 points in the second half tonight to lead No. 1-rated University of California, Los Angeles, to a hard-fought 84-74 victory over fired-up Colorado State at Pauley Pavilion.
A total of $960 in fines was assessed yesterday against the Knoxville and Nashville clubs and players for a series of brawls in their Eastern Hockey League game on Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that the last year had produced "no progress toward a just settlement" of the war in Vietnam and thus the threat of general war on the Asian mainland had increased.

ERWINNA, Pa., Dec. 22 Hickman Powell, newspaperman, author and former vice chairman of the New York State Power Authority, who retired to his Bucks County Farm here three years ago, died today in Hunterdon Medical Center, Flemington, N.J. He was 66 years old.

RIVERHEAD, L.I, Dec. 22 An 8-year-old girl's wish to celebrate Christmas was upheld in court here today, over the objections of her mother, a Jehovah's Witness who considers the traditional celebration of Christmas Day a pagan ritual.

A comedy sketch in which the participants drink to excess has caused the American Motors Corporation to reconsider whether it should sponsor a Sid Caesar television special The contract was signed several months ago with the Columbia Broadcasting System.
There seems to be no keeping the bond market down. Once again yesterday, bond prices and a few bill prices rose and some short-term interest rates were marked down.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 22 (AP) The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League today sent Rod Seiling, a defenseman, to their American Hockey League affiliate, the Baltimore Clippers.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 22 (UPI) A lighted cross was set up atop an unfinished hospital building today, ending a 24-hour strike by workmen who had built the Christmas decoration on their own time.
The city has started to move against 18 decrepit buildings under a new law aimed at identifying the true owners of slum housing and forcing them to repair their property.
