SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 22 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that, "willy nilly," Rhodesia had become a republic as a result of the United Nations Security Council's decision to impose mandatory sanctions against his country.
At Lincoln Center tonight; "Die Meistersinger," Metropolitan Opera, 7:15; An Evening of Indian Ragas, with Ravi Shankar, sitar player, and Alla Rakha, tabla player, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

Jacob Kinzler, retired women's coat and suit designer land manufacturer and a leader of Jewish organizations, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived at 146 Central Park West.

PETER SCHICKELE, whose infamous place in music history was assured when he became sole discoverer of the works of P.D.Q. Bach (18071742), came to Carnegie Hall for another evening of music by his favorite composer.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 The Center Theater Group, a new company that will perform in two theaters to be opened here in April, announced today its new director and its plans for the premiere season.
A tentative sign that demands for credit at the major New York City banks may be starting to ease a bit was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
ROME, Dec. 22 (Reuters) Following is the English text of Pope Paul's Christmas mes sage, issued by the Vatican today:
Five hundred members of the Women Strike for Peace organization marched down Fifth Avenue from 59th Street to 34th Street yesterday urging an end to the Vietnam war.

DUBLIN, Dec. 20 Both Roman Catholic and Protestant churchmen in Ireland have felt it necessary within the last week to reassure their followers that the new ecumenical spirit is not as radical as they may have been led to believe. The Rev. Canon P. Griffin, rector of Christ Church, Derry, for example, ad-...
Advertising aimed at the American military man and his family is apparently booming, and the way the media directed at them are multiplying is enough to make a media man's head spin.
The trend was firm on the London Stock Exchange yesterday although the approaching holidays dominated trading. Sellers were few and volume was low.
Pete Seeger's folk song concert at the Yorktown High School in Westchester County has been set for the evening of Feb. 2, Harold Leventhal, the singer's agent, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 22--The United States announced tonight that it was sending several million dollars worth of arms to Jordan to strengthen her defenses against Israel and to bolster the prestige of Kind Hussein in the Arab world.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Department of Defense has ordered the National Guard and the Reserves to fill manpower vacancies on a first-come, firstserved basis rather than a pickand-choose one.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 22 (AP) The Baltimore Colts announced today an adjustment in the price of tickets for the 1967 National Football League season, with the top pegged at $7.50.

Deliberately fouling Wilt Chamberlain, or some other notoriously poor foul-shooter, to gain an advantage from his probable miss at the free-throw line has been outlawed by the National Basketball Association.
ALBANY, Dec. 22--Governor Rockefeller announced today that he was appointing Vincent L. Tofany, Monroe County Republican chairman, as Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
Loan arrangements totaling $83-million for development projects in Chile and India were announced yesterday by the World Bank and the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 A leading House Republican has issued a needling invitation to Sargent Shriver to come back to Congress for more antipovrty funds if he believes he did not get enough.
TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 22 (AP) Darrell Mudra, coach of the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, was named head football coach of the University of Arizona today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 A spokesman for R. R. Donnelley Sons, Inc., the printers of Look magazine, said today that the edition new on the presses, which contains the first installment of the controversial serialization of "The Death of a President," would not have to be reprinted.
The First Boston Corporation, New York investment banker, announced yesterday the election of John H. Laeri Jr., Michael Palmer, Arthur R. Taylor and Cameron Thompson as vice presidents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) The Justice Department took a preliminary step yesterday toward what may be the first major Supreme Court test of the 1966 Bank-Merger Act.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 21 "There were many nights when one of us got beaten up on the campus," the Professor of Medicine at Central University said. "It got so that we stayed in the hospital after dark instead of going home."

MEMPHIS, Dec. 22 (AP) C. Arthur Bruce, a former lumber company executive and twice an unsuccessful candidate on the Republican ticket for Governor of Tennessee, died today at a hospital here. He was 83 years old.
The Biltmore's Grand Ballroom was the setting last evening for the Greensleeves Ball, at which 24 young women were presented.

MIAMI, Dec. 22 (AP) Jorge Velasquez, who returned from a five-day suspension last Tuesday, was back in stride at Tropcial Park today as he scored his third triple of the meeting. The 20-year-old Panamanian also has had a four-winner day and has an insurmountable lead in the Tropical Jockey standings.

The proxy battle for control of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., grew warmer yesterday with both factions announcing choices for directors. The management side disclosed that James H. Rowe Jr., a Washington lawyer, had been named to fill a vacancy on the board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The marriage of Miss Ruth Sharon Milner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Max Milner of Rockville, Md., and Scarsdale, N.Y., to Charles Jay Smiler took place here tonight. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Smiler of Scarsdale.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Littman of 320 Central Park West of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Lynn Littman, to Robert B. Ritter, son of Mrs. Saul Ritter of New York and the late Mr. Ritter.

Orville S. Carpenter, trustee for the Westec Corporation, said yesterday that the concern had run a $2.6-million deficit in the eight months ended Aug. 31, and recommended that it be "combined with another corporation possessing strong financial resources."

SANTA CLAUS is working at a feverish pace to pack his sled with goodies be fore winging down from the North Pole tomorrow night. In case the jolly old elf needs any suggestions as to what gifts he should bring the shiny-eyed little rascals in the world of sports, here are some that might be welcome.
Long Island University stayed off a final 10-minute rally by Iona to register a 57-55 victory over the Gaels in a Met conference game last night at Mount St. Michael High School in the Bronx.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 22 warren J. Heldman, a former president of the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers, died here last night at the age of 74.
The Securities and Exchange Commission's recent report on mutual funds recommends new statutory standards of "reasonableness" for payments to fund advisers engaged in managing other people's money.
NAKHON Phanom, Thailand, Dec. 21 Explosions occasionally rattle the windows of this bustling town across the muddy Mekong from Laos. United States and Thai military aircraft drone high overhead.

POUND RIDGE, N. Y., Dec. 22--Mrs. Dorothy Goldeen Nathan, a writer of children's stories, died today at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. She and her husband, Paul S. Nathan, science editor of the National Cystic Fibrosis Research Foundation, lived here.

Harper Row, Publishers, Inc., said last night that the chances "looked good" that its dispute with Mrs. John F. Kennedy would be settled out of court. However, neither Harper Row nor the negotiators for Mrs. Kennedy said a settlement was imminent. There were indications that it was slightly more difficult than had been expected.
Christmas sales results will be in doubt right down to the wire because of a continuing erratic buying pattern by consumers around the country.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 22 M.Edward Ryan, international vice president of the Sheet Metal Workers Union, died last night at St. Peter's Hospital in New Brunswick after a brief illness. He was 59 years old and lived in Milltown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Dr. Albert Victor Hugo Masket, research physicist and consultant to the division of mechanics of the United States Naval Research Laboratory, died Monday at the Holy Cross Hospital. He was 52 years old.
The Libbey Owens Ford Glass Company announced yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, the election of Robert C. Wingerter as president, effective April 18:
NEW DELHI, Dec. 22 V. K. Krishna Menon resigned today from India's governing Congress party.
JODRELL BANK, England, Dec. 22 (AP)--The Jodrell Bank Observatory picked up radio signals tonight from Luna 13 and forcast that the unmanned spacecraft would reach the moon Saturday.

MIAMI, Dec. 22 (AP) A Federal judge, Emett C. Choate, who said the Supreme Court had "already stretched the law far enough," has refused to free a convicted murderer though the defendant was not represented by a lawyer when he pleaded guilty in 1940.
LONDON, Dec. 22--Earl Mountbatten, appointed two months ago to head an urgent independent inquiry into prison escapes and security, reported today that "there is no really secure prison" in Britain.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec.22 (AP) The Federal Government has asked dismissal of a suit challenging aid to parochial schools on the ground that the group that filed the suit has no legal involvement.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 102.4 on Wednesday from 102.8 on Tuesday.

Once again the Russian courts have shown that they can be Draconian in dealing with minor offenses by Americans. In this case the victims were two young men, Buel Ray Wortham and Craddock Gilmour Jr., who changed a small sum of money illegally and, in an obvious prank, stole a statue of a bear from a Leningrad hotel.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 22 The Constituent Assembly decided today that South Vietnam should have an independent judiciary, but deferred drafting language for the new constitution.
State Senator-elect Ivan L. Warner testified yesterday that he was present when State Senator elect Eugene Rodriguez proposed to "fix" a narcotics case for $100,000.
BONN, Dec. 22 Two courts disagreed today about the status of several tons of currency printed in Munich for the regime of Ian D. Smith in Salisbury.

The extent to which moviegoing habits are being changed was dramatized here Wednesday night with the opening of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Grand Prix" at the Warner Cinerama Theater bringing to a record high of seven the number of reserved-seat films playing at one time in Manhattan.

DETROIT, Dec. 22 The American Motors Corporation revealed today it had used up nearly all of a $75-million loan established last May amid speculation that it was discussing a possible merger with Litton Industries, Inc.

One out of every five pupils in the city's elementary and junior high schools last spring was behind two years or more in reading, according to test results made public yesterday by the Board of Education.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved higher yesterday for the second consecutive session.
Fred J. Borch, president of the General Electric Company, added his name yesterday to the growing list of top business executives who see a slowdown in the econemy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Government has revised downward slightly its figure for corporate profits in the third quarter, making more clear than ever that profits stopped rising after the first quarter of this year.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 22 Athletes of 17 countries packed their baks for the long trip home today after the fifth Asian Games ended Tuesday night with a dazzling display of fireworks and singing of "Auld Lang Syne" in the torch-lighted national stadium. The games were marred by riots, death and charges of disorganization.
Twenty neighborhood residents surged into St. Francis Hospital in the South Bronx yesterday and smashed a gate lock to let two doctors treat patients in the hospital's emergency room.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) The 90th Congress is determined to trim the Great Society programs before approving a tax increase a poll indicates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) The State Department said today that it was almost certain that no United States bombs had struck civilian areas of Hanoi during recent raids, but that if they accidentally did, the United States regretted it.

CONAKRY, Guinea, Dec. 16 Less than six weeks ago, every American in this hot and humid seacoast capital was under house arrest and many whiled away the time wondering what to pack and what could be left behind.

The first major order for American-flag tankers for an independent (non-oil company controlled) shipowner since the Suez crisis of 1956 has been placed by Maritime Overseas Corporation with Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

During 47 years of trading in Asiatic and pre-Columbian art, Nasli Heeramaneck has hidden the things he liked best from the prying eyes of customers. Passing up important sales prospects, he has kept superb examples of Buddha heads, Persian miniatures, Indian temple carvings, Mayan pottery and sculpture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The United States announced the allocation of 900,000 tons of food grains worth more than $53-million to India today as an emergency measure.
Legalized betting on horse racing in the United States soared to a record $4.654-billion in 1966. This despite a statement by a leading track official that "racing's economic picture is not good."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower will spend Christmas at Walter Reed Army Medical Center even though his recovery from a gall bladder operartion has been "excellent."
Five of the season's debutantes, having made their formal bows to society at masspresentation balls here, were honored at private parties last night.
Stock prices advanced yesterday for the second session in a row. The trading pace on the New York Stock Exchange was more active then the day before.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 (UPI) Grateful Americans offered a final resting place today to a United States soldier, killed on patrol in Vietnam, whose body lies unclaimed and unmourned in an Army depot.
The Legislature's 15 Reform Democrats announced yesterday that they would push for court and legislative reforms, some of which would curtail the patronage powers enjoyed by their own party leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 A legal move to block the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the American Broadcasting Companies was initiated today. Congressional criticism of yesterday's action by the Federal Communications Commission approving the merger continued meanwhile.
Consumption of newsprint in this country set records for November and for the first 11 months of 1966.
MADRID, Dec.22 About $50-million was distributed throughout Spain today in the country's biggest Christmas lottery drawing.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec 22 Independent analysts of the war suggested tonight that the two enemy planes shot down Tuesday might have been dropping flares in an attempt to foil an allied commando landing on the coast of North Vietnam.
Cocoa traders kept their thought yesterday on the second consecutive downturn in Ghana's weekly cocoa purchases from growers.

Two armed men forced the owner of a check-cashing service into a doorway on Ninth Avenue near 33d Street yesterday afternoon, handcuffed him, struck him on the face with a pistol and robbed him of $21,150 that he had just picked up at a bank.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 A United States Court of Appeals granted a further delay today in a back-to-work order against striking steelworkers at a Union Carbide Corporation defense plant in Indiana.
LANSING, Mich., Dec. 22 (AP) A Negro defendant in a criminal case has no right to demand a jury that is friendly to Negroes, the Michigan Court of Appeals said today.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 22 (AP) Vanderbilt University announced today that it planned to spend $200-million in the next 20 years to expand its medical facilities. This will include construction of a 20-story hospital.

A crap game in the interest of "science" benefited The New York Times Neediest Fund yesterday by $5.26.
An increase this year in both occupancy rates and gross income for the 66,600 hotels and motels throughout the country is indicated in a study by the American Hotel and Motel Association.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 22 (UPI) President Johnson put in a routine work day at his ranch today and joined in a celebration of his wife's 54th birthday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 22 Richard Krementz, former president and chairman of the board of Krementz Company, a jewelry manufacturing concern in Newark, died last night at his home, 755 Salem Avenue. He was 89 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) William P. Durkee is resigning as the nation's civil defense chief effective next Jan. 1, a Pentagon spokesman said today.
The nation's automobile manufacturers announced yesterday the best 10-day selling period for new cars in more than two months.

ATHENS, Dec. 22 "The task I have shouldered is an onerous one," Greece's new Premier said today. "But I believe that no one has a right to refuse his services to his country." The Premier, Ioannis Paraskevopoulos (pronounced Pahr-ask-ay-voo-POO-los) has never refused.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 22 Bumper crops are predicted for Brazil's central granary states this year and food prices are beginning to drop.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Sargent Shriver and his family had an unscheduled visit from Christmas carolers last night that was not entirely in the spirit of the season.
HOUSTON, Dec. 22 (AP)--The Manned Spacecraft Center announced today the prime and backup crews for the second and third manned Apollo space flights scheduled for 1967.
ROME, Dec. 22--Pope Paul said today that the resumption of diplomatic relations with Yugoslavia would richly benefit the people of that country.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP) A wingless manned dart possibly the shape of things to come in space travel spiraled down from the sky today to a successful 200-mile-an-hour landing.
Angel Rafael Luna returns to his Puerto Rican birthplace next week, seven years after leaving, seven months after his Army induction and one week after his death.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) Automobile exhausts may be an important factor in changing the climate, according to a scientist at the State University of New York in Albany.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (UPI) How much is $7.2-million? "Next to nothing," the Soviet press agency Tass said tonight in a dispatch indicating Russia is sorry it sold Alaska to the United States for that amount.

Mr. and Mrs. Jules B. Travers of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Elaine Travers, to Jeffrey A. Barist, son of Mrs. Irving Barist of Jersey City, and the late Mr. Barist.

MANILA, Dec. 22 Mayor Antonio Villegas confirmed today that he would not renew permits for American companies in Manila to engage in retail business when they expire Dec. 31. He denied that the action was inspired by anti-Americanism.

LONDON, Dec. 22 The chairman of the London Stock Exchange, Martin Wilkinson, said today he was satisfied that there had been no irregularities in recent heavy dealings in shares of Pye of Combridge, Ltd.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Ernest Wildhaber of Roch ester, a leading inventor of gears and the tools for making them, received his 300th United States patent this week.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Dec. 23 (AP) The sole survivor after the ore carrier Daniel J. Morrell sank in Lake Huron Nov. 29 with a loss of 28 lives said today that the freighter "was always leaking and always had to be pumped out" during the three years he served on her.
Verdi's "II Trovatore" will have its first Metropolitan Opera performance this season Jan. 25. Francesco MolinariPradelli will conduct it for the first time at the Met.
Mrs. George R. Wilson, a church worker and writer, died Thursday in Pomona, Calif., at the age of 84.

Not even a bad case of the flu could keep Danny Thomas away from the phone yesterday when he learned the call was about his new television series, scheduled for next fall on the National Broadcasting Company.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 23 (AP) The establishment of a permanent trophy for winners of baseball's triple crown of batting was announced today by the National Brewing Company.
TORONTO, Dec. 23 Canada is facing a potential housing shortage, and economic, political and social voices are calling for Government relief.
A new controversy involving Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem has arisen, this time over the location of a school playground across the street from the red-brick, windowless building.

PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif., Dec. 23--Miss Wynn Meagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Meagher of Portland, Ore., was married here today to Kendall W. DeBevoise, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kendall B. DeBevoise of Montclair, N.J.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 23 (AP) Vince Lombardi, the head coach of the Green Bay Packers, said today that his defending National Football League champions were keeping warm in preparation for their Jan. 1 title game against the Cowboys at Dallas.
The rise in interest rates for mortgages slowed in November, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday. It suggested that they might not rise much more.
BONN, Dec. 23 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger asked the nations of the world today to renew their trust in Germany and the German people.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 23 (UPI) An electrical short circuit in a tiny heat-sensing device canceled last night's static test-firing of the Saturn 5 moon rocket's second stage, a space agency official said today.

AS THE NEW York Knickerbockers continue to flounder, having lost to the last-place teams in each division in their last two road games while just barely beating the St. Louis Hawks in their last home game, some fairly simple arithmetic sheds light on their problems.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23 (AP) The chairman and directors of Intra Bank are being called in by Lebanon's Attorney General for interrogation in connection with the bank's closing two months ago, an authorized Government source announced today.
ORONO, Me., Dec. 23 (AP) Harold Westerman, 49 years old, quit as the University of Maine football coach today.
TRENTON, Dec. 23 Anyone who drives a car with the owner's permission is protected by the owner's automobile liability insurance, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) The Boston Celtics, sparked by the defense and shooting of Bailey Howell, Sam Jones and John Havlicek, gained a 114-103 victory over the St. Louis Hawks tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 23 (UPI) The Springfield Indians, playing without four key men and recovering from a recent players' strike, posted a 9-3 victory over Providence tonight in an American Hockey League game.
DETROIT, Dec. 23 (AP) Auto production slipped to an estimated 164,997 cars this week because of the Christmas holidays.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga, refusing to bow to a Congolese Government demand to shift headquarters from Brussels to Kinshasa, the capital of the Congo, was faced today with what it considered to be the "outright expropriation" of its assets.
BUFFALO, Dec. 23 (AP) The Buffalo Bills of the American Football League confirmed today they had signed Dick Cunningham, an Arkansas tackle, but denied he would be paid approximately $200,000.

The stock market lost ground slightly yesterday after showing a burst of strength early in the session. A few more stocks declined than advanced on the New York Stock Exchange. Most leading averages closed a bit lower than the day before.
City Controller Mario A. Procaccino has refused to pay between $400 and $500 in bills submitted by Mayor Lindsay's office for expenses at the Mayor's Little City Halls.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 23 (UPI) Twelve University of Illinois athletes were suspended from competition indefinitely today for receiving illegal financial aid. The basketball coach, Harry Combes, and the football coach, Pete Elliott, were placed on probation for one year.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (AP) Erich Barnes, a defensive back, was fined $250 and Walter Roberts, a halfback, $50 by the Cleveland Browns today on orders of Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, because of a fracas in last Saturday's game in St. Louis.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Dec. 23 (UPI) Joseph Kennedy, the 14-year-old son of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, suffered a broken leg while the family was skiing this afternoon. The boy was taken to the Sun Valley Hospital.

Seven women, crying unashamedly and carrying blankets, coffee pots and shopping bags, ended a week-long sit-in yesterday at the mid-Manhattan offices of the Hospital Review and Planning Council of Southern New York.

HONG KONG, Dec. 23 For more than seven months during China's "cultural revolution" education in the universities for many secondary-school students has been suspended. Such education may not resume until next fall.

Mr. Seeger deals a lot in themes of brotherhood and peace and love slogans and sentiments that he manages to keep going most of the year, even if much of the world does not.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 24 (Reuters)--Five men escaped from a British prison last night, bringing to 13 the total of escapees since an official report Thursday said no British prison was really secure.

THE most generous Christmas present that the Rev. Dr. Stephen F. Olford will probably receive this year was opened early when the minister put his key in the lock of the new parsonage back in September.

Prices of wheat and soybean futures tumbled yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade on news of a somewhat higher production forecast for the two important crops.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (UPI) The University of California, Los Angeles, the No. 1 rated basketball team, roared off to a big early lead and then coasted to an easy 96-67 victory over Notre Dame tonight in Pauley Pavillion.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 23 (UPI) Kentucky survived a second-half rush by Kansas State tonight to win its invitation tournament, 83-79.

LISTENING to Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" last night the first two acts, anyway was, as always, one of the supreme pleasures music has to offer. Of all the Wagner operas, this is the most human, the only one that has charm. When Pogner sings the "Johannistag," or Sachs the "Fledermonolog," any body who knows the opera achieves a kind of identification with living, breathing humans.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 23 Ruth Reeves, an American artist known as an authority on Indian handicrafts, died here today. She was 74 years old.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 23 Miss Sandra Janney Sayen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Sayen 3d, was married this afternoon to Ebenhard Mathias Rosenblad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Curt F. Rosenblad.
Mayor Lindsay is moving with vigor and courage toward amelioration of the twin problems of traffic and dirt in New York.
IZMIR, Turkey, Dec. 23 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin summed up informally in a visit to a textile factory here today the purpose of his official visit to Turkey.

Miss Esther Rosemary Gardner Klein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Klein of Manhattan, was married here yesterday afternoon to Weston Arnold Fisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Weston C. Fisher of Menlo Park, Calif.
One day before Christmas, a surge of gifts from 968 donors has added $49,218.52 to the 55th annual Christmastime appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
A "snow happening" in Central Park-provided there is at least some snow will be the Parks Department's Christmas gift to New Yorkers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) About 8,600 Job Corpsmen are making free trips home for Christmas at a cost to the taxpayer of about $l.1-million.

A 69-year-old international confidence man, who has always had a penchant for elegant living, liquor and race horses, asked for leniency yesterday in Federal Court, saying: "I know I deserve a stiff sentence, but I don't want to die in jail."
The spot rate on the British pound was mostly steady at $2.7893 in quiet traing on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

The Republican leadership in the House of Representatives has reportedly reached a decision not to seek an increase in the party's share of seats on the Rules Committee. If this report is confirmed by events, it will be a small but encouraging step toward strengthening the central leadership of the House.
SADEC, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 Sadec Province regained its "independence" today amid French champagne, official speeches, brass bands and parachute jumps.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today lower freight rates on paper and paper products for export through the Port of Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (UPI) Dayton staved off repeated Loyola rallies tonight and beat the Ramblers, 100-90, after Illinois earned a 97-87 overtime victory over California in a Chicago Stadium double-header.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week on an uptick yesterday. The market made its third consecutive advance.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 American troops have been assigned for the first time to the defense of Giadinh Province, which surrounds the Saigon capital dis- trict. Each of several United States battalions of about 800 men is operating in close cooperation with a battalion of South Vietnamese Rangers and paratroopers assigned to the mission by Premier Nguyen Cao Ky from his reserve of elite troops stationed in the capital.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Dec. 23 (AP) Two detectives arrested Roy Cohn, the New York lawyer, and a companion yesterday morning for walking downtown in swimming trunks, but the detectives wound up facing charges in court.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) A new translation of a 900year-old Hebrew document has shifted from the north to the south of France the site of a massacre of Jews by a French army of the first crusade.
Isaac Stern has been chosen by Mayor Lindsay to present the city's Handel medallion to Pablo Casals next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The United States announced today an allocation of 500,000 tons of grain to help Pakistan meet her food needs until the April harvest. The shipments will start next month.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 23 (AP) Gov. Reberto Sanchez Vilella signed a bill tonight calling a plebiscite on the future of Puerto Rico's ties to the United States.
New York State's eight harness horse racing tracks will offer 786 nights (and some days) of trotting and pacing races during 1967.

BONN, Dec. 23 The editorin-chief of West Germany's illustrated magazine Stern said today he would ignore demands by Look magazine and begin serializing the original text of "The Death of a President" Jan. 15.
A train was derailed, two store windows were broken and a woman pedestrian was grazed by a piece of falling metal in an IRT accident in the Bronx yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 23 (Reuters)--Philips announced today that it planned to make a new offer to Pye of Cambridge shareholders of not less than $1.68 a share. The offer will be made as soon as possible after Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) A $10-million Alliance for Progress loan to the Dominican Republic for economic and social development projects was announced today by the Agency for International Development. It will finance school construction, agricultural improvement centers, irrigation systems, public health clinics, water and sewerage services and road construction.

Gerald W. Eskow, former president of the bankrupt Yale Express System, Inc., donated 800,000 shares, worth $500,000, yesterday to 800 of the company's employes. The stock was worth $13-million three years ago.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 23 "Are you a believer?" Ed Donohue, the Niagara University freshman basketball coach, has been asking that question after each of his team's games this season. The question has been directed primarily to firsttime viewers and the reply invariably is "Yes."
WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 23 (UPI) Wichita State University will name Boyd Converse, who never saw a football game until he went to college, as its new head football coach tomorrow.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 22--Secret ordinations of Roman Catholic priests are being conducted in North Vietnam, according to the Rev. Joseph Duc Minh, director of the Secretariat for Vietnamese Missions and a native of North Vietnam.
The National Council of Churches urged its members yesterday to "take extraordinary steps at this Christmas season" to support President Johnson's "cease-fire negotiations in Vietnam."
Bobby Burnett of Buffalo and Babe Parilli of Boston were named yesterday the winners of American Football League polls conducted by the Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The Treasury bill rate continued its downward course at today's auction, falling to levels not seen for six months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The Federal Trade Commission published today a proposed set of rules that would tighten installment sales practices and curb advertising.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 23 Indian officials welcomed today the long-delayed interim foodfor-peace agreement with the United States, but reliable sources said privately that the delay had already made inevitable a slowdown of grain supplies early next year.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 23 The White House announced today the promotion of Lawrence E. Levinson, a lawyer, to the post of deputy special assistant to the President.
MARIETTA, Ohio, Dec. 23 (AP) The Mid-American Collegiate Rowing Association announced preliminary plans today for the biggest rowing regatta held here since 1951.
MIAMI, Dec. 23 (AP) Seven men were convicted of swindling nearly 2,000 investors out of $9.5-million.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 24 A 48-hour Christmas cease-fire in the Vietnam war went into effect today at 7 A.M. (6 P.M. Friday, New York time).

JERUSALEM (Jordan), Dec. 23 Jordan named a tough East Jordanian yesterday as Interior Minister and an amiable professional diplomat as Foreign Minister to cope with this country's unruly western areas and her unfriendly radical Arab neighbors.

For four years Sandra Laing attended boarding school at Piet Retief in South Africa. Eight months ago she was sent home and the principal told her father: "I'm sorry, but she can't remiain at the school. She's been classified as colored."
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 23 Dr. Bart M. James, a dermatologist, died yesterday in his home at 3 Elizabeth Road. He was 73 years old. His office, was in East Orange.

Charges that the Maritime Administration used "reprehensible" procedures in allocating subsidies to United States-flag lines have been denied by the head of the agency and a steamship line representative.
DALLAS, Dec. 23 (AP)-- Braniff International said today the Federal Mediation Board had ordered the airline and its baggage handlers to resume negotiations toward a new contract on Dec. 27.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 23 Recovering from serious declines in trade suffered at the beginning of the year, the Port of Milwaukee has ended the season with international cargo movements only slightly below the record year.

WARSAW, Dec. 23 The Christmas tree made of plastic stands in the C.D.T. department store, its branches spaced too regularly to look real. Eren more unreal is its price tag 1,800 zlotys, a month's pay for the average Pole.

Antique music boxes, saxophones, a string quartet and the human voice will all have their contribution to make tonight as Protestant, Roman Catholic and Orthodox churches throughout the city hold traditional Christmas Eve services.

PARIS, Dec. 23 Former Gen. Maurice Challe, one of the leaders of the unsuccessful military revolt at Algiers in 1961, was freed from prison today under a Christmas pardon granted by President de Gaulle.
Former Controller Abraham D. Beame denied yesterday that he had been derelict in the auditing of municipal hospital affiliation contracts with voluntary hospitals.

TORONTO, Dec. 23 A Toronto welfare organization believes it has made significant social progress by promoting the adoption of 70 Negro children by white parents in the last three years. In the same period, 23 Negro children were placed in Negro homes.

The Grand Ballroom of the St. George in Brooklyn was the setting last night for the 48th annual Yuletide Ball, at which eight young women were presented. The event was a benefit for the Brooklyn Kindergarten Society, now 75 years old.

"A Joyful Noise," the musical by Edward Padula, Oscar Brand and Paul Nassau taken from Borden Deal's. "The Insolent Breed," will close after tonight's performance, its 12th, at the Mark Hellinger Theater. The show represents an investment and total loss of $540,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP) A man who said he was once in an orphanage with Sgt. Richard F. Campos offered to claim his body for burial today but the Army said it could not release the body to him.
NEWARK, Dec. 23 Dr. Seymour Charles, president of Physicians for Automotive Safety, charged the automobile industry today with a "desperate attempt to scuttle" the Federal auto safety program.
Forty persons were forced to the street yesterday when a two-alarm fire broke out in a Harlem tenement and spread to an adjoining building.
Shortly after midnight tonight someone in the Charles Poulos family of Brooklyn will bite into a piece of bread, strike his teeth on a silver coin and cry, "I found it."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 Cardinal Spellman arrived today for his 21st Christmas overseas with American service men.

William J. Ronan, who at the age of 91 was the oldest member of the American Stock Exchange, died Thursday in the College Nursing Home at 11915 27th Avenue in Flushing, Queens. He had lived until recently at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.
AS soon as you get a chance, you should see the Mu seum of Modern Art's new exhibition, "The Taste of a Connoisseur," which opened Wednesday.

The proposed merger between the East New York Savings Bank in Brooklyn and the Manhattan Savings Bank was abruptly called off yesterday only three weeks before the New York State Banking Department was scheduled to rule on the proposal.

For an opera performance in which the casting is ideal, the singers are invariably in good voice and the fantasy is always believable, try the Salzburg Marionette Theater's production of Mozart's "The Magic Flute," which will be on view at Town Hall nightly from Monday through Saturday.
When he was an undergraduate at the University of Michigan, along with his bride-to-be; who was a classmate, Charles David Breitel aspired to be a professor of philosophy.
MARION, Mass., Dec. 23 Dr. Frederick B. Chandler, widely known for his cranberry research work, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 63 years old.
The Port of New York Authority awarded a 4,440,- 716 contract yesterday for adding 23 acres to lower Manhattan by dumping earth and rock from the World Trade Center site into the Hudson River.

MANILA Dec. 23 (Reuters) The Manila city government canceled the retail trading license today of a Filipino-American group the first such action in Mayor Antonio J. Villegas's campaign to exclude foreign companies from retail trade in the city.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 102.6 on Thursday from 102.5 on Wednesday.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 23 The marriage of Miss Suzanne Leggett Dyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel L. Dyer to Joseph Painter Nye Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nye, took place here this afternoon in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.
GLYNDON, Md., Dec. 23 (AP) Brig. Gen. James P.S. Devereux, retired, leaned back in his chair at his Worthington Valley horse farm and remembered another December in another part of the word.
BONN, Dec. 23 The gifts beneath West Germany's tannenbaums will be a little smaller this Christmas.

Shares of American Motors Corporation boiled upward in vigorous trading yesterday despite official denials of rumors that the company might be a merger candidate for acquisition-minded Litton Industries.

OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 23 The warden of Sing Sing prison, Wilfred Louis Denno, will retire Jan. 12 after 40 years of working in the state's prisons, the last 16 years as chief of the tightest ship on the Hudson.

Prices were steady on institutional and public buying at the close on the London Stock Exchange yesterday in very light pre-Christmas trading. Dealers reported institutional buying of British Government bonds and common stocks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The United Steelworkers of America directed strikers tonight to return to work at a Union Carbide defense plant in Indiana under a courtordered Taft-Hartley injunction.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Dec. 23 The Congolese Government announced today the creation of a new company to succeed the Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga. The Congo also declared that as of today it had stopped all mineral exports from the province of Katanga, and called for all workers, including foreign technicians, to continue working normally.

Unseasonably warm weather in much of the country held down the sales growth of the nation's leading chainstore organizations during November. yesterday by The New York Times disclosed that the volume of 31 chains and mail order houses rose 7.5 per cent in the month to $2,398,928,439 from a revised $2,231,423,657 in November, 1965.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 21.8 per cent in production for the week ended Dec. 17, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) An American lawyer charged today that two young Americans had been compelled by Soviet secret police to furnish testimony that led to their conviction of crimes. He is the father of one of the young men.
Mayor Lindsay went directly to the Legislature yesterday to get a man to help lift his 1967 legislative program over the Albany hurdles.
With the help of a harried Bronx housewife, the city's Planning Commission and an article in The New York Times, the Museum of Modern Art closed. The Case of the Missing Manila Envelope yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Imports of inexpensive pig iron from several Communist countries and from Rhodesia are hampering Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson's beautification program, the domestic scrap industry charged today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) The Atlas-Centaur rocket will replace the longused Atlas-Agena for launching a series of scientific satelites starting in 1968, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

BERLIN, Dec. 23 Diplomats in East Berlin said today that East Germany was seeking support in the Communist bloc for a policy that would make an improvement of relations between West Germany and Eastern Europe dependent on de facto recognition of East Germany.

A woman fell to the tracks in a Brooklyn subway station yesterday, and as Mrs. Gloria Giarraffa tried to raise her she cried for help. One girl out of more than 30 persons on the platform came to her aid.
MERIDEN, Conn., Dec. 23 (AP) Wayne C. Smith, publisher of The Meriden Journal and The Morning Record, died today at Meriden Hospital. He was 78 years old.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 23(AP) Four American women arrived in Hanoi today to meet with North Vietnamese leaders, the husband of one of the women said today.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 23 (AP) The weather has brought the Kansas City Chiefs some of the snow and cold they expect to find in Buffalo when they play the Bills for the American Football League championship on Jan. 1.

Bond dealers wouldn't have predicted it several months ago, but they've had a Christmas season they can be jolly about. Most prices continued to rise yesterday as trading activity shut down early for the long holiday weekend.

RIFTON, N.Y., Dec. 23 "In the Rip Van Winkle foothills of the Catskills here the people are sleeping on a gold mine and they won't stoop over to pick up the nuggets!"

ALBANY, Dec. 23 Two Swedish men and a former Oklahoma beauty contest winner are among five convicts whose prison sentences have been commuted by Governor Rockefeller. All will be eligible for parole next month.

Disclosure of pupils' reading scores for all the elementary and junior high schools of New York City constitutes a landmark in the drive for educational reform. In the past, a veil of secrecy condemned successful schools to anonymity and thereby protected less creditable performances elsewhere.

MIAMI, Dec. 23 (AP) Seven officials of the now-defunct American Bonded Mortgage Company were found guilty today of 12 counts of securities fraud.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 25--Robert E. Witschey, a former president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and senior partner and founder of the accounting firm of Witschey-HarmanWhite died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.
When 10 of the 11 members of the James J. Lynch family of Wantagh, L.I. sat down to Christmas dinner last night, they needed a custommade, football-training-campstyle table to accommodate them.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 26 (AP)--The North Vietnamese press agency said today that more than 10 flights of United States planes had "repeatedly bombed and strafed" populated parts of Communist-controlled areas of Laos on Christmas Day.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 25 --Mr. and Mrs. John L. Cameron have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kate Wyatt Cameron, to Newell Flather, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Rogers Flather of Lowell, Mass. The couple plan to be married next month.

LLANO, Tex., Dec. 22--Earlier this month on State Highway 71 about 18 miles southeast of here, workmen put the finishing touches on a 10-foot-tall sign with a picture of a red steer on it. The sign, inside a fenced pasture, read: LBJ Ranch, Registered Herefords.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Dec. 25--Two hundred American marines and soldiers spent Christmas Day searching for the bodies of South Vietnamese killed when a cargo plane plowed through their hamlet last night.

The day is long past when the United States could muster big majorities at will for its policies and proposals in the United Nations General Assembly. It was passing even while Henry Cabot Lodge was ramming through the "victories" over Russia of which the Republicans boasted in the 1960 election.

WARSAW, Dec. 25--The first thing a customer sees on entering the high-vaulted marble central hall--the very model of a turn-of-the-century European bank--is the counter that displays household detergents, terramycin antibiotic, feed supplement for cattle and poultry, motor oil and portable radios.

ROSENDALE, N.Y., Dec. 25 --A network of manmade caves here that have been used for mushroom cultivation are being transformed into subterranean sanctuaries to store securities, documents and works of art.

CONISTON LAKE, England, Dec. 25 (UPI)--Donald Campbell of Britain, waiting for seven weeks for the "right kind of weather" to break his world water-speed record, got the near-perfect weather today. But he had no time keepers to make a record attempt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) --Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, expressed doubt today that the United States was trying as hard as it should to achieve peace talks in Vietnam.

NEITHER wind, nor freeze nor citywide snow emergency could stay Alexander Schneider from his appointed musical rounds. For the 12th consecutive year, the violinist and conductor presided over a midnight Christmas Eve concert, and, despite the weather, Carnegie Hall was filled almost to capacity.
