In Belle Harbor, Queens, yesterday did not seem much like a second day of Christmas. It was the day after the fire that took the lives of three children of a widow on Christmas morning and robbed four families of their dwellings and virtually everything they owned.

A free clinic, sponsored by the Committee to Save St. Francis Hospital, will open Wednesday in a five-room apartment two blocks away from the South Bronx hospital. The Roman Catholic hospital is scheduled to close Saturday, despite energetic protests by the committee, including sit-ins and a break-in.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 In some areas of the United States air pollution is already a greater hazard to agriculture than weather or insect pests, specialists said today.

SAKONNAKHON, Thailand, Dec. 20 With men, money and advice, the United States has joined Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn's regime in a variety of new civic action programs designed to offset Communist promises and propaganda in northeast Thailand.
MOSCOW, Dec. 26 (AP) Unloading of Communist supplies in North Vietnam's Haiphong harbor has been speeded up and Soviet seamen are helping unload their own ships, Pravda reported today.
JERUSALEM, Israel, Dec. 26 (UPI) The Jordanian radio, quoting reports from Lebanon, said today that the Syrian Defense Minister, Gen. Hafez Assad, had escaped death in an assassination attempt.

The city's Department of Air Pollution Control will move to the Cooper Union School of Engineering next year in what is believed to be the country's first limited merger of an operating governmental agency and a college.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) Five convicts scrambled over a 30-foot stone wall at Dartmoor Prison today and vanished into the darkening mists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 The Johnson Administration is seriously considering a compromise decision on the Nike-X antimissile system that potentially could mollify both those who favor and those who oppose a quick deployment of such a system.
Twelve religious leaders told President Johnson yesterday that the nation was losing confidence in him because of the intensifying of the war in Vietnam and bombing of civilians.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26 Troops prevented nearly 4,000 longshoremen from entering the port of Buenos Aires today despite the end of a 70-day strike.
BONN, Dec. 27 West Germany's Justice Ministry confirmed today that Bonn had exchanged a spy for a woman journalist held prisoner by the Soviet Union and three unidentified men held by East Germany.

BALDWIN, Wis., Dec. 27 (AP) An Administrator from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and four students were killed today when the car in which they were riding struck a concrete abutment on the median strip of Interstate 94.
HONG KONG, Dec. 27(Reuters) Communist China tonight criticized an exchange of Christmas greetings between an American warship and a Soviet trawler off the coast of North Vietnam yesterday.
A temporary truce was reached yesterday between representatives of the Kennedy family and Harper Row in the legal battle over the contents of William Manchester's book "The Death of a President."

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 27 (AP) This community wants New York State to de-escalate a form of border war in which the weapons are speed-limit signs on a roadway winding back and forth between Connecticut and New York.

WE all know, more or less, what happened in the American colonies in the year 1775. There were Lexington and Concord, the Second Continental Congress, the gatherings of colonists, muskets in hand, the appointment of George Washington as Commander in Chief.
Members of the Social Service Employes Union voted last night to extent their contract until Jan. 15 so their leaders can continue negotiations on a new agreement with the city's Welfare Department.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Wednesday, Dec. 28 (Reuters) The Government of Lesotho former British colony of Basutoland has placed King Moshoeshoe II under house arrest, the South African radio reported early today.
The City Controller's office is establishing a special staffheaded by a former deputy investigation commissioner to speed payments to the antipoverty program.

Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc., a California department-store chain, announced yesterday in Los Angeles the election of Eaton W. Ballard and W. Earl Miller as executive vice presidents. The posts are newly formed.

Mrs. Sally Atwood Dryden of New York, daughter of Mrs. Harry Parsons Cross of Watch Hill, R. I., and the late James A. Atwood Jr., was married yesterday to Franklin J. Wilkes, son of Mrs. Nathaniel R. Wilkes of Southern Pines, N. C., and the late Mr. Wilkes.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 The United States Davis Cup outlook has sunk to a new low with the loss of Dennis Ralston, the ranking player of the country, to professional tennis following failure to get to the challenge round five times since 1960.

MILWAUKEE (UPI) The Milwaukee Archdiocese has announced that Catholic schools in the 10-county area would drop the term "religion" on report cards and refer to the subject as "knowledge of Christian doctrine."
WARSAW, Dec. 27 The Government made public today its case against Poland's Roman Catholic seminaries.

Phones jangled throughout the day at 53 Chambers Street yesterday as Buildings Department employes handled 300 complaints an hour about lack of heat. This was more than double the usual number received at this time of year.
BOSTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) Gordic Howe's goal at 15:42 of the third period gave Detroit a 4-4 tie with the Boston Bruins tonight and snapped the Red Wings' road-losing streak at a near-record 14 games.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27 Dr. Phan Quang Dan, a prominent critic of the Government in the Constituent Assembly, was slightly injured in both legs today when an explosive charge blew up under his car.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Dick Gregory, the Negro comedian, filed suit in United States District Court today to prevent the State Department from taking away his passport after he makes his planned trip to North Vietnam to entertain United States prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27? The Administration's decision to reduce the flow of reinforcements to Vietnam next year will allow the Defense Department to remove a major source of Congressional irritation--the large backlog of untrained reservists.

The method of selecting Federal grand juries in the Southern District of New York was attacked as unconstitutional yesterday on the ground the juries did not represent a socioeconomic cross section of the community.
MOWSCOW, Dec. 27 (AP) Moscow television depicted tonight a photo panorama of the moon taken from the Soviet unmanned spaceship Luna 13.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 27 (UPI) The Cincinnati Royals went on a 17-1 scoring surge early in the second quarter and coasted from there for a 131-123 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
Robert A. Leonard was elected yesterday as the president of the I.T.T. data services division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 The Treasury auctioned $1.4billion of nine-month and oneyear bills today at average discount rates of less than 5 per cent.

Special to The New York Times. PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Dec. 27 Theodore O. Gronlund. president and a director of Wood-Metal Industries, Inc., 101 Park Avenue, New York, manufacturers of kitchen cabinets, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 589 Monterey Avenue. He was 61 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) Wes Unseld scored 20 points and pulled down 26 rebounds as Louisville crushed Niagara, 98-73, in the first round of the Quaker City basketball tournament tonight.
EVERETT, Mass., Dec. 27 A Boston Maine one-car Diesel passenger train struck a fuel truck on a street crossing tonight and 12 persons died as flames engulfed both vehicles.
PARIS, Dec. 27 The novelist Francois Mauriac shouted out in protest tonight against a song spoofing President de Gaulle.

ROME, Dec. 27 Nonclerical observers close to the Vatican were reported today to have noted with disapproval statements by Cardinal Spellman on the war in Vietnam that ran counter to Pope Paul's repeated calls for negotiations leading to "peace in freedom and justice."

The director of nurses at St. Francis Hospital in the Bronx said yesterday she had been discharged because of her activities in support of a campaign by local residents to keep the facility from closing on Saturday.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 102.8 on Friday from 102.7 on Thursday.

Although President Johnson has declined to comment on any of the versions of what happened on the plane that carried President Kennedy's body and his widow from Dallas to Washington, Mr. Johnson's own account, which is in the records of the Warren Commission, gives no clue to the bitterness that Mrs. John F. Kennedy is now portrayed as having felt toward Mr. Johnson.
CADILLAC, Mich., Dec. 27 More than 100,000 Christmas trees from the 8,000-acre Brehm Tree and Land Corporation plantation surrounding this northern Michigan city of 12,000 were marketed this year.
Professional soccer which is already "the sport" in 136 countries throughout the world is about to get its foot inside the door in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 Former President Eisenhower said today that he knew United States bombing operations in North Vietnam "are aimed exclusively at military targets."

The trade expansion program organized by 13 of the nation's 14 subsidized steamship lines has processed more than 15,000 market inquiries in its first year, the Committee of American Steamship Lines reported yesterday.
Assemblyman Bertram L. Podell proposed legislation yesterday that would give Mayor Lindsay control of the Transit Authority.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Lenox Porter of 125 East 63d Street gave a tea dance for 150 persons at the Colony Club yesterday in honor of two of the season's debutantes, the Misses Amanda Vaill and Patricia Grafmueller.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 27 Comdr. Ray Lyton Hankinson, formerly of the United States Lighthouse Service, died yesterday in his home at 60 Locust Avenue. He was 87 years old.
G. H. Walker Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of Jonathan Bush as a general partner.
Alexander Schncider led his chamber orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night in the first of two programs to be presented by the New School concerts this week.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Dec. 27 The provincial assemblies of North and South Katanga, meeting in joint session, today elected Paul Muhona Governor of the unified province.
ATLANTA, Dec. 27 Judge Claude D. Shaw of the Fulton County (Atlanta) Superior Court dismissed today a lawsuit asking for a runoff in the undecided Georgia Governor's election.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 Two ocean beaches that will be a total of 3,500 feet long and parking space for 2,500 cars will be provided at Sandy Hook State Park in New Jersey with the help of a $200,000 grant announced today by the Department of the Interior.

Operations of the National Video Corporation for the fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30 resulted in net earnings of $1,811,163, equal to 66 cents a share, against $1,753,478, or 64 cents a share, for the quarters ended Nov. 30, 1965.

TOKYO, Dec. 27 Liu Shaochi, the chief of state of Communist China, was denounced as "the Khrushchev of China" in a mass rally of Red Guards in Peking today, according to Japanese correspondents in the Communist Chinese capital.
Dr. Bela Fabian, the Hungarian exile who led freedom demonstrations here, died of a heart attack in San Juan, P. R., Sunday, while on vacation. He was 77 years old and lived at 45 East End Avenue.

National Shoes, Inc., which operates a chain of retail shoe stores, announced yesterday it had acquired J. Baker, Inc., a privately held operator of leased shoe departments in discount stores in the Northeast. The amount of the cash transaction was not disclosed.
TEN days a month Lawrence James, 17 years old, travels from his home in Brooklyn to an Upper East Side loft where he is learning what some persons consider "a dying art."
Further changes in the state's newly revised divorce laws were asked yesterday by the Association of Family Court Judges and a citizens' committee.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 27 (AP) Vietcong terrorists in Vietnam are running into lethal opposition from the United States Navy's Black Berets, an elite group of guerrilla fighters who are the sea-going counterparts of the Army's Green Berets.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (UPI) A 1965 Federal indictment charging a Bucks County man with failing to report for induction has been dismissed.
ACAPULCO, Mexico, Dec. 27 (AP)--Lynda Bird Johnson and George Hamilton, the Hollywood actor, turned aside questions at a news conference today about whether they planned to marry.

RACINE, Wis., Dec. 27 (AP) A teen-ager responsible for supporting five younger sisters after the deaths of their parents Dec. 8 remained determined today to keep his family together despite a second blow the loss of their home.
THE inheritor of one of the most distinguished names in modern Greek politics, Andreas George Papandreou, has discovered that the life of political as well as royal dynasties can be rough in Greece.
St. John's and Brigham Young won the consolation round games of the Holiday Basketball Festival at Madison Square Garden yesterday before a crowd announced as 1,712.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Cambodia announced today that she was breaking diplomatic relations with South Korea in protest over what Pnompenh called Seoul's apparent plan "to participate directly and actively in the aggression of the U.S.-South Vietnamese forces against Cambodia."
The defense was overruled yesterday in attempts to block the use of tape-recorded conversations at the trial of State Senator-elect Eugene Rodriguez, a Bronx Democrat.
Ernst Zerner, a chemist, died Sunday of a stroke at a friend's home in Bethel, Conn. He was 82 years old and lived at 175 West 73d Street.
SPOTSWOOD, N. J., Dec. 27 (AP) A 2-year-old boy who froze to death Christmas morning was buried today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) Five Andean condors, birds with a wingspan of nearly nine feet, arrived by air freight at Washington National Airport today for the start of a lifesaving experiment.

LIMA, Ohio, Dec, 27 (AP) Victor Posner, chairman of the D. W. G. Cigar Company, said today his company had extended to Jan. 12 its offer to exchange its stock for securities of the Wilson Brothers Company, a clothing manufacturer with offices in New York.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 27 Pablo Casals will be 90 years old in two day's. But the island of Puerto Rico, proud of the fact that the celebrated cellist came here 10 years ago to take up permanent residence, has already started a series of birthday tributes.

Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., has moved its downtown real estate office from 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, where it occupied 950 square feet of space, to 37 Wall Street, where the company has 2,350 square feet. The relocation is part of an expansion program that includes a training program for beginning brokers and a recruitment program for experienced real estate personnel. Brown, Harris, Stevens' main office is at 14 East 47th Street.
Ken Boyer, whose 266 batting average placed him third among the regular New York Mets, signed his contract yesterday for the 1967 National League season.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 27 Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad reported today that rising labor costs had created a cash emergency and that the management of the road would dip into a $4.5-million "burial" fund to replenish the line's working capital.
PARIS The young Turks are shaking up the world of the French haute couture so hard they might even save it from extinction.
Shares on the American Stock Exchange turned downward on a broad front yesterday as the list registered its first loss in the last four sessions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) The Bureau of Mines said today that salt domes on the Continental Shelf off the Gulf Coast might prove to be the world's best source of sulphur and crude oil.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 27 Charles Todd Newberry of Au Sable Forks, N. Y., a former director of the J. J. Newberry Company, the variety-store chain, died last night in the Mary Fletcher Hospital after a long illness. He was 52 years old.

When the new Legislature convenes in Albany next month, one of its primary tasks ought to be modernization of its own rules and procedure, which have not been substantially revised in almost twenty years. The antiquated machinery now in force helps produce the log-jam characteristic of the end of every session, in which good bills are lost in the shuffle and bad ones slide through unnoticed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27 North Vietnamese troops moved into position during the 48-hour Christmas cease-fire for an attack this morning in which American soldiers suffered heavy casualties, United States military spokesmen said.
JERSEY CITY, Wednesday, Dec. 28 More than 100 firemen battled a three-alarm fire this morning in three Kennedy Boulevard stores near the Journal Sauare shopping center.

CAIRO, Dec. 27 Ahmad Shukairy, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, announced today the formation of a secret revolutionary council aimed against both the Israeli Government and the regime of King Hussein of Jordan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) A single-engine plane made an emergency landing on the heavily traveled Baltimore Expressway today, setting down on a convertible automobile. There were no injuries.

Twelve firemen killed in the Oct. 17 fire at 6 East 23d Street, near Madison Square, may have died because of a cinder block wall in the cellar that kept others from accurately assessing the seriousness of the fire, Chief Fire Marshal Vincent M. Canty said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) Heavy drinkers who have believed that by eating while drinking they can avert cirrhosis of the liver were told today it was not true.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 27 Long Island University defeated Stone Hill College, 78-54, and C. W. Post College beat Clark University, 68-61, today in the opening games of the Worcester Jaycee basketball tournament at Assumption.
Miss Mireille Nadine de Bary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George de Gary of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Warren S. Wilkinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Almadus D. Wilkinson of Grosse Pointe, Mich.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 A Federal study group urged today a five-year national concerted drive against "the invisible menace" to aviation known as clear air turbulence.

LAS CRUCES, N.M., Dec. 27 (UPI) District Judge Edward E. Triviz, in a move believed to be unprecedented in New Mexico, announced today that he would bar newsmen and the public from a preliminary hearing tomorrow for Mrs. Diane Smith, a suspect in a murder case.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 27 (UPI) Peter Jaremko, 48 years old, of Springfield, a former member of the Central Intelligence Agency, was found dead yesterday in Look Park.
The sale of lead soldier models of Hitler's Liebstandarte, or personal bodyguard, by some toy stores here was criticized yesterday by former City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bermont have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Ellen Bermont, to Peter Max Ascoli, son of Dr. and Mrs. Max Ascoli of New York and Crotonon-Hudson.

Lieut. Col. Patrick J. O'Rahilly, U.S.A., commanding officer of the First Battalion, 28th Artillery, died Monday in Germany of a heart attack. He was 39 years old and formely lived in Tarrytown. N. Y.

Jeff Miller of Plainfield. N. J., seeded second, and Gregory Norris of Rumson, N. J., seeded third, reached the boys 16 years division quarter-finals of the Eastern junior and boys indoor tennis championships yesterday at the Midtown Tennis Club, Manhattan.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27 (AP) Western Kentucky grabbed a quick lead tonight and posted a 90-84 Victory over Holy Cross in an opening round game of the Hurricane Classic basketball tournament.
Dr. Reuben Wallenrod, educator and author, died Monday in his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 65 years old and had retired in 1964 as professor of Hebrew at Brooklyn College.
It was a bit late, but what a Christmas present.
Joe Namath, the New York Jets' quarterback, entered Lenox Hospital yesterday for knee surgery.

The United Church of Christ, one of the Protestant denominations most active in commissioning art works and in social action, has plans for a full-scale musical for presentation ultimately in New York.
Ticket-scalpers were in evidence in the vicinity of Madison Square Garden before last night's Ranger game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered today an investigation of a proposal by Frontier Airlines to give women reduced excursion fares.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (AP) A local television blackout of the Super Bowl game Jan. 15 drew court action today from a football fan and censure from the City Council.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 Artificial soft drinks may be helping to cope with the world food problem within the next few years, a specialist suggested here today.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 27 Turkey and the Soviet Union said in a joint statement today that "the Vietnamese nation should be given the right to decide its destiny freely."

LAS CRUCES, N. M., Dec. 27 (AP) The chief of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, James C. Webb, called today for establishment of an arena for the meeting of experts who could trade scientific and industrial knowledge on the space age.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 27 (Reuters) A magnificent maiden test century by Denis Lindsay put South Africa in a dominant position today on the fourth day of the first test against Australia.
NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Dec. 27 The cagou, a beautiful, flightless bird found only in New Caledonia, is in danger of extinction.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 27 The Tennessee Valley Authority is paying $23,562,486 to the United States Treasury on Dec. 31, as a semiannual dividend on the Government investment in the T.V.A. power system.
Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Bronx Democrat, said yesterday he would sponsor legislation in the next Congress to reimburse New York City for money spent entertaining foreign visitors.
Northeast Airlines and the crew of a DC-3 aircraft were commended yesterday for their participation in a rescue of nine fishermen on Aug. 12.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor predicted today that 1967 would be a year of continued economic expansion but with less inflation and with easier money than in 1966.

WASHINGTON, Dec.27 (UPI) Llewellyn E. Thompson was sworn in today as Ambassador to the Soviet Union. He said some of the differences between Russia and the United States were deep and would take time to resolve.

"Marge, this is like Christmas all over again," a harassed husband complained yesterday, following closely behind his wife as she moved boldly through a maze of shoppers at Abraham Straus on Brooklyn's Fulton Street.

Now that the mutual funds have taken their lumps, it is the turn of the bank-managed pension funds. The investment performance of pension funds has been difficult to judge since banks do not publicize the results of the stock portfolios they manage.
Gold shares made sharp gains in light trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange yesterday. This was the standout in the day's activity. Other major groups declined.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 2 (AP) The United States Embassy informally protested to the Foreign Ministry today about an anti-American demonstration in Novi Sad. The incident had not been reported until today.

ALL football players get the jitters before every game and the fluttery feeling is heightened when a championship is at stake. However, it's a cinch that the Green Bay Packers will be less bothered by the butterflies than will the Dallas Cowboys before their Cotton Bowl collision on Sunday in the National Football League playoff.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27 A leader of the Vietnamese Labor Confederation, which is striking in Saigon to protest the replacement of 600 civilian dock workers by United States troops, demanded tonight that the Government force the rehiring of the longshoremen.

Larry Terrell of Harvard, the top-seeded player who drew a first-round bye, led the way into the quarter-final round of the college freshman invitation singles squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP) A strike has been set for 12:01 A.M. Thursday against the Eastern division of Greyhound Bus Lines, an official of the Amalgamated Transit Union said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, leaving the Senate after 18 years, made public his personal finances today and commented that most voters did not realize how costly political office could be.

LITTLE ROCK, Dec. 27 (UPI) There was three times more desegregation in Arkansas schools this year than last, figures submitted to the United States Office of Education and the State Education Department showed today.

McKinley McAdoo of Penn Charter, Palmer Page of Episcopal and Elliot Berry of Choate, three of the four seeded players, advanced to the quarter-final round of the Princeton Club's annual interscholastic invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday.
The widely heralded year-end rally in the stock market got off to a strange start yesterday. Prices went downhill all the way.
The election of James Woodburn as a corporate vice president was announced yesterday in Chicago by Amsted Industries, Inc., a heavy equipment manufacturer.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) Bob Windle of Indiana, and Gary Dilley of Michigan State paced an assault on the record book today in the College Swim Forum meeting at the Hall of Fame pool.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 28 (UPI) Australia retained the Davis Cup for another year today when Roy Emerson overpowered Ramanathan Krishnan, 6-0, 6-2, 10-8, in almost 100-degree heat to give the Aussies an unbeatable 3-1 lead over India.

An uproarious episode in the Recent history of American letters and of Irish intransigence concluded yesterday with the acceptance of the Library of Congress of a surviving copy of a small book printed here in 1960 as a bootleg edition.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 27 Pesident Sukarno asked the questions and answered them himself at a recent ceremony in his cool, neoclassical weekend palace at Bogor. The occasion was the swearing in of two Indonesian Ambasadors, to Belgium and the United States. The 65-year-old President was telling his envoys how to handle questions he expected they would be asked in the West.
The earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in 1966 will be down about 5 per cent from last year's net income of $407,228,855, or $8.63 a common share, a company official said yesterday.

THE 1967 competition for the drivers' world cham pionship is expected to be one of the finest in the history of the circuit. Constructors have had more than a year to work on the new Formula. One three-liter engines and we are not likely to see any of the old and worn out power...
The Board of Education was ordered yesterday to defend in court tomorrow the legality of the $1.1-billion expense budget it is expected to approve this morning.

Mac Manus, John Adams, Inc., an advertising agency, has leased five floors with 72,000 square feet of space in the 40 story office building being erected on the west blockfront of Madison Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.

The leaders of 4,000 striking construction plumbers here and representatives of plumbing contractors are scheduled to shift contract negotiations today to Washington to the union's international headquarters.
VAIL, Colo., Dec. 27 (UPI) Rick Chaffee of Denver University, who did not ski last season because of a knee injury, won the opening event of the Alpine Holiday Classic.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) Dr. Ernest Watson Burgess, professor emeritus of sociology at the University of Chicago and a past president of the American Sociological Society, died today. He was 80 years old.
A group of conservative members of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. has issued an 11th-hour appeal to fellow churchmen to defeat the denomination's proposed Confession of 1967.
Six young women will be presented at the annual Hope Cotillion and Ball on Friday in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Dec. 27 The Buffalo Bills, not yet ready physically or mentally, settled down to work today for Sunday's American Football League championship game against the Kansas City Chiefs at Buffalo.
The New York Stock Exchange, faced with a need for more employes in this high-volume period of the stock market, has begun a recruiting program aimed at high schools.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 27 (AP) Gov.-Elect Ronald Reagan announced today a joint public-private plan to match unemloyed Californians with available jobs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 The Cuban Government of Premier Fidel Castro was reliably reported today to have agreed to allow an estimated total of 800 United States citizens and their families to leave Cuba.

In every part of Manhattan and the Bronx towering new apartment buildings stand empty, complete except for plumbing facilities. Thousands of New Yorkers who moved out of their old homes long ago in confidence of having shiny new ones to go to are forced instead to wait, week after tortured week, in hotels or doubled up with relatives.

BONN, Dec. 27 West German emigration to the United States dipped sharply last year, in part because of the unwillingness of many young Germans to face the American military draft and possible service in Vietnam.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 27 Just before 2:25 P.M. yesterday, there was a muffled distant roar, 10-foot windows in this old French-built hotel rattled and heavy gray curtains gently swayed inward.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today the school lunch program would receive substantially larger quantities of Government-donated foods during the second half of the 1966-'67 school year than it had during the first half.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 27 The Texas White House announced today that President Johnson would meet in Washington Jan. 26 and 27 with President-Elect Arthur Costa Silva of Brazil.
Otto Preminger, who lost in court last year when he sought to bar television from cutting one of his motion pictures, scored a victory yesterday in selling another movie to TV.
The Hooker Chemical Corporation has elected James G. Baldwin as a director, it was announced yesterday by F. Leonard Bryant, chairman.
A three-alarm fire in a 48family apartment house in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday noon caused the death of a 79-year-old woman and drove 100 persons into the street.
The Radio Corporation of America bucked the recent trend of bearish year-end statements issued by major corporations by predicting yesterday that it would have a record year in 1967.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 An economist for the Brookings Institution made a strong plea here today that the President be given discretionary authority by the Congress to adjust tax rates "up to $10-billion plus or minus" as a tool to maintain a stable economy.

The city's two top hospital officials are to appear today before the State Commission of Investigation as it opens its inquiry into allegations of millions of dollars of waste in the municipal hospitals and affiliated voluntary hospitals.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 Because of budget reduction first by the Administration and then by Congress, the State Department is being forced to curtail its cultural exchange program with foreign countries.
THE matter of determining who are the best players in the National Football. League is always difficult because of the lack of statistical guides.
The distribution of thousands of Pollsh-made dolls said to be highly flammable was barred yesterday by the Fire Department.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) The Justice Department admitted tonight that it had engaged in another case of electronic eavesdropping the eighth such admission since last spring.

GRENADA, Miss., Dec. 27 (AP) Volunteer tutors from two major universities have set up Christmas holiday cram courses in hopes of broadening the educational and cultural sights of some of Grenada's Negro children.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (UPI) A Swiss citizen and a Russian engineer have been convicted of bringing in Western clothes and selling them on the black market in Moscow, it was announced today.
Negotiations between Mohawk Airlines and 500 striking mechanics, recessed last Thursday, remained stalled with no date set for their resumption, it was learned yesterday.

MRS. JOHN V. LINDSAY conducted a half-hour televised tour last night of refurbished Gracie Mansion and its new wing, named in memory of Mrs. Susan B. Wagner. The interior of the Mayor's residence, the rooms reserved for his family's private use, and the room set aside for entertainment of dignitaries appeared singularly attractive in color television.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) Prime Minister Wilson intends to shuffle his Cabinet early in the New Year to eliminate some older men and promote some of the Labor party's young men, reliable informants said tonight.
LISBON, Dec. 27 Portugal is trying to maintain friendly relations with Communist China and will not permit antiPeking activities in Macao, Foreign Minister Alberto Franco Nogueira said today.
HAVING been exposed to so many of Britain's angry young men, it's very comforting to get back to Flanders and Swann again. They're not angry, they're just a bit put out.

Frankie Genaro, former flyweight boxer who once was recognized as the world champion in his division, died yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 65 years old. Mr. Genaro had worked for the Department of Marine Aviation for 15 years of Marine and Aviation for 15 years until he retired last August.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) One of the medical world's foremost husbandand-wife teams, Dr. Ernest A. Spiegel and Dr. Mona Spiegel-Adolf, are retiring at the end of the year from the faculty of Temple Univrsity School of Medicine. They came here from their native Austria in 1930.
Dr. Kaufman Wallach, a physician who practiced at 1172 Park Avenue, died yesterday at his home, 150 East 77th Street. He was 73 years old.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27 The Soviet Union's grain harvest this year exceeded even the most optimistic estimates of a record output, Vladimir V. Matskevich, the Minister of Agriculture, reported today.

Frankie Genaro, former flyweight boxer who once was recognized as the world champion in his division, died yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 65 years old. Mr. Genaro had worked for the Department of Marine Aviation for 15 years of Marine and Aviation for 15 years until he retired last August.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 27 (UPI) Sweden is said to have some of the most liberal views on sex of any country in Europe. But a television performer may have gone too far even for Swedes last night on "Hyland's Corner," the most popular and the most discussed family program in Sweden.
PARIS, Dec. 27 A basic reorganization of the French aircraft industry is imminent, it was reported here tonight. Industry sources declined to comment publicly.
BINHTUY, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 28 About 1,200 South Vietnamese paratroopers began an airborne drive yesterday against the Vietcong in the Mekong delta, an enemy stronghold.

ON A DAY when most stocks on the New York Stock Exchange suffered losses and companies producing color television sets participated in the downward slide, the Sprague Electric Company it major supplier to these set makers registered the biggest gain of the session.
The Pennsylvania Railroad has announced the appointment of John D. Morris as vice president for special services. He was formerly assistant vice president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today it had begun mailing 1966 income tax forms to about 65 million individual taxpayers. The distribution is scheduled for completion Jan. 5.
ROME, Dec. 27 Italy's annual tax-negotiating season opened today with the publication of widely differing estimates of taxable income by the taxpayers and municipal authorities.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 27 (AP) A blizzard heaped snow on the central section of the nation today and slowed travel over a wide area.
It is becoming almost more difficult to find a big businessman not interested in helping the Douglas Aircraft Company in its cash squeeze than to find those that are.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, has urged the 17 committee chairmen in the Senate to initiate a "top-tobottom" re-evaluation of major Federal programs, both new and old.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 27 The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation announced today the receipt of $450,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation to cover adminis trative expenses for a Federally financed program to subsidize teacher salaries in predominantly Negro colleges in the South.
An insurance salesman was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for allegedly giving a $10 bribe to a Selective Service clerk. If he is convicted he faces 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 The Federal Reserve Board revoked today its Sept. 1 directive to banks demanding a sharp slowdown in loans to business.
EUGENE ORMANDY, now in his 31st year as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, made his first New York appearance of the season at Philharmonic Hall last night with that mighty band.

ATHENS, Dec. 27--Andreas Papandreou today accused his father, former Premier George Papandreou, of having betrayed principles of the Center Union party in pledging its support to Greece's caretaker Government.

In the year now drawing to a close, lung cancer a rare disease fifty years ago is taking the lives of approximately 42,000 men and 8,000 women. These grim statistics have led the nation's top advisory body on cancer, the National Advisory Cancer Council, to sound a new warning against cigarette smoking, probably the toughest on the subject yet to be made by a recognized group of experts in this country.
A group of Negroes told the Police Department yesterday that they wanted to see more patrolmen walking beats in Harlem.
"Notably successful," said the accrediting agency's report about the five-year-old Graduate Division of the City University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 The great power centers of American life had more than their normal share of trouble in 1966. It was a bad year for big shots and Big Plans. For some reason history got bored with the pretensions of power and cut the giants down to size.

The steady contraction of the "revolutionary" Brazilian administration toward a permanently strong, centralized executive is on the verge of legalization. Brazil's new Constitution had its first reading in Congress last week. The full process will be completed on or before Jan. 24, and the Constitution will take effect March 15 when President-elect Costa e Silva is inaugurated.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 (AP) Governor Rockefeller will take his third-term oath of office twice at a private ceremony Friday in New York City and on Jan. 2 at the traditional inaugural in Albany.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 27 Wallace D. McLean, former general manager of the Morris Plan Industrial Bank of New York, died here today in his home at the Scarsdale Inn. His age was 93.
The spot rate on the British pound gained 9 points, to $2.7902, on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. With banks closed in London and Canada, business here was rather limited.
Heavy trading in potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange featured the commodities markets yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 The International Brotherhood of Teamsters plans to demand annual wage increases ranging from 4.5 per cent to more than 7 per cent from the nation's leading truck companies in negotiations to begin next month.
A group of Negroes told the Police Department yesterday that they wanted to see more patrolmen walking beats in Harlem.
"Notably successful," said the accrediting agency's report about the five-year-old Graduate Division of the City University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 The great power centers of American life had more than their normal share of trouble in 1966. It was a bad year for big shots and Big Plans. For some reason history got bored with the pretensions of power and cut the giants down to size.

The steady contraction of the "revolutionary" Brazilian administration toward a permanently strong, centralized executive is on the verge of legalization. Brazil's new Constitution had its first reading in Congress last week. The full process will be completed on or before Jan. 24, and the Constitution will take effect March 15 when President-elect Costa e Silva is inaugurated.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 (AP) Governor Rockefeller will take his third-term oath of office twice at a private ceremony Friday in New York City and on Jan. 2 at the traditional inaugural in Albany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, said today he did not intend to ask the House to bar Representative Adam Clayton Powell from taking his seat when Congress convenes.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 28 (UPI) George Christian, President Johnson's press secretary, entered Seton Hospital here today for surgery to remove part of a disk in the lower part of his back.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 The antipoverty program is not suffering because of the expense of the Vietnam war, Mr. Wirtz told a news conference here today.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced yesterday in Washington, D.C., the election of Michael Zarrilli as a director for a twoyear term.
PARIS, Dec. 28 Le Monde said today in an editorial: "Not a day passes any more but that the most moderate American press catches the President or his collaborators in the flagrant act of lying."
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 28 (AP) Arthur S. Milinowski, a Harvard classmate of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died in a hospital here today. He was 83 years old and lived in Larchmont, N. Y.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) A Coast Guard helicopter, searching for a missing plane, brought back yesterday a family of six who had been marooned four days on an island after a storm wrecked their boat.
Sharp increases in revenues and earnings were achieved in the first 11 months of this year by two of the three airlines that issued their reports yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 Robert D. DeLong has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Mary Bell DeLong, to George Sumner Case of New York. Miss DeLong is the daughter also of the late Mrs. DeLong of Reading Pa. Mr. Case's parents are Mrs. Charles I. Pierce of New York and Norfolk, Conn., and the late Robert D. Case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) The Interior Department announced today that imports of crude and unfinished oils would be limited to 943,649 barrels a day, in 1967 a decrease of 8,388 barrels from this year.
Politics often takes an unexpected turn in the country where the word originated, but even Greeks must have been startled by Andreas Papandreou's attack on his father.
The stock market started to rally yesterday morning, changed direction in midsession, and ended in another broad slide.
The First National City Bank announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph J. Borgatti Jr., and Basil C. Wehrman as vice presidents.
WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Dec. 28--An autopsy has disclosed that a freelance trucker found in his garage over the weekend and pronounced dead of an apparent heart attack had been shot five times.
M. John Rich, an official of the Asiatic Petroleum Corporation, died Saturday at his home, 500 East 77th Street. He was 60 years old and was to have retired at the end of this year.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 28 The Government and two American oil companies reached agreements today that promise to save Argentina about $100million a year spent on oil imports.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans yesterday to cut tolls sharply for station-to-station calls to most European countries.

The commanding officer of a naval attack squadron recently returned from six months of carrier-based raids on North Vietnam yesterday disputed several points in the dispatches from Hanoi by Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times.

PALM BEACH, Dec. 28 The phone rang this afternoon in the huge, elegant living room of El Solano, the Spanish-style seaside house where Claude Kirk is doing the work preliminary to his becoming the first Republican Governor of Florida in 94 years.

The Metropolitan Club at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street held its second Debutante Ball last night. Five young women were presented, all relatives of members of the men's club founded in 1891 by J. Pierpont Morgan.
ALBANY, Dec. 28--The membership of the State Board of Regents does not have to comply with the one man, one vote principle, the State Supreme Court Appellate Division announced today.
SHERMAN, Conn., Dec. 28 Miss Magdalene Vanderburgh Fincke and John Franklin Sears were married this afternoon in the Sherman Congregational Church by the Rev. Richard Hill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 A tentative agreement was reached here today in the New York City plumbing strike, and union officials were hopeful it would end the 157-day tie-up.
The Ellicott Machine Corporation of Baltimore announced yesterday that the first model of its new line of "SuperDragon" dredges would be shipped to French Guiana next month.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Dec. 29--Communist China has announced that it set off a new nuclear explosion yesterday. The Chinese asserted that the test had been successful and that it was a heavy blow to the policies of the United States and the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Secret studies of a space reflector that could light the Vietnames jungles at night have stirred uneasiness and some alarm among astronomers.

JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla. Dec. 28 (UPI) Coach Doug Dickey, the Tennessee coach, put the Volts through another strenuous workout today, but said he would taper off drills for the Gator Bowl game with Syracuse on Saturday.

Wilson Co. announced yesterday it planned to declare a 50 per cent stock dividend and to increase its quarterly cash dividend to 42 cents on the new common shares to be outstanding following the stock dividend.
M. J. Fassler Co., Inc., a Brooklyn producer of plas tic-coated materials, announced yesterday the election of Herman Braverman as president.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 29 (Reuters) American Air Force jets dived through heavy antiaircraft fire over North Vietnam yesterday to attack defenses along the country's southern coastline, a military spokesman said today.

ROME, Dec 28 The Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, praised today as "a service to truth" the dispatches by Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, reporting on United States air raids in and around Hanoi.
STORRS, Conn., Dec. 28 (UPI) The University of Virginia, with three players scoring over 20 points, crushed Columbia 112-88 tonight in the opening game of the Connecticut basketball classic.
City and state health officials yesterday denied charges that medical experiments were conducted on patients in the municipal hospitals without the patients' consent.
The spot rate on the British pound gained 10 points to $2.7912 in fairly busy trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

The president of the American Jewish Congress said yesterday that "inevitable slaughter of innocent victims" by air attacks on North Vietnam must be halted if the Johnson Administration sincerely wants peace.
LUCK played a part in two of Pal Benko's games in the United States chess championship, which winds up tonight at the Henry Hudson Hotel.
PEOPLE are asking, "Is the borzoi disappearing in America?" The answer is nyet, nyet, nyet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Federal officials will be asked to re-examine the contention that the air over southern New Jersey is too crowded to permit construction of a jetport there.

A ranking official in the Manhattan District Attorney's office who has examined the Congressional banking account of Representative Adam Clayton Powell said yesterday that "if there was a million dollars in the account, we didn't see it."

Mr. and Mrs. W. Wells Newell of 1212 Fifth Avenue and Fair Harbor, Fire Island, N. Y., gave a reception for 125 in the library suite at the St. Regis-Sheraton last evening in honor of their daughter, Miss Leslie Brooke Newell.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (UPI) A sniper described as apparently an excellent shot spread terror through a southwest section of the city early today, wounding three persons, one critically.
PHILIP J. LEVIN, the dissident director of Metro Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., seeking control of the company in a proxy fight, is apparently not letting any grass grow under his feet.
Construction of a l0-story commercial building at 325 Hudson Street, corner of Vandam Street, has been started by Jack Resnick Son, investors and builders.
Austin Nichols Co., Inc., the whisky distributor, moved yesterday to secure the loyalty of its stockholders.

VAIL, Colo., Dec. 28 (AP) Robin Morning, 19 years old, of Mamoth Mountain, Calif., won the women's event and Ken Phelps, 23, of Vail, the men's race in the downhill competition today of the Alpine holiday ski classic.
The American Stock Exchange had its worst session in more than a month yesterday as the list declined in active trading.

MADRID, Dec. 28 Spain, which has a record $1-billion trade deficit with the European Economic Community for 1966, believes that her negotiations with the Economic Community may lead to a satisfactory association.
American Airlines opened a two-day recruitment fair at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel here yesterday to help the college men and women of today become the pilots and stewardesses of tomorrow.
Rosalyn Tureck, pianist, gave another of her Bach recitals at Carnegie Hall last night and as always, she provided direct, energetic, colorful and thoughtful performances.
BUFFALO, Dec. 28 Pat Lalor of Haverford, Pa., is a 19-year-old figure skater who has a lot of confidence on and off the ice.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (UPI) A Cuyahoga County grand jury investigating last summer's rioting by Negroes in the Hough District criticized members of the clergy today for "helping" the rioters.

THEY tell the tale of an old woman's chopper: It had been in her family more than a century, and had had four new handles and six new blades. I feel much the same might be said of Paul Taylor's fine ballet "Post Meridian," which was last night introduced into Mr. Taylor's all-too-short but sweet Broadway season at the ANTA Theater.

PLANDOME, L. I., Dec. 28 Miss Nancy Kathleen Hunter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Don D. Hunter of Manhasset, was married this afternoon to Hugh Taylor Kemper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kosciusko Kemper 3d of Roslyn Estates.
ATHENS, Dec. 28 George Papandreou, leader of the Center Union party, threatened tonight to oust his rebellious son, Andreas, from the party.
The bond market climbed sharply yesterday, responding to the Federal Reserve's decision to give the green light to banks to expand business loans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 "We chew loyalty pills," a member of Senator Robert F. Kennedy's staff said early this year when someone suggested that work days in the Kennedy office were long.
HONG KONG, Dec. 28 Western analysts of affairs in China are treating with skepticism Peking's claim that China reaped this year the biggest crop in its history.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 28 A hoard of 44 gold coins, many of them looking as if they had been newly minted, rewarded archeologists last summer as spades broke ground in ancient Morgantina, Sicily.

Seven Negro comedians will perform on a one-hour television show, "100 Years of Laughter," that will trace the origins and history of Negro humor. Harry Belafonte will be the executive producer and will sing on the show, too.

St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pamela Gerli Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McNamee Sullivan of 620 Park Avenue and Southampton, L. I., to David Louelwyn Banker, son of Mrs. W. Barrett Brown of 1120 Fifth Avenue and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Vincent L. Banker.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department announced today formal approval of a new farmer-financed research and market promotion program for cotton that will go into effect next year.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 28 (AP) Patients suffering from respiratory diseases are attending classes at the Medical College of Georgia to learn how to improve their condition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI)--The Treasury Department defended today its savings bond ads against any suggestion that they didn't comply with the Government's own new truth-in-advertising rules.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving and Bernard B. Zients, executive head of Gimbels, New York, yesterday opened a theater workshop for schoolchildren in the auditorium of the department store on Broadway and 33d Street.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Dec. 29 Several armed men, believed to be North Korean soldiers, attacked a guard post of the Second United States Infantry Division near Panmunjom Tuesday night, a United Nations Command spokesman said today.
The loneliness of the elderly is frequently mentioned in letters to The New York Times Neediest Fund by donors who want to alleviate the persistent worries of the afflicted and the poor.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Robert Wilcox gave a tea dance tonight at the Country Club of New Canaan in honor of three of the season's debutantes, the Misses Frances Fielding Lewis Beatty, Catharine Dixie Miller and Mary Gillett Rockefeller.
The New York State Department of Commerce issued the following ski reports yesterday:
ANTIGUA, B.W.I., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, evidently weary after her recent book controversy, asked again today that her Caribbean vacation be private.

Larry Terrell of Harvard, the top-seeded player, and George Alcorn of Army, seeded No. 2, advanced yesterday to final of the fifth annual squash racquets invitation tournament for freshmen at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) Reflecting the impact of tight-money conditions, home-mortgage debt increased by onlY $2.7-billion during the July-Sept. quarter, reaching slightly more than $223-billion on Sept. 30.

Gerald Coyne and Gregory Carney have been friends Since boyhood. They went to the same schools and the same church and served in the same unit in the Army. When they were discharged they joined the Fire Department at the same time and both are attached to Ladder Co. 38 in the Bronx.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (UPI) Ron Holmberg of Dallas, seeded No. 1, won a 6-0, 6-1 victory over Jack Jackson of Knoxville, Tenn., today in the rain-delayed opening of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament.
New executives have been named by two major magazine publishers.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 28 (UPI)--Australia retained possession of the Davis Cup today with assurance that at least one of its top players will return for the challenge round defense next year.
Police commissioner Howard R. Leary told his men yesterday that until more of New York's nearly 800,000 Puerto Ricans speak English, "we'll speak Spanish whenever they come to us for help."

Mayor Lindsay directed Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet yesterday to determine whether it was possible for the city to lease St. Francis Hospital in a move to keep the 380-bed Catholic in- stitution from closing.
Joe Namath's $400,000 knee underwent surgery yesterday, and if post-operative expectations are correct he may be a million-dollar quarterback next fall.

MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 28 (AP) Tufts University's Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy has been awarded $500,000 by the Ford Foundation to establish a graduate teaching and research program in international development.

Directors of the Columbia Pictures Corporation announced yesterday that a special meeting of stockholders has been scheduled for Jan. 31 in lieu of the annual meeting postponed from Dec. 21. The record date for the meeting is Jan. 9.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) A Congressional staff report depicted tonight some of the nation's biggest financial institutions as interlocked through stock control and wielding the power of $215-billion in assets administered by trust departments.
SACRAMENTO, Dec. 28 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown, assessing the white backlash in American politics, said today that "whether we like it or not, the people want separation of the races."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Communist China's fifth atomic explosion was viewed today by United States experts as another step toward the development of a hydrogen bomb.
Three new partners and three associates have been named by Fordyce Hamby Associates, a 31-year-old architectural and engineering firm here.

The domestic scheduled airlines set new records for service in 1966 to meet the increasing demand for passenger and cargo transportation, the Air Transport Association of America reported yesterday in a year-end review.

Pablo Casals, who is 90 years old today, will be smothered in tributes from all over the world. Yet the greatest thing that can be said of this wonderful old man is that no tribute can do justice to him.

Temple Emanu-El was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Vivianne Ponte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Ponte of London, to Michael Leonard, a composer. He is the son of Mrs. Etta Leonard of New York.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 28--With formal negotiations at a standstill, a series of private conferences today failed to find a solution for a strike by 5,000 Vietnamese longshoremen.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) The State Department said today that it had granted permission to 57 Americans to go to North Vietnam.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (Reuters) Headlines such as "U.S. Ad- mit Air Raids Are Killing Civilians" marked British press reaction today to American disclosures of bombing damage in North Vietnam.
Works by Haydn, Beethoven, Berg and Ray Luke were played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by the Lyric String Quartet, which was making its New York debut.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The best time of day to spray a housefly or a cockroach is 4 P.M., a scientist assured an audience of other scientists here today.
PEKING, Dec. 28 Red Guards have arrested the former Defense Minister, Peng Teh- huai, who commanded Communist China's forces in the Korean war, a Red Guard newspaper reported here today.

ANACORTES, Wash., Dec. 28 (AP) A nationwide strike involving 60,000 oil industry workers "can be expected" Jan. 1 unless there is "some significant change" in attitudes of either side, a union official declared here today.
HOUSTON, Dec .28 (AP) The new North American Soccer League was officially sanctioned today as the only major professional soccer league in the United States.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 A strike that had been threatened for one minute after midnight against the Greyhound bus lines' Eastern division was averted tonight with a tentative agreement on a new contract.
Frank Chodorov, author and editor of politically conservative books, magazines and newspapers, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 420 East 59th Street. His age was 79.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 102.9 on Tuesday from 102.8 on Friday.

EAST MOLINE, Ill., Dec. 28 (UPI) Justice Ray I. Klingbiel of State Supreme Court today assigned Cook County Circuit Court Judge Herbert C. Paschen to preside at the trial of Richard Speck in Peoria on charges of murdering eight Chicago nurses.

The tree surgeons of the Parks Department have been ordered to devote their full time to the care of the two million trees in the city parks, and ignore another half million trees lining the city's streets. The only exceptions are emergency cases, such as occur when a broken limb endangers passersby or obstructs a traffic light.

FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 28 An investigation into the effect of two Arno River hydroelectric dams on the Florence floods of Nov. 4 has found nothing thus far to incriminate any person or agency, Dr. Nicola Serra, Florence district attorney, said today.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 28 President Johnson was described today as satisfied that the bombing of North Vietnam by American planes had been directed only at military targets, as ordered.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 28 The South Vietnamese Foreign Ministry charged today that the Vietcong violated the 48-hour Christmas cease-fire more than a hundred times.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 28 (UPI) Gov-elect Ronald Reagan has already taken the oath of office as California's Governor, but he says he did not realize what he was doing.
Gov. George Romney of Michigan held an all-day meeting here ysterday with seven top associates and friends to talk over his prospect for winning the Republican nomination for President in 1968.
JERUSALEM (Israel), Dec. 28 Israel's Nobel Prize winner, the 78-year-old S.Y. Agnon, has returned to his writing after a three-week tour that he said would take 30 years to tell about.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Dec. 28 President and Mrs. Johnson invited some conservationminded teen-agers to their ranch today to encourage them in the fight on blight and ugliness throughout the country.
The Wire Service Guild, representing 1,350 employes of The Associated Press, announced last night that it was asking its members for a strike authorization.
Engineer officers on the tugboat fleet of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad telephoned the company that they were "sick" and did not report for duty on the morning watch yesterday, the railroad said.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 28 Fourteen young women were presented tonight to the Most Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, at the Regina Cotillion in the Garden City Hotel. Proceeds from the annual event will go to the Bishop's Fund for Children.
Pedestrians Who waded through icy gumbo slush and drivers whose cars crept slowly through still-slick midtown streets yesterday were faced today with more soggy discomfort.
The Standard Oil Company of California, Parke, Davis Co., and the Delaware Hudson Company each announced yesterday the election of a new chairman as part of general management changes.
The Lindsay Administration disclosed the details of its new "universal summons" yesterday and predicted it would be "a major weapon in the drive to uncork the city's traffic congestion."

MASERU, Lesotho, Dec. 28 King Moshoeshoe II of Lesotho is a king without a throne tonight. His kingdom is no more than the grounds of his old tin-roofed, British colonialstyle "palace" where the 28year-old king is under house arrest.

A teen-age girl and her young nephew, out on a sleighriding expedition yesterday, were killed by a train while crossing the Long Island Rail Road tracks at Utopia Parkway and 39th Avenue in Flushing Queens.

EDISON, N.J., Dec. 28 A 22year-old former Miami, Fla., laborer who had dropped out of school in the 11th grade was congratulated today by the Kilmer Job Corps Center as its 1,000th graduate to be placed in employment.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 In the Bacon Memorial Chapel of Northeastern University this afternoon, Miss Ellen Wickham Harding became the bride of Peter Edward Gordon. The Rev. Dr. Charles W. Havice, dean of the chapel, performed the nondenominational ceremony.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 28 (AP) Mrs. John F. Kennedy has been named by the American people for the fifth straight year as the most admired woman in the world, the Gallup Poll reported today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 More than 200 student leaders from across the country opened today a three-day conference at the University of Chicago to plan a national student strike for peace.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 28 (AP) United States military sources said today that it was known that some civilians had been killed in bombing raids in the Hanoi area. "It'll happen again," they added.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 The Board of Regents proposed to the Legislature today a $12.9million program of financial aid and other measures to help overcome the shortage of nurses in the state.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Dec. 28 Bryan Lambe of Westbury, L. I., a sophomore of Oneonta State College, swept through six straight opponents to win the award as the outstanding wrestler at the C. W. Post invitation tournament tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (UPI) Another book on the Kennedy family will appear in Britain in 1967, it was disclosed today.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 A series of landing accidents in recent months has brought the international airport here under attack for inadequate control facilities.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28 (AP) Five employes were presumed dead, the police reported, in a fire today that destroyed part of the famed Marcy Hotel in this Adirondack resort. The 475 guests escaped safely.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 28 Mrs. Carol Gewirtz Rosenthal of Stamford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Gewirtz of New York and New Fairfield, was married this evening to Theodore Yudain, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Yudain of New Canaan.
The American Cyanamid Company announced yesterday in Wayne, N. J., the election of L. Emery Katzenbach as a director.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) Catie Ball, a 14-year-old blonde from Jacksonville, tied the women's 100meter breast-stroke world record today in the second annual international swimming meet at the Hall of Fame pool.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The Food and Drug Administration has begun an investigation of various iron-cobalt preparations used to fight anemia and has asked manufacturers to stop shipping the medicine to druggists.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 29 (Reuters) The Red Guards denounced Foreign Minister Chen Yi in their wall posters in Peking yesterday, a Japanese correspondent reported from Peking today.
WHEN Seymour R. Thaler gets mad, a vein in his neck bulges, his face flushes, his dark eyes tighten, he tenses, raises his head and starts, quite simply, to shout.
