THE trouble with most plays written on two levels of meaning is that they don't exactly work on either level. Instead of doubling an audience's interest, they simply halve it both ways.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 Miss Katia Hirschman, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Albert O. Hirschman of Cambridge, was married today to Alain Salomon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Boris Salomon of Paris.

Angered because they had been without heat since Monday, 100 tenants of six East 110th Street buildings started a huge fire in the street yesterday and blocked traffic for more than an hour in the block between Madison and Fifth Avenues.
The city began to mail 20page booklets to three million residents yesterday instructing them on the filing of their city income tax returns.
John H. Mathis, 58-yearold president of the Lone Star Cement Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 A balanced state budget, including another increase in public-school aid, is possible without increasing taxes, State Controller Arthur Levitt said today.
The Academy of American Poets has awarded John Berryman a fellowship and the $5,000 that goes along with it one of the more distinctive honors for American verse.
Gardner Rea, the cartoonist, died yesterday in Brookhaven Memorial Hospital on Long Island after a long illness. He was 72 years old.
CONAKRY, Guinea, Dec. 17 Not far from the Cuban Embassy here is a walled villa overlooking the sea. The wall is heavily guarded by armed gendarmes, and the man inside rarely ventures forth in public.

In a tense and ugly moment in a crowded room overlooking Eighth Avenue yesterday, Cassius Clay called Ernie Terrell an "Uncle Tom" and slapped him on the arm over the heads of bystanders scrambling between the two heavyweight boxers.
The Manhattan Advisory Committee of the New York Urban League will hold a New Year's reception at the Gallery of Modern Art on Jan. 8.
Charles C. Bassine, chairman of Spartans Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the first assignments of management supervision for the E.J. Korvette Division, Spartans and Korvette merged Sept. 25.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Nature, according to a computer analysis, has set a limit of about two weeks on how far ahead man can predict the weather.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 28 Finance Minister Peter D'Aguiar, leader of the United Force party, the junior party in the two-year-old coalition Government, has threatened to resign in disagreement with Prime Minister Forbes Burnham over Cabinet changes.

BANDUNG, Indonesia They're stomping again at the Savoy-Homann. It's a pretty sedate stomp, and the management of the largest and best-known hostelry here still puts up a sign outside its ground-floor lounge on Saturday nights that says, "Twist and Jiving Forbidden."

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 28 Henry F. Schricker, the only Indiana Governor ever elected to two terms, died today in Starke County Memorial Hospital at Knox, Ind. He way 83 years old, and had been in the hospital since Dec. 1.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 28 (AP) The head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, Assistant United States Attorney General John M. Doar, said in a letter received yesterday by the Houston School District that the city was not following its announced plan to desegregate schools.
THE season of mittens lost and strayed is upon us and, next to one shoe, there are few things less useful than a lone mitten.
YONKERS, Dec. 28 As deftly as a seamstress threads a needle, a helicopter deposited a 2,750-pound steel condenser through a roof to the eighth floor of a sugar factory here today.
Profit taking by speculators emerged in trading on the commodities exchanges yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (UPI) John L. Waner, an industrialist, who managed Charles H. Percy's victorious campaign for Illinois Senator here, was nominated today as a Republican candidate for Mayor of Chicago.

A suggestion that private citizens examine the Federal budget when it is made public and make recommendations on revisions was advanced yesterday by Dr. Raymond J. Saulnier, professor of economics at Barnard College and at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission said today it would allow more time before new rates for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Telpak services become effective.

One plus one adds up to two in almost anyone's thinking. But in the case of the two-income, working-wife family "it ain't necessarily so," as the song plaintively holds. To- day 25 million women work, out of the nation's total labor force of 73 million. Of these 25 million women, about three-fifths are working wives, many of them with children.

LAS CRUCES, N.M., Dec. 28 (UPI) Lawyers for Diane Smith, a murder suspect, changed their minds late today and agreed to allow news media to attend her preliminary hearing, earlier ordered closed in a move apparently unprecedented in New Mexico.
District Attorney-elect Thomas J. Mackell of Queens announced yesterday that all 43 of his assistant district attorneys would give up the private practice of law.
British Government bonds advanced yesterday in a firm but quiet market on the London Stock Exchange.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) Gov.-elect Ronald Reagan today appointed Earl Coke of San Francisco as Director of Agriculture the man in charge of California's biggest industry.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 James J. McGuiness, Albany lawyer and former Democratic Assemblyman, died yesterday at his home here. He was 63 years old.

A close associate of Senator Robert F. Kennedy said yesterday that any criticism of President Johnson in William Manchester's book, "The Death of a President," came not from Mrs. John F. Kennedy but from other sources.
SMITHTOWN, L. I., Dec. 28 Suffolk County, long noted for its beaches, ducks, golf courses and fishing waters, is getting deeper into the ski act.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 28 The Foreign Ministers of the six Common Market countries France, West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg agreed last week that further study was required before the Common Market Commission could receive a mandate to negotiate with Spain.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 28 Israeli soldiers patrolling the northeastern frontier today uncovered the first attempted sabotage on the Syrian border in nearly two months.
Rod Steiger is ill and will not be able to appear in "Galileo" with the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center.

MADRID, Dec. 28 The possibility of the first railroad strike in Spain since before the civil war began 30 years ago was raised here tonight as union leaders met in an emergency session to demand the payment of the legal minimum salary to the workers of Spain's national railways.
PARIS, Dec. 28 The Rev. Martin Niemoller and three other well-known Western clergymen announced today that they were on their way to Hanoi on a mission of "peace and sympathy."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration is renewing warnings to physicians restricting the use of four potassiumcoated prescription drugs to treatment of only serious cases of edema.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 The Mas- sachusetts Legislature quickly approved today an investigation of the fiery crash of a selfpropelled diesel passenger car and a stalled fuel oil truck at a grade crossing shortly after midnight in neighboring Everett.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that if a suspected crime unknown to the police is uncovered in the course of electronic eavesdropping into a crime they are investigating, the evidence is admissible in court.

During his Christmas visit to American troops in South Vietnam, Cardinal Spellman ignited a sharp controversy by describing the hostilities as a war for civilization and calling for an unqualified victory.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the volume of outstanding commercial paper rose $1.1-billion, or 9 per cent, to a record $14,156,000,000 in November.
HONG KONG, Thursday, Dec. 29 (Reuters) United States planes dumped gas canisters on a South Vietnamese village in Tayninh Province on Dec. 16 and 17, the North Vietnamese press agency said today.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 28 (UPI) Gov. Edmund G. Brown, in one of his last official acts, commuted the death sentences of four murderers today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 28 South Vietnamese troops have killed 89 Vietcong guerrillas in an operation in the Mekong Delta launched with the only large-scale para- chute assault of the year, a Government military spokesman said tonight.
CAIRO, Dec. 28 The Sudanese Government announced today that it had crushed a revolt by troops from a Khartoum garrison early in the morning.

The Episcopal Church of the Epiphany was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Miss Nancy Champe and Merz Kenton Peters. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Carlton George Champe of Rumford Center, Me., and New York, and Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Orval Peters of Gaithersburg, Md.

BONN, Dec. 28 The appearance of a recruiting advertisement for the West German Bundeswehr (armed forces) in the official newspaper of the ultrarightist National Democratic party has produced a flood of public criticism here.

LONDON, Dec. 28 In the six days that have elapsed since an official inquiry headed by Earl Mountbatten concluded that no prison in Britain was really secure, the nation's prison population has gone out of its way to prove him right.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 A group of American citizens and their families and close dependents, 200 persons in all, have been permitted to leave Cuba after protracted negotiations.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 28 The marriage of Miss Sheila Martin, daughter of Mrs. Richard McFall Martin and the late Mr. Martin, to William Mackintosh 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mackintosh Jr. of Little Compton, R. I., took place this afternoon.

Paperboard production rose 6.2 per cent with 459,100 tons in the week ended Dec. 24 from 432,000 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 28 (UPI) Bill Shoemaker brought the favored Natashka home a half-length ahead of Admirably today to win the $25,250 Las Flores Handicap before 25,000 spectators at Santa Anita.
Anyone for golf? The answer must be yes, since more and more companies are jumping on the golf cart and sponsoring tournaments.
The heads of the second and third largest American steel producers warned yesterday of tougher import competition in simultaneous year-end statements.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) Many children who stayed up late tonight to see a special television version of Lewis Carroll's "Alice in Wonderland" found the show boring.
Percy E. Sutton, Borough President of Manhattan, anpounced yesterday that he wanted additional funds next year to establish 12 Little Borough Halls in Manhattan.
ATLANTA, Dec. 28 A medical officer from Brooklyn was charged today at Fort Jackson, S.C., with refusing to teach a medical skill to be used by Special Forces troops in Vietnam and elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The Mexican airplane will make two more flights between Havana and Merida tomorrow to evacuate the 112 others who are now authorized to leave Cuba.
MONTREAL, Dec. 28 (AP) Wayne Connelly's goal with fewer than 2 minutes remaining gave the Boston Bruins a 1-1 National Hockey League tie with the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

Underdeveloped nations could be helped to accomplish economic stability by more "compensatory financing" to limit variations in export earnings and by new commodity agreements covering some additional primary products.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 29 (AP) Following is the broadcast text of Communist China's announcement, as monitored here, that it has conducted a new nuclear explosion:
DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) An interfaith seminar on how to avoid fighting in Vietnam attracted about 60 draft-age youths to Detroit Central Methodist Church today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (UPI) Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz questioned today the "credibility" of news media in covering Government affairs.
The National Council on the Arts is developing a wide-ranging program in the visual arts to aid artists and museums across the country.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- In still another move by a tobacco company to protect future earnings by diversification, the British-American Tobacco Company has decided to bid for shares of Yardley, the perfume and cosmetics concern.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 28--Hanoi officials say they have blueprints for a complete new capital to be built after the war on a site already selected not far from the present capital. The new capital is being planned on the assumption that sooner or later Hanoi will be destroyed in the war.
HARTSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 28 Evergreens, holly and red carnations decorated the Scarsdale Golf Club tonight for the presentation of 21 daughters of club members at the annual Holly Ball.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 28 (UPI) The Green Bay Packers drilled in clear, cold weather for about an hour this morning, then moved indoors to complete the workout on the 10.5acre concrete floor of the Tulsa Exposition Center.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 28 (AP) An earthquake that collapsed houses and crumpled stone walls rolled across copper-mining country in northern Chile today. Officials reported that three persons had been killed and six injured.

NEWARK, Dec. 28 Gov. Richard J. Hughes, sensitive to statewide Democratic election losses last November, appealed to the state labor movement today to start thinking about "rewarding its friends and punishing its enemies" in the year ahead.
A Buildings Department inspector was arrested yesterday on charges of extortion and accepting bribes and unlawful fees from a Bronx contractor. The amount involved was $75.
A white physician has charged in a Federal Court suit that he was dismissed from the city's Coney Island Hospital because of his race. He said he would not have been dismissed if he had been a Negro.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Both exports and imports declined in November and the trade surplus narrowed from the October level, the Department of Commerce reported today.
The Port of New York Au- thority raised its estimate of the total cost of the World Trade Center by $50-million last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) The wife of Liu Shao-chi, Communist China's chief of state, has made a written confession saying she has betrayed the teachings of Mao Tse-tung, The Washington Post said today.

Eugene Picker, a vice president of United Artists since 1961, has resigned to become executive vice president of the Trans-Lux Corporation and the president of its entertainment division. The Trans-Lux Corporation operates theaters and imports and distributes films.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The International Association of Fire Fighters named a nine-man commission today to consider altering the union's no-strike policy.
LEONARD BERNSTEIN, returning to the podium of the New York Philharmonic in Philharmonic Hall last night, had chosen three diverse works for his program that managed to do several things.
LISBON, Dec. 28 Portugal, entering her sixth year of guerrilla warfare in Africa, has set aside 38 per cent of her 1967 budget for defense.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) The 1967 edition of "Your Federal Income Tax" is now available for 50 cents a copy, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

Providence and St. Joseph's, both champions of Christmastime tournaments a year ago, meet tonight at Madison Square Garden to settle the championship of the 15th annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Basketball Festival.

YODER, Kan., Dec. 29 (UPI) --Plans for the first full-scale legal review of the rights of Amish parents to send their children to church-operated schools were announced today with the opening of a fundraising campaign by a national committee of educators.

VAN WERT, Ohio, Dec. 29-- Miss Susan Emily Sharp, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Clinton Sharp, was married here this afternoon to George McGill Carter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Jr. of Wayzata, Minn. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. William Irwin Carter, the bridegroom's uncle, with the Rev. Robert L. McCachran, the church's pastor, assisting.
Donald Wideroter of Valley Stream, L.I., and Vannie Edwards of Shreveport, La., were named yesterday to head the Amateur Athletic Union gymnastics program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29-- Mrs. Adam Clayton Powell risked a contempt of Congress citation and loss of a $20,578 annual salary for not obeying a subpoena to appear here today to testify before a House subcommittee.
The name of State Senator Ivan L. Warner was drawn back into the Bronx trial of State Senator-elect Eugene Rodriguez by the defense yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (AP)--An economist says he is against developing supersonic transport planes now, because it does not appear they would be profitable to operate.

THE pioneers never knew how underprivileged they were. However, that seems to be the fate of all pioneers. They are grateful for even small favors and really don't become envious of those who profit later from their trailblazing activities. The old-timers merely give their shoulders a philosophic shrug and say, "I guess I was born too soon."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)--An issue that bloomed during last summer's six-week airlines strike--whether the Railway Labor Act should be junked--has blossomed anew.

The election of Matthew G. Ely Jr. as secretary of Horace S. Ely Co. has been announced by the real estate concern that Mr. Ely's grandfather founded. He continues as vice president and a director of the company.
An agreement was reached yesterday between the city and the union representing 3,500 supervisory employes in the Welfare Department, hospital-care investigators and dental assistants.
Measures to make, public authorities more responsive to the will of the people were recommended yesterday by a legislative committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) --The Government accepted today $562,935 in settlement of a damage suit it had filed against six manufacturers of aluminum conductor cable who were charged with price fixing and rigging bids.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (Reuters) --Bertrand Russell has sent a seven-man team to Hanoi to investigate bomb damage in North Vietnam.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Dec. 29--Some of the best New Year weekend skiing in many winters is expected throughout upper New York and New England as a result of an overnight snowfall that dumped from 6 to 12 inches of powder on almost all snowrunning centers.

Emmette Bryant, who played exceptionally well in the New York Knicks' victory over the Los Angeles Lakers Wednesday afternoon in Madison Square Garden, has been lost to the team again for an indefinite period.

"THE DISPLACED PERSON," which opened at the American Place Theater last night, is a series of character vignettes that revolve as slowly, as regularly, and as indifferently as the blades of a windmill or the silent arrows of a weather vane.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--A recent nuclear experiment in a salt dome in Mississippi was reported today to have established the possibility of concealing an atomic test by conducting it in a large underground cavern.

Miss Theresa Monka, daughter of Mrs. Stephen Monka of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and the late Mr. Monka, was married here yesterday morning to Daniel P. Hollman, a hearing officer to the Civilian Complaint Review Board of the city's Police Department. He is the son of Mrs. son of Mrs. Daniel Hollman of Manhattan and the late Mr. Hollman.
Three major New York banks announced yesterday the promotions of executives.
LONDON, Dec. 29--A frigate without a name was unceremoniously launched today by a foreman at the Yarrow shipyard, Scotstoun, Glasgow.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday it had accepted a settlement award of $6.8-million in its five-yearold, trade-secret damage suit against Vokin Holdings, Inc., of White Plains.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth E. Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril Valentine Moore of Westerly, R.I., to Frank Janeway Keeler, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Martyn D. Keeler of Williamsville, N.Y., took place last evening in the chapel of the Central Presbyterian Church.

It is keenly disappointing that the Port of New York Authority, after lengthy study of possible sites for a fourth major jetport in the metropolitan area, has simply wound up exactly where it started. The authority can still think of nothing better to suggest than building the jetport in the Great Swamp in Morris County, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--An economist formerly on the staff of the Office of Economic Opportunity said today that evaluations of community action programs, though good and expensive, were scarcely influencing the agency's policies at all.
News from Africa helped to stir activity in copper futures yesterday, but prices still ended on the downside.

New Yorkers seemed prepared to bury unpleasant thoughts of war in Vietnam, and other lesstraumatic tensions of 1966, in New Year's Eve celebrations tomorrow night that may rival anything since World War II in gaiety and cost.
Hospital rates in many voluntary institutions in the city will increase from 10 to 22 per cent, effective Sunday.
PEKING, Dec. 29 (Reuters) --Red Guards and other citizens staged day-long celebrations today after the announcement that Communist China had carried out its fifth nuclear test.

The Anaconda Company announced a price increase yesterday for the copper content of brass products. A spokesman insisted that the move was unrelated to basic producer prices and was not to be construed as the beginning of a wedge into a general rise.
Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., edged Cicero Murphy of New York, 150-148, last night in seven innings and maintained a slim lead in the defense of his world pocket billiards title.

DALLAS, Dec. 29--Don Meredith, who once was known locally as Dandy Don and may be again, said today that it would take 28 points "and maybe a field goal" for the Dallas Cowboys, Meredith's team, to beat the Green Bay Packers in the National Football League's championship game here Sunday.

A predawn rainstorm struck the city yesterday, delaying subways in Brooklyn, disrupting traffic in Manhattan, disconnecting many telephones and dismaying some residents of Queens, who peered cut their windows and didn't quite believe their eyes.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Dec. 29 (AP)--Gov. Grant Sawyer has been offered the governorship of the Panama Canal Zone, a source close to the Nevada Governor said today.
Signs that money is getting easier were evident in statistics released yesterday by the Federal-Reserve.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29--Back on Nov. 12, Mississippi defeated Tennessee, 14-7, largely because Ole Miss got to the Vols' record passer, Dewey Warren, by way of a strong rush up front.

State Supreme Court Justice Victor L. Anfuso, an Italian immigrant who shined the shoes of some of the people he later represented in Congress, died of a heart attack late Wednesday night: He was 61 years old and lived at 25 Clark Street in Brooklyn.
Hector Hollister, president of the W.R. Kelly Company, mortgage bankers in Washington, died of a heart attack Tuesday on a street near his home there. He was 53 years old.

Leonid Brezhnev has succeeded in performing a major feat that Nikita Khrushchev was unable to accomplish despite his best efforts. It is the breakthrough in food production which Khrushchev sought unsuccessfully from 1959 to 1964.
SPANKING white ice skates barely got out of their Christmas wrappings this week when they were laced around wobbly ankles on the city's ice rinks.
As bond investors and traders hurried to get under the yearend wire, the various sectors of the credit markets moved in different directions yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The United Automobile Workers union charged the nation's labor federation today with complacency and a failure to fulfill the aims of the 1955 merger.

NEWARK, Dec. 29--Leo Cluesmann, a musician and a lawyer who was international secretary of the American Federation of Musicians from 1942 to 1959, died Saturday in St. Michael Hospital here after a brief illness.
The bombing of North Vietnam has been both effective and restrained, military offi- cials in the Pentagon said yes- terday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 29-- The Baghdad radio announced tonight that the Iraq Petroleum Company would pay the Iraqi Government $93.256-million tomorrow in quarterly oil royalties.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 29 (UPI)--Jack Brabham of Australia began his quest for a second straight world driving title today by shattering the lap record on the Kyalami circuit in trials for Monday's South African Grand Prix.
A controversial landlord "hot line" law, signed by Mayor Lindsay on Dec. 22, is being modified to meet objections that it amounts to "house arrest" of multiple-dwelling owners.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 29--Miss Susan Goodwin Goldberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Goldberg, was married here this evening to Robert S. Solomon, son of Mrs. Seymour Solomon of East Orange and the late Mr. Solomon.
About 2,400 persons gave a warm reception last night at Carnegie Hall to Patrick Sky, a folk singer, song writer and sometime comedian.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29-- Arthur J. Goldberg, Chief United States representative at the United Nations, defended today the Administration's support of United Nations economic sanctions against Rhodesia.
Joseph M. Kirchheimer and Philip Clark will be admitted as general partners of Burnham Co. on Jan. 1, the New York Stock Exchange firm announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 (UPI)-- The Wayne County Circuit Court declared unconstitutional today a Detroit law that allowed home owners to refuse to rent or sell their property to anyone for any reason, including race.

This administrative letter is written upon the instruction of the U.A.W. International Executive Board. Its purpose is to clarify current problems with regard to the relationship of the U.A.W. with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

BUFFALO, Dec. 29--Three little ladies from the metropolitan area--Mary Lynn Gelderman of Wantagh, L.I., Louise Vacca of Lindenhurst, L.I., and Joanne Darakjy of North Caldwell, N.J.--took the top three places in the novice women's division of the Eastern figure skating championships tonight on the Dann Memorial rink.

DALLAS, Dec. 29 (AP)-- The coaches of the Cotton Bowl teams concerned themselves today with building up the other team and discussing the effect rain might have on Saturday's game between Southern Methodist and Georgia.
COLUMBUS, Ohio. Dec. 30 (AP)--Three prisoners were credited today with saving the life of a prison supervisor during a $2-million fire at the Lebanon Correctional Institution.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 29--Paul Hornung, who has had the knack of making the big plays in the big games for the Green Bay Packers, was pronounced physically fit today for the National League championship game in Dallas Sunday.
BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP)--Heavy snow and high winds struck New England today. Snow warnings were issued for northeastern New York and sections of Maine, Vermont and New Hampshire.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 29--After nearly six months of diplomatic bickering, Dutch officials talked today with eight Chinese technicians who have been living in their Government's diplomatic office here since the mysterious death of a ninth technician July 17.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 29 --Capt. Murray B. Frazee Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Frazee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Carolyn Frazee, to David Deas Sinkler Poor of Washington. Mr. Poor's parents are Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Army Charles L. Poor of Washington and Mrs. John F. Tynan of Annapolis, Md., and New Delhi.
Sales and earnings of the Beatrice Foods Company for the three and nine months ended Nov. 30 set records, William G. Karnes, president, reported yesterday.
Already a year late, the city's $100-million electronic trafficcontrol program is in a jam, and the patience of almost everyone involved with it is beginning to wear a little thin.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP)--Some 500 members of the American Philosophical Association's Eastern Division have approved a resolution morally opposing the war in Vietnam.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 29 (UPI)--The State of Pennsylvania will ask the United States Supreme Court tomorrow not to delay further the proposed merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.
DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Seven libel suits seeking more than $11-million in damages from The Detroit News and three Republican leaders were dismissed today in Wayne County District Court.

ATLANTA, Dec. 29 (AP)-- The American Civil Liberties Union said today it would defend a Fort Jackson (S.C.) medical officer charged with willfully disobeying orders and making disloyal statements about American involvement in Vietnam.

The engagement of Miss Leslie Gibbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Gibbs of 325 East 79th Street, to Stephen B. Mackler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Mackler of Smithfield, N.C., has been announced by the future bride's parents. A June wedding is planned.

MISSOULA, Mont., Dec. 29 (UPI)--The University of Montana dismissed its football coach, Hugh C. Davidson, today, shifted Dr. Walter C. Schwank, the athletic director, to a new position, and named a high school athletic director and coach in Olympia, Wash., to fill both vacated jobs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI)--In the days after the assassination of John F. Kennedy, President Johnson gave in to many "unusual demands" by the Kennedy family, a news magazine reported today.

ALBANY, Dec. 29--Motorcycle operators and passengers must wear approved protective helmets and the operators must either wear safety glasses or use a windscreen under a new state law that becomes effective Jan. 1.
LONDON, Dec. 29--Lord Brain, an eminent neurologist, a national figure in medical affairs and a distinguished writer died at his home here today. He was 71 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) --Nearly half of all Americans suffer from a chronic disease, a Senate report disclosed today. It said the estimated cost of this to the economy was $57.8billion a year.

VAIL, Colo., Dec. 29 (AP)-- Rich Chaffee, a university of Denver student from Rutland, Vt., won the slalom at the Alpine Holiday Ski Classic at the Vail course today. He also took the giant slalom on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)--A computer "fever chart" for nations in trouble-- designed to predict those that will face internal revolt and perhaps those that will start wars --was reported today.
CAIRO, Dec. 29--The government-controlled Cairo press reported today that Amman had refused to admit Iraqi and Saudi Arabian troops to Jordan to help defend the country's long border with Israel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29-- Robert M. Ball, Commissioner of Social Security, reported today that one of every nine Americans now receives cash benefits from one or more of the many programs run by his agency.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 29 --Mr. and Mrs. Edward F.X. Ryan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deirdre Caitlin Ryan, to Eric Felix Menoyo. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ehrique Menoyo of Pelham Manor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--It appears that the blue whale, largest creature that has ever moved across the face of the earth, has a fighting chance of being saved from extinction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI)--The American Bankers Association said today it saw nothing sinister whenever trust accounts administered by banks invested in bank stocks.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 29 (UPI) --White House Press Secretary George Christian underwent surgery at Seton Hospital today for the removal of part of a spinal disk.

LONDON, Dec. 29--Protests mounted today against the reported United States bombing of civilian areas in North Vietnam and the British Governments' recent reluctance to condemn American bombing policy.
The nation will soon know whether the House of Representatives has the will to do anything about the lawless and contemptuous behavior of Adam Clayton Powell, Member of Congress from Manhattan.
Coach Hank Stram attended a sendoff luncheon today for his Kansas City Chiefs. For dessert, he received a new five-year contract.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday, which was 102.9.
The New York Jets came up with a present yesterday for Joe Namath, their quarterback who is convalescing from knee surgery. They gave him a new pass receiver with an impeccable family background.
A Bronx man who was fined $6 for selling scorecards outside Yankee Stadium without a license has taken his case to the state's highest court and won a reversal of his conviction.

Ray C. Schlotterer, executive secretary, of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association, 2 Lexington Avenue, died Tuesday at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at Saddle River, N.J.

The publisher of The Amsterdam News, Dr. C.B. Powell, yesterday announced the resignation of Earl Brown as executive editor, effective today. He has been ill recently and has not worked for several weeks.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation yesterday started a $7.5million program to stem what it called the decline of science education in the nation's independent liberal arts colleges.

WHAT was obviously intended by Channel 9 to be a light-hearted report on some of the men who have served New York State well or ill as its Governor showed up on the home screen last night as a witless exercise in journalistic triviality. "The Albany Capers" was little more than a catalogue of officeholders, beginning with George Clinton, the first Governor, and ending with Governor Rockefeller.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 29 (Reuters)--The New Zealand sloop, Fidelis, seemed an almost certain winner today in the 640mile Sydney-to-Hobart ocean yacht race.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 29--Jelled fuel was successfully used to ground-run a powerful jet engine, the Federal Aviation Agency's National Aviation Facilities Experimental Center announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29-- The United States lost another $49-million of gold in November, bringing the loss for the year to date to $544-million, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29--The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in a far-reaching opinion, ruled today that guidelines of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare should be followed by Federal courts in school desegregation orders.
The Metropolitan Opera will provide chartered buses to the Upper East Side after each evening performance in January, it was decided yesterday.

SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 29--The marriage of Miss Deborah A. Oakes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Oakes, to Lieut. Richard Merrill Whitney Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney of West Roxbury, took place here this afternoon in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

The anonymity of contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund who ask not to be named is scrupulously observed in listing their gifts on these pages, but some of these donors express sentiments worth sharing.
ARTHUR KNAPP was "on the floor" yesterday, a phone call to Wall Street disclosed.
The Inter-American Press Association protested yesterday a restrictive press bill that President Humberto Castelo Branco of Brazil has sent to Congress.
Blyth Co., Inc., the New York investment banker and broker, announced yesterday the acquisition of all of the shares of the Banque Mobiliere et Industrielle of Paris.
Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet announced yesterday that the city was negotiating to take over a portion of St. Francis Hospital and provide out-patient services for residents in the South Bronx area.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29-- A suit to halt the proposed merger of the Provident National Bank and the Central-Penn National Bank was dismissed here today by Chief Judge Thomas J. Clary in Federal District Court.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 28, (AP) --More than 400 angry customers stormed the admissions office and ticket booths at the Laurel race course today when the day's program was canceled 25 minutes before post time.
LONDON, Dec. 29--The publishing of organization of Lord Thomson of Fleet finally abandoned today its plans for two new newspapers near London.
TRENTON, Dec. 29--The State Commission on the Defense of Indigent Persons Accused of Crime recommended today that New Jersey establish a public-defender system.
Three promotions have been announced at Philip Morris Domestic, the largest of the three operating companies of Philip Morris, Inc., and one at the publishing company of McGraw-Hill, Inc.

In your talk to the student interns last summer, as on other occasions, you have recognized and discussed problems that have been troubling members of our generation. We have been grateful for your concern and encouraged by your invitation to express some of our thoughts.
TOKYO, Dec. 29 (Reuters)-- Red Guards denounced Foreign Minister then Yi in their wall posters in Peking yestrday, a Japanese correspondent reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (UPI)--Louisville outlasted Syracuse, 75-71, tonight to reach the final of the Quaker City basketball tournament.
Michael P. Grace 2d of Dallas, an heir to a shipping, chemical, oil, banking and beer fortune, filed suit yesterday against his brother, Joseph Peter Grace Jr. of New York City for $15-million.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 29-- President Johnson discussed his War on Poverty with Sargent Shriver today and hinted that they were developing new proposals to extend the Head Start program into the early school years.
ALBANY, Dec. 29--A state commission recommended today that certain "peace officers" be limited in their powers to make arrests and carry weapons.
Stocks were firm on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, continuing their recent trend.
The American Biltrite Rubber Company, a Chelsea, Mass., producer of heels, soles and floor tiles, announced yesterday the election of David W. Bernstein as president.

HONG KONG, Dec. 29--Analysts of Chinese affairs said here today that leaders of the opposition to Mao Tse-tung and Lin Piao within the Chinese Communist party might have used self-criticism as a tactical maneuver.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday that Everett N. Case, chairman of the bank since the beginning of this year, has been reappointed to a three-year term to begin Jan. 1.
The second volume of the "Great Dictionary of the Yiddish Language" will be published today, with aleph, "A," the most prolific initial letter in the Hebrew alphabet, still going strong.
PARIS, Dec. 29--Marc Chagall, who is staying in his Riviera home at Saint-Paul-deVence, is not aware of the case of the missing water colors at a Moscow gallery, according to friends.

Teledyne, Inc., an aviation and electronics equipment manufacturer in Los Angeles, said yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Brown Engineering Company, a producer of aerospace and electronic hardware with headquarters in Huntsville, Ala.

The Federal Communications Commission in Washington gave formal approval yesterday to the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas to expand its Columbia Pictures Corporation stockholdings.

SASKATOON, Sask., Dec. 29 (AP)--Bob Seagren of Los Angeles soared 17 feet 1 inch tonight, breaking his world indoor pole-vault record by a quarter of an inch in the Knights of Columbus Games. Seagren set the record on his first try at the height.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29-- The Defense Department contended today that North Vietnamese figures on the number of civilians killed by American aircraft in Namdinh indicated "precise, careful bombing" in view of the number of raids on military targets there.
Twenty-nine American authorities on Germany have signed a statement declaring that recent state elections in West Germany do not indicate a rebirth of Nazism.

A wind-whipped fire swept the top floors of an old Brooklyn hotel early this morning, and a woman resident, her clothes on fire, dropped 11 floors to her death out of the grasp of two firemen whose ladder reached to within a few feet of her.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29-- Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy faces trial next month in a civil suit that, if it were a criminal case, would mean that the highly respected wife of the New York Senator was accused of being a horse thief.
The Standard Bank Group of London announced yesterday it had acquired franchises to operate Diners' Club, Inc., plans in East, Central and West Africa. It already holds a franchise for South Africa.
John B. Balmer was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the Wallace-Murray Corporation, a New York producer of automotive components and plumbing fixtures.

The parents of 650 teen-agers paid $18 a ticket for them to attend the Gold and Silver Ball in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom last night. Some of the youngsters were given $11 more to start the evening with a dutch treat dinner in the hotel's Baroque Suite.

The city received a Federal grant yesterday that will clear the way for the construction of two rent-controlled apartment dwellings and the long-awaited new high school of music and the performing arts opposite Lincoln Center.

Negro, leader after Negro leader defended Representative Adam Clayton Powell here yesterday and charged that any effort to unseat him would be viewed not as an attack on Representative Powell, but as an attack on all Negroes.

Columbia University said yesterday that its School of Dental and Oral Surgery had been restored as a fully approved institution by the American Dental Association. The school has been operating for two years with provisional accreditation.

Construction contracts continued to drop in November, joining the downtrend of several other important economic indicators. The contract figure for the month was 8 per cent below the level in the month a year earlier.

The long proxy fight for control of the Studebaker Corporation was formally settled yesterday in United States District Court in Grand Rapids, Mich., with the signing of an order by Judge Noel P. Fox.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- Francis Gloyd Awalt, a lawyer who was Acting Controller of the Currency during the banking crisis of 1932-33, died Wednesday. His age was 71.

IOWA CITY, Dec. 30 (UPI)-- Dr. James A. Van Allen, the scientist, said today that an American lunar probe, which failed in its primary mission, had confirmed a theoretical concept of an interplanetary shock wave.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- The Government was urged today to divert one month's war expenses in Vietnam to support an international peace force to seal off infiltration from the North into South Vietnam.
At least 50 persons saw a man shot and critically injured in the subway eight days ago but only four have come forward with information, the police said yesterday.
William A. Jordan was named yesterday an executive vice president of the P. Lorillard Company, producer of Kent, Newport, Old Gold and True cigarettes.
Two Republican judges who failed to win election in November were given new bench appointments yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

DALLAS, Dec. 30--The weather report for tomorrow is for "scattered showers," during the Cotton Bowl game between Georgia and Southern Methodist, a development that would affect the playing field for Sunday's National Football League championship game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The Treasury bill rate rose slightly at today's auction after several weeks of steep decline, the Treasury said tonight.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 30 (Reuters)--President Sukarno has finally bowed before pressure and will give a public account of the policies that led to last year's attempted Communist takeover in Indonesia.
A voice identified as that of State Senator-elect Eugene Rodriguez was heard on tape recordings in his Bronx trial yesterday, promising to "fix" a narcotics case for $50,000.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec 30--The dock workers of Saigon tonight accepted terms proposed by the United States Army and ended their five-day strike.

THESE two books, a novel and a group of short stories by two of Germany's best known writers whose reputations in the United States are already high, can fit neatly under the title of one of them, "Two Views." One deals with the fight for liberty, the other with the uses to which it is put.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 30 (UPI)--Cardinal Spellman called on Roman Catholics throughout the world today to pray that the Communists see the light and bring peace to Vietnam.

The Coast Guard was hampered by language difficulties yesterday in its efforts to rescue the Liberian freighter Georgia as she was being battered in heavy Atlantic seas. The crew, which is of Greek origin, apparently knows little English. The ship lacks a radio telephone, and all messages were sent by wireless.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- The State Department said tonight it had not received the formal British proposal for a three-power meeting to negotiate an end to the war in Vietnam.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 30 (UPI)--Dennis Hulme of New Zealand had the fastest run on the Kyalami circuit today, an average lap speed of 103.01 miles an hour, in preparation for Monday's South African Grand Prix.

RYE, N. Y., Dec. 30--Miss Carolyn Marjorie Messiter, daughter of Mrs. S. S. Messiter of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Messiter of Dallas, was married here tonight to Lyle Dennison Van Valkenburgh Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Valkenburgh of Rye.
Mark J. Sloman, who retired seven years ago as a vice president of Reporter Publications, publishers of American Fabrics magazine, died yesterday in his home at the Surrey Hotel. His age was 78.
Negotiators for The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Guild continued their efforts yesterday to reach agreement on a new contract.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The I Council of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which represents, by and large, the American scientific community, expressed today its concern over the danger of biological and chemical agents that modify the environment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- Light from some laser beams could almost blast a man's eye out of his head, a scientist said today.
NEW YEAR'S Eve is a proper moment to pay tribute to drinking glasses. Some of the best such vessels of the 17th and 18th centuries were produced in Britain.
The American Stock Exchange made a last try for a year-end rally yesterday but didn't make it. The final session of the year was an exciting one, nevertheless.

DETROIT. Dec. 30 (AP)-- William S. Brittain, a World War I Army lieutenant whose act of heroism was cited by Gen. John J. Pershing as one of the great individual feats of the war, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 76 years old.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 30 (AP) --The Armco Steel Corporation achieved a partial victory today in its attempt to recover $1,784,493 in taxes that the company says it overpaid.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 30--Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga has offered a package of minor concessions to the Congolese Government in an effort to avert expropriation of its copper-producing properties in Katanga Province, authoritative sources reported today.

Vincent Kevin Drury, former Richmond County Clerk from 1935 to 1939, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 62 years old and lived at 49 Ward Avenue. Stapleton, S. I.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- A corporation executive. who has been active in studies of the patent system, received a patent this week himself. The inventor is Fred
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 30 (AP)--The 53-room mansion formerly owned by the late tobacco magnate, James B. Duke, was heavily damaged today by fire caused by a cigarette.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 30 --Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bell Laidlaw have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Colton Laidlaw, to Norman McLeod Carter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter.
The spot rate on the British pound was basically steady in moderate-to-active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

Tomorrow is the deadline for radio stations that have both AM and FM outlets in major cities to comply with a Federal ruling that programing on both channels not be duplicated more than 50 per cent of the time.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 30 (AP)--Representative H. R. Gross, Republican of Iowa, said today that the Kennedy Administration "either approved or condoned" wiretapping in a 1963 investigation of a now dismissed State Department employe.

DALLAS, Dec. 30--Jerry Levias, a split end who emerged as one of the most spectacular sophomores of the recent college football season, will be on display tomorrow for a national television audience when Southern Methodist University opposes Georgia in the 30th Cotton Bowl game.

DALLAS, Dcc. 30--The ability of Bob Hayes and Dan Reeves to complete the "big play" for the Dallas Cowboys represents the primary problem for the defensive unit of the Green Bay Packers in the National Football League championship game Sunday.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 30 (Reuters 1--Eight Chinese technicians left here for Peking today, ending a five-month diplomatic wrangle over the mysterious death of one of their colleagues.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30--Secretary General Thant called today for an early end to the war in Vietnam, which, he said, is preventing a "breakthrough in international cooperation."
"Art International: U.S.A.," the mammoth art show that was to open a six-week run at the Coliseum in June, has been canceled.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 30-- Sot Petrasy said today that the pro-Communist Pathet Lao, which he represents in Vientiane, was not planning to set up a separate government in opposition to Premier Souvanna Phouma's neutralist-rightist coalition.

CAFE SAHBRA, Hotel Westover, West End Avenue and 72d Street, "An Evening in Israel," with Joe Burns as master of ceremonies, the New Negev Dancers and Menasha Baharav and his orchestra. Held over: Guella Gill and her trio.

This is the season when Administration officials customarily don rose-colored glasses to give their forecasts of things to come. The first to do so was Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor, who glowingly predicted that the next twelve months will be another record-breaking year of expansion for business, bettering 1966 because credit will be easier and inflation less of a problem.

ALBANY, Dec. 30--Governor Rockefeller will appoint Gustave G. Rosenberg, former chairman of the New York City Board of Higher Education, as a State Supreme Court justice effective Monday, the Governor's office announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)--Dick Barnett and Willis Reed sparked a fourthquarter spurt tonight to lead the New York Knicks to a 130115 victory over the Baltimore Bullets. The triumph was the Knicks' fourth straight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)--The Civil Aeronautics Board pointedly told 18 airlines today to keep a close check on their lobbying tactics in the hotly contested trans-Pacific route case. Charles S. Murphy,

A Federal Government grant matching a $25,000 provision from the state of Missouri will enable the Repertory Theater of the Loretto-Hilton Center in Webster Groves, Mo., to go on tour with "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and "Twelfth Night."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- The Administration decided today, because of new Congressional restrictions on the Food for Peace program, to suspend the sale of surplus foods to Yugoslavia.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 30--Clarence M. Burchard, a retired vice president of Deering Milliken Inc., textile manufacturers, died here on Tuesday. He was 68 years old.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 30-- Breaking away in the last five minutes, Montclair State College captured the first annual Northern New Jersey Kiwanis basketball tournament tonight by defeating Fairleigh Dickinson, 70-67.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP)--Unbeaten Louisville, led by Westley Unseld and Butch Beard, won the sixth annual Quaker City basketball tournament tonight, dealing Princeton its first loss, 72-63, at the Palestra.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Communist China, in its latest atomic test, apparently was experimenting with a triple-stage bomb--the "dirtiest," most powerful type of atomic weapon. That was indicated today in an Atomic Energy Commission announcement of the results of its preliminary analysis of the radioactive debris from the Chinese explosion Tuesday in Sinkiang Province near Lob Nor.
Wearing black cowls and carrying grotesque masks impaled on poles, eight members of the Bread and Puppet theater group solemnly picketed St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 30--An old secret that technologists tried time and again to penetrate has finally been unraveled, scholars at a convention here were told today.

The Kaiser Aerospace and Electronics Corporation is acquiring from the Cox Broadcasting Corporation the 50 per cent interest held by Cox in the jointly owned Kaiser-Cox Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

The postal channels that link the Port of New York with the world were crowded with more than 200 million Christmas greetings this year.

Jeff Miller of Plainfield, N. J., won the boys' l6 years title in the Eastern junior and boys indoor tennis championships yesterday by defeating Greg Norris of Rumson, N. J., 11-9, 6-3, at the Midtown Tennis Club.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 30-- The wedding of Miss Katharine Kennedy Keith and Donald Eldredge Jackson 3d took place today in the Westminster Presbyterian Church, with the Rev. Arnold Lowe and the Rev. C. John Bates officiating.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday that it hoped to build a primary-aluminum smelter in Belgium, possibly to begin production by 1969.

Mayor Lindsay's administration has produced a simple, easily understandable tax form for residents and nonresidents who have to pay city income taxes next year. Yet these new forms will mean more paperwork and expense to taxpayers and less revenue for the city than they should. The reason was the refusal of Governor Rockefeller--and the Legislature --to permit the state to take over administration of the city's tax.

Roger Frederick Clark, one of the three beach boys who stole the: Star of India star sapphire from the American Museum of Natural History, was released yesterday after serving two years of a three-year sentence.
Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz has filed action in Federal Court here seeking to upset the election--held by the National Maritime Union last spring.
The old Metropolitan Opera House moved closer, perhaps decisively, toward demolition yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y. Dec. 30 (AP)--Production workers voted today to return to their jobs at the General Electric Company plant here, but a union spokesman said they would not do so until strikes by two other unions had been settled.
LONDON, Dec. 30--Britain invited the United States, North Vietnam and South Vietnam tonight to meet at once on British territory to "arrange a cession of hostilities" in Vietnam.

Three women and two men were plucked last night from a battered 70-foot yawl whose rigging was torn away in heavy Atlantic seas 360 miles southeast of New York. Five men remained aboard as a Coast Guard cutter headed for the scene to take the yawl in tow.
BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 30 (AP ) --Chase Addison Clark, former Governor of Idaho, died today after being hospitalized since Dec. 13. He was 83 years old.
Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller was sworn in for his third term as Governor at 12:23 P.M. yesterday.
Some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are sharing their Christmas gifts with the less fortu-, nate in the hope that 1967 will witness a world at peace.
A group of historians said yesterday that an advanced state of decay threatened the nationally famous Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature and Art in Harlem.
The stock market closed out the year in wild and woolly fashion yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) --President Johnson's Federal judicial appointments in 1966 topped the annual total made by any previous President and doubled the number of Negro Federal judges.
The city has entered a tentative agreement to take over a part of St. Francis Hospital for outpatient services, starting next Wednesday.
A fast-burning fire broke out in the superstructure for an office building being put up over Pennsylvania Station a few minutes before 2 A.M. today.
WASHINGTON, Dcc. 30 (AP)--The Agriculture Department reported today that prices for farm products declined by one-third of one per cent during the month ended Dec. 15.
NEWARK, Dec. 30--Fines of up to $100 and suspended 90day jail terms were imposed today on 45 motoreyclists rounded up by the police after a party became a riot here early last Saturday.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 30-- President Johnson let it be known today that he "strongly supports" his Administration's antipoverty programs and expects further progress from them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- Will "filet of wild gaur," lizard stew, or "sambar steak Provencale" be added to the roster of world delicacies?

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 30-- Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison agreed today to hire an architect, whom he had described as incompetent and politically appointed, to design an $18-million county office building.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec, 30 (AP)--Bob Ward, Maryland's first all-American, was hired today as the head football coach of his alma mater and was given a five-year contract at $20,000 annually.

The New York Knickerbockers, off to their best start in the National Basketball Association in eight years, close the 1966 portion of the campaign against the Cincinnati Royals tonight at Madison Square Garden.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 31--The second 48-hour truce in the war began at 7 o'clock this morning (6 P.M., Friday, New York time), tempered by South Vietnam's threat to reconsider its offer of another truce during the lunar New Year in mid-February.
ROCKVILLE, Conn., Dec. 30--A small fire insurance company here has decided to go out of business and donate its $500,000 in assets to the local hospital's building fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec.30 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission told the Supreme Court today that the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads could "fall apart" if indefinite delays sought by the Justice Department were approved.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP)-- The American Motors Corporation reported today it had given its top officers token pay raises in 1966 but had skipped for the second consecutive year the payment of any bonuses to them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)--The Department of Housing and Urban Development is the newest operative Cabinet Department, but its public relations people yield to no one in governmentese.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- Government officials today greeted with undisguised elation the decision by a United States Court of Appeals upholding the Federal school desegregation guidelines.

WARSAW, Dec. 30--High officials of the Communist leadership and the Roman Catholic Church held an unannounced meeting today to discuss the widening gulf between them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--A Federal Power Commission examiner proposed new and lower prices today for natural gas produced in southern Louisiana --a producing area that serves gas users in the entire eastern third of the United States.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Dec. 30 --Miss Rosemary Tenander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tuure Tenander, was married today to Richard Stirling Cross of the Air Force, son of Mr. and Mrs Richard E. Cross, of Detroit The Rev. Donald R. Goodness performed the ceremony it Christ Episcopal Church.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP)--America's Apollo 1 spaceship today successfully hurdled a rugged series of tests inside a vacuum chamber here, raising hopes that it may carry the nation's first three-man astronaut crew into orbit about Feb. 21.

ALL'S well that ends well in art and in memoriam. Five years after the competition win ning design for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt memorial in Washington was unveiled, attacked, revised, rejected and recommissioned, the Roosevelt Memorial Commission has released its new, handsome and, hopefully, final proposal.

A too-long-delayed act of justice has finally taken place in Yugoslavia with the release from prison of Milovan Djilas. WHEN home gardeners read in their nurserymen's catalogues this month that the strawberry plants offered for sale are virus-free, little do they realize the work involved to make this statement. For as any strawberry fancier knows, virus infection has been a constant threat to strawberry plant vigor and harvest. Viruses are spread in the field by aphids and they render the strawberry plants difficult to propagate.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 31 Miss Susan Carol Daunis, daughter of Rear Adm. Stanley Stephen Daunts, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Daunis was married this morning to Lieut. (jg.) Edward Robinson Fickenscher 3d, U.S.N., son of Captain Fickenscher Jr., U.S.N., and the late Mrs. Jane Schulte Fickenscher.
The 1967 licenses of more than 20 harness drivers are being withheld by the New York State Harness Racing Commission, it was reported yesterday.

IF only a Happening would happen in the Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum. If Henry Geldzahler could find the campy furniture he seeks. If the Government would just increase its financial support of the arts!

NEW DELHI, Dec. 3l At 3:34 P.M. last Monday, two burly Sikhs began placing perfumed sandalwood in concrete cylinders on the roof of Amritsar's Golden Temple while another mournfully intoned: "The time is drawing nigh, pray to God for only God can save our leaders."

PARIS, Dec. 31 (UPI) Aviation sources here greeted today the news that Boeing had won the competition for a supersonic airliner with quiet confidence that France and Britain's Concorde would sweep the "first generation" market.
The spirit of Hanoi as the year 1967 comes in seems to this American observer to be one of grit your teeth and prepare for the worst.

Jim Nance of the Boston Patriots, who became the most adept hit-and-run man in American Football League history this season, was selected yesterday as the league's player of the year in balloting by the United Press International board of experts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 A drive for automatic cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits is developing as one of the most promising projects of a strengthened Republican minority in the new Congress.
ALASSIO, Italy Midway between Nice and Genoa, along the Ligurian coast, lies the Riviera dei Fiori, with this bustling resort town as its main tourist center.

"The broadcaster cannot expect to have a key to the house, yet disregard to whom he lends it." This was the warning issued to television as the medium that has become for better or for worse the ever-present entertainer, teacher and seducer of pre-school children in homes all over the country and most of the industrialized world.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The manager and captain of the team that won the World Cup for England in World Cup in soccer were named today on a British New Year's honors list issued by Queen Elizabeth.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Dec. 31 (AP) Alaskans will set off their biggest celebration since statehood tomorrow.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Dec. 31 Mr. and Mrs. George Angus Douglass Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Douglass's daughter, Miss Laura Garmany Holt, to Mr. Douglass's son, Robert Gates Douglass. The future bride is the daughter also of Lamar Holt of Silver Spring, Md. Her fiance's mother is Mrs. David Prescott Hall, of Oxford, N.J.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 31 (AP) Dog Schollander of Yale won the 100- and 200meter free-style races at an international swimming meet today. He set an Irish allcomers' record for the longer event.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Dowling of Manhasset and Centerport Cove, L.I., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Helen Dowling, to David Paul Roselle, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Roselle of Apollo, Pa.
NASHVILLE, Dec. 31 A fully reapportioned and largely restructured Tennessee Legislature will convene here Tuesday to face a multiplicity of complex problems.
A design for a 500,000-ton oil tanker, twice the size of the largest now in operation, has just been completed by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 31 Secretary General Thant has called on the United States to take the first step, toward peace in Vietnam by halting the bombing of North Vietnam "even without conditions."
THIS department was left With one nagging question at the end of 1966. When Columbia University last year redesigned her doctoral academic dress, why was music represented by the color pink?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, vowed today that he would fight to repeal a law that would finance 1968 Presidential campaigns with tax revenue.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 31 Dr. Evans J. Crane, editor from 1914 and 1958 of Chemical Abstracts, the Americal Chemical Society's "key to the world's chemical literature" and winner of the Priestley Medal, highest award in American chemistry, died yesterday at the age of 77.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 31 Bob Strohmeier of the Larchmont Interclub fleet and Peter Bethge of the Sea Cliff Penguin fleet were the first-day leaders as 106 yachts sailed today in the 35th Frostbite Yacht Club New Year's regatta.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 "Tap 'er light," that old Butte copper miner, Mike Mansfield, will softly say to younger, impatient Democratic Senators when they urge him to put more force into his leadership and get more speed out of the creaky legislative machine.

KANSAS CITY, Dec.31 (AP) Carl Garrett, a sophomore speedster from New Mexico Highlands, heads a talent-laden backfield named today to the National Association of intercollegiate Athletics 1966 allstar football squad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 This is no ordinary New Year. We have now slipped into the last third of the twentieth century, and if its first two-thirds are any guide, the outlook is for a cataract of surprises that will transform the universe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (UPI)--The favored East, playing more like a pro eleven than a bunch of college seniors, rolled to a 45-22 victory, over the West today, with Danny Talbott of North Carolina, Nick Eddy of Notre Dame and Clinton Jones of Michigan State the individual offensive heroes.
The New York Rangers management has set aside $18,000 for player bonuses during the present National Hockey League season.

ST. LOUIS, Dec, 31 (UPI) Ken Holtzman, a left-handed pitcher for the Chicago Cubs, will share the St. Louis rookieof-the-year award presented by the St. Louis chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

HOLLYWOOD. MIKE NICHOLS, whose first film, "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?," focused in part on the disappointments of middle age, has now started work on his second picture, which deals with quite a different theme--the frustrations and rebellion of youth.

American underwriters are out to recapture a major segment of the $1.3-billion net marine premiums paid to insure the nation's exports, according to Walter Wells, vice president of the Marine Office of America.

"THE Killing of sister George" appears to be heading toward another killing in the ranks of movies with adult themes that are currently exciting artistic or profit-minded producers while giving conscientious objectors the fantods.

New England's 210 million pairs of shoes produced in 1966 is keeping its established 33 per cent of the industry's output for the nation. For four decades, the six-state area, particularly Massachusetts, Maine and New Hampshire, has been the top shoemaking region in the nation.
The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 332.2, from 310 the preceding week. A year earlier it was 289.3.
PARIS, Dec. 31 Paris is starting work on a new airport, Paris-Nord, that is expected to handle 20 million passengers a year. The first of its five units should be ready for service in 1972.

An office building of white concrete and glass rises dramatically atop a hill in a 165-acre woodland preserve near New Haven. The building is laid out in a square around an atrium and overlooks a tree-bordered pond.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 After months of protracted and complex negotiations, a chartered Mexican airliner lifted off the Havana airport late Wednesday bearing 64 United States citizens and 24 children most of them on their parents' laps home by way of Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 As a sad year of death and destruction comes to a close in Vietnam, no one can say with certainty that 1967 can bring that violated land and its tragic people nearer to peace. Still, this New Year's Eve, there are a few small suggestions of dawn somewhere beyond the dark night of war.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Dec. 31 Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Mehlig have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Ann Mehlig, to J. Winthrop Aldrich, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Aldrich of Woodbury, Conn. A June wedding is planned.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 31 (AP) Want Ritchie and Fred McCarthy scored two goals apiece today as Yale skated to a 5-2 victory over Princeton in a nonleague hockey game between the Ivy rivals.
DENVER, Dec. 31 (UPI) A 10-man and 5-woman United States ski team was chosen today. The team's first meet is Jan. 5 and 6 at Berchtesgaden, Germany. The competition will last three weeks.

ISLAMORADA, Fla. At 11:30 A.M. on Tuesday, about 100 baby green turtles born and captured in Costa Rica will be freed on Cape Sable, just across Florida Bay from here. The release of these amphibious reptiles, which has become an annual event in the last few years, is part of a program sponsored by the nonprofit Carribbean Conservation Corporation to save the green turtle from extinction.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 1 United States troops greeted the New Year by relaxing a little, but not too much, midway through the 48hour cease-fire.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 31 Gov. John B. Connally Jr. moved today to quiet some of the criticism surrounding the proposed Lyndon B. Johnson State Park by appointing John Ben Shepperd, a former Texas Attorney General, to manage contributions to the park fund.
LONDON, Dec. 31 Eight paintings, valued at more than $5-million and including three Rembrandts and three Rubenses, were stolen last night from the Dulwich College Art Gallery in southeast London.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The war on poverty and the war in Vietnam have combined in an unexpected way to help solve a vexing legal problem how to provide enough lawyers to meet the nation's needs.
BUFFALO, Dec. 31 A lot of people in this western New York city appear to feel that the rest of the country has a distorted image of the climate here and of their football team, the Buffalo Bills.

MONTREAL, Dec. 31 (AP) R. M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, says Canada's production of pulp and paper increased more than 9 per cent in 1966 but profits in the industry did not match the rise in output.
Rehabilitation leaders entered the year 1966 with confidence that there would be a rapid and significant expansion of services for the nation's disabled during the year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Administration has determined to stand by its controversial school desegregation guidelines for at least another full school year.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Dec. 31 President Johnson said today that the nation can, must and will continue to afford both the war in Vietnam and the fight for a better life at home.
