JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 31 (Reuters) President Sukarno said today that he would speak out on policy matters whenever his conscience demanded.

WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 31 A collection of more than 1,600 photographs taken by the late Carl Van Vechten, who was an accomplished portrait photographer as well as a novelist and music critic, came as a recent gift to Brandeis University.
A proposal that city agencies lend engineers to departments that need them was given a cool reception yesterday by the two agencies that would be expected to lend the engineers.
COPENHAGEN A few weeks ago, my wife suggested that we spend some vacation time in Copenhagen. "You must be crazy," I said. "Tivoli's closed in the winter, and besides it's cold in Denmark."

The buying power of the average factory worker's paycheck barely kept pace with the rise of consumer prices here in the last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.
NORTON, Mass., Dec. 31 Miss Dorothy Doty Prentice, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C.H. Prentice, was married today to Richard Ludmil Ziegler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Ziegler of Malverne, L.I.

DALLAS, Dec. 31--New Year's Eve held neither significance nor promise for the Green Bay Packers and the Dallas Cowboys. They had no night of revelry to anticipate, no gay parties and, most of all, no hangovers. It was an early-to-bed occasion, unseasonably grim and purposeful. On the morrow these gridiron Goliaths were to meet in the Cotton Bowl Stadium for the championship of the National Football League.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UPI) Second-period goals by Gordie Howe and Norm Ullman helped the Detroit Red Wings score a 3-1 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight in a National Hockey League game.
The New York City division of the American Cancer Society is scheduled to open a campaign today to help New Yorkers learn to detect cancer.

Rabbi Joseph Karasick, president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, said yesterday that he had appealed to the United States Government to come to the aid of American business concerns blacklisted by the Arab Boycott

LONDON, Dec. 31 For Harold Wilson as for Lyndon Johnson the year 1966 has been one of bitter disappointment following political triumph. The Prime Minister's hopes for dealing with his two greatest problems the British economy and Rhodesia were dashed during the year, and both still look ominous for his Government and his country as the year ends.
Rodney Gove Dennis, a partner in Patterson, Teele Dennis, certified public accountants of 120 Broadway, died Friday in the New York Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 1105 Park Avenue.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 31 Miss Judith Ann Keller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Keller, was married today to William Charles Shilstone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Shilstone of Redwood City, Calif. The Rev. Arthur Block performed the ceremony in Christ Lutheran Church.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 31 St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Chureh was the setting today for the marriage of Miss Susan Boteler Shelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tully Shelley Jr, of London and New Canaan, to Lockett Coleman Pitman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Holley Pitman of Darien.

The cease-fire in Vietnam this weekend, brief and fragile as it is, enables New Year's Day to open on a note of hope. What is more important is how the day and the new year will close. In neither case is great optimism justified.
The American Newspaper Guild and The Associated Press extended their two-year contract last night until midnight next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The marriage of Miss Susan Valre Davis and George Edward White took place this afternoon at the Dumbarton Avenue Methodist Church in Georgetown. The Rev. Richard F. McFarland officiated.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 31 Suffolk County officials were generally pleased today with Governor Rockefeller's action.

DUBLIN, N.H., Dec. 31 Miss Sylvia Fleetwood Pool, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Beekman Hoppin Pool, was married today to Peter Ridley Sperling, son of Mrs. Ridley Sperling of Hamden, Conn., and Jerome Sperling of Arlington, Va.

"I LIKE this job better every day," John V. Lindsay said as he began his 346th day as Mayor of New York City. "I even think the city is governable. Anyway, it beats working," he said ad laughed, which he rarely does when he talks about his job.
Ralph A. Miller, director of the Museum of the City of New York, announced yesterday the appointment of Mrs. Carlin E. Gasteyer as assistant director, effective today.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 The appointment of Dr. James F.X. O'Rourke as Mayor of Yonkers was announced today by Governor Rockefeller.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. The new $2,390,000 passenger terminal at Palm Beach International Airport is an 88,000-square-foot structure that is four times the size of the former facility, and with many added comforts and architectural innovations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The nation's need for public facilities will rise from $31-billion in 1965 to $48.6-billion in 1970 and $61.6-billion in 1975, a Congressional study estimated today.

The inalienable right of the American woman to sprawl in front of the television set for 7 hours each day will be pre-empted today by the American male. Millions of them will crouch and quiver in living rooms across the nation, watching first the American Football League championship game from Buffalo, then the National Football League game from Dallas.
The Federal Maritime Commission and the Department of Justice have given strong backing to the Military Sea Transportation Service's new method of seeking freight rates from steamship companies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The 1967 edition of the Tax Guide for Small Business is now on sale at most local Internal Revenue Service offices or at the Government Printing Office here.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court refused today to declare unconstitutional the state law under which textbooks are lent to children in parochial and private schools.
For the first time, the public may purchase the city's official telephone directory, giving the names and telephone extensions of some 15,000 employes, including Mayor Lindsay.
William Manchester, author of "The Death of a President," the story of the assassination of President Kennedy, was released yesterday afternoon from Middlesex Memorial Hospital at Middletown, Conn.
CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 31 (Reuters) A crowd of 80,000, a record for India, watched the West Indies cricket team reach 212 runs for four wickets by the close of play today when the second test began.
HONG KONG, Dec. 31 The last week of 1966 achieved the distinction of being the most bewildering week of a very bewilderine year in Communist China.
Convention visitors to Chicago in 1967 are expected to number about 1.3 million, or 100,000 more than in 1966, Charles O. Newlin, president of the Chicago Convention Bureau, estimates.

A $250 contribution was received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in memory of Michael J. Quill, the colorful president of the Transport Workers Union. Mr. Quill died last Jan. 28 of a heart attack 28 days after he had led the union into a transit strike a year ago today. The strike crippled the city for 12 days.

WE paid Dr. Fl bbergast a visit the other day. For once his study was clear. Relatively clear, anyway. Gone were the graphs and slipsticks, the musical instruments and test equipment. Even the color scheme had been changed. Instead of anti septic white, the walls were now painted brown. Dr. Fl bbergast was in a brown study. We tiptoed in so as not to disturb the great man.

Grants of $2.5 million each that must be matched on a 3for-1 basis in three years have been awarded by the Ford Foundation to Barnard College and Teachers College, both affiliates of Columbia University.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 31 Miss Wendy Jean Halstead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Mayer Halstead, was married today to Peter Douglas Meyer, son of Mrs. Edna P. Blair of New York and Mack Meyer of Westport, Conn.

James O. Belden, United States consul in Paris, and Mrs. Belden have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mona Venetia Belden, to Pvt. Thomas Francis Bayard 4th, of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard 3d of Wilmington, Del.
Thomas Marks, a soldier attending officers' candidate school, was held in $1,000 bail yesterday by Judge Maurice W. Grey in criminal court on charges of assault and robbery.

JAMES RORIMER, the late director of The Metropolitan Museum of Art, once said to a reporter: "We don't want the public to think that a visit to a museum is a painful ordeal. If more decent toilets make it easier to see Titians, let's have more decent toilets."

HOBART, Tasmania, Dec. 31 (AP) Nam Sang, a 66-foot cutter owned by Robert Baum of Los Angeles, crossed the finish line in the Sydney-toHobart yacht race last night to become the ninth craft to complete the 680-mile contest.

THE central character of this long and richly realized novel is David Champlin. The central fact of David's too-brief life is that he is Negro. This is certainly no innovation in current fiction. What may be refreshing is the fact that David is also a hero, in the best sense of that term.

BELIZE, British Honduras-Except for its picturesque, teeming capital on the coast, this subtropical land is for the rugged and enterprising tourist. And for the man of such persuasion, British Honduras is an exciting country, indeed. Just outside Belize, a metropolis of 32,000, there are fascinating areas for camping, caves to be explored and waterfalls to be viewed. There is hunting, fishing and riverboating, as well as visits to be made to nearby Mayan ruins.

POETRY of today, of yesterday and perhaps even of tomorrow gets an airing on a number of disks that are stimulating in their variety and subject matter and by their reflection of the taste of past and present generations.

The professional byline, Kate Cameron, the movie critic with the largest newspaper circulation in the United States, appears for the last time in The Sunday News today. Loretta King, the Woman behind the byline, has retired after 32 years as chief film reviewer and motion picture editor of The Daily News. She is succeeded by Wanda Hall, who will continue to write under her own name.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Has anyone noticed that disk jockeys these days never refer to "Hoagy Carmichael's immortal 'Stardust'?"
HAPPY New year stamp greetings are traditional in a number of countries. In the Far East, stamps take note of the astrological year ahead. Other Countries present traditional greetings.

The head of three television stations on the West Coast has broadcast an editorial criticizing President Johnson's conduct of the Vietnamese war and urging an immediate halt to the bombing of North Vietnam.

The election defeat of many Administration stalwarts, the rising cost of the Vietnam war and the economy-mindedness caused by inflation's bite into the dollar have combined to produce a go-slow mood in Washington on Government action to deal with the country's domestic needs.

FOR, those who see the American physician as a healing saint in a white coat, "The Doctors," by Martin L. Gross, will be a great shock. Those who dislike and distrust doctors will relish each account of physician error, misjudgment and downright incompetence. Anyone not thoroughly committed to either of these points of view may find the book disturbing, thought-provoking, but also disappointing.

NEIL "DOC" SIMON turned up for lunch some 36 hours after the arrival of his latest comedy, "The Star-Spangled Girl," clean-shaven, well dressed, no dark circles under his eyes. Contemplative yes, dour no. True, "The StarSpangled Girl" got a split verdict from the aisle-sitters but, with a reported $700,000 advance sale in the till, it has a chance for a run depend ing, of course, on the word-ofmouth.
A simplified framing system for construction of lowcost houses has been developed by the Department of Agriculture in an effort to improve housing in economically depressed areas such as Appalachia.
The rapid growth of mold and large blisters rising on frescoes in Florence are unexpected new dangers to that city's artistic heritage, and are spurring action here for emergency aid.
Mayor Lindsay ended the year yesterday by issuing a buoyant and optimistic report on the economic condition of the city.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) The California Angels will spend the first 10 days of spring training at their minor league complex at Holtville. The team will report on Feb. 16, and will shift over to the main base at Palm Springs for the remainder of the drills.
LINCOLN, N.H. A former New Hampshire Governor, an American Olympic skier and an Austrian baron are the leaders in a movement to make the central part of this state a major ski area.

WHEAT Edwin Gilbert has done this time is to write a Pyg malion-Pop story. He's taken this little Connecticut wife and tossed her from suburbia to urbia and then some. "The Beautiful Life" is la dolce vita, Park Avenue style. It has a cast of hundreds, all readily recognizable to readers of Suzy Knickerbocker and Eugenia Sheppard. It is Society today the mixture of the good old family.
BONN, Dec. 31 President Heinrich Lubke called on West Germans today to bring their nation out of its economic slump through their own efforts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The President's Commission on Crime in the District of Columbia, after a $400,000 17-month study, reported today that crime was rampant in the capital and was likely to remain so unless fundamental social improvements were made.

FARMVILLE, Va., Dec. 31 The supervisors of Prince Edward County, where public school education was shut down from 1959 to 1964, face a Federal court edict that they restore $180,000 in tuition grant money to the county's treasury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 There is a peculiar morality in nature that forbids any species from long remaining dominant over all others. However one species man has made himself immune to that morality. The result is that the world's human population is doubling every few decades.

One of the major concerns of the International Air Transport Association in the new year will be to try to stem the rising tide of airport charges, Knut Hammarskjold, director general of the organization, said last week in his year-end statement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Boeing Company and the General Electric Company were picked today to design the American supersonic airliner, which will be the largest project in aviation history.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 31 The marriage of Miss Mary Fales Masland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Meyer Masland of Manhasset, to Matthew Thornton Adams of New York, son of the late Dr. Dabney Moon Adams of New York, took place this afternoon.
Thanks to the expert advice of a group of retired American businessmen who ventured abroad and worked without remuneration, these accomplishments were made possible:
New York's major figure-skating club, the Skating Club of New York, faces the loss of its present home atop Madison Square Garden.

TOKYO, Dec: 31 Asahi, one of Japan's leading newspapers, proposes in an editorial in tomorrow's editions that the United States stop its bombing of North Vietnam in a "gamble" that Hanoi will reciprocate with a peace-making gesture.
MADRID, Dec. 31 Spanish riot policemen today broke up a demonstration in downtown Madrid by 3,000 workers at electronic equipment plants in which a United States company has the controlling interest.
The figures are in and there can be no doubt that Christmas, 1966, was the greatest on record for retailers in the United States.
PARIS, Dec. 31 President de Gaulle called upon the United States tonight to end what he called its "detestable" intervention in Vietnam.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) Dick Chapman, former United States and British Amateur champion, and Kevin Butler of Palm Beach tied for the medalist position today in qualifying for the Champion of Champions golf tournament at the Breakers Golf Club.
Sir Tyrone Guthrie, in New York to stage "Peter Grimes" for the Metropolitan Opera and to arrange a lecture tour, took inventory yesterday.
IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. One of the charming whimsicalities of the Victorian age in the United States was the octagonal house.
A CANDIDATE for the best-played game in the recent United States chess championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel was Arthur Bisguier's victory over Donald Byrne.
HOLTON, Kan., Jan. 1 (UPI) A plane carrying four persons to the Sugar Bowl football game at New Orleans crashed today in an ice-covered farm pond in northeast Kansas. There were no survivors.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 The Superior Council of the Catholic University of Argentina and its highly regarded faculty of social sciences and economics have reached a showdown on teaching methods.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 1 The nation's only state fluoridation law went into effect in Connecticut today.

HONG KONG, Jan, 1 Mao Tse-tung and his chosen successor, Defense Minister Lin Piao, will achieve "decisive victory" in 1967 in their struggle against domestic political opponents, the Chinese press predicted today.

PHATDIEM, North Vietnam, Jan. 1 A cock's crow and the bark of a village dog brought the new year in to this rich delta land in Ninhbinh Province 75 miles south of Hanoi, and t 6 A.M. the iron toll of church bells called the faithful to early mass.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 Conflicting statements were made today by Drew Pearson and attorneys for Senator Thomas J. Dodd about whether or not the Connecticut Democrat had made an "overture" to settle his libel suit against the columnist and Jack Anderson, his colleague.

"Happy New Year," wrote a benefactor on Manhattan's Upper East Side in a note with her gift of $5 for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She elected to be identified only under her initials "S.R."
The disarray in NATO has made clear the damage caused by the absence from the Atlantic structure of one of the motor forces for unity within Western Europe.
A Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with having killed his common-law wife with a weightlifting bar. The police said he was trying to bury her body in a basement when they arrested him.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 1 (AP) Skaters from the Soviet Union set the pace today as the top speed skaters in the world met for the first time this season.
ATLANTA, Jan. 1 (AP)--Gov. Robert E. McNair of South Carolina challenged today the validity of the new Federal guidelines on desegregation of schools.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y. The Federal Government is withholding about $250,000 in urban renewal funds for this village in a dispute over the relocation of one family.

BUFFALO, Jan. 1 In open galoshes and yellow slickers, the crowd moved slowly into War Memorial Stadium, through a cold drizzle, past a gantlet of mean and boys trying to unload tickets to the football game.
WASHINGTON, Jan.1 (UPI) A leading nuclear physicist said today that he did not believe that any antimissile system could protect a nation against nuclear attack.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 1 (AP) The Coast Guard said today that rescue vessels had apparently saved all but five of 50 seamen who were reported missing after the sinking of a Soviet refrigerator ship in the Bering Sea yesterday.
A.M.R. Rosenthal, metropolitan editor of The New York Times, has been promoted to assistant managing editor.
HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 1 (AP) The 30-foot sloop Cadence, the smallest boat in the Sydney-to-Hobart yacht race, was declared the winner today on corrected time.
Commissioners and staff members of the City Commission on Human Rights will make evening visits to community centers throughout the city to receive complaints and answer inquiries.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 1 Dr. Tina Buchter Strobos, staff psychiatrist at the Guidance Center of New Rochelle, was married today to Walter Ai Chudson, an assistant director of the United Nations Industrial Development Organization. Ernest H. Sommerfeld of the Westchester Ethical Society performed the ceremony at the home of the bridgeroom.

THE promise of Garry Moore's show to make an elephant disappear before a viewer's eyes turned out last night to be the anticlimax of the humorist's program devoted entirely to the feats of magic. The hour was seen on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (UPI) The Journal of the American Dental Association accused dentists and candy manufacturers today of letting down on the job of banning candy and other sweets from youngsters' diets.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 1 (AP) Units of the Indian Army had to be called today after rioting crowds at a Calcutta cricket stadium prevented the resumption of play in the second test match between the West Indies and India.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1 Benjamin Frank Black, a retired New York grain broker, died here today. He was 80 years old.
Two hundred patients, mostly doctors, applied for treatment yesterday at a temporary clinic operated by the Physicians' Wine Appreciation Society of New York.

LAUREL, Md., Jan. 1 The Laurel Race Course will terminate its winter meeting tomorrow with a 10-race card featured by two stakes events, the $27,500 Monumental Handicap and the Laurel New Year's Handicap. Each race islat seven furlongs, with eight horses listed for the Monumental and nine for the New Year's.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 Government storage bins are coming down.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 The frustration of the Dallas Cowboys appeared to be symbolized on their final play today in the National Football League championship game. Don Meredith, realizing that Bob Hayes was covered, passed desperately and suffered an interception, the only one of the game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 The direct and indirect effects of the Federal Reserve System's tight money policy helped reduce total borrowing in the economy in the third quarter last year by 20 per cent, or an annual rate of $15-billion.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 1 The engagement of Miss Bettina Boettger Hesse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Hesse Jr. of Englewood and Colebrook, Conn., to Stephen Edward Bepler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Belper of Rochester, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A long line stretched yesterday from the registration desk in a small, warm reception room and overflowed into the chilly hallway of a private apartment being used as the "St. Francis Emergency Clinic."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, says organized labor will use every force at its command to prevent a retreat from the war on poverty in 1967.

A panel of 12 nationally known economists predicted yesterday that the economy would slow down during the coming year from its hectic pace of 1966, but then stopped well short of predicting a recession.
State Controller Arthur Levitt is investigating the feasibility of constructing a major state office building on the site of the Brooklyn Navy Yard or the Brooklyn Army Terminal.
CORNING, N. Y., Jan. 2 Miss Carolyn Patricia Ann Clark and John Baker were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Thomas Brennan performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.
A 12-year-old boy ran into the smoke-filled apartment of a blind, 80-year-old woman yesterday and led her to safety.

Dr. Charles H. Roberts of 11 Fort George Hill, Manhattan, believed to have been the first Negro ever elected to the old Board of Aldermen, died Sunday at Jewish Memorial Hospital. He was 94 years old.
Church membership is lagging behind population growth in the United States, according to data compiled by the National Council of Churches.
ROSELAND, 239 West 52d Street, Stan and Judi Martin, Viki and Yuri, Allegro and Troy, dance acts.

Worldwide highway expenditures reached a new high in 1966, increasing by 13 per cent over 1965 to a total of $29.9billion for the 145 countries that supply the statistics to the International Road Federation. The announcement was made recently by Robert O. Swain, president of the Federation, who noted that the statistical data did not include Russia, Communist China or some Eastern European countries.
SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 2 (UPI) Mrs. Lorena Chipman Fletcher, Mother of the Year in 1965, died here today. She was 78 years old.
ALBANY, Jan. 2--Mayor Lindsay predicted today that he and Governor Rockefeller would work out a regional plan to solve some of New York City's major transportation problems.

In his third inaugural yesterday Governor Rockefeller offered some useful guidelines for the new Legislature and the Constitutional Convention, but he was depressingly vague about how he thought the state's most pressing problems should be solved. We hope the legislators when they begin work tomorrow will show a greater willingness to grapple with specifics and not leave every major issue for resolution at the constitutional conclave next April.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 2--President Johnson ended tonight a 17-day holiday stay at his ranch near here and headed for a busy schedule of new-year planning and budgeting in Washington.

Investment bankers, who watched the bond market gather upward momentum in the last few weeks as no large new issues came to market, prepared to attack a relatively heavy schedule this week. Many are predicting that the recent trend of higher prices and lower yields will continue.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 Governor Rockefeller called on the people of New York in his third inaugural today to reject "public apathy" about the state's problems and join him in trying to "build together the dream of free men of all ages: A Just Society."

The legal defense and educational fund of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will benefit from the proceeds of Artur Rubinstein's piano recital Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 3 United States Air Force pilots lured enemy jets out of the clouds over North Vietnam yesterday and destroyed seven of them, American military officials disclosed today.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 The Melton National Bank and Trust Company reported today net operating earnings of $37,129,271 or $5.58 a share, against $34,983,176, or $5.25 a share, a year earlier.

THE rubber bridge player very rarely doubles his opponents "into game." His tournament counterpart indulges in this dangerous move much more frequently, because he has to strain to make small profits.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2 (Reuters) The Iraq Petroleum company's managing director, Christopher Dalley, held a meeting with Iraqi premier and acting Oil Minister Naji Taleb here today his third since he arrived last Wednesday.

The average interest rate charged on short-term business loans leveled off during the fourth quarter of 1966, after rising sharply during the first nine months of the year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
MIAMI, Jan. 2 Premier Fidel Castro hinted today at a gradual ending of his largely personal style of government in Cuba.
The Hooker Chemical Corporation achieved record sales and earnings for the fifth consecutive year in its fiscal year ended Nov. 30, F. Leonard Bryant, chairman, reported over the holiday weekend.

MARATHON, Fla., Jan. 2, Customs agents and the police broke up tonight a heavily armed, uniformed band of Cuban exiles and American adventurers on a deserted beach here as the group tried to march off toward Key West.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 2 (UPI) Dr. Alan F. Guttmacher, president of Planned ParenthoodWorld Population, is one of 10 recipients of Modern Medicine's 1967 distinguished achievement awards announced today.
A Westchester motorist who, the police said, tried to get his impounded car back without paying the fines and fees, would up in jail last night.
GROOKS, a word that sounds like a loose screw in an atom smasher, are the special creation of Piet Hein, who is a sort of special creation himself.
The freshman college student is more likely to smoke if he has poor grades and fails to participate in campus activities, a University of Illinois study has shown.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 2 Union Miniere du Haut Katanga has declared commercial war against the Congo in retaliation for the seizure of its assets in Katanga province. The
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 2 J. Lester (Pete) Mauthe, former board chairman of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, died today at his home in nearby Poland. He was 76 years old.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Jan. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Laurence G. Tighe Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorna Tighe, to Howard G. Peterson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peterson Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Edgartown, Mass.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 2 George Romney opened his third term as Michigan's Governor today with a pledge to fight against overcentralized government. He gave no hint whether he would seek the Republican Presidential nomination in 1968.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Terrible things are done against children. The latest is the development of the Youth Specialization System. The object is to force the youngster, long before his first shave, to decide what kind of youth he intends to pursue and make him get on with it instead of dawdling aimlessly in general practice.
Three young women rescued from the striken yawl Petrel in a freezing Atlantic gale came ashore yesterday and told a story of two days and nights of terror.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Liberal Democrats in the House appear to be gravitating to the view that Representative Adam Clayton Powell should be disciplined but not deprived of his seat.

DALLAS, Jan. 2 Tom Landry, the coach, stood squarely behind the quarterback, the maligned Dandy Don Meredith, today as the last two minutes in the life of the 1966 Dallas Cowboys were relived again and again.

MIAMI, Jan. 2 Larry Smith, a sophomore tailback from Tampa, stole the show from his famous teammate, Steve Spurrier, tonight as he ran for 187 yards, a record, and for a 94yard touchdown, also a record, in leading Florida to a 27-12 victory over Georgia Tech in the Orange Bowl.
A communications problem in involving Fordham University, state education officials and Dr. Marshall McLuhan, the communications theorist, was resolved last night.
LAUREL, Md., Jan. 2 Top weight proved just the thing in each of the feature races today on the final card of the Laurel Race Course meeting.

An election among 27,000 plant employes of the New York Telephone Company will be conducted by the National Labor Relations Board during the next two weeks. The workers will choose among the Communications Workers of America, which currently represents the plant group; the Technical, Electronic and Communications Union, independent, or no union at all.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Jan. 2 (UPI) Dr. Pieter Geyl, a distinguished historian, died Saturday at the age of 81.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Martyr was the setting here at noon yesterday for the marriage of Miss Marian Ruth Schleindl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Andrew Schleindl, to Joseph P. Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark of Queens Village, Queens.

Milton Kovner, former president of Majestic Industries, Inc., 100 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, converters of paper products, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 98-11 65th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.
Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., has appointed two top executives for the Arrow Company, the largest of the Cluett divisions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 Norman Kraft, retired vice president of the Kraft Foods Company, and brother of the company's founder, the late J.L. Kraft, died Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 79 years old.
The city, has a new procedure for thwarting landlords who harass tenants into vacating rent-controlled apartments, Frederic S. Berman, Rent and Rehabilitation Commissioner, announced yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 2 (AP) Richie Guerin, the player-coach, sank a jump shot at the buzzer to give the St. Louis Hawks a 122-120 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

In the face of heavy pressures, President Kaunda perseveres with a nonracial policy in Zambia, next door to white-ruled Rhodesia. He has just appointed the first white man to his Cabinet since Zambia achieved independence in 1964.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 2 Bill Kelly of the Larchmont Interclub Class fleet turned on the pressure with two firsts and a second in the first three races today, then covered his opposition in the finale to capture top honors as the Frostbite Yacht Club's three-day New Year's regatta ended on Manhasset Bay.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) Directors of the PacificEight athletic conference have changed league rules on junior college transfers in an effort to conform with National Collegiate regulations.
MIAMI, Jan. 2 During the last few days Florida practiced under wraps as Coach Ray Graves kept visitors away from his heroes. So the rumor began going around that Steve Spurrier's arm was hurt.

HARRY and David, who run a successful Fruit-of-the Month Club from their Bear Creek Orchards in Medford, Ore., are now making unusual canned fruits and pickles. The home-style canned goods are being sold in stores in the New York area.
ROME, Jan. 2 Pope Paul VI endorsed today the British efforts to arrange a meeting between the United States, North Vietnam and South Vietnam and he promised prayers for its success.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 2 The marriage of Miss Anthea Diane Merrick Coveney of London, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merrick Coveney of Henley-onThames, England, to Maurice Rene Pascal of Khakum Wood, Greenwich, son of Mrs. JeanPierre Stern, also of Greenwich and of Rene Pascal of Aix-ehProvence, France, took place here this morning.
An anonymous benefactor who makes a habit of starting each year with a gift to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund contributed $10 yesterday.

Medical practice in the United States is about to undergo revolutionary changes, if forecasts voiced at the American Association for the Advancement of Science meetings in Washington last week are correct.
BONN, Jan. 2 Plans are afoot to turn this quiet university-town-turned-capital-city into a major metropolis.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 Coach John McKay of Southern California, had the highest praise today for Bob Griese, Purdue's sterling quarterback, who is rated, along with Steve Spurrier of Florida, as a top professional prospect.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) Jeff Alpert of Woodbridge, Conn., carded a threeunder-par 67 today to take the lead after the first 18 holes of the 54-hole Champion of Club Champions golf tournament at the Breakers Golf Club.
Grave diggers and gardeners at 32 cemeteries in the metropolitan area rejected new contract proposals yesterday and voted to go on strike today.

TOKYO, Jan. 2 (AP) Encouraged by thousands of comrades reading a quotation by Chairman Mao Tse-tung, 66 factory workers in Communist China swam in a nearly frozen lake on New Year's Day, Peking's official news agency Hsinhua reported today.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 2 Miss Ellen Fogarty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Fogarty of New York and Laurel Hollow, was married here today to Edward Carl Oelsner 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oelsner Jr. of Upper Brookville.
One of the profound changes taking place in the United States cultural landscape is the marked tilt toward the Pacific.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 2 A third-period goal by Dick Keeley tonight gave the University of Wisconsin a 1-0 hockey victory over Army.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuters) The British consul general in Hanoi has reported seeing damage to the outskirts of the North Vietnamese capital, but was unable to say whether it was caused by United States bombs or shrapnel from the city's antiaircraft defenses, well-informed sources said today.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Jan. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Howes Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ann Howes, to Lieut. (jg.) Willard Dawson Richardson, U.S.N., son of Capt, Francis Willard Richardson, U.S.C.G., retired, and Mrs. Richardson of Cambridge, Md.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 (AP) The Soviet Union accused Communist China today of having illegally detained a Soviet ship for 20 days and said this "jeopardized normal shipping between the ports of the U.S.S.R. and China."
SEATTLE, Jan. 2 (UPI) Oliver David Fisher, a financier and industrialist, died here yesterday. He was 91 years old.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 The Soviet Union has agreed to provide at least a fourth of the wheat that the United Arab Republic must import this year to keep its expanding population from going hungry, it was announced today.
YONKERS, Jan. 2 There was utter confusion at Yonkers Raceway today as reports of driver suspensions spread throughout the harness racing plant on the eve of its opening night.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 2 Gov. and Mrs. Roberto Sanchez Vilella greeted some 22,000 visitors today with music, song and sweet cakes at La Fortaleza, the executive mansion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 State Department officials expressed particular interest today in Premier Castro's remarks on leadership.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 2 An Israeli soldier was wounded today in an exchange of gunfire on the Syrian border. It was the first bloodshed along the troubled Israel-Arab frontiers since Nov. 13 when the Israelis made a reprisal attack against the Jordanian town of Es Samu.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 2 Curt Fisher's ball-handling and scoring led Hofstra to a 77-72 double-overtime victory over Fairleigh Dickinson in a Metropolitan Conference game tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The National Right-toWork Committee said tonight that it would push for a Federal law requiring labor unions to bargain only for their own members.

MIAMI, Jan. 2 (UPI) Sikkim raced to his fourth straight stakes victory of the Tropical Park meeting today when he broke his own track record and came close to the world record in winning the $15,975 New Year's Handicap by five lengths.

A dramatization of "Adventures in the Skin Trade," the late Dylan Thomas's short novel about his adventures when he went to London at the age of 19, is headed for New York this season. The producers, Theodore Mann and Lester Persky, soon will decide whether to offer it on or off Broadway.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 2 (AP) Hot-shooting Princeton knocked North Carolina's thirdranked Tar Heels from basketball's unbeaten class tonight, 91-81.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 2 Miss Eleanor Mogan Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mizeli Wilson, was married here this morning to Nicholas Joseph Spokovich Jr. of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Spokovich of Canfield, Ohio. The Roman Catholic Church of St. Bernard was the setting of the ceremony and nuptial mass, where the Rev. Christopher Mogan Wilson, brother of the bride, officiated.
Bus and railroad terminals were jammed yesterday as college students started returning to campus after the holidays, and many seemed happy to be going back.
This spring, Brillo soap pads are going to blossom forth in new boxes that have been designed to give them more visibility on the supermarket shelves.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuters)--An airmal letter that was on a plane that crashed in attempting an Atlantic crossing in 1919 was sold at auction for the equivalent of $8,400 here today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 3 The Government said today that it had accepted Britain's offer to take part in a peace conference.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan, 2 When you're No. 3, you try even harder, as the University of Alabama's football team did today in the 33d Sugar Bowl Classic.

PARIS, Jan. 2 (Reuters) The British-French Concorde supersonic airliner will be flying on trans-Atlantic and United States routes three years ahead of its American rival, a spokesman for Sud Aviation said today.
MADRID, Jan. 2 A daylong sitdown strike by 13,000 employes in four Madrid electronics plants led tonight to the release of six labor leaders in jail since Saturday.

ATHENS, Jan. 2--An influential Athens daily newspaper was accused in court actions today of libel and forgery after it published an article alleging a palace plot to ease Greece's right wing back into power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Nature's more violent manifestations were at a minimum in the United States and its territories during 1966 and the Office of Emergency Planning found time to study new approaches to disaster relief.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 American industry is optimistic about the outlook for 1967, the Secretary of Commerce, John T. Connor, reported today in the 1967 edition of "United States Industrial Outlook."

The Canadians are beginning to celebrate the centennial of their existence as a geographic entity. The anniversary will be marked with a $500-million world's fair, which is a slight indication of how wealthy the country is. Yet something is wrong with the picture, as the article by Jay Walz in yesterday's Times proves.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 2 Philip W. Swan, a retired executive of the General Foods Corporation, died yesterday at the United Hospital in Port Chester.
Another good business year and a continuing growth for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was predicted over the weekend by Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president of I.T.T.

JAMESBURG, N.J., Jan. 2 Miss Carol Elizabeth Lehman and Lawrence Joseph Eron were married here this afternoon at the Forsgate Country Club by Dr. Thomas Weber, chairman of the history department at Douglass College and Mayor of Metuchen.
A number of brokerage firms announced yesterday the appointment of new partners.
The appointment of John J. Loughery as vice president for marketing of Icelandic Airlines, Inc., was announced yesterday by Sigurdur Helgason, the president.

BONN, Jan. 2--The new West German Government is planning to carry out its first probe in a large-scale diplomatic offensive aimed at improving its ties with Eastern Europe. The move is to start in a month.
PARIS, Jan. 2 Hughes Lapaire, poet, playwright, novelist, travel writer and chansonnier, died today in a home for the aged. He was 98 years old.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 2 (UPI) Premier Souvanna Phouma's slate of pro-Government National Assembly candidates has won 15 of the 22 seats decided so far in yesterday's general election.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz has expressed deep concern about the recent tendency of some union members to reject labor agreements proposed by their leaders.

MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 2 Miss Karen Victoria Wright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Ashley Wright and Charles Raymond Meyers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyers of Hampton, N.J., were married here this afternoon in the Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Robert C. Alexander.

In an acquisition involving an exchange of stock valued at more than $60-million, the Bendix Corporation, a major supplier in the aviation, space and automotive fields announced yesterday an agreement to acquire the Fram Corporation of Providence, R.I.
The busy cafeteria at the Central Park Zoo will be closed today for two weeks as a new management takes over.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 In calling for "a Just Society" in his third inaugural address today, Governor Rockefeller seemed sure to generate more speculation about his interest in the Presidency a goal he insists has been renounced and one that has eluded him twice before.

A Federal conference on curbing air pollution in the metropolitan area starts here today--under restrictions that would highlight New York City as the chief polluter, instead of New Jersey, as Governor Rockefeller first complained.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Cities could advance some distance toward solving their urgent need for more tax revenues with better administration of the real estate tax and imposition of an intangible-property tax, which was once thought impossible to administer but is so no longer.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 2 (AP) The Soviet Union's Valery Kaplan finished fifth today in the 10,000-meter race, the last event on a two-day program, and emerged the overall winner of the speed-skating meet.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 2 John E. Wakefield, vice president of the marketing division of Barrington and Company, Inc., management consultants at 230 Park Avenue, New York, died today at Greenwich Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 23 Park Avenue, Old Greenwich.

BONN, Jan. 2 President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam declared in an interview published today by the news magazine Der Spiegel that the United States was becoming daily more "enmeshed" in a war it could not win.

PARIS, Jan. 2 The staff and business associates of Machines Bull-General Electric were shocked today by a report that it was about to halt the marketing of two important lines of medium-size computers.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 2. (AP) John D. Cronin has resigned after seven seasons as executive vice president and general manager of Freehold Raceway.
The Baptist Ministers Conference of Greater New York, an organization of 400 Negro clergymen, endorsed yesterday a 17-page petition denouncing efforts to unseat Representative Adam Clayton Powell.
TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 2 (AP) There are drive-in restaurants, drive-in theaters, drivein banks and now a drive-in income tax payment window.
JODHPUR, India, Jan. 1 In this strife-scarred desert, where Rajput princes once rode out to battle on camels, another kind of attack is about to begin.

The police are investigating the shooting early yesterday of two men on Madison Avenue between East 104th and 105th Streets. Both men were taken to Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital in critical condition. The assailants escaped.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 As the New Year begins, President Johnson is fighting a threefront political war about Vietnam, about his domestic policies, about himself. There appears to be little chance that he can make much progress on any but the second of these fronts in 1967.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Fine seam bowling by Graham McKenzie, who sent back three key batsmen for 221 runs in 11 overs, put Australia in a strong position today at the end of the second day of the second cricket test against, South Africa.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 From the humiliation of its 51-0 massacre by Notre Dame in its regular-season finale, Southern California regained the might of its October form to come within a point of tying heavily favored Purdue in the 53d Rose Bowl game today.
Allen Ullman, painter and sculptor, died Friday in Altea, Spain, Mr. Ullman, who was 61 years old, had been living in Spain for the last two and a half years. He also had a home in Sag Harbor, L.I.

MADRID, Dec. 31--The once airy city of Madrid is proud of its tree-shaded, broad avenues and plazas, caressed by the winds from Sierra de Guadarrama. But its people are acquiring a dry cough and smarting red eyes from smog.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 2 With 32 television cameras focused on him, Ronald Reagan, grinning broadly, remarked to Senator George Murphy of California early this morning:
Jack Ruby has recorded a statement that no conspiracy was involved in his killing of Lee Harvey Oswald, who was named by the Warren Commission as the assassin of President Kennedy.
DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP) American auto makers set today a goal of about 720,000 cars for January, as all four major companies reduced their original production goal of about 790,000 units.
The Coast Guard said last night it had received a distress broadcast from the Liberian-registered oil tanker Failaika in the Atlantic about 400 miles east of Boston.

The Saturday Evening Post publishes in its Jan. 14 issue, distributed today, a review of the assassination of President Kennedy and of the findings of the Warren Commission and its critics. The author concludes that circumstantial evidence supports the theory of a second assassin.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The Veterans of Foreign Wars protested tonight the free holiday travel pay granted to members of the Job Corps and urged broader payment of travel costs for servicemen.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 2 The South Vietnamese Government is pressing the United States to give it new jet airliners, informed sources said tonight.

WINNIPEG, Man., Jan 2 (AP) The Soviet Union's national team blistered 50 shots at the United States' goalie, Carl Wetzel, and walloped the Americans, 7-1, today in the opening round of the Centennial world hockey tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) More than 400 scientists and engineers have asked for a chance to fly to the moon. Others who wish to go have until Jan. 8 to apply, the National Academy of Sciences said today.
The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania is asking parents to take the pledge, but not for themselves for their children.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 2 (AP) Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico, driving steadily as cars in front of him were forced to make pit stops, won the South African Grand Prix today, the first world championship racing event of 1967.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Kuwait Foreign Trading, a contracting and investment company, has canceled an agreement with IntraBank to lend it 50-million Lebanese pounds (about $16.6-million).
FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 2 (AP) The Sovietowned Narodny Bank, Ltd., of London, plans to open a branch in Frankfurt, West Germany's financial capital.
LONDON, Jan. 2 The seventh Earl of Harewood, a first cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, is being sued for divorce on grounds of adultery.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Two more antihistamines have been added to the Food and Drug Administration's list of medicines that may cause birth defects.
A new series of Jeepster models was announced yesterday by the Kaiser Jeep Corporation. They include a convertible and Commando station wagon, roadster and pick-up models.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 3 (AP) A United States Air Force squadron commander says he saw two enemy missiles explode on the ground at the edge of Hanoi Dec. 14, one of the days on which American fliers were alleged to have killed civilians in the North Vietnamese capital.

One way to win a football game, Coach Hank Stram said yesterday, is to make the other team play your kind of a game. That's how his Kansas City Chiefs' beat the Buffalo Bills, 31-7, Sunday to win the American Football League championship, and that's what he hopes to do against the Green Bay Packers Jan. 15 at Los Angeles in the sport's first Super Bowl.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 2 (AP) Six of 85 seamen who abandoned ship when a Russian refrigerator vessel sank in the Bering Sea Saturday were officially declared lost today, and a widespread search was called off.
Thirty-eight young women were presented at the Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball in the Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.
WARREN, Vt. Hedonism reigned supreme here this weekend as about 3,500 outlanders swarmed into Sugarbush Valley to ski out the old year and skoal in the new.

The United Church of Christ announced yesterday that it would begin a national project to seek a political "balance" in programing on radio and television stations. The church group feels the airlanes are now weighted with extremist propaganda.

HOLLAND, Mich., Jan. 2 (AP) A wife suffering throat cancer could not make herself understood in a telephone call for help today, and both she and her husband perished in a fire at their home just east of this southeastern Michigan city.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP) For 364 days a year they're plumbers, carpenters, accountants and factory workers but today some 16,000 Philadelphia men were part of a living tradition the 67th annual Mummers' Day parade.
WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Jan. 3 The widow of a trucker who was shot to death Christfast Eve and a man whom the police Call her lover were arrested today and charged with conspiracy to commit murder.
The New York Rangers and Chicago Black Hawks, who share first place in the National Hockey League, also dominate the individual scoring race.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Air Force announced plans today to increase its pilot training program by 15 per cent so that it will turn out 3,247 pilots a year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The Smithsonian Institution plans to move the slum to the museum and to take the museum to the slum.

With the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People leading the way, New York Negroes yesterday charged that the House Administration Committee was applying a "double standard" in its investigation of Representative Adam Clayton Powell.
The Associated Press issued yesterday the following list of corrected prices for issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, Dec. 30, 1966:

LONDON, Jan. 3 The British Treasury deemed Britain's general economic health so far improved at the beginning of 1967 that it decided today to make a payment on debts, to the United States and Canada on which it had defaulted in 1965 and 1964.

Jack Ruby was like a character out of nineteenth century Russian fiction. Gogol or Dostoevski would have found comprehensible this strange, unhappy, obsessed man. In the denouement of a historic national tragedy, he suddenly stepped into the glare of the television lights and fatally wounded the suspected assassin.

PALMETTO, Ga., Jan. 3 (UPI) A 19-year-old college student was in critical condition today after he had driven his car off a 50-foot cliff at the end of an unfinished highway today, fallen 100 feet through the air, and lein in the wreckage for 12 hours.

Consolidated net income of the Chesapeake Ohio and the Baltimore Ohio railroads in 1966 was $88.1-million, or $7.61 a share, on the C. O.'s common stock, it was announced yesterday. This compared with $64.7-million, or $7.45 a share, in 1965.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 Hundreds of bills, ranging from a suggestion that glass doors be distinctively marked so that people do not walk into them to one that would create a state ombudsman, have been prefiled for consideration of the 1967 Legislature.

The recently organized National Society of Film Critics has voted the vividly original color movie, "Blow-Up," as the best film of 1966 and has selected its director, Michelangelo Antonioni, as the year's top director.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it would begin an investigation immediately into the problems faced by small shippers.
Percival Punter was appointed yesterday as regional administrator of the United States Labor Department's Bureau of Employment Security for Region II.

"MacBird," a contemporary satire drawn from "Macbeth," in which there are recognizable political figures, will open Feb. 8 at the Village Gate, 185 Thompson Street. Barbara Garson adapted the drama and retained its verse format.
A happening honoring Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving and benefiting the Park Association of New York will take place on Jan. 18 at 7 P.M. in the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 3 Food and oxygen deliveries were halted today by pickets at the Cafaro Memorial Osteopathic Hospital here.
Steel production in the last week of 1966 fell to its lowest level of the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 3 (UPI) The National Collegiate Athletic Association named Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today as the recipient of its first Theodore Roosevelt Award.
Blyth Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the appointment of L. Prather Stack Jr., as a senior vice president and executive committee member.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 Joseph A. Ball, who was senior staff counsel to the Warren commission, said today that he did not see how the death of Jack Ruby could have any effect on the validity of the commission's report on President Kennedy's assassination.

MIAMI, Jan. 3--The legal battle to get the cruise ship Nili back on the high seas continued today as Federal Judge C. Clyde Atkins gave the owners of the impounded vessel 20 days to present pleading in answer to suits filed by 30 claimants who have recorded liens against the Ship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The United States is standing by its commitment to a cease-fire in Vietnam next month despite warnings that the South Vietnamese Government is wayering.

WHEN Fidel Castro's revolutionary forces over threw the Government of Fulgencia Batista eight years ago, one of the first things a mob in Havana, did was to wreck the offices of the daily newspaper El Tiempo.

LONDON, Jan. 3 Prime Minister Wilson declared today that restrictive labor practices in the British newspaper industry "have reached the dimensions of a national scandal." He virtually invited publishers to get tough with labor in resistine "blackmail."

LONDON, Jan.3 The divorce suit against the seventh Earl of Harewood, first cousin of Queen Elizabeth II and 18th in line of succession to the British throne, poses no constitutional issue, although it undoubtedly is of considerable embarrassment to the royal family.

WARSAW--She is a darkhaired Polish psychiatrist who has pretty clothes and well-groomed hair and hands. Her husband writes for the newspaper of the Communist party, but calls her "darling" in English, makes tea as the British do and kisses the hands, of women with the aplomb of the old regime.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 3 (Reuters) After Sunday's riots, which ruled out play for the day, the second cricket test between India and West Indies resumed on a quiet note today, with India making 89 runs for one wicket in reply to the West Indies' 390.
The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday it was changing the metered copy rate for its entire line of copiers, copierduplicators and engineering products, effective March 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Federal Government reaffirmed tonight its jurisdiction over the United States offshore continental shelf, apparently to protect oil royalties worth millions of dollars.

Two avenues of appeal were opened to Representative Adam Clayton Powell yesterday in his efforts to cut sharply a $164,000 judgment he owes and to reverse a finding that he is guilty of criminal contempt of the New York Supreme Court.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 3 (UPI) The St. Louis Hawks of the National Basketball Association were put up for sale today to "either local interests or other cities."

TENAFLY, N.J., Jan. 3 Austin A. Agnew, ex-officer of an oil-well concern and formerly a stockbroker in New York, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 81 years old and lived at 121 Surrey Lane here.
PARIS, Jan. 3 (UPI) Melvin Belli, who defended Jack L. Ruby in his trial for the murder of Lee Harvey Oswald, accused Dallas civic authorities today of negligence in "letting Ruby die."
MALVERNE, L.I., Jan. 3 John A. Morhous, attorney for the Town of Hempstead for the last 12 years, died in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, today. He was 56 years old and lived at 134 Park Boulevard.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla.. Jan. 3 James R. Hoffa expressed optimism today about reaching a national trucking contract peacefully but said the industry would have to raise rates to pay for it.
Paul F. Pellicoro, a senior member of the architectural concern of Rogers, Butler Burgin, 219 East 44th Street, died Monday of a cerebral hemorhage. He was 46 years old.

The main-floor exhibition gallery of the Pepsi-Cola Building at Park Avenue and 59th Street will be filled with antique furniture, paintings and art objects during a three-day sale starting Jan. 12. Proceeds will go to Cancer Care.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) Vice President Humphrey and others prominent in Government and diplomacy paid final respects today to Christian A. Herter, former Secretary of State, at a funeral service in St. John's Episcopal Church. Mr. Herter died on Friday at the age of 71.
BANGKOK, Thiland, Jan. 3 Thiland will send a 1,000man combat battalion to South Vietnam in the near future, the official Thailand radio announced today.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 3 Union Miniere du Haut Katanga today placed the value of its assets seized in the Congo mining equipment, metal stockpiles and bank accounts at more than $800-million.

Unable to hold a 5-point lead with 40 seconds to play, even though Philadelphia's Wilt Chamberlain had dust missed five free throws in succession, the New York Knickerbockers saw what would have been their most exhilarating victory of the season turn into their most disappointing defeat at Madison Square Garden last night.

William (Bud) Gilmour, one of the country's most successful trainer-drivers, and two other horsemen were denied their 1967 licenses by the New York State Harness Racing Commission yesterday pending the outcome of a commission investigation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Pentagon announced today the names of 72 servicemen killed in action in Vietnam.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Jan. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Thomas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Clark Thomas, to Wayne R. Andersen. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Andersen of Chicago.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 (AP) Commuter fare increases of 5 per cent on the Boston Maine and the New Haven Railroads were ordered today by the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, which subsidizes the commuter service.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 Three more of the nation's major automobile manufacturers announced today that they would be unable to meet between 6 and 10 of the Federal Government's 23 proposed safety standards for 1968 models.

Leland Stanford Buckmaster faced some stormy battles during his tenure as president of the United Rubber Workers, including removal from office in 1949 by the union's general executive board for "malfeasance in office."

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan, 3 Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson announced today the appointment of 36year-old Daniel T. Sweeney as First Deputy County Executive. Mr. Sweeney, now Second Deputy County Executive, will succeed Howard J. Koop, who will become operating director for the Educational Compact of States, a research and coorlination council for state education commissions. Mr. Sweeney's appointment is effective this Saturday.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 AP The Philadelphia Phillies acquired first baseman Jim Gentile today from the Cleveland Indians' Portland farm club as a backup man for the injured Bill White.
St. John's University was accused last night by the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. of being hostile to the values that make "an adult university."

Staff members of the city's Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx are protesting the closing last week of nearby St. Francis Hospital, complaining that a medical "crisis" has been caused in the low-income area of 400,000.
For the first time in its history the North Atlantic the world's busiest international travel route handled more than 5 million travelers a year.

LEESBURG, Va., Jan. 3 (AP) Lester H. Carr, an expert in antennas and communications systems, died in a Washington hospital yesterday after being stricken on Christmas Eve with a heart attack at his farm near Fort Evans. He was 56 years old.
The Rev. Dr. Robert L. Wilken, a Lutheran church historian, has been named to the theological faculty of Fordham University, a Jesuit institution.
WILTON, Conn., Jan. 3 No garbage has been collected in this town since Saturday and its 12,000 inhabitants are getting worried.
The old Metropolitan Opera House was still standing yesterday, awaiting the completion of legal formalities that would allow it to be demolished.
Not by money alone will the needs of the unfortunate be met, wrote the donor of a $300 contribution that was received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

City Controller Mario A. Procacoino strongly intimated yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had tried to dodge the "basic responsibility" for enforcement of affiliation contracts between municipal hospitals and voluntary, nonprofit institutions.

The General Electric Company has made a new move in textile fibers with a polymer substance it describes as the "greatest advance in polymer chemistry since the invention of nylon." It gave no details.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 3 The 95th Indiana General Assembly will convene Thursday, faced with the task of getting rid of a $230-million surplus for the next two fiscal years.
ATLANTA, Jan. 3 (UPI) Aides of Lester Maddox stood in the doorway of the Maddox campaign headquarters today and barred Representative Callaway from entering.
Many Negro college seniors returning to campus after the holidays found in their waiting mail a booklet entitled, "They're out to get you."
Wall Street firms continued yesterday their flood of yearend promotion announcements.
Nathan Schulman, a financier and philanthropist, died Monday in his home, 145 Central Park West. He was 74 years old.
In an unexpected switch of tactics, Mayor Lindsay called on the City Council yesterday to pass a local law setting up 27 Little City Halls, each to serve a full Council district.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 (UPI) The Boston Celtics made it three straight over the San Francisco Warriors with a 126-121 overtime victory in a National Basketball Association contest tonight.

MACAO, Jan. 3 (AP) Macao's Portuguese Government bowed to Chinese Communist demands today and posted orders prohibiting Nationalist Chinese in the colony to fly Nationalist flags or engage in any activities against Communist China.

THE beginning of the year finds the New York State Conservation Department without the services of a respected official there. Cecil E. Heacox, deputy commissioner; who put in three decades in the service of conservation, has retired.

The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association moved in Federal Court yesterday for the reinstatement of 12 men who had been dismissed from the department after refusing to answer questions in a bribery investigation.

The New York Times and sevaral hundred other newspapers across the nation that subscribe to the stock-table service of The Associated Press carried erroneous closing prices last Saturday morning on about one-third of the issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday.

Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler, said yesterday that a five-week investigation of more than 60 cheap hotels, many of them housing welfare clients, had disclosed "truly incredible" conditions of squalor and danger.

The Lockheed-California Company said yesterday that it was temporarily laying off about 350 employes, mostly engineers and scientists, because it had lost the design competition for the supersonic jet transport.

Express checkout lines for baggage and passenger-operated pushcarts were the order of the day on North River luxury liner piers yesterday as 5,225 cruiseship passengers debarked during a five-hour period from nine returning cruise liners.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 A spokesman for Pan American World Airways said tonight that he expected a truce for a few days in the dispute between the United States and the South Vietnamese Government concerning the airline's landing rights.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) President Johnson announced today he had accepted the resignation of Howard G. Freas from the Interstate Commerce Commission.
HARTFORD, Jan. 3 Starspangled bunting and new gold draperies decorate the marble and granite Capitol here in preparation for the opening of the biennial session of the General Assembly tomorrow.

ROME, Jan. 3 Richard Burton said today that he was planning to return to the stage either in "The Devil and the Good Lord" by Jean Paul Sartre or a highly controversial play about a giant of the 20th-century political scene.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 3 It will become increasingly (difficult and expensive during the next dacade for metropolitan areas to purchase suitable, well situated land for airports, according to a study released today by Arthur D. Little, Inc., an industrial research and management consulting company.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 3--Max C. Hurwitz, a leader in Hudson County commercial and philanthropic endeavors, died yesterday in New York University Hospital. His age was 81 and he lived at 416 Washington Street.

WYNNEWOOD, Pa., Jan. 3 Mrs. C. O'Hey Pickering of Wynnewood and Loring Pickering 3d of Lanham, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dale Woods Pickering, to James Pearson Northrop. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Northrup of Haverford.
For two important metals in relatively short supply copper and silver yesterday's futures trading brought some sharply higher prices.
DETROIT, Jan. 3 (AP)-In addition to reaction from manufacturers in the United States, the safety agency received corn ments from loreign auto mak. ers.

The Toronto-Dominion Bank, the fifth largest of Canada's eight chartered (commercial) banks, announced yesterday that it had purchased a "substantial interest" in the World Banking Corporation, a commercial and trust bank based in Nassau, the Bahamas.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 The state lottery plan to be put before the Legislature is expected to call for sales either through vending machines in public places, or through "controlled outlets," such as banks, or a combination of both.
GARY, Ind., Jan. 3 (UPI) The former editor and co-owner of The Gary Post-Tribune, Henry Burgess Snyder, 83 years old, was missing today and believed drowned in Lake Michigan.
The 1967 stock market started off with a rousing rally yesterday morning, but the strength vanished in the afternoon. Prices closed only slightly higher on average.

Miss Florence May Hutt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Hutt of Paris, was married yesterday to Richard Comyn Eames 2d, son of Mrs. Betty Waldo Parish Eames of New York and Mr. Eames of the Virgin Islands.

4 SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 4 (AP) The Viet Cong radio has announced that two American civilians who disappeared last May and who apparently have been held by the Communists since then will be released, United states officials said today.

ADOLFO, a slim, blond and reticent milliner born in Cuba, and Mr. John, a not-so-slim, dark and voluble milliner from New Rochelle, opened the year's fashion calendar yesterday with their statements for spring.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 3 Miss Judith Kathryn Farrell, a reporter for The Topeka State Journal, and Charles Adams Corcoran, a reporter for The Topeka Daily Capital, plan to be married next month.
An official of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks expressed confidence yesterday that his union would remain the bargaining agent for clerical employes of Pan American World Airways.
LOUISVILLE, Jan. 3 (AP) Westley Unseld and Fred Holden paced Louisville's undefeated basketball team to a 76-62 Missouri Valley Conference victory over Tulsa tonight.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 Today, one day before the opening of the State Legislature, the massive granite Capitol was placed under siege by an army of carpenters, clerks and cleaning women.

The proposed invasion of Haiti and, at a later stage, of Cuba had a comic movie ending but it was not funny. Haitians, Cubans and Americans armed themselves, acquired ships and tried to launch an expedition from United States shores, in violation of American law.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan, 3 (UPI) A Moscow-based Yugoslav newsman has reported that Chinese Communists crossed the Soviet border and clashed with Soviet defenders, it was disclosed today.
ROME, Jan. 3 (UPI) Pope Paul VI will receive Nikolai V. Podgorny Jan. 29 in the first papal audience for a Soviet chief of state, Vatican sources said today.
Leslie P. Eichel, editor, writer and public relations man, died on Monday in his home at 34-41 85th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. His age was 76.

The First National City Bank of New York announced yester day the election of John P. Dowd and George Yates as vice presidents in the operations section of its metropolitan division Mr. Dowd and Mr. Yates formerly served as assistant vice presidents.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 3 (AP) Richard Brooks, producer-director of the film version of Truman Capote's "In Cold Blood," announced today that the roles of Dick Hickock and Perry Smith, the two killers, had been filled.
New York's thoroughbred horsemen have asked the State to adopt legislation that would increase their purses this year by about $6.5-million.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Jan. 3 (Reuters) A group of United States rocket experts headed by Dr. Wernher Von Braun flew today from Christchurch, N,Z., to Antarctica to study conditions that may have some bearing on problems related to a projected manned moon landing.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 3 State Supreme Court Justice James D. Hopkins and Mrs. Hopkins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Alison Hopkins, to Robert Bradford Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Smith of Warwick, R.I.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan 3--Gov. John H. Chafee predicted today a "substantial tax increase" in his inaugural message to the General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) A stipulation to resolve a dispute between two historical organizations with similar names was approved today by United States District Judge Alexander Holtzoff.
CHICAGO, Jan,3-Jack Ruby will be buried beside his parents in Westlawn Cemetery here.
MARRIED couples have won the top awards for 1966 in the New Jersey Council of Sports Car Clubs' rally championship series.
PARIS, Jan. 3 The Compagnie Bull-General Electric announced today that it was abandoning an important new line of computers and would impose a limited reduction in payroll and working hours.
James Edward Sutton, an educator and missionary in the Middle East, died in Beirut, Lebanon, last Thursday after two months' illness. He was a member of the Society of Friends and was 68 years old.

NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Jan. 1 During the last year Lawrence Ash, a young American parasitologist from Northampton, Mass., has gained the reputation of being the most persistent nocturnal prowler in Noumea.
The election of Albert P. Gagnebin as president was announced yesterday in Toronto by the Internattonal Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., as part of a realignment of its management.
