Raymond Myers, a British baritone, will make his American debut singing the title role in the New York City Opera's production of Vittorio Glannini's "The Servant of Two Masters."

St. Francis of Assisi, who considered all living creatures and all aspects of the natural world his brethren, has been suggested as a model for modern man increasingly troubled by the unexpected consequences arising from his rapacious exploitation of earth's resources.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 4 (AP) United States planes attacked a North Vietnamese torpedo boat off Haiphong yesterday and set it afire with rockets, the United States Command said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 3 (UPI) Glenn Ford, a commander in the Naval Reserve, was called to temporary active duty with the Marine Corps today for a special assignment in Vietnam. The 50-year-old actor is expected to leave Thursday.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3 (UPI)--George Hamilton, the actor, left today by plane for Los Angeles after spending Christmas week in Acapulco with Lynda Bird Johnson, elder daughter of President Johnson.
LONDON,Jan.3 (Reuters) A reward of l,000 ($2,800) was offered today for information about the weekend theft from a London gallery of eight paintings worth an estimated 2.5 million ($7-million).

PARIS It is unwise for Washington to try and tie NATO into U.S.-Asian defense commitments. The alliance is already convulsed at its heart by the French problem. Nevertheless, our policy has been seeking to link American support for Europe in the Atlantic to European support for America in the Pacific. This is misguided diplomacy and can only be counterproductive.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Jan. 3 The "jewel" of this community's school system, the fouryear-old, $5.5-million Berner Junior-Senior High School, was invaded early this morning by vandals, who broke into offices and desks, apparently seeking money, scattered files and papers and then set five fires.
MIAMI, Jan. 3 The arrest last night of the members of a Haitian invasion force was the last act of what experienced local observers have always regarded as an "Invasion farce."
ROCHESTER, Jan. 3 Bishop Fulton J. Sheen named a young priest associated with a militant Negro group as his special vicar today to minister to the poor in this industrial city.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 3 Gustave Bisgyer of this city, campaign director in Virginia and North Carolina of the Israel Bond Organization, died yesterday while visiting a daughter, Mrs. Milton Shaw, of Chevy Chase, Md. His age was 65.
ATLANTA, Jan. 3 The Georgia Governor's election went to the State Supreme Court today and the odds in favor of Lester G. Maddox, the Atlanta segregationist, rose higher than they had been.

All of the shipping assets of the United States Lines Company including terminals, the superliner United States and 45 freighters, have been transferred in a corporate reorganization to a new company, United States Lines, Inc. The change went into effect yesterday under an authorization approved by stockholders last June.
The tape-recorded voice that has become the dominant witness in the trial of State Senator-elect Eugene Rodriguez seemed for the first time yesterday to be telling two quite different stories.

BONN, Jan. 3 Political sources here spoke with growing optimism today about the possibility of West German participation in the treaty to prohibit the spread of nuclear weapons being prepared by the United States and the Soviet Union.
Horace Bartfield, the son of Soldier Bartfield, an old-time top welterweight boxer, selected a piece of paper, from a bowl yesterday and announced: ...

AUSTIN, Tex, Jan. 3 John Ben Shepperd of Odessa took over today as sole administrator of the controversial Lyndon B. Johnson State Park, Fund. Mr. Shepperd was present as the Texas Parks and Wildlife Commission adopted resolutions amending the organization of the private fund, which has raised more than $200,000 to buy land for a state park across the Pedernales River from the LBJ Ranch.
THE decorating may be underplayed, but the shop per's needs are kept well in mind in the refurbished model rooms that open today on Bloomingdale's fifth floor.

KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 3(AP) A planned invasion of Haiti, said to have been designed as a stepping stone for war against Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, sputtered out today with the roundup of dozens of armed plotters in the Florida Keys.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods dropped in November to the lowest level in a year while inventories continued to rise sharply, the Commerce Department reported today.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 (Reuters) An American marine lieutenant told tonight how a chance encounter between his 16-man patrol and a column of 1,000 enemy troops during the New Year truce led to a night-long air and artillery assault on the enemy force.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (UPI) The Chicago Bulls overcame a 6-point deficit in a 72-second spurt midway through the final period and then stood off repeated rallies for a 116-111 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight.

In the spirit of the season, the New York Yankees and the Mets broke bread with each other at Yankee Stadium yesterday and announced that they would play their annual charity baseball game next July 12.
The American Stock Exchange started the new year with a broad advance yesterday as the list made its best showing in more than a year and a half.
The spot rate on the British pound improved 4 points, to $2,7907, in very quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

WITH his third book, a collection of short stories, Jerome Charyn, a young New Yorker now teaching at Stanford, seems to be making it clear that he has marked out a special precinct for himself and is determined to be its chronicler. It is a world of immigrant and first generation Jews living in enclaves perhaps ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Some American, officials saw signs tonight of a possibly significant shift in Hanoi's position toward Vietnam peace talks in remarks by the North Vietnamese Premier, Pham Van Dong.

Before dawn yesterday Gerard M. Weisberg, the new Commissioner of Markets, ventured into the Fulton Fish Market where $60-million worth of fish is traded each year without such basic conveniences as railroad sidings.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, Jan. 3 (UPI) The National Professional Soccer League of America should get full recognition from the International Football Federation by the end of the month, Sir George Graham, an adviser to the league, said yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3 After at least one postponement, the fourth congress of the Union of Soviet Writers has now been scheduled for May 22, the organization announced today.

MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 3 (UPI) The police reported that they killed one of 50 Africans trying to storm a police station at Leribe, 45 miles northeast of here, today. The attackers were armed with swears, axes and guns.
The hectic pace of the postChristmas week failed to lift December sales at New York's department stores much above the small gains recorded during the Christmas shopping period.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 3 (AP) Gary Penderthy, a virtually unknown Australian, upset Jim Osborne of Salt Lake City, 6-4, 6-4, In the second round today of the state tennis championships.
All but one of the insurgents seeking election to the board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were defeated yesterday.

Enthusiastic support from France's five Common Market partners is essential if Britain's bid to enter the European Economic Community is to have a chance of success. That support appears assured for the first time by indications that Prime Minister Wilson now is ready to accept, without fundamental change, not only the 1957 Rome Treaty but the rules and decisions adopted by the E.E.C. since that date.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan 3 (UPI) The John F. Kennedy Memorial Library will not accept profits from the sale of the record that includes the secret interview with Ruby, a Kennedy spokesman said today.

The Associated Press made public last night what it called its final money offer to the Wire Service Local of the American Newspaper Guild. But the guild rejected the offer as "unacceptable and unrealistic."
The construction of a 34-story office building at 110 East 59th Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues, will start in February, it was announced yesterday by Jack Resnick, the builder-owner.
Striking gravediggers picketed most of the major cemeteries throughout the metropolitan area yesterday and prevented most burials.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 103 on Friday from 103.1 on Thursday.

Wall Street started off 1967 with a dramatic delayed opening in Boeing shared yesterday on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. But in brokerage board rooms the customer caution born of the 1966 market slump lingered.
The bond market, which ended 1966 in a blaze of glory, began 1967 by taking time out to reappraise its recent swift advance.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., achieved record revenues and profits in the first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 24, according to a report issued yesterday by Robert H. O'Brien, president and chief executive officer.

Mal Graham broke his own New York University singlegame record last night as he scored 48 points to lead the Violets to a 100-74 victory over Wagner College in a Metropolitan Conference basketball game.

Harry Howell, a defenseman who once was booed brutally but is now considered the noblest Ranger of them all by many New York devotees, will be honored at a "night" at Madison Square Garden before the game with the Boston Bruins on Jan. 25.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 3 (AP) Judge Ramex Attiyeh ordered today the arrest of four accounting experts on charges of submitting false balance sheets in connection with Lebanon's Intra Bank.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 3 (AP)Albert Hilla,ire, 44 years old, oP Englewood, N. J., was sentenced today to 10 years in prison after pleading guilty to Federal charges of conspiracy involving smuggling of $2.5-million worth of marijuana from Mexico.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 3 In a detailed discussion of North Vietnam's views on the war in Vietnam, Premier Pham Van Dong emphasized that once hostilities were brought to an end, it would be possible to "speak of other things."
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) The nation's traffic death toll for the long New Year weekend was well under expectations and marked the second successive holiday in which a death record was not set.
Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., is planning to expand its industrial fittings operations through the proposed acquisition of the Kropp Forge Company of Chicago.

DALLAS, Jan. 3 Jack Ruby, Who shot President Kennedy's assassin before a nationwide television audience, died at 10:30 A.M. today at Parkland Memorial Hospital, the same hospital in which Mr. Kennedy and the assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald, died.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 3 Walter V. Moneypenny, owner and president of the Commercial Chemical Products Corporation of Midland Park, died yesterday at his home at 127 Netherwood Avenue. His age was 61.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 3 (AP) L.S. Buckmaster, former international president of the United Rubber Workers, died today in Henderson, Ky., where he had been visiting with his two sons. His age was 72 and he had suffered from cancer.

Let's run quickly through some of the more obvious ways in which the new production of "Marat/de Sade" at the Majestic differs from the cold, brilliant, resolutely contrary Peter Brook mounting that was offered us last spring: ...

A man who always wanted to be esteemed, who wanted to be known for his "class," Jack Ruby was, until Nov,24, 1963, an undistinguished and obscure operator of a Dallas striptease night club. On that hot, muggy Sunday, however, he achieved a place in history; He fatally shot Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin of President Kennedy in the sight of the Dallas police and millons of television witnesses.

The largest exhibition ever presented of Pablo Picasso's art will be televised live and in color over Early Bird satellite in a two-continent news special of the National Broadcasting Company. MADRID, Jan. 3 A painting of the dead Christ supported by an angel by the 15thcentury Italian Antonello da Messina has been quietly placed on display at Madrid's Prado Museum, which regards its acquisition as an important art discovery.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Jan. 3 A Fort Benning soldier surrendered to military authorities today after fleeing the fort hours earlier to dramatize his opposition to military service and the war in Vietnam.

Mr. and Mrs. A.V. Lennox Mills of Montreal have announced the engagement Of their daughter, Miss Katharine Georgina Mills, to Albert Tracy Johnson of Roslyn, L.I.

The University of California, Los Angeles, Louisville, North Carolina and New Mexico maintained their basketball rankings as first, second, third and fourth teams, respectiyeiy, in the wire-service polls issued yesterday.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 3--Kaghuto Sukhai, who describes himself as "the Prime Minister of the Federal Government of Nagaland," was asked today why he had come here for another round of talks with the Indian Government, which recognizes him only as an "underground" leader.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Dent have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Sanders Dent, to John Pescud Withers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Withers of Greensboro, N.C.

CHANNEL 13 may wish to go back to the little red schoolhouse to get a head start in educational television. Last night the station tried to explain the application of computer technology to teaching, and finished up as television's late, late bloomer.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the world's largest corporate enterprise, announced yesterday that it had achieved the highest profits in its history in the three and 12-month periods ended Nov. 30. Revenues also increased.

BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Jan. 3 (AP) Scott Romney, son of Gov. and Mrs. George Romney, and Miss Ronna Eileen Stern plan to be married in December.

ROSEVILLFf, ' Minn. (Religious News Service) There will be an organ in a Marine chapel in South Vietnam, thanks to the congregation of North Heights Lutheran church here.

Four organizations and two individuals attacked in Federal Court yesterday the detention by Customs officials of 317 packages of North Vietnamese literature addressed to them. The printed matter is being held, they said, pending the issuance of a license by the Treasury Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) Robert C. Weaver, secretary of Housing and Urban Development, announced today the formation of a 17-member advisory committee to assist in implementing the new model cities and metropolitan development program approved by the 89th Congress.

The United States Trust Company, the smallest member of the New York Clearing House Assocation in terms of total assets but one of the nation's largest administrators of trusts and estates, reported record net operating earnings yesterday for 1966.
In a tape-recorded conversation less than a month before his death, Jack Ruby told his brother that he had no recollection of the moment in which he fatally shot Lee Harvey Oswald .
WASHINGTON, England, Jan. 3 The "New Town" of Washington will attempt to combine the best qualities of village life with the amenities of larger communities.
The 50,934-ton Liberian tanker Failaika, her bridge smashed by a freak wave, was reported by the Coast Guard yesterday to be riding well en route to Portland, Me., her original destination.
Mr. and Mrs. Leo Kaiser of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Louise Kaiser, to Richard Lewis Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rosen of Hewlett, L.I.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kurmel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Geraldine Catherine Kurmel, to Richard S. Dworanczyk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Dworanczyk. Both families are of Brooklyn.

Governor Rockefeller held out little hope yesterday for a large increase in state aid for New York City. The Governor said "the city will get more money from the state, but it won't be in the magnitude the Mayor is seeking."

NAGOYA, Japan, Jan. 3 (UPI) Masahiko (Fighting) Harada of Japan successfully defended his world bantamweight title for the third time and avenged the only knockout defeat of his career tonight by winning a unanimous 15-round decion over Jose Medel of Mexico.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 3 Ambassador at Large Ellsworth Bunker married Carol C. Laise, the United States Ambassador to Nepal, in a private ceremony in this remote mountain kingdom today.
WASHINGTON Jan. 3 Dr. Haddon had no specific comment today on the criticism of his proposed vehicle safety standards.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 3 The United States Steel Corporation asked to have a negligence suit against it dismissed today but a Superior Court judge decided that he could not rule until he received an interpretation of a "finiquito" by Costa Rican legal experts.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company reported yesterday a net income of $4,075,539, equal to $2.47 a share, in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. This compares with $3,279,729, or $1.61 a share, on a greater ...
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 3--Two acts of violence along the Israeli border were reported from Galilee today.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 (AP) A onetime showgirl, Madeline Webb, who was sent to prison 24 years ago for conspiring in the killing of a wealthy woman in New York City, will be freed next Monday, the State Parole Board decided today.
EVEN THOUGH money was not as readily available as in the preceding year and the stock market declined substantially, merger activity advanced to a new high in 1966.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The Republicans are returning to Washington in a state of jovial optimism. They have been reading the popularity polls. They have been gloating over the trials of President Johnson in the press, and convincing themselves that all the troublesome riddles of life are going to bring him down.

LONDON, Jan. 3 British Petroleum and the Distillers Company, two of Britain's biggest industrial concerns, have made a 86.75-million ($242.9million) deal under which the oil company will buy out practically all of Distillers' interests in chemicals and plastics. Distillers is primarily a whisky and gin manufacturer.

New York Supreme Court Justice Jacob Marlcowitz appointed yesterday a special referee to hear additional evidence on a stockholders suit aimed at blocking the American Express Company's proposed $60-million settlement with creditors of its warehousing subsidiary.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 3--The storm-battered yawl Petrel returned at dusk today at the end of a towline to the harbor she had left nine days ago, on what was to have been an idyllic cruise to the tropics.
DETROIT, Jan, 3 (UPI) A lawyer who led the drive to nullify Jack Ruby's murder conviction said today that Ruby had died an "innocent man" and called his death "a merciful one."

THE quarter-final matches in the Greater New York Bridge Association's double elimination knockout championship will be played this month. With one match from the third round still undetermined, the draw among the undefeated teams is: Betty Kaplan vs. John Hester; Harry Fishbein vs. Alvin Landy; Dr. William Lipton vs. Dan Oken; Roger Stern vs. Max Ritter or Jerry Friedlander.

The Times Mirror Company acquired yesterday the privately owned General Features Corporation, a newspaper feature syndicate that distributes more than 80 columns, comics and special items from its offices here.
The running drama of the Douglas Aircraft Company, the financially ailing maker of the DC-8 and DC-9 jetliners, took a leap toward a denouement yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 The 190th session of the Legislature will convene tomorrow and go to work with an unaccustomed burst of speed.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 3 The Southern Maryland Agricultural Association of Prince George's County, Md., Inc., started its campaign today. The organization with the lengthy and pastoral title is actually, the Bowie race course, one of the three major tracks, along with Laurel and Pimlico, in the Free State.

Dr. Herbert Schreiber, a dentist of 1075 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, and a former associate professor of dentistry at the School of Dental and Oral Surgery, Columbia University, died in Purchase, N. Y., Monday while visiting a daughter, Mrs. Anne Grusmark. He was 67 years old.
TROY, N. Y., Jan. 3 The University of Denver hockey team turned a close game into a rout with a 4-goal final period tonight, scoring an 8-3 victory over Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 3--Secretary General Thant's preliminary soundings of North Vietnam's attitude toward peace talks have disclosed that progress hinges on an unconditional cessation of bombing by the United States.
Like a submarine in uncertain waters, sugar futures have been finding no bottom reGently. The downward price plunge continued yesterday, with new lows set for the contracts.
CONISTON, England, Jan. 4 Donald Campbell was killed here today as he gunned his jet-powered boat to about 300 miles an hour during an attempt to break his world water speed record.
Eight more painting contractors and seven more corporations were indicted here yesterday in the alleged multi-million-dollar city painting-bid scandal.

ALFRED, N.Y., Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Campbell have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Merrillyn Anne Campbell, to Capt. James Robert Barney, U.S.A.F. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Canfield Barney of Upper Montclair, N.J.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. William H. Harrington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gwendolynne Louise Harrington, to Robert Greeff Fisher of Baltimore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell Emerson Fisher of New Canaan, Conn.

Henry Guettel, son-in-law of Richard Rodgers, has resigned as general manager of the Music Theater of Lincoln Center, of which Mr. Rodgers is president and producer. Mr. Guettel will continue to supervise the nonprofit group's special events, such as concerts and experimental musicals.
AT a national championship, it is naturally the battles for the major titles that attract headlines. This tends to obscure many secondary championships that should be reported.
Strong, but differing, reactions among those who drive, ride or own cabs were touched off yesterday by the report on the city's taxi industry by Mayor Lindsay's panel.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday Jan. 5 (Reuters) United States patrol boats and South Vietnamese amphibious assault troops battled with Vietcong forces by the light of flares in the Mekong River Delta last night in an operation to suppress guerrilla river traffic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The United States Commission on Civil Rights, adding its voice to what appears to be a growing demand for welfare reform, recommended today that the Federal Government establish a national minimum standard for welfare payments.

"That wasn't me!" This emphatic denial was made by State Senator Eugene Rodriguez, who is accused of attempted extortion, after he heard a tape recording of a voice, already identified as his own, in an incriminating conversation.

KANSAS CITY, Jan 4 An 11-year dream of Joyce C. Hall, founder and chairman of Hallmark Cards, to upgrade the area around his headquarters was culminated today with the filing of a plan to convert 85 acres near the Kansas City business district into a model urban community.

Grove Press, Inc., a publishing concern that has made a success by converting what used to be considered far-out literary material into books that are in with a growing public, has bought the Mid-Century Book Society and the Cinema 16 Film Library, Inc.

Stores, unfortunately, do not always have the things that most customers want. When they do, the cash registers ring loud, clear and often. When they don't, there is the fretting problem that retailers call "walkouts."
The Coast Guard reported yesterday that the 50,934-ton Liberian tanker Failaika was riding through 10-foot swells at five knots under escort of the cutter Vigilant.
LONDON, Jan. 4 Donald Campbell lived for speed.

The Frank G. Shattuck Company, which operates a chain of about 45 Schrafft's restaurants and is noted for its confections, is planning to get out of the candy business, a spokesman for the company confirmed yesterday.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 5 (AP) The Tokyo Central Meterological Agency reported today a major earthquake, the center of which was believed to be in the region of Ulan Batora, the capital of Mongolia.

HOLLYWOOD Fla., Jan. 4 (UPI) Alvin Odom Jr. of Galveston, Tex., the defender, and a former Brooklyn Dodger pitcher, Vic Lombardi of Visalia Calif., shot a one-underpar 71 each today to share the first-round lead in the National Left-Handed golf championship.
The United States Naval Observatory has seen what appears to be a 10th moon of Saturn whose discovery was reported, by a French astronomer two days ago.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Jan. 4 Dr. Hugh Chaplin has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Barbara W. Chaplin, to Alfred H. Stewart of Paterson, N.J., son of Mrs. Elizabeth Stewart of Saugus Mass., and Alfred Stewart of Lexington, Mass.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 Gov. George Romney, stepping up his national political operations, said today that a key aide would establish a large, privately financed research office near the State Capitol in Lansing.
MEMPHIS, Jan. 4(UPI) The Elvis Presley Coliseum; 13,000 seats, cost $4.3 million; suitable for basketball, hockey, stage shows and the like.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 Milovan Djilas, who was released from prison by President Tito Saturday, said today he had courted arrest and imprisonment in 1956 with his criticisms of the Tito regime. But he said he had not intended his 1962 book, "Conversations With Stalin" as a challenge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) Screening of prospective jurors began today for the trial of Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Senate Democratic majority, on charges of tax evasion, larceny and conspiracy. It begins Monday in United. States District Court.

Richard Miller appeared at Town Hall last night in the second of seven concerts being sponsored by the Oberlin College Conservatory of Music in honor of its 100th year. Mr. Miller, a seasoned tenor who has sung in Europe and who teaches at Oberlin, put together an interesting program.

A RECENT sampling of opinion at New York private schools indicates that they are making haste slowly on the question of sex education. The schools are reviewing programs where they exist or discussing what form a program of sex education might take.
Mayor Lindsay will step into a Washington Square telephone booth at 10 o'clock this morning and will dial the operator without depositing a dime.
Two of New York's giant wholesale banks catering chiefly to big business the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Irving Trust Company reported yesterday their earnings for 1966.
THIS is the year to see double purpose in furn ishings. The rash of ingenious designs introduced recently show much can be done with hinges, metal glides, locks and pure inventiveness.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) The president of the Cook County Teachers Union said tonight that a strike by 650 junior college instructors had been postponed at least one day.
MADRID, Jan. 4 The Spanish police were reported to have detained at least 52 Algerian nationals today for questioning in the assassination of an Algerian Opposition leader, Mohammed Khider.
A fact that has always amazed this writer is that most youngsters, given a hunting weapon, are not really satisfied until they have rendered some wild thing dead.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 4 The aims, aspirations and operations of the National Liberation Front are viewed by its leadership in terms sharply different from the picture held by many Americans.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 4 (AP) Deputy Premier Praphas Charusathien said today that the Thai Government had not taken a final decision to send combat troops to South Vietnam.
The London Stock Exchange was generally quiet yesterday, as most sections of the market moved irregularly.

The film rights to Christopher Hampton's. "When Did You Last See My Mather" ?, the British play that opened off Broadway last night at the Sheridan Square Playhouse, have been acquired by United Artists for production by Bryan Forbes, the British writer-director of such films as "The Wrong Box" and "King Rat."

ATHENS, Jan. 4 A dispute between former Premier George Papandreou and his 47-year-old son, Andreas, threatened tonight to split the Center Union, the largest political party in the Greek Parliament. The son had stayed away from a party caucus that his father, the party leader, had summoned to approve his pledge to support the new Greek Government.

PARIS, Jan. 4 Miss Marina Beatrice Sulzberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus L. Sulzberger of Paris and Spetsais, Greece, was married this afternoon to Adrian Berry, son of the Hon. Michael and Lady Pamela Berry of London.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) A ruling that the New York Stock Exchange has the authority to fix minimum commissions for handling securities transactions was upheld today by the Seventh United States Circuit Court of Appeals.
Robert S. Gawthrop Jr., a West Chester, Pa., lawyer, was elected yesterday to the board of the Lukens Steel Company, Coatesville, Pa.
KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) All members of a Haitian "invasion" force were released on bail today. However, Masferrer was detained by immigration officials and taken to Miami for questioning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Americans for Democratic Action called today for a tax increase to finance broad social programs, including what it called a guaranteed living income for all.

RUGGIERO RICCI offered an evening of beautifully controlled violin playing last night at Philharmonic Hall. His tone was big and warm, his manner of playing elegant and eloquent and his fingers completely dependable.

THERE was a basketball game played at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night that deserves further comment, especially since the same two teams, the New York Knickerbockers and Philadelphia 76ers, are meeting again tonight in another National Basketball Association ...
Stock prices swung upward in late trading yesterday, reversing a downward pattern that prevailed for most of the session.
William B. Bergen, a 51-yearold former test pilot, unexpectedly resigned yesterday as president of the Martin Company, the aerospace division of the Martin Marietta Corporation.

If you need a cab, New York should be one of the easiest cities in the United States in which to get one. The ride will cost you less than in almost any other city. But you're more likely to have a gripe about the cab driver.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 Governor Rockefeller opened the 1967 Legislature today with a proposal for a vast highway and mass transportation bond issue expected to total at least $2billion.
Cushman Wakefield, Inc., has announced the election of Anthony J. Rizzo, a member of the brokerage department, as a vice president of the company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The Federal Trade Commission ordered four major manufacturers of hemorrhoid preparations today "to stop falsely advertising them as cures."

Mayor Lindsay had warm words yesterday for the general aims of Governor Rockefeller's new transportation plan. But he reserved judgment on details and balked specifically at a provision that appeared to increase the likelihood of a rise in the subway fare.

James McGuire, chairman of the new North American Soccer League and the United States representative to the International Associations said yesterday that there was no meeting of the scheduled in the United States in connection with sanctioning of the other new league, and that the North American would remain the only sanctioned league.

LONDON, Jan. 4--The eight paintings stolen five nights ago from the Dulwich College Art Gallery in southeast London have been recovered by Scotland Yard. The value of the paintings has been estimated at $5-million to $7-million.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 Governor Rockefeller told the Legislature today that no new taxes would be needed during the state's fiscal year starting April 1.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Jan. 4 The Congo will seek new markets if Union Miniere du Haut Katanga boycotts the sales of Congolese copper, the Minister of Information, JeanJacques Kande, said today.
LEVALLOIS,France, Jan. 4 The leader of France's Communist party accused Communist China today of aiding the United States by blocking efforts to aid North Vietnam.
A New Jersey-bound commuter was shot yesterday afternoon after he refused a man's request for a dime to use a pay toilet in the West Side Port Authority Bus Terminal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4(UPI) The Federal Communications Commission authorized today the purchase of the satellite ground station in Andora, Me., by the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat).

THE United States champion, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, who captured his eighth championship recently at the Henry Hudson Hotel by scoring seven wins and four draws over a strong field, is most to be feared when the situation on the board is deceptively placid.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Jan. 4 (UPI) Larry Miller drove in for a lay-up shot in the last second tonight to give the North Carolina Tar Heels a 76-74 victory over Wake Forest.

LONG BEACH, Calif. Jan. 4 (UPI) The Kansas City Chiefs, champions of the American Football League, arrived here today to prepare for the Super Bowl game against the Green Bay Packers, the National League champions. Coach Hank Stram ordered the men to the practice field almost immediately. He barred the press and the public.
The Waterfront Commission has ordered a hearing on whether a stevedore, suspected of commercial bribery, should be allowed to stay in business.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 4 The International Brotherhood of Teamsters plans to press for provisions to enable 500,000 more members to carry their pension credits with them when they change jobs.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Jan. 4--Mr. and Mrs. Morton Pickman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Pickman, to Richard Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Friedman of Great Neck.
The Parks Department announced yesterday that it was planning to develop the city's first park for handicapped persons.

Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., is putting some very active-looking and pretty young women into kitchen settings to make this point for Armstrong Cork Company's One-Step Floor Wax: "For Women With More Exciting Things to Do Than Scrub Floors."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 A Brooklyn manufacturer of brewer's yeast tablets is recalling 1,056 packages of the product because of possible contamination with Salmonella germs.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 Ormond E. Hunt, a pioneer in the automobile industry who sat in the highest councils of the General Motors Corporation for three decades, died of cancer last night at the Henry Ford Hospital here. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 A New York City slum rehabilitation project involving an unusual degree of industry-government cooperation was hailed here today as a model approach for "ending slum and ghetto environments."

Part of the cast was removed from Joe Namath's super-knee yesterday, and if the quarterback of the New York Jets can survive the monastic life for two more days he will leave Lenox Hill Hospital the day after tomorrow.

President Johnson is once again the man most admired by the American public, but by a reduced margin, according to the results of the annual Gallup Poll appearing in yesterday's World Journal Tribune.
Mal Graham, New York University's single-game record scorer, will lead the Violets into Madison Square Garden tonight to meet Virginia in the second game of a college basketball double-header.
NEW HOPE, Pa. The day the kitchen sank is re membered with joy in the Michael Ellis family.

LONGBIN, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 5 Two American civilian construction workers and a Filipino woman were released by the Vietcong yesterday in "reasonably good health" after having been held captive for more than six months.

Jaromir Kosar, a graphic arts scientist and director of research and development for the Ulano Companies of Brooklyn, suppliers to the graphic arts, died yesterday at his home, 157-12 Powell's Cove Boulevard, Beechurst, Queens. He was 42 years old.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 Nobody rose to offer an excuse for the absence of State Senator Eugene Rodriguez today when he failed to answer a roll-call at the opening session of the Senate.
MOSCOW, Jan. 4 A plea was raised here today for adopting private enterprise to meet the country's growing needs of fruits, vegetables and other foods.
Cigarette smoking and advertising came under a new attack yesterday with the premiere of an American Cancer Society movie designed to rally community forces throughout the country to fight them.

A reception will be given at Gracie Mansion on Tuesday by Mayor and Mrs. Lindsay for the Mayor's Committee of the New York Shakespeare Festival. The event will open the committee's 1967 campaign to present free Shakespeare in the parks, city playgrounds and schools for the 13th year.

TORONTO, Jan. 4 Inspired by several spectacular saves by their goaltender, Ed Giacomin, the New York Rangers salvaged a 1-1 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight on a goal by Phil Goyette with less than three minutes to play.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) Within the next few weeks the 25th Amendment to the United States Constitution providing for Presidential succession should be formally approved.

The Fine Arts Workshop has opened a fund appeal to continue its program of instruction for children aged 10 to 18 in dance, drama, speech and the fine arts. Talented youngsters are referred to it by the New York City Board of Education and by private agencies.
HONG KONG, Jan. 4--North Vietnam's Foreign Ministry today officially rejected a British proposal for a Vietnam peace conference and described the proposal as "an impermissible vicious act."

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 4 (AP) A truckload of vitally needed oxygen was delivered to strikebound Cafaro Memorial Hospital today despite efforts by pickets to block its passage. One picket was arrested.
LONDON, Jan. 4 Despite the rebuff from North Vietnam, Britain pursued tonight her attempt to arrange peace talks.
A three-man fact-finding panel was designated yesterday to hold hearings and make recommendations for a settlement of the contract dispute between the city and its firemen and police.
The bond market rebounded yesterday from its one-day setback on Tuesday, and sales of new issues of fixed-income securities turned into full swing in their first active day of 1967.

A middle-aged couple died last night when a smoky fire swept through an apartment in an East Harlem tenement. Their only escape route was blocked by iron bars intended to keep burglars from climbing through the rear windows of the ground-level flat.

Bill Bridges of the St. Louis Hawks and Jerry Sloan of the Chicago Bulls were named by National Basketball Association coaches yesterday to complete the West squad for the annual All-Star game against the East next Tuesday at San Francisco.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Thurston Greene have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Greene, to Allen Wright Rork, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Willard Rork of Westboro, Mass.
TO the question: How are we going to keep our dancers down on the farm after they've seen Paree?, the United States Embassy in Paris seems to have devised an interesting answer.
Navy contracts for production of aircraft and aircraft components were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 An unarmed Air Force missile went wild today during a test off the coast of Florida and soared over the western tip of Cuba before landing, apparently harm lessly, in the Caribbean about 100 miles south of the island.
The spot rate on the British pound was steady at $2.7907 in moderate trading on foreign-ex change markets here yesterday.

The time is ripe today for shooting one or more vehicles to Mars. No shots are planned by the United States, but it is expected that the Soviet Union will dispatch several spacecraft on the 153-day journey.
Charles Segar, the chairman of the major league rules committee, announced two rules changes yesterday adopted for scoring purposes.
CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 4 (Reuters)--The West Indies was poised for a series-clinching, victory over India, after the third day's play in the second cricket test today.
MIAMI, Jan. 4 (AP) A broadcast from Havana said tonight that Cuban forces had captured four "pirates from Florida" and had killed one of them as they tried to smuggle 20 people out of Cuba.

HONOLULU, Jan. 4 (AP) Cardinal Spellman said today that he had heard nothing from the Vatican on his Christmas sermon to United States soldiers, in which de declared that anything less than victory in the war is inconceivable.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) There will be restrictions on newsmen and photographers covering the trial of Richard Speck, according to Judge Herbert C. Paschen.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor denounced Mayor Lindsay's plan for neighborhood city halls yesterday and declared he would do all in his power to kill the proposal.
Following price increases last month by a number of sulphur producers, the Essex Chemical Corporation announced yesterday it planned to raise the price of its sulphuric acid.

A husband and wife testified at a closed jury trial here yesterday in a case that is expected to result in the first ruling in the state on whether artificial insemination constitutes adultery if performed without the consent of the husband.

Authority to regulate the New York City taxi industry rests with the City Council and the Mayor, who retain immediate jurisdiction over rates of fare, but delegate administrative authority to the Police Department Hack Bureau, which licenses owners and drivers, promulgates and enforces operating rules to govern their conduct, establishes physical specifications...
PARIS, Jan. 4 President de Gaulle agreed today to attend a meeting of leaders of the six European Economic Community countries in Rome next spring.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Both New York and Texas will retain seats on the House Ways and Means Committee if a plan favored by Democratic leaders is approved at a party caucus next Monday.

AT a time of night when schoolboys usually are deeply involved with homework, about 25 pre-teen and teen-age ski jumpers leave their Lake Placid homes three times a week to brush up on their technique.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. James F. McCarthy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Anne McCarthy, to Bruno Tomassi, son of Mrs. Guido Tomassi of Rome and the late Mr. Tomassi.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 4 (AP) Boris Krajger, Vice Premier of Yugoslavia and a member of the presidium of the Communist party, was killed today when his car skidded on the icy Zagreb-Belgrade highway and hit a tree. He was 53 years old.
The admission of Jeremy C. Jenks as a general partner was announced here yesterday by F. Eberstadt Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

MIAMI, Jan. 4 A hearing was set today for Jan. 25 for seventy members of an "invasion force" alleged to have been planning to attack Haiti. The hearing, in Key West, before United States Commissioner William V. Albury, will be on charges of conspiracy to export arms illegally.
The Interstate Commerce Commission, which last April denied the request of three large Western railroads to merge into one 26,000-mile system, will take another look at the proposal.

The New York Society of the Order of the Founders and Patriots of America will hold its annual mid-winter dinner on Jan. 25 at the Yale Club. The Rev. Dr. Harold E. Mayo, a retired Methodist minister and governor of the society, will be guest of honor.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) Jack Ruby will be buried on Friday morning after a private funeral. Ruby, who killed Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin of President Kennedy, died in Dallas on Tuesday.

James R. Hoffa seems bent on leaving has members well provided for when he goes off to prison. The Teamsters Union chief makes it plain that he expects to sign a new three-year national trucking agreement providing annual pay increases of 5 to 7 per cent. He makes it just as plain that he expects the trucking companies to raise rates to cover the cost of their generosity at the bargaining table.

YONKERS, Jan. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Bert F. Grossman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Gail Grossman, to Kenneth Harvey Kirshenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark L. Kirshenbaum of New Rochelle.

Mayor Lindsay formally asked the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday to submit a plan within two weeks to cut its sulphuric air pollution by 30 per cent this winter. But the utility replied this was "not feasible" because of inability to get lowsulphur oil.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 4 Pope Paul VI and Secretary General Thant have donated the prestige of their autographs to raise funds for restoring the flood-damaged art treasures of Italy.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (UPI) The Philadelphia 76ers led all the way tonight in defeating the Chicago Bulls, 136-115, for their 11th straight victory.

Braniff International announced yesterday a major expansion of its facilities here, where the Dallas-based carrier will set up a headquarters for its international operations and the eastern region of its domestic system.

George Wisnewski, a New York University sophomore who is best known as a two-miler, tried his hand last night at the mile and the result was a huge success.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The British Government has warned that strict enforcement of the proposed United States automobile safety standards could cause "considerable damage" to British-American trade relations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 4 (UPI) United States fighter pilots have received authority to attack North Vietnamese jet interceptors "the instant the wheels of the Communist planes leave the runway," informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Outstanding consumer installment credit rose by $444-million in November a larger rise than in October but still smaller than the average for other months of 1966.
DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) G. Mennen Williams said today he had been thinking of becoming an Episcopal priest.
LONDON, Jan. 4 Mary Garden, the famous soprano who was once a pillar of the Chicago Civic Opera Company, died yesterday in Aberdeen, her native city. Her age was 92.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 4 The Princeton University hockey team downed Brown University in Meehan Auditorium tonight, 8-5.

Outside the transit field Governor Rockefeller's ambitious plans for assuming a "new role of leadership" in solving the problems plaguing the state's citizens and cities seem likely to take second place to his firm pledge not to seek higher taxes.

DENVER, Jan. 4 The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union announced today agreement on a new contract with the Gulf Oil Corporation's refinery in Port Arthur, Tex., and union officials said they were "hopeful" that a strike with other refineries could be averted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Representative Lionel Van Deerlin advised all his House colleagues by letter today that he remained firm in his plan to move for the exclusion of Representative Adam Clayton Powell next Tuesday pending an investigation of Mr. Powell's qualifications.

Harold F. Rathe, president of E. Rathe Sons, 1840 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, manufacturers of window shades and Venetian blinds, died of a heart attack Tuesday night at a meeting of the Building Industry League, Inc., at its headquarters at 317 East 183d Street, the Bronx.

Preliminary figures suggest that savings in employe credit unions continued to expand last year, but at a slower rate than in 1965. Caught up in a highly competitive rate war with commercial banks and other thrift institutions, the credit unions lost ground. The average deposit, or "shareholding," in Federal employe credit unions so-called because they are chartered by the Federal government rather than state authorities is about $525.

AMONG those present at the CowboyPacker playoff in Dallas last Sunday was Dr. Robert W. Brown, one of the most distinguished and successful heart specialists in Fort Worth. He still is tall, blond and handsome, with the springy stride of the ex-athlete and with all the friendly warmth he had when he played third base for the New York Yankees. He was known as "Golden Boy" in those days. The golden touch remains with him.
MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (UPI) Authoritative Soviet sources today categorically denied foreign reports of armed clashes on the long Soviet-Chinese borders.
The city school system has halted distribution of a seventhgrade social studies textbook because of a complaint that a passage in the book reflected unfairly on Italian-Americans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--President Johnson held a secret meeting at the White House tonight with his Council of Image Advisers amid speculation that he intended to ask Congress for authority to revise his image before the end of the current fiscal year. The White House had no comment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, called today for a defensive barrier across Vietnam. He said this would be more effective in reducing Communist infiltration than bombing North Vietnam.
