BOSTON, Jan. 6 Gov. John A. Volpe, beginning a third term, took the oath of office today as the first Massachusetts Governor elected to serve for four years.

Itzhak Perlman, the concert violinist, yesterday married Miss Toby Lynn Friedlander, also a violinist, at the America-Israel Culture House, 4 East 54th Street. The ceremony was per formed by Rabbi Avraham Soltis.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 5 (UPI) Notre Dame was named 1966 college football champion today by the Football Writers Association of America in the only balloting held after the completion of postseason bowl games.
TORONTO, Jan. 4 Looking back, Claude Watson thinks he was oversensitive. He had recently adopted Timothy, a partNegro 2-year-old, and he was telling the barber he wanted a haircut "for my son."

After months of study and deliberation, Mayor Lindsay's panel has come up with some excellent and long overdue recommendations for improving taxicab service. The Mayor and the City Council should act on them without delay to remedy conditions that grow steadily worse.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 William S. Pickett, a vice president of the American Motors Corporation, said today that there existed no ground to justify reported plans of Young Americans For Freedom to picket dealers of American Motors products because of alleged company plans to trade with the Soviet Union.
WITH ski area operators prepared to welcome an other invasion of enthusiasts this weekend, Nordic and Alpine competitors were looking ahead to the first major events of the Eastern season.
Macrae Sykes, a senior partner of Shields Co., has been elected vice chairman of the board of governors of the American Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday.
The National Professional Soccer League will conduct a draft of college soccer players at its meeting in Atlanta next Tuesday and Wednesday.

Shortly after 8 A.M. yesterday William Olsen of Creskill, N.J., lit a "pronto tank" on the second floor of the Federal Customs Court under construction at Foley Square and started to melt lead to join pipes.
Stock prices rallied strongly on an unusually broad front yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 5 Suffolk County's proposed $1billion sewer system, hailed as a public health necessity and decreed as a taxpayer's burden, may become snarled in political controversy.

Gold is far from being the "barbarous relic" that John Maynard Keynes called it. On the contrary, the annual gold review published by the First National City Bank points out that, for the first time in modern monetary history, private demand last year absorbed all newly mined gold. Even though interest rates all over the world reached new highs last year, many hoarders and speculators preferred to put their funds into useless noninterest-bearing gold.

SEVERAL weeks ago it was announced that the Metro politan Opera National Company would be disbanded after this season. Thus, its opening last night at the City Center was something of a sorrowful occasion.
MADRID, Jan. 5 Hocine AitAhmed, an Algerian opposition leader, charged the Government of President Houari Boumediene today with the murder here last Tuesday of Mohammed Khider.

BONN, Jan. 5 West Germany's Christian Democratic Union remained a party in search of a chairman tonight after a meeting of its presidium attended by its most powerful member, Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger.

PARIS, Jan. 5 North Vietnam's chief diplomatic representative in Western Europe said today that if the United States stopped bombing his country, "definitively and unconditionally," the Hanoi Government would "examine and study" American proposals for negotiations to end the war.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 5 James R. Hoffa said today that any trucking strike this year would be limited in scope to prevent it from causing a national crisis.
A union official was shot in the neck and face yesterday as he left the office of his local at 37 Union Square West.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) The American Oil Company has announced plans for the addition of a 40,000 barrel-a-day hydrocracking unit at its Texas City refinery.

Thailand's Foreign Minister, Thanat Khoman, said last night that his country would soon seen combat troops to South Vietnam despite Deputy Premier Praphas Charusathien's statement Wednesday that no such decision had yet been made.

The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday it had been formally requested by the Distillers Company to approve the transfer of the British company's 50 per cent holding of shares in Distrene Company to British Petroleum. Dow holds the other 50 per cent in Distrene.
NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 5 (UPI) A protest against the war in Vietnam spurred an outburst of shouting and fist fights today in the lobby of the Student Union at the University of Oklahoma.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan, 5 The Rev. T. Jerome Hayden Jr., former rector of Christ Episcopal Church here, died yesterday at his home in Dorchester, Mass.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Jan. 5 Mrs. Lucy Mitchell, former president of the Women's Republican Club of New Jersey and a former member of the governing board of the Women's National Republican Club, died in her home here today. Her age was 96.

There may be poisonous plants on your street, in your garden or even in your home that could endanger the health or life of anyone who eats their poisonous parts, a Cornell University botanist warned here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission dismissed today an application by the Western Union Telegraph Company to construct a network of satellite communication stations.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 5 South African imports from Rhodesia last year rose by about $42-million, a sizable part of which was in tobacco, according to the latest trade figures.
Sugar futures plumbed new depths yesterday. In the busiest day in several months, 1,933 contracts were traded. New lifetime lows were made in 9 of the 10 deliveries available.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 5 (AP)--An unheralded pair of Australians jolted Arthur Ashe and Cliff Richey, the United States Davis Cup stars, today in the doubles quarter-finals of the West Australian tennis championships.
New York University's swimming team rolled to a 70-30 victory over Seton Hall University last night at Quigley Pool on the Bronx campus of N.Y.U.
The American Stock Exchange made its third consecutive gain yesterday as the list advanced strongly in active trading.
NEW SHREWSBURY, N.J., Jan. 5 Nine persons were killed this morning when a twin-engined plane crashed in a light rain seconds after taking off from the Red Bank Airport.
BONN, Jan. 5 The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, reduced its discount rate today to 4 per cent from 5 per cent, effective tomorrow.
Talman Bigelow, Whittemore, Ltd., has announced that Mrs. Ruth F. Brown and Samuel J. Krift have joined the real estate company as vice presidents.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 Albert Monroe Greenfield, multimillionaire financier, real-estate man, philanthropist and political power, died today at his estate, Sugar Loaf, in the Chestnut Hill section of the city after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 5 Nigeria's supreme commander and regional military governors wound up two days of secret talks in Ghana today trying to find a formula for preserving Nigeria's unity.
DETROIT, Jan. 5 (UPI) --Gordie Howe scored the 699th and 700th goals of his career tonight as the Detroit Red Wings posted a 6-4 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 5 Raul de Thuin has devoted most of his life "to the art of making philatelic rarities for those who wanted something unique."

Yesterday morning, a group of vacationing Puerto Ricans walked through their first snow to see their first show at the Radio City Music Hall and wound up buying the 200-millionth ticket at the country's largest movie house.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Jan. 5 (AP) This atomic city once a Government reservation surrounded by steel fences and an air of secrecy observed its 25th anniversary today.
Owners of taxicab fleets denounced yesterday a plan to revamp the taxi industry, calling it a "pie-in-the-sky" proposal that would lead to the return of criminals into the industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today its investigations led to conviction last year of 450 persons accused of violating military draft laws almost double the 262 convicted in 1965.

OXFORD, Md., Jan. 5 The next best thing to opening the duck and goose gunning season is closing it out under top-flight conditions. Since most waterfowling on the East Coast ends tomorrow, it seemed only sensible to hustle down to Maryland's Eastern Shore, check into a hunter's haven, the antique Robert Morris Inn, and wait for the predawn knock on the door.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 5 Never before, observers of the political scene said today, has a Governor been inaugurated so thoroughly and with such pageantry as Ronald Reagan. The former movie and television performer delivered his inaugural address today during a packed official schedule that carried him late into the night.

Alfredo Kraus, the Spanish tenor who sang in "Don Giovanni" at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday night, appeared last night in the company's sixth performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor," taking the role of Edgardo for the first time here.

ROBERT MURPHY'S very nice new nature novel occupies that amorphous literary no-man's-land where innocence and sentimentality, adult perceptions and juvenilia meet and fade into one another. It is a most delicate spot to be in, and a certain tip-toe effect is almost unavoidable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 President Johnson has turned down the official, commissioned portrait of himself by Peter Hurd as "the ugliest thing I ever saw."
The new emergency telephone system in the Washington Square area that requires no coins for "send help" calls from pay booths made a somewhat shaky debut yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading today in the stock of Crescent Corporation, a diversified company whose stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

At last a feeling of urgency seems to be entering the campaign against air pollution here. The new sense of immediacy, plus a realization that the problem must be attacked on a broad regional basis, are the most significant initial developments at the interstate air pollution conference.
The Bristol-Myers Company, a pharmaceuticals producer, announced the election here yesterday of Arthur J. Santry Jr., as a director.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 5 Dr. George W. Smeltz, former chairman of the psychiatry department at the University of Pittsburgh's Medical School, died here yesterday. He was 83 years old.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 5 (UPI) A 15-day strike of more than 300 welfare workers against the Cuyahoga County Welfare Department ended today with acceptance of a new contract.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The former managing director of the Federal Maritime Commission testified today that American exporters were "unquestionably" facing freight rate discrimination by trans-Atlantic steamship operators, compared with their overseas competitors shipping goods from Britain.
The nation's money markets reflected massive churning over the year-end, according to statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve System.

For the second year in a row, six of North Carolina's largest banks have made it possible for Lyn Ely's nonprofit Theater in Education to present "Shakespeare Scene by Scene" in 60 of that state's public schools. The tour will get under way Jan. 30 in Smithfield.
CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 5 (Reuters) The West Indies spinners completed the destruction of India's batsmen in the second test today, clinching the series for their team before a crowd of 50,000.

MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 5 (Reuters) King Moshoeshoe II gave up his struggle for wider powers today when he signed a document providing for automatic abdication if he failed to accept his purely constitutional role.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 The Chase Manhattan Bank has offered to be the chief agent for the state in selling lottery tickets throughout New York.

Mary Garden became one of the operatic idols of the first quarter of this century through sheer personality. She was the Callas of her day. At a time when singers ran to size and immobility on stage, the pert Mary Garden an actress supreme could walk out and hypnotize an audience with her unique combination of dramatic resource and vocal skill.

INDIVIDUAL contests have been out of favor among tournament players for many years. A few tournaments include such an event in their schedule, but, with the exception of a New England event, they are poorly attended.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 5 Rear Adm. John Reginald Beardall, retired, who served in the opening months of World War II as naval aide to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died here last night. He was 79 years old.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (UPI) Thousands of British Government secretaries last month spent many office hours, handaddressing Christmas cards to Rhodesia.

IN a showroom near the Coliseum yesterday, three skin divers from Hackensack, N.J., ogled a new boat described by its builder as "the biggest boon to diving since compressed air." Farther uptown, motorists gawked through the snow as an $80,000 yacht cruised across George Washington ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Federal Power Commission ruled today that it had no authority to regulate rural electric cooperatives.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP)-- Babe Stribling, the last surviving member of a family that was prominent in boxing in the nineteen-twenties and thirties, died yesterday. He was 59 years old.
ARDMORE, Pa., Jan. 5 (AP) Mrs. Donald G. Brien, who under her maiden name of Louise Lerch sang at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, died yesterday at her home here. She was 71 years old.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 5 Harvard's hockey team broke a 2-2 tie with three goals late in the second period and went on to beat Rensselaer, 8-2, tonight at Watson Rink.
The American Jewish Committee will hold a luncheon at the Plaza, Tuesday to benefit its Appeal for Human Relations.
Today is Christmas Eve, Christmas or Epiphany dependin g on what religious denomination is involved.
John N. Stauffer, president of Wittenberg University of Springfield, Ohio, was elected yesterday as a director of the Columbia Gas System, Inc.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 5 Dave Merhar and Ed Cutting scored four goals each today as Army beat Massachusetts, 17-2, in hockey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Sales of Government Savings Bonds in 1966 were the highest in 10 years, the Treasury reported today.
HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 5 (AP) Chief Nipo Strongheart, a Yakima Indian who appeared in movies and lectured on behalf of Indian rights, died last Friday. He was 75 years old.
George D. Rosenbaum, senior partner in the firm of A. L. Stamm Co., stockbrokers, 120 Broadway, died Wednesday at his residence in the Town House Hotel, 108 East 38th Street. He was 74 years old.

The Brooklyn Children's Museum, which, since its founding in 1899, has been housed in two mansions now a century old, is gaining a new home on the same site. It will be temporarily closed to the public from Feb. 1.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 5 (UPI) Bowie Race Course reopened today after a muddy track forced it to close yesterday. A crowd of 9,643 showed up to watch. He Can Deal outgame the favorite to score by a half-length in the $8,250 Prince Dare purse.

ROME, Jan. 5 Socialist commitment to the widest possible European integration emerged as the central theme of an "informal" conference of international Socialist party and government leaders that ended here today.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) Michael Hall, a 32-year-old unemployed London bachelor, was arraigned today on charges of stealing eight Old Masters valued at from $5-million to $7million from the Dulwich College Art Gallery. He denied the charges.
The General Telephone and Electronic Corporation announced yesterday the election of William M. Fuller as a director. He is a partner in W.M. A.P. Fuller, a Fort Worth, Tex., oil exploration company.
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 5 (UPI) King Hussein fought back today against the Palestine Liberation Organization, which has pledged to topple him to open the way for an attack on Israel.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation yesterday raised its price of copper 2 cents a pound, to 38 cents.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 (UPI) The New York Knickerbockers snapped the Philadelphia 76ers' 11-game winning streak, 112104, tonight and at the same time lifted their won-lost record to the .500 mark for the first time in eight years at this point in the season.
The State's investigation of harness racing took an unexpected turn yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5-- Speaker John W. McCormack told a group of liberal Democrats today that he would not support a move to discipline Representative Adam Clayton Powell in any way.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 5 Miss Mavourneen Maura Deegan and Colman McCarthy plan to be married in Washington on Jan. 21. Their engagement and approaching marriage has been announced by Miss Deegan's ...
International issues led a strong advance yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

JONATHAN MILLER'S television production of "Alice in Wonderland," which provoked a lively stir in London, is a wildly different and often magnificently inventive interpretation of the Lewis Carroll classic.
ARMED with imagination, nerve and tape that won't mark, college students are contriving to improve upon a dormitory decor for which they have many descriptions none of them favorable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The Army Corps of Engineers was sharply criticized today for permitting industrial plants to continue to pollute navigable rivers.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 5 (UPI) Two quarterbacks with a penchant for passing were named today as probable starters for Saturday's 18th annual Senior Bowl Game.

A site in the Lincoln Center area has been purchased for a new home for the Hebrew Arts School for Music and Dance, an institution that now teaches 250 children and 200 adults in rented quarters at 120 West l6th Street.
Best Co., the 88-year-old Fifth Avenue-based specialty store chain, will remain a quality fashion retailer.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 5 Mrs. Cyrus E. French has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Martha Belle French, to Second Lieut. David Barton Cable, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Jack Cable of Canton, Ohio.
The city's upstate water supply showed an increase at 8 A.M. yesterday of 500 million gallons more than on Wednesday.
The appointment of William E. Ferguson as managing partner was announced yesterday by Thomson McKinnon, a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange.
MANILA, Friday, Jan. 6 (UPI) Two buses crowded with religious pilgrims collided on a mountain road today and plunged down a sheer 60-foot ravine with a heavy loss of life.

Robert Hill McCullough of Baldwin, L.I., treasurer of the Entwisle Corporation, brick distributors of 104 East 40th Street, died Wednesday at South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, L.I. He was 50 years old.

Eight players from the east, headed by Long Island University's Reinhold Jabusch, and three from the Midwest were named yesterday to the AllAmerica college soccer team picked by the National Soccer Coaches Association of America.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5 (AP) Governor Kirk and a blonde Brazilian socialite he met two years ago on a business trip are planning to marry, her former husband said today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Janelli have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Ann Elizabeth Janelli, to John Urban Farley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Farley of Evanston, Ill. The wedding is planned for next month.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 5 (UPI) The National Labor Relations Board has rejected charges of unfair labor practices brought against Tucson Newspapers, Inc., by 142 striking printers belonging to the International Typographical Union.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday the appointment of Jacques Nevard, a New York Times reporter for almost 12 years, to be Deputy Commissioner in charge of press relations.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 6 (AP) Former Gov. Grant Sawyer announced today that he had decided not to accept "certain proposals" that would have necessitated his leaving Nevada.

A group of exiles from Haiti charged yesterday that the Haitian Government had lied to the Organization of American States about the circumstances of the death of an imprisoned member of a prominent family.

The fantastic ramifications of the Chinese political scene have taken on new intricacy with the revelation that Mao Tse-tung long regarded as the unchallenged ruler of China was booted out as President less than a decade ago and that he had to wait many months before he was finally able to launch the present "cultural revolution."
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 6 The United States Commission on Civil Rights did not reappoint the chairman of its Arkansas advisory committee, a critic of the commission, when his term expired Dec. 31.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Jan. 6 High Moroccan Government officials and exiled Algerian opposition leaders attended the funeral here today of Mohammed Khider, the Algerian guerrilla army treasurer, who was murdered in Madrid Tuesday.

TORONTO, Jan. 6 The Toronto Stock Exchange said today that starting Monday it would add to its stock tables a special list of mining and oil companies that have advised the exchange they have entered underwriting and option agreements for the sale of treasury shares.
DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) The Detroit Lions dismissed Harry Gilmer, their head coach, today after two losing seasons.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 6 There is little prospect of an immediate improvement in the serious shortage of gasoline in Zambia, and the Government has taken emergency measures to cut down consumption.

Mrs. Christine Schmitt Kroell, widow of Theodore Kroell, managing director of the Ambassador Hotel here from 1921 to 1932, died on Tuesday in her home at 735 West Penn Street, Long Beach, L.I. Her age was 72.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (UPI) American and Soviet airliners are expected to make the first flights on the new MoscowNew York route in May, United States officials said today.
Ellen T., a baby elephant beloved by children at the Children's Zoo in Central Park, is dead.

Although retailers here traveled an unsteady course during much of 1966, reports yesterday from large chain organizations left little doubt that business in December reached an exceptionally high level.

Fong Chow is a dark-haired, personable, self-effacing man who is associate curator in charge of Far Eastern Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Like most curators, he prefers understatement and avoids superlatives.
A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered an immediate trial of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's charges that milk dealers have conspired to fix prices.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) One of the men who has kept the wheels of the Senate turning for many years has decided to retire.
MANILA, Jan. 6 (AP) In possibly the world's worst highway tragedy, two buses loaded with Roman Catholic pilgrims collided today and plunged into a deep gorge where they crumpled like accordions.
Pick's World Currency Report, which takes a look each January at "What Was Best" in the previous year, has found that prices for art works rose as much as 80 per cent in 1966.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 6 The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Hudson Morse to Daniel B. Reardon 2d has been announced by Prof. and Mrs. Marston Morse, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Reardon is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Reardon of Hingham, Mass.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Jan. 6 Congolese President Joseph D. Mobutu complained yesterday of the high-handed manner in which Belgian officials of Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga dealt with him and a Congolese delegation in talks over the future of the company.
SHRUB OAK, N.Y., Jan. 6 Everybody talks about the weather but Lakeland High School students here are doing something about it.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he believed Governor Rockefeller's mass transportation plan for the metropolitan area would not result in a fare increase here.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP)-- Judge Francis J. Quirico in Suffolk Superior Court imposed state prison or jail terms today on six of seven defendants in a small loans trial. Testimony during the trial disclosed that bribes had been offered to state officials to insure that the interest rate on small loans would not be lowered in 1962.
HONOLULU, Jan. 6 (AP) The Coast Guard rushed heavyduty pumps today to the American freighter Santa Ines, reported leaking about 1,000 miles northwest of Honolulu.
The Orchestra da Camera at Hofstra University will begin its new series of young people's concerts Saturday, Jan. 21 at 2 P.M. at the Hofstra Playhouse, Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I.

Dr. Irwin E. Deibert, a former surgeon in Camden, N.J., and president of the New Jersey Board of Health from 1930 to 1938, died Thursday in his home at Pen Key Club, Islamorada, Fla. He was 73 years old.
ANYBODY want an oversize white fox stole to cuddle into these cold nights? Allen Grant had eight of them this week, their 86 inches of snowy fur in mint condition.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 6--The president of the Eastman Kodak Company charged today that a militant Negro organization's "talk about employment" was "being used as a screen" for "making a power drive in this community."
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 6 (AP) Tony Roche beat Cliff Richey of Dallas, 6-4, 6-3, 7-9, 7-5, to reach the men's final of the West Australian tennis championships today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 6 Princeton opened its Ivy League season tonight in impressive style with a 94-50 rout of Brown. The Tigers now hold a 10-1 won-lost record, having lost only to second-ranked Louisville.
The International Longshoremen's Association will renew efforts in Albany to get a state waterfront safety code to help reduce accidents on piers.

An opera program only six weeks old was auctioned at Carnegie Hall last night and was sold for $1,100. It was not the document's rarity but what it stood for that brought the high price, that and the fact that the money went to the Florentine Relief Fund. For the program was that used for the first performance the Comunale Theater in Florence gave after last autumn's floods.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) Frederick M. Alger Jr., former United States Ambassador to Belgium and a member of a prominent American family, died yesterday at his suburban Grosse Pointe home after a short illness. He was 59 years old.
A Soviet-built pleasure craft has been added to the line-up for the National Boat Show, which opens next Saturday at the Colisuem.

The primary legislative aim of the merchant marine industry this year will be to abolish the hypocritical meat-ax method" of budgeting Federal shipping funds, a leading maritime official said yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I, Jan. 6-- A state law providing pay increases to welfare workers who pursue graduate study has been declared unconstitutional here in State Supreme Court.

The dispute between the State Harness Racing Commission and William (Bud) Gilmour, who earns a quarter of a million dollars a year training and driving horses, escalated into the State Supreme Court yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 6 Marijuana is being taken by dozens of high school pupils here as well as by an unknown number of Princeton University students.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 5 The best present you can give your girl friend in Hanoi is not a box of candy or even a diamond ring. It's a new chain for her bicycle.
WHEN children grow up and leave home, their parents generally move into a smaller house.

WILMETTE, Ill., Jan. 6 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Schulz of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Cecilia Schulz, to James Schink, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Schink of River Forest.

President Johnson's rejection of the portrait he commissioned from Peter Hurd and his citation of a likeness produced by Norman Rockwell as the kind of job he would have liked, presents Mr. Johnson in the legitimate image of dissatisfied customer and the odd one of art critic.

REVIEWS of the exhibitions at Asia House, 112 East 64th Street, tend to be a little repetitious, falling into a groove of comments on the scholarly nicety of their selection and the perfection of their installation. Devoted to ancient or exotic cultures where the arts were more given to ceremonial dignity and intellectual or spiritual contemplation than to razzmatazz, Asia House exhibitions really should not require anything more than an announcement that they are there.

Bernard E. Van Dam, executive head of Van Dam Products and Van Dam Overseas, 1299 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, importers of party goods and manufacturers of toy balloons, died Thursday of a heart attack. His age was 53.
Four major races were added to the 1967 international calendar and officers were elected yesterday at the annual meeting of the Automobile Competition Committee of the United States yesterday.
Trading volume in United States Treasury bills rose to $2,423,000,000 a day on average in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The Federal Government has told Mayor Lindsay that his proposal to reroute the Richmond Parkway away from Staten Island's greenbelt of parks and streams "is not acceptable as submitted," a spokesman for the Mayor said yesterday.
Hoffmann-La Roche, Inc., the producers of drugs, chemicals and vitamins, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Robert J. Robinson as director of medical affairs, a new top executive post.
Gov. George Romney of Michigan arrived in New York City yesterday after an unannounced flight from Lansing.
TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP) The Air Force is switching part of its military troop lift to Vietnam from Travis to McChord Air Firce Base in Washington tomorrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 (UPI)--A Federal effort to end the two-month-old strike of electricians against 13 West Coast shipyards failed today when both sides stood firm in their previous positions.

Mrs. Sophia Kamish Ehrlich of New York and Dr. Gerald Ehrlich of New York and Putnam Valley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marianne Ehrlich, to Lewis M. Koppel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Koppel of Morton Grove, Ill.

WESTON, Conn., Jan. 6 Miss Phoebe Berry Frisk's engagement to James Edwin Commins has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gustaf Frisk. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Frank Newton Cummins of Staunton, Va., and the late Dr. Cummins.
American Book-Stratford Press, Inc., the publisher, announced yesterday the election of Francis S. Levien as a director, raising the size of the board to 12 members.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The United States Patent Office was gratified this week by the first result in its campaign to make patents easier to understand.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Green Bay Packers will run up against a different type of offense when they meet the Kansas City Chiefs in the Super Bowl on Jan 15.

Suspense over the fate of the old Metropolitan Opera House was heightened yesterday when the office of the Corporation Counsel of New York City advised Charles G. Moerdler, Commissioner of Buildings, that he might be held in contempt of court if he withheld a demolition permit for the building beyond Monday.
BOSTON, Jan. 6 Elliott Carter's Piano Concerto received its world premiere this afternoon at Symphony Hall. Erich Leinsdorf conducted the Boston Symphony, and Jacob Lateiner was the piano soloist.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) Former Senator Maurine B. Neuberger, Oregon, Democrat, was named today as a consumer relations consultant for the Food and Drug Administration.

Grace Bumbry, mezzo-soprano, and Montserrat Caballe, soprano, will return to the Metropolitan Opera roster during the 20th week of the season, beginning Monday, Feb. 6. Miss Bumbry will sing her first Amneris with the company in the Feb. 6 nonsubscription performance of "Aida." Miss Caballe will sing her first Met Leonora in the Feb. 8 "Il Trovatore."
WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Volkswagen began production of a new, less powerful and less expensive "beetle," it was announced here today.

HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 6 The judge assigned to decide whether a brunet couple of Italian descent should be permitted to adopt their blue-eyed, blond foster child announced today that he favored the adoption.

BUENA PARK, Calif., Jan. 6 (UPI) Larry Griggs of Long Beach, Calif., posted a courseequaling 65 today for a onestroke lead in the second division of the split first-round play in the $22,000 Southern California open golf tournament.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Jan. 6 (AP) Milton Luros, 55-yearold Los Angeles publisher, was sentenced today to five years in a Federal pentitentiary for sending obscene matter into Iowa.

TORONTO, Jan. 6 Two Toronto accountants were charged today with conspiring with each other and with the late C. Powell Morgan, president of the insolvent Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, to defraud a Toronto company of $140,000.

Use of nuclear explosives to blast out underground storage for natural gas for the metropolitan area was suggested by the state yesterday as one way to ease air pollution. This would allow the burning of more gas and less fuel containing sulphur.
QUONSET POINT, R.I., Jan. 6 (UPI) A Nayy helicopter on a training flight guided a troubled single-engined private plane to a safe landing at the Quonset Point Naval Air Station last night.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 6 Gov. Ronald Reagan wants to cut the state appropriation proposed for the University of California next year. He also wants to end a century-old tradition of free education by requiring tuition payments that would help finance the school.
State Supreme Court Justice George Tilzer ruled in a test case yesterday that state and city taxes must be paid on every pack of cigarettes mailed to customers in New York.
Having filed my oath of office in the Ulster County Clerk's Office, I submit herewith my report as special guardian:

Ten seldom-shown movies based on well-known literary sources make up a new program to be presented on Friday evenings during the spring semester of The New School, 66 West 12th Street. Tickets for the entire series, "The Play and Novel as Film," or for single screenings are available through the registrar's office at the school.

MALANG, Indonesia, Jan. 4 Java's political leaders are waiting for a signal that has not come. Like the volcanoes that brood in purple menace over the lush rice and sugar fields here, forces that produced violent political eruptions in this area a year ago are dormant but not extinct.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Senate ethics committee has been inquiring into allegations that Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, received a sizable campaign contribution in cash from a New Haven manufacturer in 1964 and did not report it to the Secretary of State of Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) President Johnson named 17 members to the auto safety advisory council today, including representatives of the public and auto industry but leaving off Ralph Nader, the safety critic.

Paperboard production rose 27 per cent to 321,200 tons in the week ended Dec. 31 from 252,900 in the corresponding week a year ago, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 6--A March wedding is planned by Miss Constance Ruth Allis and John Milton Neale 2d. The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Oswald Thompson Allis have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Neale of Radnor.
Hugh MacLennan, the Canadian author who has won the Governor General's Award five times, has written his first novel in seven years.

Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo urged Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Democratic State Chairman John J. Burns yesterday to prevent the election of any ally of Charles A. Buckley as county leader.

Let Freedom Ring, an ultra right-wing organization that has attacked prominent persons in recorded telephone messages, is now using a recording that says large quantities of LSD are being smuggled into this country from the Weizmann Institute in Israel.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) Two fliers plan to relive history tomorrow in a fragile, reconstructed, two-seater biplane with limited instruments, no radio and an open cockpit.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 6 (UPI) Gretel and Dame Pattie, two challengers that hope to bring the America's Cup to Australia this year, meet tomorrow in the first of a series of trials to help prepare the yachts and crews for a showdown with the United States.
ROME, Jan. 6 Pope Paul VI said today he wished to renew contacts with the mainland Chinese and "discuss peace" with their leaders.
LITTLE girls will soon be able to spill ice cream, draw pictures and make cutouts on their clothes while their mothers smile benignly at their creativity.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 6 Dr. Walter Edward Lundblad, who founded the allergy clinic at Orange Memorial Hospital in 1924, died yesterday at that hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 6 Briar Hill Road here.
BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 6 (AP) The wife of a boulder bank president was tied up and held prisoner in her home today white $50,000 was paid for her release.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 6 (AP) Virgil Carter of Brigham Young and Terry Southall of Baylor renew their all-star rivalry tomorrow in the Senior Bowl, with both yet to prove themselves in postseason play.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6-- Tight money, which has worsened the Government's budget picture in several ways, has also given the budget some help, the Federal Reserve Board reports.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 23 Turkey's first successful domestically manufactured car, the Anadol, was unveiled recently amid recollections of an earlier, ill-fated ceremony.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 A California aeronautical engineer was granted a patent this week for a method of determining whether life exists on other planets.
The giant Connecticut General Life Insurance Company has decided to augment an industry trend by taking the first steps toward corporate reorganization on a holding-company basis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Revenue freight traffic volume generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended Dec. 31 was behind the level of the corresponding week of 1965.
Policemen cruising in a decoy taxicab in the Bronx early yesterday morning interrupted a holdup of a cabdriver and arrested two suspects fleeing the scene.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Soviet press accused Mao Tse-tung today of a host of shortcomings, including the coddling of capitalists, condoning student cheating in the classroom and splitting the world Communist movement.
WARSAW, Jan. 6 The Premier of Denmark counseled Poland today to put aside her "old and understandable" mistrust of Germany and listen with an open mind to "the new signals" from Bonn.
BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 5 Artifacts reliably dated at 800 B.C. have been unearthed by Brown University anthropologists on the banks of the Kobuk River, 50 miles north of the Arctic Circle, in Alaska.
ALBANY, Jan. 6--Senator Robert F. Kennedy urged the state Democratic party today to become involved with community service programs as part of its effort to rebuild its organization.

On the surface, Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan has won a clear victory over King Moshoeshoe II and other political foes in the first test of strength since Lesotho became independent last October. After ten days of detention, the young, Oxford-educated king has agreed to halt his campaign for more authority and accept the role of constitutional monarch. The leaders of both opposition parties are under arrest.
SAMTHONG, Laos, Jan. 3 In a bungalow next to an airstrip here, Carol Mills of Keyser, Va., turned on a shortwave radio that hummed and crackled all night.
The election of two vice presidents by the United States Lines has been announced by John M. Franklin, board chairman. They are Leonard F. Nichols and Jesse Simons.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Newsmen staged a symbolic 10-minute strike here last night against the Government's controversial press bill.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 6 (AP) Americans call it terror. The Vietcong call it war. Regardless of the name, it means death.

DANANG, Vietnam, Jan. 6 (AP) Marine Pfc. Charles W. Keenan of Nitro, W.Va., was sentenced to hard labor for life today on conviction of having killed two Vietnamese civilians while on patrol, a Marine spokesman announced.
Francis Stilwell Dixon, a painter, died yesterday in his home at 1349 Lexington Avenue. He was 87 years old.

New York's 84-year-old abortion law is cruel and out of date. It permits therapeutic abortion only when it is necessary to save the life of the mother. The rigidity of this law annually results not only in many unwanted births but also in many needless deaths and in permanent damage to the health of countless women who have been driven in desperation to unskilled practitioners willing for a price to help them evade the law.

HOUSTON, Jan. 6 (AP) John (Joseph) Keane, the former baseball manager of the St. Louis Cardinals of the National League and the New York Yankees of the American League, died tonight in his Houston home of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 6 (UPI) Mrs. Ophelia Gaza, 30 years old, returned to Saigon today after more than six months in a Vietcong jungle prison.
The American Stock Exchange closed yesterday with another show of strength.
THANHPHONG PENINSULA, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 7 A United States Marine Corps force waded ashore in this Mekong River delta area yesterday and went by helicopter to landing zones inland.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 Premier Eisaku Sato's Government, beleaguered by Opposition charges of corruption, inaugurated a joint body of governmental and private organizations today to try to insure that the general election Jan. 29 will be a "clean" one.
MADRID, Jan. 6 The Foreign Ministry officially announced today the signing in Paris yesterday of an agreement establishing full consular and trade relations between Spain and Rumania.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 6 Forty-four Chinese fishermen in American hands since early in December will probably be returned to their homes on Hainan Island off the southern coast of China within a week, informed sources said here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The executive committee of the Democratic Study Group affirmed its neutrality today on the matter of disciplining Representative Adam Clayton Powell.
HARBOR BEACH, Mich., Jan. 6 (AP) The Coast Guard reported today the finding of the stern of the freighter Daniel J. Morrell, which took 28 of her 29 crewmen to the bottom of Lake Huron on Nov. 29.
Ninety years ago today, August V. Lambert, a young Alsatian, decided for no reason other than a sense of opportunity to open a jewelry store in New York.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) A spokesman for Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that the former actor had sold 250 acres of his Malibu ranch, Yearling Row, to 20th Century Fox studios for about $2-million.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 New York State was told today that it would have to pay for the first four months of its multimillion-dollar Medicaid program out of its own pocket.

A WORLD champion left New York last night after a two-day visit. Benito Garozzo, a member of the Italian Blue Team and rated by some as the world's number one player, was on his way home to Rome after a trip to California.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 Jack Ruby was buried today after a funeral service at which he was described as a misguided patriot and avenger who destroyed his world in one moment.

Price increases for palladium, rhodium, cobalt and tungsten carbide were announced yesterday by United States and Canadian producers. Further, several steel makers indicated they would charge more for tubularsteel products.
KEY LARGO, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) Gov. Claude R. Kirk denied reports tonight that he and a beautiful Brazilian divorcee plan to marry immediately.
State Senator Eugene Rodriguez took the stand at his Bronx trial yesterday and for two hours denied again and again that he had been involved in attempted extortion.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 Railroad service between Peking and Nanking has been suspended since December as a result of bloody clashes between opposed groups of workers, the Peking correspondent of Asahi, a leadling Japanese newspaper, reported from the Shinese capital today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The index of primary market prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent to 105.8 during the week ended Dec. 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods increased in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 6 Until June 30, 1960, the Congo was a Belgian colony in Equatorial Africa, a colony of extensive mineral deposits and tropical forests, with a land area more than 80 times bigger than the mother country.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Walter Carl Schuster have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Gillespie Schuster, to William Hugh Downey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh James Downey of Wolcott.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 6 Peasants in 1,000 of South Vietnam's villages and 4,000 of its hamlets will elect local governments this spring.
Columbia University's basketball team, after a seven-game Christmas-holiday trip, returned home to University Gymnasium last night and scored an 80-71 victory over Harvard.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 Construction of the part of Interstate Highway 87 in Westchester County that conservationists oppose most vehemently has been delayed for several weeks because of insufficient bids from contractors.
The turnover in copper futures trading spurted yesterday as prices declined. The volume totaled 1,680 contracts, for the busiest day in many months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 A 33-year-old Negro Baptist minister, who calls Representative Adam Clayton Powell's personal conduct "reprehensible and despicable," nevertheless is directing the Negro-sponsored "National Pilgrimage to Preserve Powell's Chairmanship."
LONDON, Jan. 5 The National Theater Company at the Old Vic is considering producing a new documentary play on World War II in which Richard Burton may play the role of Sir Winston Churchill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) The three Federal bank supervisory agencies today called on banks to report on their financial condition as of the close of business Dec. 31. It was one of the four regular bank calls issued each year.
Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Marvin of Rio de Janeiro have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Rae Marvin, to Harleston Read Wood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood of Gladwyne, Pa.

Dr. Edwin G. Langrock, a leading obstetrician, who delivered women of more than 10,000 babies in 50 years of practice, died yesterday in his home, 400 East 58th Street. His age was 78 and his office was at 115 East 61st Street.
Joe Namath, the New York Jets quarterback, was discharged from the Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday.

THERE must have been a good idea in this long, lumpy, inert novel, but it has probably disappeared under the pounding of a style that has more cliches than a chamber of commerce brochure, of a technique that gives naturalism a bad name, of a psychology that would be an insult to an afternoon soap opera.
Sybil Lamb may be the only stand-by actress who does not want the leading role for herself in this case the only female part in "The Fantasticks."
ONE fairly sure way to spot a new trend in furniture collecting is to note the actions of the dealers.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 6 Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos expressed hope today that newly elected Deputies of the National Assembly would support him and his policy of neutralism.

Miriam Makeba, the South African singer, is a familiar figure in our concert halls. But last night at Philharmonic Hall she offered some new songs and new arrangements and introduced a bright new teen-age duo.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 6 Governor Kirk will make a personal announcement "of some significance" Sunday afternoon in Palm Beach, an aide said today.

The Metropolitan Opera National Company brought its new production of Verdi's "La Traviata" to the City Center last night as the second performance of its five-week run. The production had been given in Brooklyn Nov. 11.
Samuel Baron, one of our best flutists, gave a recital of 18th-century and 20th-century music at the Carnegie Recital Hall last night, and it was excellent in every way.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 6 (UPI) Agreement has been reached in the five-month Alabama Power Company strike and a union vote on a new contract was set for tomorrow night.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP) An experimenttal model of the 2,000-mile-an-hour SR-71 strategic reconnaissance jet is missing and is presumed down in a remote area east of Las Vegas, Nev., the Air Force said today.

INUVIK, N.W.T., Jan. 6 (Canadian Press) Only three of 17 white whales trapped in the ice last fall have been seen recently at a breathing hole in Eskimo Lakes, 30 miles northeast of here and 1,200 miles northwest of Edmonton.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 6 A 10-foot-long scale model of a giant crane and an uncompleted bridge, which collapsed in Costa Rica four years ago, became part of the evidence today in a negligence suit against the United States Steel Corporation.
ROME, Jan. 6 Roman Catholic and Protestant Bible experts were reported today to have agreed to recommend formulas to overcome obstacles to the production and distribution of a common Bible.

Twenty-nine travelers are embarking today on a month-long expedition sponsored by the Archeological Institute of America. A highpoint will be the prehistoric cave paintings in the Tassili Mountains of southern Algeria. To reach the famous but seldom-seen caves requires an arduous desert crossing.
The Liberal party charged yesterday that "in the main" county officials failed to count the votes the day after the state election in November as required by law.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H.B. Cudmore of Greenwich and Fairfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Hosford Cudmore, to Robert Hutsel Bokum, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Bokum of Old Greenwich.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 Plans to raise $250,000 to establish a chair of canon law in the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, from which the Most Rev. John P.Cody, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, would deliver the first lecture, were announced here today.
The two largest copper producers in the United States yesterday followed a price increase announced Thursday by the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the third in size.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 6 Four thousand Israeli Christians, most of them Arabs, crossed into Jordanian Jerusalem today, some to celebrate the Feast of Epiphany and others to celebrate Christmas.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) An official of the American Medical Association suggested today thatphysicians be costconscious when prescribing drugs for their patients.
A committee has been formed here in the hope of giving about $2-million to help set the people of Florence back on their feet.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 6 Warren Stokes Seulowitz, vice president in charge of marketing for ATCOR, Inc., a nuclear consulting firm, died after a heart attack at his home here last night. He was 37 years old and lived at 23 Richelieu Road.
The London Stock Exchange turned hesitant yesterday, but prices were generally firm at the close.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 6 (AP) Golfers at the Bancroft Club in Zambia's copper belt believe they have an unusual local rule. It enables them to drop a ball out of a hippopotamus's footprints without being penalized.

WOODMERE, L.I., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Milton Freedman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Louise Freedman, to Norman W. Goldin, son of Mrs. Samuel Goldin of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Mr. Goldin.
PARIS, Jan. 6 A French Communist leader today attacked "little groups" of proChinese "renegades and adventurers" in France who, he said, have substantial financial means but no chance of success.
The Justice Department formally dropped yesterday its 17year-old espionage charges against Judith Coplon.
Scoring 14 points in the final six minutes, Art Beatty, a 7foot-1-inch center, led American University to a 95-87 victory over Long Island University last night on the losers' court.

A Columbia University professor has been dismissed as staff director of Governor Rockefeller's blue-ribbon panel investigating the municipal hospitals because, he says, he was outspoken in his conviction that the municipal hospital system be retained.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 Teachers struck all eight branches of Chicago's junior college system today, severely disrupting classes.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 6 (AP) Bjoern Wirkola, Norway's world champion, had leaps of 295 feet 2 inches and 306-10 today and won the third event in the GermanyAustria Four-Hill ski meet. The record for the hill is 313 feet.

MACAO, Jan. 6 (AP) The Macao police padlocked a proNationalist Chinese headquarters today that had defied a Government prohibition by flying a Nationalist flag in this Portuguese overseas territory bordering Communist China.

BONN, Jan. 6 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger today asked the chief Government spokesman, Karl-Gunther von Hase, to stay on at his post as head of the Federal Press and Information Service through 1967.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 6 Argentina's extension of her territorial waters to 200 miles provoked protests today in Brazilian naval and fishing circles.
William McChesney Martin Jr., who at last report was sunning himself on a private island in the Bahamas, probably could not have cared less.

Miss Bernadette Castro and David F. Austin plan to be married on Feb. 10 at the Surf Club in Miami. Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Castro of New York and Fort Lauderdale and Ocala, Fla., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred L. Austin of Fort Lauderdale.
In a change of policy, the city personnel director has bean approving jobs for parolees, unwed mothers and homosexuals for the last year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 6 The Damascus radio reported today a new shooting incident on the Syrian-Israeli border. Quoting a Syrian military spokesman, the broadcast said Israelis had opened fire on Syrian farmers just north of the point where the Jordan River joins the Sea of Galilee.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 (AP) Eleven record-holders headline the San Francisco AllAmerican meet, which opens the nation's indoor track and field season tomorrow night.
Wall Street's bond men left their offices yesterday pretty well pleased with this week's new-issue sales and optimistic about doing as well next week with another big batch of securities offerings.

MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (Canadian Press) Seven shop-craft unions representing about 25,000 workers across Canada have turned down a tentative agreement with the nation's railways worked out during three months of negotiations by a Federal mediator, H. Carl Goldenberg.

PEKING, Jan. 6 Yard-high posters placed today at Peking's Gate of Heavenly Peace denounced Premier Chou En-lai, who had been considered a supporter of the purge led by Chairman Mao Tse-lung and Defense Minister Lin Piao.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Leading Democratic liberals in the House promised a determined fight today against the promotion of an anti-Administration Southerner to the chairmanship of the House Rules Committee.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Navy disclosed that a Navy P5 Marlin patrol plane carrying 10 men crashed at sea during a routine flight today off the Philippines, killing all aboard.
NEWARK, Jan. 6-One of New Jersey's top air-pollution inspectors today called Jersey City the most flagrant violator of the state's air-pollution laws.
DETROIT, Jan. 6 (UPI)-- The nation's auto industry turned out 25 per cent fewer passenger cars this week than it did a year ago, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

It is a small island separated by a shallow stretch of water from the "elbow" of Cape Cod. Dependent upon the rough mercies of the Atlantic and the restless probing of the sea wind, it varies in width from a few hundred yards to a mile.
Secretary General Thant's proposals to end the war in Vietnam were endorsed yesterday by the World Union for Progressive Judaism, which represents 750 reform synagogues in 25 countries.

Mack Trucks, Inc., an Allentown, Pa., manufacturer of trucks, buses and firefighting equipment, announced yesterday that it earned an estimated $13-million, equal to $4 to $4.24 a share, in 1966. This compares with $7,861,000, equal to $2.50 a share, in 1965 before accelerated amortization of deferred costs of $3,558,000.
Continued strength of the Canadian dollar was the main feature in relatively quiet dealings on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, January 6 (AP) President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey were among those paying tribute to Albert M. Greenfield, the financier and real-estate man, who died here yesterday at the age of 79.

By now a good many of us will have listened to solemn groups of correspondents telling us on the small screen what last year meant and what this year will bring. It will probably occur to few to wonder why they have always with single exceptions been men.

Tom Rush gave his first New York concert last night at Town Hall, and the young singer-guitarist proved highly adept at all manner of musical hybrids. He sang folk rock, pop folk, rhythm and blues, rockabilly, country and western, Elvis cum Nashville and sundry other styles less readily classifiable, infusing them all with personal meaning, and giving the program a far greater sense of unity than it had any right to have.

The Brazilian press bill has not only aroused dismay and antagonism in Brazil, but has led to strong protests from the International Press Institute in Geneva and the Inter-American Press Association. These two institutions cover the world press in general and Latin America in particular.
LONDON, Jan. 6 Prime Minister Wilson reshuffled his Government tonight to bring in some younger men and to switch the jobs of many junior ministers.
TOKYO, Jan. 6 (AP) Chairman Mao has conceded that he was partly to blame for elevating his current antagonists to high party positions, according to wall posters appearing in Pekine today.

MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 6 (Reuters) The Lesotho Government released King Moshoeshoe II from protective custody today and may allow him to leave the country to study political science at the University of Toronto.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 The General Motors Corporation announced tonight that it would seek recovery of more than 269,000 of its 1967-model automobiles because of a steering defect found in eight of the cars.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) George Sanders, the actor, who says he has nearly $1million in debts, told a Federal bankruptcy referee today that he receives no money from his old movies now showing on television.
BOWIE, Md., Jan.6 (UPI) Tulmar, dropping back to second after taking the early lead, rallied in the stretch and won the $5,500 Open Range Purse by a length today at Bowie.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 6 (AP) The chief of Nigeria's central Government said last night that the break-up of Africa's most populous nation had been averted by the agreement he reached at meetings in Ghana with Nigeria's four regional governors.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 66 The touchy relations between James A. Hoffa and a top teamster union vice president appear to have been further damaged by a St. Louis teamster newspaper editorial.
A TEST of maturity confronts the New York Knickerbockers in the threeweek period that begins tonight, when they play the Baltimore Bullets in their last Madison Square Garden home game until Jan. 24.
WHEN an ambulance siren sounded on the crowded streets of the Lower East Side 50 years ago, Morris Irving Eisenstein would begin to run toward the sound.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 103.3 on Thursday from 103.2 on Wednesday.
THE RANKS of the nondiversified municipal bond houses have been thinning steadily lately, reflecting such factors as inventory losses taken by bond dealers and the high level of interest rates.

Television's neglected minority the American child appears at last to be getting some attention from the three networks. Whether it is even half enough to satisfy TV's critics among educators and child psychologists is doubtful.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers overcame an 18-point thirdperiod deficit to defeat the Baltimore Bullets, 121-115, in overtime tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

The Rev. Mother Ruth, founder and headmistress of the only Episcopal co-educational day school in the city, showed off a new building yesterday and pointed out that no long-haired boys were welcome there.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., specialists in space, communications and electronics, has obtained controlling interest in Wilson Co., the nation's third largest meat processor, at a cost exceeding $80-million.
For the first time in its seven-year history of deep-draft navigation, cargo traffic on the St. Lawrence Seaway has exceeded traffic estimates made before it opened in 1959.

MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (UPI) Coach Hector (Toe) Blake of the Montreal Canadiens was fined $200 today for his "intolerable" actions at a game last Sunday in which he "used abusive language in a loud voice" to Referee Vern Buffey.

Negotiators for The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Guild continued bargaining sessions yesterday in an effort to reach a contract settlement and avert a nationwide strike threatened for tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 (AP) A leading jockey at the Fair Grounds track suffered serious facial injuries today when he was kicked by a horse during an early-morning workout.
At Lincoln Center today: "Fledermaus," 2 P.M., "Lohengrin," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) Dr. Karl M. Houser, a specialist in ear, nose and throat ailments, died yesterday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Wynnewood, Pa.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 35.7 per cent in production for the week ended Dec. 31, compared with the level of the corresponding week a year ago.

A "Gourmet Galaxy" with five stars will begin Jan. 17 at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park. Five chefteachers will demonstrate their art on consecutive Tuesday mornings to raise funds for Irvington House, for children with rheumatic diseases.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) A mouse that is no larger than a man's thumb, has been fitted with pea-size radio transmitter and is being groomed for possible future space journeys.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 6 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that negotiations to end the Vietnamese war were "getting closer every day." He made the statement to newsmen at Tansonnhut Airport, where he was bidding farewell to Bui Diem, his closest political adviser, who left for the United States to replace Vu Van Thai as ambassador.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Charles Chaplin called the film critics who did not like "A Countess From Hong Kong," his latest movie, "bloody idiots" today.

State Supreme Court Justice James A. Roe Jr., his father, wife and sister were named yesterday with five other persons in a $2-million suit brought by the parents of a 16-year-old girl who was killed by a hitand-run driver.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Defense Department announced today that it was planning larger atomic explosions in underground caverns to determine the feasibility of concealing nuclear tests.
ATLANTA, Jan. 6 The Georgia Supreme Court ruled today that the state legislature had the "power and the right" to choose Georgia's next Governor.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Jan. 6--Thanat Khoman, Foreign Minister of Thailand, said yesterday that his government's decision to commit combat troops to the war in Vietnam was not an escalation of the conflict but a measure to safeguard Thailand, which has received repeated threats from the Communists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee suggested today that Congress may scuttle President Johnson's model cities and rent supplement programs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Government announced today that the stockpiles of 77 scarce or imported materials considered high enough to meet the needs of conventional war were high enough for a nuclear war, too. There was one exception opium.
The stock market closed out the first trading week of the new year yesterday with its fourth consecutive daily gain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Johnson Administration let it be known tonight that it did not see any heightened prospects for peace negotiations on the basis of recent declarations by North Vietnamese spokesmen.
CONISTON, England, Jan. 6 (UPI) A Royal Navy diving team probed the bottom of chilly Coniston Water foot by foot today in a search for the body of Donald Campbell.
Whatever else Peter Weiss hoped to achieve with his "Marat/de Sade," he surely never expected it to become a potential image-changer.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. George Hastings Chittenden have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carey Panet Chittenden, to Michael Gray Curtis, son of Prof. and Mrs. W.Edgar Curtis of Berlin, N.Y.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 East Germany has served notice on the three Western Allies and in West Germany that it intends to break up the postal unity of Germany preserved under fourfour-power occupation arrangements, officials declared today.
GAAR, the Lower Yafa Sultanate, Jan. 6 The Government of this tiny Arab state on the Gulf of Aden has devised a novel method for coping with the narcotics problem in its four towns.
PARIS, Jan. 6 A stiff prison sentence imposed on a French truck driver in Yugoslavia has brought the threat of an international boycott.
NEW SHREWSBURY, N.J., Jan. 6 A 12-man team of Federal and state investigators sought clues today to the cause of yesterday's crash of an airtaxi plane. All nine aboard perished.
A "topless" houseboat caused a stir at the Coliseum yesterday, but only among the workmen who had to squeeze the 32-foot craft into its fourth-floor berth for the National Boat Show.
LISBON, Jan. 6 (AP) Portuguese forces killed 243 rebels during an attack on Teixeira de Sousa, Angola, on Christmas day, a military communique announced today.

"Vertical and Horizontal," Lillian Ross's satirical short stories about upper-middle-class Jewish life in New York, will be brought to the screen by Ismail Merchant, the Indian film producer, and James Ivory, the American director.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William J. Bates 3d of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Landis Bates, to Joel Walter Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Johnson of Garden City, L.I.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 6 Two of the lesser developed regions of the world, North Africa and Latin America, are getting increased attention from the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 6 Miss Stephanie Strakosh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Strakosh, was married this afternoon to David James Whitaker, son of Gaylord C. Whitaker of Pittsford and the late Mrs. Elizabeth Qwynne Whitaker.
WHEATFIELD, N.Y., Jan. 7 Vice President Humphrey rose on a cushion of air this morning and sailed over the Niagara River.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, denounced today as "outrageous and unnecessary" the public com plaints of Democratic governors who blamed President Johnson's domestic policies for the party's 1966 election losses.

HO-HO-KUS, N.J., Jan. 7 The engagement of Miss Catherine Louise Boulton to Keith Lincoln Hughes has been announced by her parents Mr. and Mrs. Charles Vincent Boulton. Mr. Hughes is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Hughes of Bloomfield.

Dr. Robert Langer, who retired as adjunct professor of history and political science at C.W. Post College of Long Island University last June, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 149-22 85th Drive, Jamaica, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) George Preston Marshall Jr. denied today that he was a party to any agreement with his sister concerning the Washington Redskins that include Harry Wismer, a former minority stockholder of the club and the former owner of the New York club in the American Football League.

PABLO CASALS was 90 years old on Dec. 29, as the whole world knows by now, so universal has his birthday celebration been. Columbia adds its own tribute by devoting four January classical releases to the cellist-conductor-composer-humanitarian who is a legend while still alive.
HONOLULU, Jan, 7 Coach Allie Sherman of the New York Giants came here to see two quarterbacks Steve Spurrier of Florida and Bob Griese of Purdue in action last night and he got an eyeful.

GATLINBURG, Tenn., Jan. 7 Great Smoky Mountains National Park, which has figured in a national controversy over whether another highway should be built across it, had 6,466,000 visitations in 1966, according to Superintendant George W. Fry.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 H. A. Shepard, president of TRW, Inc., producer of components and systems for the aerospace, electronics and automotive industries, announced yesterday that the company had donated its $2-million research facility at Roanoke, Va., to the Virginia Polytechnical Institute.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 7 Four African countries have expressed a "serious preoccupation" over Brazil's policy toward Portuguese territories in Africa.

BEGINNING March 13, an unregistered dog that is from a registered litter or an imported dog with an acceptable pedigree can be entered in an unlimited number of shows during a 30-day period instead of only three shows before being registered as at present.

PULLMAN Wash., Jan. 7 (AP) Lew Alcindor gut into foul trouble and No. 1-ranked University of California, Los Angeles, had some anxious moments today, but the Bruins survived and posted a 76-67 basketball victory over Washington State. It was the Bruins' ninth straight triumph.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 7 South Korea hopes to earn $200-million this year from Vietnam through exports of general commodities, supplies of military goods, construction and other service contracts, and civilian workers for American contractors.

Three sales will be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. They will offer Spanish colonial and later European and American paintings; English and French furniture, works of art and decorations, and, on Tuesday, English, American and Continental literature.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Jan. 7 The First Congregational Church of Chappaqua was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mary Katherine Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Mitchell, to Lieut. (jg.) Roger H. Brown, U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Brown of Orland Park, Ill.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 7 (AP) Some United States track coaches expressed concern today over high altitude training procedures in preparing athletes for the 1968 Olympic Games at Mexico City.
Nigeria's crisis is far from over, but the drift toward dissolution and regional war has been arrested by the dramatic confrontations of regional military chiefs in Ghana.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 7 Wasfi al-Tall, Premier of Jordan, charged today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic had made a "gentlemen's agreement" in 1956 with David Ben-Gurlon, then Israeli Premier, that ended Egypt's "role in the struggle for Palestine."
HARTFORD, Jan. 7 "Never use an obscure word when a simple and familiar one will do."

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 7 (UPI) Torrid, second-half shooting today by Jim Burns and Ron Kozlicki helped the Northwestern Wildcats register a 93-73 victory over Michigan, the defending Big Ten champion.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 7 Gov. Roberto Sanchez Vilella will ask the legislature on Monday to approve a budget of $713-million for the fiscal year 1967-68, a record request intended to maintain the momentum of Puerto Rico's industrial development and achieve new levels of social progress.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 7--A "nose-to-nose confrontation" between California's new Republican Governor, Ronald Reagan, and the barely Democratic-controlled Legislature was accepted on both sides this Weekend as inevitable.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 7 (Reuters) The Rhodesian Government today denied British suggestions that mail coming into the country was censored.
A million-dollar center on job training and development is being established here through the combined efforts of a labormanagement group.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 7 A misty rain and rising temperatures failed to stop Roger Dion, a former soldier from Lebanon, N.H., as the skijumping season opened at the Palisades Interstate Park's 50meter hill today.

IN the course of years of shameless television viewing, I have indulged myself in a variety of fantasies about the medium, some of which probably indicate that my grip on reality isn't what at should be. (However, I still think it will be some time before I show up in the Tournament of Roses Parade.)

LONDON Records has entered the burgeoning low-price reissue field with its new label called "Stereo Treasury Series." It follows the precedent established by Nonesuch several years ago by offering disks at $2.49 list price, but a new trend in budget lines is established since the Treasury Series will be issued in stereo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) Two private American citizens have gone to Hanoi to invite a number of North Vietnamese to a meeting in Geneva in May to examine requirements for peace.

HERAKLEION, Crete It takes less than an hour to fly here from Athens. The airport is on the beach, and the introduction to the sea, sand and sun of this outpost, the most important island in the Levant, is an attractive one in fact, more attractive than Herakleion itself.
A 20-room house in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, is being divided into two attached dwellings by a young executive, who still has seven bedrooms for his growing family in the section he occupies.

IN 1939 Karl, a Jew living in D sseldorf with his parents and brother, was forced to flee Gestapo persecution. With the Nazi Occupation of Denmark in 1943, Karl, now 18 and separated from his family, must disappear again. His flight through Denmark to Sweden includes lonely nights under the stars, disguises, escape routes and hiding places arranged by the Resistance.

THE American Horse Shows Association will hold its annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel from Wednesday through Saturday and this year some far-reaching procedural changes will be put into effect.
Capt. Michael Salisbury Stark, a Marine Corps pilot, was killed in a mid-air collision on Friday at the Naval Air Base at Chase Field, in Beeville, Tex. He was 25 years old.

MOSCOW, Jan. 7 (UPI) An American, backed by $22, 222 raised by the people of his hometown, will ask a Leningrad court next week to free him on bail pending appeal of his three-year Soviet prison sentence, it was announced today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 7 (UPI) A dynamite bomb, appatently triggered by a man bent on suicide, ripped open a modern three-story motel in this gambling capital early today, killing six persons and injuring at least 12 others.

The first installment of "The Death of a President" tells of Lee Harvey Oswald drifting into madness, of Mrs. John F. Kennedy timidly rejoining the world of crowds and campaigns after the death of her baby and of her husband's delight and anxiety that she did.

A NUMBER of outstanding books on bridge were published during 1966, but most of them were for the tournament enthusiast. The solitary exception, and the best-seller of the year in its field, was Dorothy Hayden's "Bid Better, Play Better," published by Harper Row.

BELPER, England, Jan. 7 (AP) Foreign Secretary George Brown said today that the "key to peace" in Vietnam rested with Hanoi and appealed again to the Communists to "match the Americans' readiness to talk."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 7 The marriage of Miss Susan Victoria Knotter to Anthony John Walton tools place this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Robert C. Harvey and the Rev. S. Hughes Garvin performed the ceremony.
Paris, Jan. 7 The French Communists met this week for their 18th party Congress. They had a new look.
HUE, South Vietnam, Jan. 7 (Reuters) Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that he was prepared to talk with President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam in a third country if it would bring peace.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP) Steve Cohen of Penn State, the national allround gymnastics champion and two-time Eastern all-round champion, was sidelined indefinitely yesterday because of a knee injury.

The current tight money situation will catch up with J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., the textile industry's second largest producer, in 1968, when capital outlays will be "substantially" reduced from the 1967 and 1966 levels, Robert T. Stevens, president, said in a recent interview.

THE air passage from Europe to Asia these days can be swift, easy and frustrating. Flying over the Mediterranean, the Middle East and the Arabian Sea at 38,000 feet, one spends the hours wondering, "What goes on down there?"

MIAMI, Jan. 7 Top-weighted Davis II captured the $23,050 Orange Bowl Handicap at Tropical Park today before 12,863 fans.

While the paper manufacturing industry, making paper, paperboard, containerboard, kraft and other packaging materials, achieved record sales and earnings last year, there are "some negative prospects," in the view of Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of Scott Paper Company.
The city administration is trying to break a 10-year monopoly a foreign manufacturer has enjoyed in the sale of tires for sanitation trucks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 The first session of the 90th Congress, which opens Tuesday, is expected to generate an unusual amount of conflict but little in the way of innovative legislation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 A liberal Democrat from Arizona said today he would move in a Democratic caucus to deprive Representative Adam Clayton Powell of his House committee chairmanship.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 7 In the 650-mile navigable Tennessee waterway the nation has "a living demonstration that river navigation is a mighty lever in achieving its [the nation's] goals for the future."
Alaska Airlines, Inc., has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to operate a scheduled air service between Nome and Provideniya, Siberia, in the Soviet Union.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 7 The North unleashed a herd of bruis ing backs and accurate passing to defeat the South today in the 18th annual Senior Bowl, 35-13. It was the North's first victory in the post-season game since 1960, and established a clean sweep for Northern elevens in four all-star games this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 Something stranger than beards is happening in American colleges. Professors are being paid more than the football coach.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) Representative Craig Hosmer, Republican of California, said today that the huge atom smasher planned at Weston, Ill., had felt the impact of the Johnson economy ax..
