GENEVA, Jan. 7 A leading expert on the Kennedy Round tariff negotiations predicted today that "the results will be of considerable value" even if the negotiations do not achieve their original goal, a 50 per cent across-the-board reduction in tariffs on hundreds of industrial products.

Tulips flown from the Netherlands, Dutch regional costumes, antique sleds, windmills and Delft tiles will contribute to the atmosphere of Hans Brinker's Holland at the sixth annual Dutch Winterfeest. The skating gala, to be held on the evening of Jan. 24 at Rockefeller Center, will benefit the Child Study Association of America.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Jan. 7 (UPI) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived today to play golf and recuperate in the Southern California desert sun from gall bladder surgery last month. Mrs. Eisenhower is with him.

THE life and work of the Austrian painter Egon Schiele form a chapter in the history of modern art which, though brief, is unforgettable in its combination of irrepressible talent, tortured vision, and personal agony. Schiele was the very embodiment of the artist maudit, and the course traced by his short, electric career in the Vienna of the turn-of-the-century has an almost allegorical quality in its unequal mingling of suffering and accomplishment.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 The Repulican leadership in the Senate is exploring the idea of changing the expense system for legislators so they would receive a daily allowance instead of a lump sum expenses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 A commission of constitutional experts, convened by the American Bar Association, recommended today that the Electoral College system of electing the President be abolished in favor of election by direct, popular nationwide vote.

LUCIANO BERIO is a controversial composer even among the farthest-out composers around. He has strong feeling about many aspects of music including the relationship between the performers and the audience. His "messa in scena," "Passaggio," which has its American premiere at Juilliard tomorrow night, puts in the mouths of apparent members of the audience hostile remarks aimed at a woman, the sole figure on stage.

Retail sales topped the $300-billion mark last year for the first time in history. Consumers bought an estimated $305-billion worth of various and sundry items ranging from notions to automobiles, demonstrating beyond any doubt their ability to purchase and their willingness to spend.

TARPON SPRINGS, Fla. This unusual Gulf Coast resort of 8,000 bills itself alternately as "The Venice of the South," "The City of Island Waterways" and "The Sponge Center of the World," and it has a reasonable claim to all three titles.

United Air Lines expects revenues from its growing cargo operations to exceed $140-million this year, or nearly 50 per cent more than in 1966.

THREE manuals and an album of commercial photographic effects, all recently published by Amphoto, should interest amateur photographers seeking help, ideas and inspiration in several fields of photographic application.

BRASILIA, Jan. 7 President Humberto Castelo Branco has advised congressional leaders that the Government is prepared to accept amendments to a restrictive new press law that has provoked opposition from Brazil's newspapers and broadcasters.

CORNELIA OTIS SKINNER has written the life of Sarah Bernhardt as it must be written, with love and devotion. Even her title, "Madame Sarah," poses this nice problem as it should be posed: Sarah was not "Bernhardt"; she was not Sarah Bernhardt; she was "Madame," like a queen, or "the Great," or "the Divine." She was not an actress, but a Presence, an institution.

The United States Coast Guard, scheduled to become part of the new Department of Transportation, plans no basic change in its primary mission--to serve the nation and the maritime community to the best of its ability--Adm. Willard J. Smith, commandant, said yesterday.

Barking at the gates of the American Kennel Club is a shaggy toy dog from China the Shid Tzu. The pet of the Imperial Court of another age is striving to gain admittance to the A.K.C. stud book. Until he succeeds, he must continue to be shown only in the miscellaneous class and is not eligible to compete for a championship or for best in show.

A FEW years ago it was fashionable to speak of the Indian as "the vanishing American" and with good reason. Today, the situation has changed; with respect to certain tribes it has changed remarkably.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 Practically the entire securities industry appears to be up in arms against a proposed Government regulation that would require securities salesmen to recommend to customers only stocks that are "suitable" to the customer's financial situation.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Terry Collins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Louise Collins, to Lieut, Donald Grayson Pennell, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Edward Pennell of Madison, New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) A man who sought to make Lyndon B. Johnson the President in 1960 reported today that former Vice President John Nance Garner had told him then that Mr. Johnson would not be nominated but would be offered the Vice-Presidential spot and should take it.
PARIS, Jan. 8 Three Algerian exile leaders said today that they had agreed in Casablanca this weekend to work jointly with the courts in finding the murderer of Mohammed Khider.
A threefold or fourfold increase in day-care facilities for children is scheduled to be recommended shortly to the Lindsay administration as a means of cutting its steadily mounting relief load.

WASHINGTON To borrow a hipster's phrase, the problems of urban America made the official scene in 1966. There have been city problems, of course, since cities were built, along with housing and poverty programs to solve them. But never before have the nation's metropolitan areas received such close attention from the Government and public.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 8 Raymond J. Kelly, sports editor of The New York Times from 1937 to 1958, died tonight of a heart attack in his home at 1133 Midland Avenue. He was 68 years, old.

An upturn in business bankruptcies, a continuing slowdown in commercial credit collections and a moderate leveling off in the business growth rate in 1967 were predicted over the weekend by the New York Credit and Financial Management Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) A vastly increased Federal program aimed at stimulating greater rainfall by 1972 was proposed tonight by Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall. The emphasis of such a program will be on finding practical methods, Mr. Udall said.

Bear markets mean trouble for anyone who is overextended, and so does tight money. Both elements were very much in evidence last year, and so for some concerns like the Westec Corporation there was double trouble.

Anyone who watched television fairly regularly last year has a good Idea of the aerospace industry's health. There was Cassius Clay demolishing Henry Cooper in London the live television coverage by way of the Telstar satellite, a feat of aerospace science.

Civilian complaints against the police have dropped off sharply since the November referendum, according to the Police Department's new review board. But much latent hostility remains, in the view of civil rights leaders.
Ed Zieminski, an Archbishop's Molloy senior, turned in the third fastest indoor 1,000-yard run for a Catholic high school runner last night at the 102d Engineers Armory.
The merry cry of 1966 still echoes from several agency quarters: "Its the best year we ever had!"

This year's Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition for Conductors begins in Carnegie Hall at 9:30 this morning, when 42 young conductors from 17 countries Start a grueling round of auditions. It will end Jan. 23, when the four first-prize winners conduct the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall.

Following is a list of major collective bargaining agreements terminating in 1967, each covering 1,000 or more workers. These plus other contracts to be renegotiated this year cover a total of 3.1 million workers. The list has been compiled from information prepared by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 Practically the entire securities industry appears to be up in arms against a proposed Government regulation that would require securities salesmen to recommend to customers only stocks that are "suitable" to the customer's financial situation.
Miss Marjorie Rudick, daughter of Mrs. Henry Rudick of the Bronx, and the late Mr. Rudick, was married yesterday to Paul A. Rochlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jospeh Rochlin of New York and Westport, Conn.
Accidents, not labor disputes, provide the largest number of cases handled by the American Arbitration Association.
The world of electronic computation encompasses more than one species.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coleman Bye have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Elizabeth Bye, to Thomas Howard Kean. He is the son of Robert Winthrop Kean, a former Representative from New Jersey, and Mrs. Kean of Livingston, N.J.
HONG KONG, Jan. 8 (Reuters) The North Vietnamese newspaper Nhan Dan refected today a British appeal to Hanoi to reconsider its condemnation of Britain's proposal for peace talks on Vietnam.

Construction projects amounting to $47-million have been completed in the past year under the program of the Mental Hygiene Facilities improvement Fund and the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Jan. 8--Marty de Leyer rode Dutch Mate to the junior jumper championship at the Hollandia Farms horse show today, but did nothing to enhance his chances of winning the Long Island high-score title.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP) Prof. Charles M. Hulten, since 1959 chairman of the department of journalism of the University of California at Berkeley, died Friday at his home. He was 57 years old.
Economic forecasting is in trouble. And because forecasters have failed to provide accurate projections about the course of business activity, the economy is in trouble too.

YONKERS, Jan. 8 An airmail letter goes out each day from Yonkers Raceway, crammed with information on the next night's races. It arrives three days later in Saigon, where three G.I.'s read the contents carefully and make their "mind bets."

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market gave it a good try last year but just missed ending in the plus column. Both markets started 1966 in strong fashion. Most stocks made good advances until late April when selling pressure depressed both markets until midOctober.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy returned to the United States last night with the same privacy that surrounded her two-week vacation with her children on the Caribbean Island of Antigua.
BOSTON Two Harvard Business School students have qualified for a $45,000 Ford Foundation grant to assist Negro businessmen.

Yesterday's sharp new outbreak of shooting on the Israeli-Syrian border is a reminder that the main axis of hostilities for months has been across that frontier and not Jordan, which the Israelis unwisely attacked in November after a terrorist raid.
There is a new rock 'n' roll group in Greenwich Village that bills itself as Dow Jones and the Industrials, but there is more of a link than that between music and finance.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 8 A boarding school where Israeli and American Jewish teen-agers will be able to get a high-school education side by side is to be opened by the Zionist Organization of America, it was announced here today.
As the stock market steadily plummeted last year and interest rates moved upward, hundreds of proposed corporate mergers were torn asunder by the economic tug of war.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 8 Lindsay Hoben, who retired only last week as editor of The Milwaukee Journal and vice president of The Journal Company, died of cancer today. He was 64 years old.

The Zurich Chamber Orchestra, a string ensemble of 25 members including a harpsichordist, opened its third American tour at Carnegie Hall last night, Edmond De Stoutz, who founded the orchestra in 1945, is still its conductor, and he is obviously a good one.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers romped to a 117-108 victory over the Chicago Bulls tonight in a game marked by a fight between Guy Rodgers and Wally Jones.
The builders of machine tools, the machines that make machines, were beset with trouble piled on trouble last year, but they came through with more business in 11 months than they did in all of 1965.
A surprisingly harsh report on the mutual fund business by the Securities and Exchange commission last month set the stage for a Congressional battle in 1967.

PARIS, Jan. 8 France's Communists concluded their 18th party congress today with a strong denunciation of Peking, restrained praise for President de Gaulle and announcement of another new political pact for the coming French elections.

Despite the tight money situation and a continued drop in conventional housing starts, mobile home sales rose about 5 per cent last year from the 1965 level.

The Board of Examiners in the city school system yesterday scorned a recent recommendation that it be abolished and suggested, instead, that it be given a stronger hand.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9--Gov. Ronald Reagan got a chilly response today from University of California officials on his proposal to cut the university's budget and to institute tuition fees.

The plans to make film, sometimes called the art form of the 20th Century, into a full-fledged constituent of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, came closer to realization yesterday with the election of William F. May to the center's board of directors.
Jack J. Bittner, Warren Felix, Joel I. Popper and Peter Schwalbe have been appointed assistant vice presidents of Adams Co. All are specialists with Adams in commercial real estate.

GROSSE POINTE FARMS, Mich., Jan. 9 (AP) Former Gov. G. Mennen Williams and Mrs. Williams have announced the engagement of their daugh- ter, Miss Nancy Quirk Williams Jr., to Theodore Ketterer 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ketterer Jr. of Pittsburgh.

SEATTLE, Jan. 9 (UPI) Lew Alcindor fouled out for the first time this season, but it didn't help the Washington Huskies as the University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team scored its 10th straight victory without a defeat, 83-68, tonight.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9--The Soviet union has moved into the international magazine market with a glossy, tightly edited journal intended to offer competition to Reader's Digest.
Ninety-two constituents of Representative Adam Clayton Powell filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday in an attempt to void an arrest order for Mr. Powell.
Proctor-Silex has redesigned three of its portable appliances so that if a part breaks down it can be removed at home and returned to the manufacturer for replacemont.

A State Supreme Court jury decided yesterday, after two days of deliberation that a 56year-old Park Avenue physician had consented to the artificial insemination of his 35-year-old wife. The 11-1 verdict thereby rejected the doctor's claim that his wife had committed adultery.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 9 (AP) Barry Goldwater, Republican Presidential candidate in 1964, left Taipei today for Hong Kong after a three-day visit.
Wayne Zahn of Atlanta and Bobby Cooper of Fort Worth, won two of professional bowling's most coveted awards yes terday.

Another legal maneuver developed yesterday in the muddled local harness racing picture when the lawyer for one of the three drivers who were denied licenses said he would seek a show-cause writ today against the State Harness Racing Commission.

The old Metropolitan Opera House, which has been facing the wrecker's ball since last May, has been granted a reprieve for at least 24 more hours. The house had been due to face the first steps of demolition at the start of working hours this morning.
The Board of Regents asked the Legislature yesterday to increase the state's total annual support of education by $221.7million.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 9 (AP) Players in the South African amateur tennis championships, which open in March, will be expected to declare money or gifts they receive, a revenue official said today.
LONDON, Jan. 9 "Positive discrimination" in favor of primary schools in Britain's slum areas is recommended in a report published here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Justice Departnicnt said today it had filed suit to invalidate a parish (county) school board election in Louisiana because, it said, local officials discriminated against Negroes in soliciting absentee ballots.

THE American Broadcasting Company belatedly joined the other national television networks last night in offering a half hour of evening news. The expansion from 15 to 30 minutes was not attended by any notable innovation on the premiere but there were some hints of addition that might materialize after the usual shakedown of a new format. Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., a Fullerton, Calif., food producer, has announced the election of Donald C. Power and Louis W. Menk as directors.

HONG KONG, Jan. 9--The prolonged dispute between a Chinese Communist party faction led by Chairman Mao Tse-tung and another faction that includes many important leaders appears to have reached a critical stage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court affirmed today by an 8-0 vote a decision that approved the Missouri Pacific Railroad's bid to acquire stock control of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad.
The American Patrons of the Israel Museum has been organized to obtain funds and works of art for the institution, which opened in Jerusalem in May, 1965.

Doctors at 196 health clinics and child health centers run by the Department of Hospitals announced last night that they would go on strike at 6:30 A.M. tomorrow along with their colleagues affiliated with Harlem Hospital.

The engagement of Miss Tessa Anne Greene to Kenneth S. Robbins, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. S.E. Robbins of Old Greenwich, Conn., has been an- nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. N.D.G. Greene of Maresfield in Sussex, England. A spring wedding is planned.
An 18-year-old youth was arrested yesterday and accused of shooting to death a 61-year-old man in an unsuccessful attempt to steal the purse of the victim's wife.

MONTREAL, Jan. 9 (AP) The Howe brothers of Philadelphia, Ralph, 28 years old, and Sam, 26, dominated the North American squash racquets championships that ended yesterday with the crowning of Ralph as champion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) Richard Helms, head of the Central Intelligence Agency, met today with a Senate watchdog subcommittee whose membership has been broadened to include foreign policy experts.
While most retailers are projecting higher sales for 1967, the year's rate of increase is generally expected to be substantially smaller than in 1966.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The nation's three largest copper producers were hailed and assailed today in the same statement from Gardner Ackley, Ichairman of the President's Council of Ecnnomic Advisers.
The 55th annual appeal on behalf of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund established a record yesterday, bettering last year's total, the previous high, by more than $1,000.
DENVER, Colo., Jan. 9 (AP) The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union announced today additional contract settlements in the oil industry.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 Senator Seymour R, Thaler was abruptly squelched by a Democratic colleague today as he attempted to take the floor to denounce alleged "experimentation on medically indigent hospital patients without their informed consent."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 9 William Benjamin Grafton Kirk, an architectural designer associated with George B. Post, a New York City architect, died Saturday at United Hospital in Port Chester. He was 61 years old and lived here at 19 Senate Place.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Nine of the nation's big-city mayors began a drive today to form a new "urban coalition" to alert the nation to the problems and needs of American cities.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 9 The state legislature left little doubt as it convened today that tomor- row it would elect Lester G. Maddox the next Governor of Georgia.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9 (UPI) The National League batting champion, Matty Alou, signed his 1967 contract with the Pittsburgh Pirates today. The terms were not disclosed in accordance with club policy.

Vladimir Horowitz was curious about the people who stand in line all night just to hear him play the piano, and the standees were curious about Mr. Horowitz when he is not playing the piano, and Sunday afternoon everbody's curiosity was rewarded.
THE Metropolitan Opera National Company performed a miracle in its new production of "The Marriage of Figaro," seen Sunday afternoon at the City Center for the first time in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Four civil rights leaders charged today that the House Un-American Activities Committee was planning to attempt to discredit the civil rights movement. They said this added new urgency to the effort to abolish the committee.
TEL AVIV, Jan, 9 At the request of Anne Frank's father, the Soldiers Theater of the Israeli Army has withdrawn its production of Meyer Levin's vetsion of "The Diary of Anne Frank."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (UPI) The Kansas City Chiefs and the Green Bay Packers were given added impetus today for victory in next Sunday's Super Bowl game when it was announced that the winner would receive the world championship trophy.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Howard Elliott Jr. have announced the engagement of their daugthter, Miss Justine January Elliott, to Charles Theodore Hazzard Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Hazzard of Chappaqua and Georgian Bay, Ont. A summer wedding is planned.
One of four American women who visited North Vietnam recently charged yesterday that the United States was using "barbarous" antipersonnel weapons designed to maim North Vietnamese civilians.

ALBANY. Jan. 9 (AP) Richard C. Mathieu of The New York Daily News was elected president of the Legislative Correspondents Association today. He advanced from first vice president to succeed Charles Dumas of The Associated Press.
HOUSTON, Jan. 9 The basketball champion of the six-college Western Athletic Conference will not be given an automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament this March.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) Richard S. Reynolds 3d announced today that he had consummated an agreement to purchase The Miami Beach Daily Sun.
The State Supreme Court was asked yesterday to enjoin the Legal Aid Society from representing defendants in the New York City criminal courts.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. (AP) Fred Stolle, the Australian Davis Cup star, said yesterday he would sign to play as a professional as soon as his contract came from the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) A painting of a beautiful young girl by Thomas Eakins, the 19th century artist, has been donated to the White House collection by Joseph H. Hirshhorn, philanthropist and art enthusiast, the White House announced today.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Jan. 9 (AP) A heavy snowstorm hit northern Mexico today, almost isolating Monterrey, the country's most important industrial city. It stranded motorists and raised fear for residents of flimsy slum shacks.

Irvington House will gain from five classes in gourmet cooking on consecutive Tuesdays at Tavern-on-the-Green, beginning next week. The instructors will be five directors of cooking schools or private classes, who will teach specialties. Each of them is donating his services.
Drivers for R.E.A. Express stopped work yesterday in a walkout described as illegal by the company.
New York City's 12 public golf courses will remain under city operation during 1967 with the same schedule of greens fees and the same $15 price on season permits instead of being reduced as hoped.

In an assessment of the economic outlook for 1967, published in Monday's editions of The New York Times, a portion of a statement by George Jaszi, director of the Office of Business Economics, Department of Commerce, was inadvertently ommitted.
BONN, Jan. 9 West Germany sent a group of Foreign Ministry officials to Prague today to explore the possibility of establishing diplomatic relations with the Czechoslovak Government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to intervene in a copyright controversy involving a book by John Keats entitled "Howard Hughes, a Biography."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 "I have never seen Adam look so shaken before," a long-time supporter of Representative Adam Clayton Powell said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The Treasury bill rate declined slightly at today's auction but remained in the narrow range set in the last three weeks, the Treasury disclosed, tonight. The average discount rate on 91-day bills was 4,818 per cent, down a little from, 4,822 per cent at the previous auction Dec. 30.
It is always a pleasure to visit Manhattan Festival Ballet, our lively and permanent Off Broadway classic ballet, at its modest yet elegant home at Theater 80 on St. Marks Place.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 9 (UPI) A total of 23,581,760 harness racing fans, a record, wagered almost $1.5-billion in 1966, the United States Trot ting Association reported to day.
Ernest Erkkilla, assistant professor of English at the Baruch School of City College, died of a heart attack at Beckman Downtown Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 310 West 106th Street.

The unbeaten University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team maintained first place and Louisville, also undefeated, held the No.2 position yesterday in the college-rating polls conducted by the Associated Press and United Press International.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 A strike of teachers at Chicago's eight junior colleges was settled early today, permitting resumption of classes disrupted Friday.
Steel production rebounded sharply last week from the level of the Christmas holiday week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester- day.
NEWARK, Jan. 9 (AP) Anthony DeAngelis lost a final appeal in Newark Federal Court House today to have his 20year jail sentence reduced.

BREDASDORP, Cape Province, South Africa, Jan, 9 (Reuters) Francois Christiaan Erasmus, South Africa's Minister of Defense and Minister of Justice at the time of the bloody "shooting at Sharpeville" in 1960, died Saturday night while on holiday near here. He was 70 years old.

THE affinity of the Italian composer for lyric drama was demonstrated in remarkable fashion at the Juilliard School of Music last night. Two short works were staged, one written in 1624, the other in 1962, and both showed the power that good music has to illuminate and heighten a dramatic situation.
The first retrospective film series honoring Ginger Rogers will be presented Jan. 31 through Feb. 12 at the Gallery of Modem Art on Columbus Circle. A second series will be announced later.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 9 The credit race among industrialized countries, competing to sell heavy machinery and other capital goods to the less developed, has vastly inflated the volume of export credits extended to the buyer nations, the United Nations Department of Economic Affairs reported today.

Football, baseball and basketball are riding high as the nation's top sports with equipment sales, not to mention tickets, running in the millions and a rise in interest in soccer and hockey are sending them into the bigmoney class.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The trial of Robert G. Baker got swiftly under way today as the selection of the jury was com- pleted by midafternoon.

The American Textile Manufacturers Institute, Inc., strongly pretested yesterday a recommendation of the Brookings Institution to eliminate by stages a United States cotton textile import arrangement that sets import quotas for 28 countries.
The First National City Bank announced yesterday the appointment of George C. Scott as chairman of its credit policy committee.
Earnings of the Magnavox Company rose by about 50 per cent last year, while sales gained by 36 per cent over the year before, Frank Freimann, president, reported yesterday.
Donald L. Sanders, vice president of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the producer of chemicals and photographic products.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The Supreme Court clamped down today on redistricting plans that allow too much deviation in population between various legislative and Congressional districts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) President Johnson appointed a 15-member commission today to work out plans to develop the resources of the oceans.
Picking up where it left off last Friday, the stock market registered another broad-based advance yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay's proposal for a new $16-million subsidy to the Transit Authority to enable it to hold the line on the twenty-cent fare through 1967 must be viewed in the light of Governor Rockefeller's constructive program for metropolitan transportation unification.
The Pan American Sulphur Company announced yesterday that it had been permitted nearly to double its sulphur exports from Mexico in the first quarter of this year.

PANAMA, Jan. 9 This was a day of mourning here. It was the third anniversary of the start of bloody rioting by Panamanians against the Canal Zone that resulted in the death of 21 Panamanians and 4 United States citizens, scores of wounded and great property damage from Jan. 9 to 12, 1964.
The Export-Import Bank is planning to sell between $400million and $500-millien of participation certificates early in February.

Inflation still has a lot of sting in Brazil. Government policies to stem inflation worked well in 1965, even though the rise in the price index was 45.4 per cent. That was just over half of the 86 per cent increase registered in 1964. But last year there was only a small improvement and the price index increased by 41.1 per cent.
State Controller Arthur Levitt has asked the Federal Government to investigate the prices of three vital tranquilizing drugs that are used extensively in the state's mental institutions.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 The legislative lobby of New York City has a new leader, new quarters and an old purpose: to try to convince conservative upstate lawmakers that giving financial aid to the city is not the same as erecting a memorial to Boss Tweed.

Seen at a leisurely buffet luncheon in the lounge of the Federation of Jewish Philan thropies headquarters, there is nothing remarkable about them. They could be almost any casual assemblage of intelligent young people eating and chatting ami ably together. They are com posed and assured.

KINGSTON, N.Y. Jan. 9 Ulster County Welfare Commissioner Joseph Fitzsimmons obtained a week's delay in the ease involving a blond, blueeyed child whose brunet ItalianAmerican foster parents seek to adopt her.

Fifteen thousand dollars worth of advertising and a million in publicity is one way of summing up the 1st International Paper Airplane Competition being staged by Scientific Amcriean magazine. Now they're after their second million.
LONDON, Jan. 9 Chinese Communist diplomats are on their way home from at least a dozen foreign capitals in what is evidently a reflection of the political turmoil in China.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Jan 9 Mrs. Talcott Slater has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Shirley Slater to John Marshall Crosman Jr. son of Mr. Crosman of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Mrs. Adelaide Pyle Crosman.

"It was a nothing day," a copper broker said, meaning there was little to add about copper futures that hadn't been said a week ago. The tension continued about the same between the Congo Government and Union Miniere du Haut Hatanga, the big Belgian-dominated producer in Africa.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 9 Waldo Frank, the writer, died today at the Miller Nursing home. Mr. Franz, Who had been ill for some time, was 77 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 9 Five leading labor-management experts spoke out today against any severe new legislation to cope with strikes affecting the national interest.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 9 (UPI) Coach Vince Lombardi said today that his Green Bay Packers and the Kansas City Chiefs would be confronted with the same problem of unfamiliarity with their opponents when they meet in the Super Bowl football game Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The Supreme Court extended the constitutional guarantees of freedom of the press today to invasion-of-privacy cases.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Representative Adam Clayton Powell asked the United States Supreme Court today to block authorities in New York at least temporarily from arresting him in the state as long as he sits as a Congressman.
President Johnson's State of the Union message will be carried live tonight at 9:30 o'clock on radio and television.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 9 (UPI) Joe Russell scored 21 points and played standout defense tonight as Niagara University fought off a late Villanova rally for a 68-65 upset triumph.

HOUSTON, Jan. 9 The American Football Coaches Association expressed pleasure today with the current college unlimited substitution rule, which has been in force for two years. At the same time, the coaches voiced displeasure with television time-outs called while a team was making a drive.

MADRID, Jan. 9 Algeria to day protested the 13-hour de tention by the Spanish secret police yesterday of an Algerian diplomat in connection with the Mohammed Khider a leader of the Algerian opposition.
SALEM, Ore., Jan. 9 Mark O. Hatfield said farewell today to a joint session of the Oregon Legislature, passed his mantle to a fellow Republican and flew East to begin a new career in the Senate.

The General Electric Company has taken a major step aimed at coordinating its computer operations under one executive. J. Stanford Smith, vice president for marketing and public relations, was named to head G.E.'s worldwide dataprocessing business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy testified today that a horse she took from the farm of a Washington breeder who is suing her for $30,000 was the "saddest sight I ever saw in my life: starving, just a bag of bones."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 State Department officials believe that Communist China's cultural revolution is encountering widespread resistance from local party leaders, but they doubt that the nation is on the verge of civil war.
The wholesale commodity price index remained unchanged on Friday from its Thursday level of 103.3.

The Federal Government declared yesterday that sulphur dioxide air pollution in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area was "the worst, the most critical, in the United States" and endangered health and welfare.

Hyman Filtzer, a sculptor, who retired a year ago as senior restorer of sculpture for the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died Sunday night in the Williamsbridge Manor Nursing Home, the Bronx. He was 65 years old and lived at 1639 Fulton Avenue, the Bronx.

The Baroque Room of the Plaza will be the setting Jan. 20 for the annual Maple Leaf Dinner Dance, sponsored by the Canadian Women's Club of New York, for the benefit of the Lighthouse Nursery School for Blind Children in New York and for general activities of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--A Special report to President Johnson by the Agency for International Development said today that "no more than 5 to 6 percent of all economic assistance commodities delivered to Vietnam were stolen or otherwise diverted" last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The authority of the police to stop and search persons on the street will come under close scrutiny in the Supreme Court later this year.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 9 In this county, where the bucolic scenes of yesteryear are being restricted to ever-diminishing pockets on the North Shore, the baa of sheep became a cause celebre in the village of Mill Neck recently.
The New York Chapter of the Interracial Council for Business yesterday elected R. Peter Straus and Lyle A. Marshall co-chairman.

Two steamship lines yester- day announced executive appointments in the container shipping field.

In preparing his message on the State of the Union, President Johnson found himself and his Administration in what James Russell Lowell once described as "that most unprofitable of predicaments, a state of transition."

Bolstered by the highest first-hour trading on record, volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday soared to 13.23 million shares, the third highest turnover in the history of the exchange.

Walt Disney Productions has increased its revenues and earnings to record levels for the sixth successive year, Roy O. Disney, president and chairman, reported yesterday.
Tom M. Arnold, a retired newspaper editor, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Dublin, Ga., after a short illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Kennesaw, Ga.

THE New York Stock Exchange revealed yesterday in a newsletter to its members that activity under its revised Rule 394 averaged less than one trade a day in the final two months of 1966, two months of 1966.

A study made public early this week asked the city to open three or four times as many day-care centers as it now has, to free mothers on relief to take jobs and thus reduce relief costs.

The victory enabled the Hawks to share first place with the New York Rangers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)-The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to uphold the constitutionality of a law prohibiting draft-card burning.
Ross Bass, a former United States Senator from Tennessee, was elected yesterday to the board of the MerrittChapman and Scott Corporation, a construction, shipbuilding and industrial finance company.

The stock market took a nose dive in the first half hour of trading yesterday, began to pull out of it before the first hour was over, and then climbed steadily upward to close the day with a strong and broadbased advance.

LONDON, Jan. 12 Britain's trade picture deteriorated in December, the Board of Trade reported today.

TOKYO, Jan. 12 Japanese official observers expect prolonged confusion in Communist China but doubt that either side in the political quarrel can muster sufficient military support for the situation to become a civil war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 A White House aide said it was like playing a giant accordion: a great compression to produce one big sound the State of the Union Message followed immediately by a great pulling apart.

A venerable Long Island Sound yacht club, which two years ago this month faced extinction following a fire, enters the 1967 yachting season with its membership at a high, a new 70-slip marina, and land acreage on Neptune Island in New Rochelle almost tripled in size.
A total of 234 thoroughbred racing days, the maximum allowed by law, was approved by the State Racing Commission at its monthly meeting yesterday.

The Leonard Jerome mansion at the southeast corner of Madison Square and 26th Street, a designated landmark in danger of demolition, may be saved. The Greater New York Section of the Optical Society of America is seeking to purchase the house with contributions from associated professional groups and manufacturers of optical equipment.

HONG KONG, Friday, Jan. 13--Mao Tse-tung and Lin Piao took steps today to insure the army's loyalty to their faction in the bitter power struggle that has plunged Communist China into a political crisis.

Frederick Marvin, the pianist, came to Town Hall last night, and took up where he had left off in his last New York recital 10 years ago giving the American premiere of a Sonata by Padre Antonio Soler. Mr. Marvin has discovered more than 200 sonatas by the 18th-century Spanish monk, and this C Minor Sonata is certainly an attractive find.

The State Liquor Authority revoked the license yesterday of the Shore Club in Sayville, one of two Long Island discotheques that were allegedly operated as fronts for ex-convict Julius F. (Julie) Klein.

Adequate Congressional supervision of the Central Intelligence Agency, long advocated by this newspaper, has been advanced by the surprise inclusion of Chairman Fulbright and two key members of his Foreign Relations Committee in meetings of the Senate panel that watches over the C.I.A.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Revenue freight traffic generated by total carloadings on United States railroads in the New Year's holiday week ended Jan. 7 was below the level of the corresponding 1966 week which did not include a holiday. Intereity truck tonnage during the name period registered an increase.
NORWALK, Conn.--The makers of the Aqua-Cat aren't particularly modest; they like to refer to their product as the Volkswagen of the boat business.

At the start of a year that is expected to bring more strikes than any since 1959, the President in his State of the Union message had no suggestion of any kind to put before Congress on measures to protect the nation from disruption caused by industrial conflict.
The city's 104 departments and agencies have asked Mayor Lindsay for nearly $5.5-billion for operating expenses in the coming fiscal year.

The Federal Government declared yesterday that new state and local laws were necessary to bring sulphur-dioxide in the air below a present healthdanger level in the New YorkNew Jersey metropolitan area.

An unusual no-strike, nolockout labor agreement, providing for the future arbitration of contract terms in the event of a deadlock, was announced yesterday by two of the largest chain restaurant companies here and the union representing their waitresses and kitchen employes.
James J. Nance is stepping down as chairman and chief executive officer of the Central National Bank of Cleveland, the bank announced yesterday. Mr. Nance is 66 years old.
Noted for its fast water-ski tow boats, Correct Craft, Inc., of Orlando, Fla., is showing three inboard runabouts in the show. All are built of fiber glass.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The exemption of low income families and individuals from the special 6 per cent tax surcharge proposed by President Johnson would reduce the Government's collections from that tax by only $90-million a year, the Treasury Department said today.
Nine Penn Yan and Duratech boats are being shown at the Coliseum by Penn Yan Boats, Inc., of Penn Yan, N.Y.
After Wednesday's booming bond market, things became a little quieter in the credit markets yesterday. Everyone stepped back to survey where things stood.

PROBABLY the frankest review of sexual morality ever offered by television was presented last night on the American Broadcasting Company's "Stage '67." The Irving Gitlin production, "Sex in the Sixties," covered the more sensational manifestations of sexual expression and the serious aspects of where today's mores may be leading.

Challenges of figures on air pollution from the United States Public Health Service were made yesterday by some of the scores of corporations accused of emitting large amounts of sulphur dioxide into the air of the metropolitan area.
TORONTO, Jan. 12 The head of Canada's largest bank called today for a positive policy toward foreign-banking operations in Canada.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 A cold air mass from Canada penetrated farther south than usual to cause flooding and snow in some parts of Mexico, the United States Weather Bureau said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Government announced today that it would terminate Federal support for welfare programs in Alabama unless the state gave full and prompt assurance that it would administer those programs without racial discrimination.

An expert on public utilities has charged in a special report to the city that the Consolidated Edison Company, through allegedly improper bookkeeping, turned a million-dollar investment in World's Fair bonds into higher dividends for its stockholders and higher electric rates for its customers.

The appointments of Ramon de Murias and Louis J. Garcia as vice presidents of Braniff International were announced yesterday by Hard ing L. Lawrence, president of the airline. Both executives have been assigned to the airline's new headquarters here.

Radio station WCBS, which postponed a discussion of the book "The Passover Plot" because of a protest by a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, has rescheduled the program for Sunday, Feb. 5, from 8 to 10 P.M.

GENEVA, Jan. 12 Although President Johnson's decision to reduce tariff duties on Swiss watches by about onethird was acclaimed today by Government officials here and by the Swiss Watchmakers Federation, it is unlikely to produce any major savings for the American consumer.
Fordham's basketball team defeated Columbia, 56-52, in a somewhat tumultuous finish before about 2,000 spectators last night at the Columbia gym.

Three gunmen held up two employes of Sardi's West restaurant yesterday and robbed them of $1,100, which they were taking to the executive office of the restaurant on the fourth floor of 234 West 44th Street.
The Merritt - Chapman Scott Corporation has backed away, perhaps permanently, from a tender offer approved by directors last October.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 15 (AP)--A Congressional investigation of President Sukarno's activities at the time of the attempted Communist coup in 1965 was announced today. It aomunted to the sharpest move to date against Mr. Sukarno, still President but deprived of most of his power.
MIAMI, Jan. 12 (UPI) A fishing boat captain involved in a gun battle over a lobster fishing grounds was charged today with murder on the high seas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) The Administration asked Congress today to raise the national debt ceiling, possibly by $8-billion. The present legal ceiling of $330-billion may be reached by the end of next month.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. It is almost impossible to own a boat without gaining some skill as a painter but Jack Gray, a marine artist from Nova Scotia, is so handy with his brush that he employs it to support his idyllic life aboard a 47foot Matthews sport fisherman.
AN oarsman on an ancient galley made himself im- mortal by his plan to leave the sea when his hitch was up.

When the last boat has been shoved into place before the opening of the big show at the Coliseum, Joe Choate and Pete Wilson shake hands, join in a silent prayer and await the onrush of about 400,000 people.

Canoe sales have been on the rise for several years, thanks, in part, to built-in versatility. A canoe offers a full range of fun for the family or the outdoorsman. It's good for camping, exploring or just plain loafing.

The brightest spot in an otherwise dull commodity market yesterday proved to be pork-belly futures, in which volume moved at the brisk pace of 4,092 contracts. Prices ranged upwards from 15 to 63 points.
When a motorist needs' navigational help, he consults a road map. Boating has no road maps, but it does offer a substitute: nautical charts.

LONDON, Jan. 12 Consolidation of the six existing unions into one representing the entire printing industry in Britain was strongly urged here today as a means of helping overcome the problems posed by rapid technological advances.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Blair Blaikie of Port Washington and Nassau Point have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Blaikie, to George Franklin Fisher 3d of the Navy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fisher Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New Suffolk. A spring wedding is planned.

The Supreme Court has enlarged the freedom of Americans to travel abroad by rejecting the punishment as criminals of persons with valid passports who visit Communist countries in defiance of a State Department travel ban. But it has not enlarged that freedom very much. This week's unanimous decision in effect makes one trip possible, but no more.

Ask a landlubber if he's going to the boat show and he's apt to reply, "Boat show? What do they have there?" Some people just aren't with it. Yet when the 57th National Boat Show opens oops, weighs anchor for its nine-day public cruise tomorrow at the Coliseum, customers who know what is normally there will be asking only a slightly different question: "What do they have there this year?"
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 Latin-American diplomats have achieved a breakthrough in efforts to complete a treaty banning nuclear weapons from their countries.

Insurance companies, like boatmen themselves, are recognizing that the average owner of a recreational craft does not want to be bound by policies that limit the active season to six months, plus six months of dry storage. As a result, the insurance policy that provided inwater coverage for six months only (May 1 through Oct. 31) has become rare.

The Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, paid tribute yesterday to a forceful little nun who took a crowded classroom 16 years ago and built it into a $4.6-million institution.
The Right Rev. James A. Pike, the resigned Episcopal Bishop of California, agreed yesterday to a temporary postponement of a hearing on heresy charges against him.

LAST August, at a rally in Peking celebrating Com- munist China's "cultural revolution," an unfamiliar woman stepped to a microphone to introduce Defense Minister Lin Piao as Mao Tse-tung's second in command, and thus his heir apparent. The woman, who had not previously played

SHEFFIELD, Ala., Jan. 12 The Rev. Brice Joyce, a Roman Catholic priest and civil rights activist, has been told he can no longer hold any pastorate in the Mobile-Birmingham diocese, sources within the diocese said today.
BERLIN, Jan. 12 In a surprise move, East Germany announced today that it would continue operation of the special passes office in West Berlin through March.

The engagement of Miss Stephanie Anne Morhard to Lieut. Stephen Charles Rinehart, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rinehart of Cheyenne, Wyo., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph William Morhard of Riverdale, the Bronx. Plans have been made for a wedding in the spring.

The state's highest court has struck down a last-ditch plea to save the old Metropolitan Opera House from the wreckers, but its decision has served to redouble efforts to rescue the 83-year-old building by other means.
Walter Kidde Co., Inc., in a diversification move, announced yesterday that it plans to acquire Lighting Corporation of America for stock worth about $54-million.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 12 (Reuters) Five members of Bertrand Russell's unofficial Vietnam "war crimes tribunal" arrived here today from Paris for a 10-day visit to Cambodia.
TOKYO, Jan. 12 Emperor Hirohito listened today to ceremonial readings of the 15 best of 43,000 poems on the subject of fish that were sent to him last year.
An 18-acre boating center that will be accessible only by water is to be built on an island in the Intra-Coastal Waterway at North Palm Beach, Fla.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Why did the House choose this point in Adam Clayton Powell's career to discipline him? Members of the House now are giving some illuminating answers to that question.
The annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association ended here yesterday on a sober note similar to the one with which it began five days earlier.
The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association outlined yesterday its first campaign to help newspapers sell themselves as an ad medium.
YONKERS, Jan. 12 Seven per cent of all the trotters at Yonkers Raceway competed tonight in the feature race. It was a small field.
In Japan, where gamblers can bet their hard-earned yen on powerboats, they're still talking about the skin diver who fixed a boat race.
"I think President Johnson's State of the Union Message will help the market. I'm bargain hunting and intend getting some of the recently depressed issues with good earning prospects."
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12 Russell Lee Dearmont, former president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, died today in a nursing home here. He was 75 years old.

The sailing enthusiast, who likes just to be on the water and look at it, and the one who prefers to use the sea as an arena for competition, can while away the time till spring with two new major books of contrasting moods and writing styles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) A bill to set a second moratorium on construction of hydroelectric power dams in the Grand Canyon area was introduced today.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 12 Paul Hornung, the Golden Boy with the pinched nerve and the numbing arm, remained the enigma of the Green Bay Packers today as they came 24 hours closer to Sunday's Super Bowl game against the Kansas City Chiefs in the Los Angeles Coliseum.
"It is a plain fact of life that serious consideration must be given to an increase in freight rates," Louis W. Menk, president of the Northern Pacific Railroad, said here yesterday.

At Lincoln Center: New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15 P.M.; Gabriel Banat, violinist, Library and Museum, 6:30; "La Boh me," Metropolitan Opera, (Beverly Bower will replace Mary Costa as Musetta).
The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held yesterday that a grand jury foreman has authority to order the return of a witness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 President Johnson said so many controversial things in his State of the Union message about Vietnam, taxes, poverty and foreign aid, that the central unifying theme of his address is in danger of being lost.
Mice stalked the Night Mayor at City Hall for the second night in a row last night.
A drive around any neighborhood with a preponderance of boat owners at this time of year will disclose numerous powerboats coccooned for the winter.

THE history of a century's literature of imaginative disaster--which would include fantasy, horror stories, science fiction, chronicles of future wars and predictions of things to come, fiction and nonfiction--is also the history of progressive disillusionment.
Volunteers will begin working in the Department of Air Pollution Control Monday night, to free department inspectors for cruising duty on the streets at night and on Saturday.
Two fiber-glass motor yachts (41 and 44 feet in length) are being displayed at the show by the Hatteras Yacht Company of High Point, N.C.
Francis Day Rogers, a trustee of the Marine Historical Association since April, 1939, and a vice president since January, 1961, has been elected president of the association.
A record budget of slightly more than $379-million was adopted yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) Gen. Holland M. (Howlin' Mad) Smith, commander of the marine forces in the Pacific during part of World War II and leader of the assault on Iwo Jima, died today. He was 84 years old.

HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 12 (UPI) Rain upset the schedule at the Tasmanian lawn tennis championships today and only one men's singles quarter-final match was completed before play was called for the day.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 Operation Cedar Falls, the largest allied offensive of the war, took on today the plodding, unspectacular characteristics that some American military officers predicted for it from the outset.

Red and pink roses on columns, walls and tables made it clear that last night's event in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom was the Ball of Roses, the 14th annual party benefiting Roosevelt Hospital. Proceeds went to the free medical care fund.
Profit taking in late trading left prices mixed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
The Environmental Science Services Administration, the new Commerce Department agency with the hard-to-pronounce name, is using a shorter slogan for its exhibit at the boat show:

An association of staff physicians at the city's hospitals charged yesterday that State Senator Seymour R. Thaler was employing "smear and scare tactics" in his sweeping indictment of medical practices in the municipal institutions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) President Johnson announced today allocation of $135-million in Federal funds to promote and develop "innovative educational programs" in elementary and secondary schools.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan 12 If the Kansas City Chiefs upset the Green Bay Packers in the Super Bowl Sunday, they are likely to achieve their surprise without surprises.

LONDON, Jan. 12 Reginald Maudling, asserting that the American concept of an Atlantic alliance was "in some ways too rigid," said today that the alliance should "develop in a form which would recognize the new strength of Europe."

One of the oldest stock builders of wood yachts is displaying a flying bridge, flush-deck cruiser at the Coliseum. The Matthews Company of Clinton, Ohio, has the 45-foot Wanderer on exihbit, powered by a pair of 238-horsepower General Motors diesels. The yacht is priced at $73,850.
A jury of 11 men and a woman began deliberating late yesterday in the trial of State Senator Eugene Rodriguez, charged with three counts of attempted grand larceny and 21 of perjury.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 12 (UPI) Cassius Clay suffered another setback today when his draft board refused to consider his request for an exemption as a Black Muslim minister

Leonard Bernstein had just finished conducting a new recording of Mendelssohn's "Reformation" Symphony for Columbia Records, and he invited me to sit with him in the control room backstage at Philharmonic Hall to listen to the playback. He insisted on hearing the exquisite little andante
SECTIONAL tournaments throughout the United States almost always follow a familiar pattern: a permutation of pair contests combined with an open team event scored on a board-amatch basis.

Hospitals Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio was bitterly assailed yesterday in an often unruly four-hour public hearing before the Board of Estimate. He was jeered when he said the closing of St. Francis Hospital in the southeast Bronx had resulted in no medical emergencies.
Two equipment manufacturers and a government agency have displays in the Canadian exhibit at the boat show.

A major function of the Tongue Point Job Corps Center at Astoria, Ore. is the training of young men as servicemen for marinas and yacht yards in the recreational boating industry. This is the only Job Corps center in the nation that has a boating serviceman's course.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Murphy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Elizabeth Murphy, to Matthew T. Murray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray of New York and Lawrence, L.I.
Six versions of three familiar fiber-glass sailboats are being presented at the show by Alcort, Inc., of Waterbury, Conn.
Last year, a man with five sons old enough to know the difference between reality and dreams swore he would never go back to the National Boat Show.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 (UPI) Marine Corps courts-martial have convicted two more marines in the slayings and alleged mutilation of two South Vietnamese villagers during a patrol Sept. 22 near Chulai, it was disclosed Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) Conservatives served notice in Congress today that they would seek reversal of the current policy that supports economic sanctions against Rhodesia.

Democratic delegates to the State Constitutional Convention yesterday elected a 25member steering committee to make party preparations for the convention. Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia was named chairman.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 12 The $4.5-million golf tour, the richest the sport has known, opened today, but not according to form.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has endorsed the view that the tar and nicotine content of cigarettes should be listed on their packages and in advertising.

Two officers of the Sanitation Department's confidential squad assigned to investigate alleged bribery at the East 91st Street Marine Transfer Station have been dismissed on charges that they had joined the bribery ring.

IN a handsome, four-story town house in the East 70's that has just been newly furnished, almost everything looks old, well-worn, seasoned, sometimes even downright shabby. Nothing could be more pleasing to its owners, who moved in only a few weeks ago.

Sales of new cars fell sharply in the first 10 days of 1967, auto makers reported yesterday from Detroit. The nation's three largest car manufacturers all listed consider ably lower sales for the Jan. 1-10 period than in the recordsetting 10 days of a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The State Department told the Soviet Embassy here today that continuing distribution of the new Soviet magazine Sputnik in the United States would depend on Soviet permission for American publications, such as Reader's Digest and The New York Times, to circulate freely in the Soviet Union.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 12 Albert DeSalvo, who says he is the "Boston strangler," heard himself described by his own lawyer today as as an "uncontrollable human vegetable" who during a period of 18 months "committed 13 acts of homicide."
A close kinship exists between boating enthusiasts and recreational-vehicle owners, according to a leading boating official.
Bishop Holt was a pioneer in the movement for Protestant unity.
Members of the Social Services Employes Union voted overwhelmingly last night to strike on Monday against the Department of Welfare.

GAZZADA, Italy, Jan. 12--Representatives of the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches announced here today that they had "taken the first steps toward restoring full unity," broken 400 years ago by schism.
FREEPORT, L.I. The Town of Hempstead is planning a $1-million marina here to plug the gap in public boating facilities between New York City and Bay Shore on Long Island's South Shore.

Seven years ago Gladys Stein gave a recital devoted to Schubert's three posthumous piano sonatas that was much admired. Last night in Carnegie Hall she played more Schubert the eight Impromptus, which made up the first half of the program. For the second half there were Mozart's A minor Sonata (K. 310) and Beethoven's C minor Sonata (Op. 111).
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 12 A 20-year-old former mental patient today admitted starting a fire on Wednesday in St. Joseph's School for the Blind, where she is assigned as a cando helper.

SEATTLE, Jan. 12 (AP) The National Basketball Association awarded the new Seattle franchise today to Eugene V. Klein and Samuel Schulman of Los Angeles. They are the principal owners of the San Diego Chargers of the American Football League.

JACQUES D'AMBOISE'S ballet "Prologue," given its first performance by New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater last night, is a ballet about Othello sort of. The ballet purports to take place before shakespeare's play opens. At times it seemed legitimate to wonder what had taken place before Mr. d'Amboise's ballet had opened. Not enough, one suspects, for here, at least on first sight, was a different idea indifferently handled.
Prices moved ahead again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but volume declined slightly from Wednesday's lively pace.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that it was possible the political turmoil in Communist China would lead to civil war but that it was too soon to tell.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 12 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. L. Dewey Babcock of Fairfield and St. Croix, the Virgin Islands, of the engament of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Lee Babcock, to Thomas Michael Sharp. He is the son of Mrs. Marie Sharp of Bay Shore, L.I., and Raymond D. Sharp of Kansas City.

A man convicted of driving a get-away car in a $22,000 holdup of the First Westchester National Bank in New Rochelle last summer was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy to 20 years in prison.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 12 The broad terms of a compromise settlement in the Congo copper dispute appear to be taking shape with the aid of active Belgian diplomacy.

Not everyone taking the Power Squadrons' piloting course is a boatowner or a member of a boating family. Although most of the people taking the course are new boatowners who are interested in learning the rules of the road and other fundamentals, the Palisade Power Squadron of Englewood, N. J., has found that there are other motives involved, too.
AN OFFICIAL of a brokerage firm whose market vintage dates back to the 1920's was asked yesterday what he thought of the behavior of stock prices the last several days.
DETROIT, Jan. 12 (UPI) Paul Henderson scored two goals as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4-1, in a National Hockey League game tonight.
Two hundred and fifty members of the White Russian colony here celebrated New Year's Eve with their friends last night according to the Julian calendar at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

HONG KONG, Jan. 11 The most controversial subject concerning military operations in Vietnam is the United States air bombardment, what the United States is seeking to bomb and what the bombs are hitting.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 12 (AP) An official of the Equal Employment Opportunities Commission said today that there was evidence of limited progress in the hiring of Negroes in the textile and other Southern industries.
Thirteen British companies are showing their latest designs in yachts and marine equipment in a combined exhibit at the Coliseum.

Legislation that would ban electronic eavesdropping by public officials and private persons, and curb the manufacturing, sale and advertising of the devices, will be introduced in the Legislature on Monday.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 12 (Reuters) Lynden O. Pindling, a 38-year-old lawyer, said here today that he hoped to form the first Negro government in this British colony's 300-year history.

A. Philip Randolph, one of the key leaders in the civil rights movement, announced yesterday that he intended to call what he described as a "Negro summit conference" to re-examine and revise Negro strategy against "the white power structure."
ALBANY, Jan. 12 The Department of Motor Vehicles is considering an increase in the annual inspection fee for automobiles.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) expects to report record results for 1966 from practically every phase of its operations.

Outboard-driven hulls at the Coliseum range from 7-footers to twin-powered cruisers and they are made of many materials wood, aluminum, fiber glass, neoprene rubber and impregnated nylon. A novelty is a transparent boat by Submernautics made of cellulose acetate butyrate.

HONG KONG, Jan. 10 Throughout China, in cities and in villages, boldly stroked characters command the public's attention from stone fences, pillars, trees and the walls of private homes and public buildings.
MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (Reuters) Soviet scientists are working on their own version of a birthcontrol pill fom women, it was reported here this week.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 13-- Ernie Terrell, whom Cassius Clay refers to as "the one-armed bandit," floored a sparring partner today with his "other" hand.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) --President Johnson announced today that he would nominate 12 men for Federal Judgeships. Those chosen were:
Doors flew open quickly yesterday when disaster struck in Jamaica, Queens--doors to churches, an armory, a bakery plant, homes, schools, a hamburger stand.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 (AP) --Four children were killed and six persons injured tonight in a fire that hit a 10-family apartment building on the East Side.
DECORATIVE objects made between 1880 and 1920 have been popular for some time, but only lately has the superb workmanship of some of these "antiques" of the last 75 years attracted serious attention.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 13 (Reuters)--The United States gave Pakistan $350,000 today for its atomic energy program and pledged aid with reactors and fuel. The money will be used for Pakistan's only operating nuclear reactor, an American-installed one, at Islamabad.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 13 (AP) --Charlie Gelbert, a World Seles star for the St. Louis Cardinals and later the successful coach of the Lafayette College baseball team, died tonight in Easton Hospital, apparently of heart attack. He was 60 years old.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 13 (AP)--The Indiana legislature was asked today to approve a study of the effects that alcohol, carbon monoxide and certain drugs have on traffic fatalities. Results of the study and recommendations stemming from it would be submitted to the 1969 leigislature.

Beckman Instruments, Inc., showed a 24 per cent increase in earnings on a 17 per cent gain in sales in the six months ended Dec. 31, William F. Ballhaus, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

No one should be surprised on Monday night if David Burns shatters his bass drum when he arrives onstage as a member of the Yonkers marching band and thunders, "Damn, how can I be expected to play 'Yorkers, My Yorkers' with all that bellowing in my ears?"

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 13-- Four Chinese Nationalist patrol planes clashed with 12 Chinese Communist MIG-19 jet fighters northeast of Quemoy today and shot down two of them, the Nationalist Government said.

ROCKY MOUNT, N.C., Jan. 13--Mrs. Nantce Weaver Mebane has announced the engagement of her daughters Miss Ann Fonvielle Mebane, to Arnold J. Levine, soil of Dr. and Mrs. Max Levine of Forest Hills, Queens, New York.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 (AP)--A leading manufacturer of motor homes, Ray C. Conner, general manager of the Cortez Motor Home division of the Clark Equipment Company, said today that proposed Federal safety standards could halt production of engine-powered homes on wheels.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 13 (AP) --A half-dozen pickets with signs calling for free elections in Greece were on hand outside the Music Hall tonight as Princess Irene of Greece arrived to attend a concert.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13--The United States military command announced tonight that it had sent combat support troops into the Mekong River delta, apparently as a prelude to stationing American infantrymen there in force.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 13 (Reuters)--The Swedish Pilots Association predicted mammoth air disasters with the advent of jumbo jets and supersonic aircraft unless there was more research into pilot error.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 13-- Undefeated Lehigh University upset Iowa State University's wrestlers, 16-13, tonight before 3,500 fans. The loss was the first of the season for the Cyclones, rated second in the nation, while Lehigh, which scored its fifth victory, is ranked fifth.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 13 (AP)-- Charles E. Pierson, who retired in January, 1966, after 10 years as executive editor of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, died in a hospital here last night of complications following surgery. He was 61 years old.
Biding their time, potato futures traders tended to even their contract positions yesterday, with the result that prices changed little, although volume was brisk.
PARIS, Jan. 13--West Germany's new Chancellor, Kurt Georg Kiesinger, conveyed to the French Government today his wish to restore the recently battered friendship between the two countries.

BELLEAIR, Fla., Jan. 13 (UPI)--Joseph Greene, 61 years old, of St. Petersburg, defeated Jack Russell of Clearwater on the 20th hole today to advance to the final of the ninth annual Belleair seniors invitation golf tournament. He will play Curtis Person of Memphis, the medalist, tomorrow.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP)--Lew Alcindor, with 26 points, led unbeaten University of California, Los Angeles, to a 96-78 victory over California tonight in a Pacific-Eight Conference basketball game.

LONDON, Jan. 13--Lord Moran, Sir Winston Churchill's private physician, has dropped his libel suit against the British Medical Association for criticizing him for his disclosures about Sir Winston's illnesses in a controversial book about the late British statesman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13-- A ticket holder turned away from an airplane because of overbooking would collect $50 to $200 as compensation from the airline under a rule-proposed today by the Civil Aeronautics board.
MADRAS, India, Jan. 13 (Reuters)--India's batsmen failed today to capitalize on a good start against the West Indies as the third and final test began before a capacity crowd of 32,000.
A LOT of women wouldn't dream of wearing our raincoats in the rain," Jay Stone of Naman Rainwear said as he flipped through the racks of new spring styles in his showroom.
With rising industry confidence providing buoyancy, the Nationl Boat Show will set sail today on what is nautically referred to as its nine-day public cruise.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (AP)--Twenty Vietnamese civilians were drowned yesterday when a motor boat capsized in the Bentre River in the Mekong Delta, the Vietnam newes service reported.
IS THE Dow-Jones industrial average saying that the stock market probably will move higher over the near term?
Starting with the first alarm at 5:19 A.M. yesterday, a complex and sophisticated alarm system sped men and equipment to South Jamaica, Queens.
HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 13 (AP)--Arthur Ashe of Richmond, and Cliff Richey of Dallas struggled past a pair of Australians today and reached the semi-finals of the Tasmanian tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13-- Some American scientists engaged in biological warfare research are trying to adapt serious insect-borne diseases so that they can be transmitted from person to person through the air, according to an article in Science magazine.

PARIS, Jan. 13--For a police bulletin to quote Aristotle, Plato and Klerkegaard might cause surprise in some cities, but when the house organ of the Paris Prefecture did just that in its latest issue, nobody raised an eyebrow.

Gas leaking from a main exploded early yesterday and sent a towering, rolling wave of flame and heat through four residential blocks in South Jamaica. Nine houses were demolished and eight others badly damaged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13-- Officials of four companies testified today in United States District Court that they had given checks totaling $36,000 to Wayne L. Bromley, a Washington lawyer-lobbyist, who was formerly a friend and associate of Robert G. Baker.
The city administration invoked fact-finding yesterday as a means of resolving the Welfare Department labor dispute and averting a strike threatened for Monday.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 13 --Bob Goalby has been judiciously studying the golf swing in recent months. Today he said he had gained a better understanding of how to hit a golf ball as he scored a 64 in the San Diego open. The seven-under-par round lifted him into a tie for the 36-hole lead at 132 with Randy Glover of Florence, S.C.
Peter M. Daly, former justice of the State Supreme Court, died yesterday in the Fairview Nursing Home, Forest Hills, Queens. He would have been 76 years old on Wednesday.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (UPI)-- Maurice Cullen, British lightweight champion, today canceled a proposed trip to Panama to fight Ismael Laguna because his purse was cut from $6,000 to $5,000.

A group trying to organize an interracial country club in Westchester County said yes terday that it was running into difficulty from local residents and was thinking of taking the issue to the State Commission for Human Rights.

The Most Rev. Charles H. Helmsing, Roman Catholic Bishop of Kansas City-St. Joseph, formally disscoiated himself yesterday from certain editorial policies of the National Catholic Reporter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) --President Johnson announced today that he would nominate James J. Reynolds Jr. to be Under secretary of Labor.

MOSCOW, Jan. 13 (Reuters) --The Soviet Union will deliver tugs and barges to North Vietnam this year to carry vehicles and farm machinery in areas damaged by American air raids, Tass reported today. The official press agency said the deal was concluded in Moscow, but did not say when.
LONDON, Jan. 12--New evidence has become available of the extent to which Britain is losing people, particularly those with vital skills.

ACCRA, Ghana, Monday, Jan. 16 (AP) Former President Kwame Nkrumah has assets worth at least $6.4-million inside and outside the country, an inquiry commission reported today.

PARIS The French economy, largely through increasing manipulation by the French Government, has achieved a historic recovery from some of the problems that have plagued it for decades. But it is still not vigorous.

AUGUSTA, Italy A minor naval base in the prewar era, Augusta, on Sicily's east coast, is now Italy's second largest port topped only by Genoa in the amount of cargo tonnage handled each year.
ROME, Jan. 15 (AP) Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge discussed the Vietnam war for an hour tonight with Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Jan. 15 (AP) The Congolese Government withdrew today its threat to seize the property of Societe, Generale, the large Belgian holding and investment company, but decreed the seizure of preperty belonging to its subsidiary, Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga.

PHILADELPHIA, Monday, Jan. 16 A settlement of the one-day-old transit strike in the nation's fourth largest city was reported to have been reached early this morning.

PHUCUONG, South Vietnam, Jan, 15 In canvas-topped sheds thrown up on a wasteland, 6,000 Vietnamese, all but a handful of them women, children and old people, were trying today to put together the pieces of suddenly shattered lives.

HAMBURG, West Germany, Jan. 15 (Reuters) The next installment of "The Death of a President," to be published tomorrow in Stern, the West German magazine, tells how President Kennedy parted from his wife on the eve of his assassination, informed sources said tonight.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Gary Bauman, a rookie goalie, starred as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Boston Bruins, 3-1, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

Unable to cope with the greatest mail-order request in its history, Madison Square Garden gave the public the opportunity yesterday to purchase tickets for the New York Rangers' l6 remaining home games.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving is planning a new look for Coney Island's beachfront and has put to work a team of nationally prominent architects to ply him with ideas.

MOSCOW A, white-haired man in a gray suit, wearing the badge of a Deputy to the Supreme Soviet (parliament), was in Moscow for the legislature's brief December session. Besides his duties as a deputy, he had another important task in Moscow shopping.

THE world champion. Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, playing first board for his team in the recent chess Olympiad at Havana, won first prize for best percentage results. This was a worthy recovery from his incredible 50-50 score in the 1966 Piatigorsky Cup Tournament at Santa Monica, Calif.
LONDON, Jan. 15 Prime Minister Wilson took off today on the first leg of a fateful tour of Europe his exploration of the chances for British entry into the Common Market.

BOSTON, Jan.15 (AP) Doctors at Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary have used an artificial tube and valve fashioned from the patient's skin to replace a shattered larynx and restore the voice of a marine wounded in Vietnam.

HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 15 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Richmond lost to Tony Roche of Australia in the men's singles final and Nancy Richey of Dallas beat Lesley Turner of Australia for the women's title today in the Tasmanian tennis championships.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 15 The women's auxiliary of St. Joseph's Hospital will give its annual Midwinter Ball on Jan. 21 at the Stamford Yacht Club.
