The national networks have rejected demands by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists that network reporters, correspondents and commentators be granted a five-day, 40-hour week and a minimum weekly salary of $400.
A submarine under construction in Switzerland has been certified by a ship classification society. It is the first such craft to be so certified.
Joseph Gurin, who retired 12 years ago as a civil engineer in the New York State Department of Public Works, died yesterday in his home at 19 Schenck Avenue, Great Neck, L.I. He was 84 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 President Johnson is expected to ask Congress in his Budget Message later this month for about $3.2-billion to finance economic and military foreign aid in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

FLORENCE, Italy Jan. 15 A little marble plaque that reads "Il 4 Novembre 1966 l'aqua d'Arno arrivo a quest' altezza" (on Noc. 4 the waters of the Arno reached this height) has just been put up on the facade of the l3thcentury Ognissanti church. Tourists stop in front of the sign and measure the height of it. The plaque is almost eight feet from the ground.
LONDON All over Britain this winter good men who have lost their jobs are sitting at home, drawing benefits, and waiting for their old jobs to open up again.
Herman Joseph, a former circus clown, died last Tuesday at St. John's Hospital, Queens, after a coronary attack. He was 78 years old.

OSLO, Norway A producer of packaged salads and other delicatessen products loads a truck regularly and sends it across the border to sell directly to Swedish retail stores. The border is no barrier, and he looks upon Sweden as part of his home market.
A Civil Aeronautics Board decision on Atlantic air routes has reopened an old dispute, but with a difference.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers, led by Wilt Chamberlain and Luke Jackson, stunned Boston with 17 straight points in the second period and routed the Celtics, 110-95, today in a National Basketball Association game before a crowd of 11,246.
BEIRUT, Lebanon Coexistence among the regimes of the right and the left in the Middle East ended last year.
A party after an opening night performance generally an expensive item for the theater angels will become a source of revenue for the Actors Fund and may usher in a trend.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 15 Samuel Howe 3d of the home club won the William F. White Memorial Cup invitation squash racquets tournament for the second successive year by defeating Stephen Vehslage of New York City, 15-10, 15-10, 15-12, today at the Merion Cricket Club.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Jan. 15 (AP) Jerry Hillebrand, a linebacker for the New York Giants of the National Football League, said yesterday he would rather play for someone else next season.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 16 Military sources said today that the Vietcong had shot and killed 41 of 48 prisoners at a Mekong River delta prison camp after the site was discovered by South Vietnamese troops.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 Bryan Bartlett (Bart) Starr, the quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, led his team to a 35-10 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs today in the first professional football game between the champions of the National and American Leagues.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 15 (AP) The two co-editors of Johns Hopkins University's student newsletter have been suspended because the weekly carried a highly critical reference to President Johnson.
ATHENS Hopes that Greece's stagnant economy may soon pick up dawned here with the start of the new year as a new Cabinet under a banker, Ioannis Paraskevopoulos, took over.

LONDON, Jan. 15--Duncan Sandys led a few thousand Conservative friends of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith to Trafalgar Square this afternoon to start a "peace with Rhodesia" campaign. Mr. Sandys is a Conservative Member of Parliament and a former Colonial Secretary.

HONG KONG, Jan. 15 The forces of Mao Tse-tung, Chairman of the Chinese Communist party's Central Committee, and Defense Minister Lin Piao asserted today that the success of pro-Mao workers in crushing an opposition "counterattack" in Shanghai showed that the "cultural revolution" had reached a new turning point.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 15 (AP) Lidiya Skobilkova, the Soviet Union's Olympic champion, broke the women's world record for the 3,000 meters in speed skating today at an International meet. She also won the 1,000 meters.
HELSINKI, Finland The tall former longshoreman who had risen to head a workers' savings bank attracted much attention soon after he took over as Finland's Finance Minister last May.
HONG KONG, Jan. 11-- About 10 days ago Le Duan, First Secretary of the North Vietnamese Workers' (Communist) party, made a speech to army cadets, outlining the basis of party policy.
TURIN, N.Y. Jan. 15 (AP) Warren Witherill, a school teacher from Lake Placid, N.Y., took first place today in the men's division of the 13th annual Oneida Silversmiths Trophy ski competition.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15--The Soviet people, increasingly worried by the turmoil and violence in China, were presented a grim picture today of widespread fighting and chaos amid a sharpening power struggle.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 15 The formation of a new political party in Rhodesia is being explored by a group of prominent business and professional men. Its purpose would be to persuade Prime Minister Ian D. Smith to implement the draft constitution he agreed to with Prime Minister Wilson of Britain last month.
ALBANY, Jan. 15--The leadership roles at the forthcoming state Constitutional Convention appeared today to be shaping up as encores of the present session of the politically divided Legislature.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) Four Chicago starters poured in 107 points among them to lead the Bulls to a 131-116 victory over the New York Knicks tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 15--Secretary General Thant moved today to lessen what he said was an imminent threat of a large-scale clash of military forces on the border between Syria and Israel.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan 15 One of this community's power centers the Berkeley Consumers' Cooperative has been badly shaken in the last few weeks by a bitter re-election campaign waged by a director.

White-collar workers in Germany's heavily industralized Ruhr District are getting used to carrying an extra shirt because they know the first one will be gray after half a day in the area's polluted air.

A three-judge United States District Court in Chicago has unanimously affirmed as Interstate Commerce Commission decision approving the acquisition of Terminal Transport Company, Inc., by American Commercial Barge Lines of Houston.
